HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury's Long Bond Yield Slides Below 7%

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The Treasury's long bond yield slid below 7 percent for the first time in more than a year yesterday, as the market continued to rally on more evidence of an economic slowdown.
Prices, which move in the opposite direction from rates, rose, both for the long bond and at yesterday's three-year note auction. A few analysts said the weak three-year note auction yesterday did not bode well for today's 10-year note auction. 
 The average yield at the three-year auction was 6.16 percent, down from 7.34 percent at the previous auction in February, and the lowest since Feb 1994, when the yield was 4.83 percent.
In when-issued trading late yesterday, the 10-year note being auctioned today was offered at a price to yield 6.59 percent.
Traders attributed the rally to a growing consensus that the Federal Reserve's seven interest rate increases since last February are taking effect in the economy. As a result, inflation will be held in check and rates will not rise, eroding the value of fixed-income investments.
Matthew F. Alexy, chief market strategist at CS First Boston, said there were buyers at all maturities, a clue to the market's mind-set. "It may be that the market is reflecting a belief that the Fed is finished raising interest rates," he said.
The session, which extended overnight gains, heated further in early morning trading after Government reports showed that sales at a wholesale level, such as from producers to distributors or other producers, declined for the first time since December.
Wholesale inventories, in the meantime, rose a larger-than-expected 1.2 percent, compared with market expectations for a six-tenths of 1 percent increase. Analysts say a buildup of inventories is considered a signal of declining demand.
Late in the afternoon Johnson Redbook reported seasonally adjusted retail stores sales down 3.9 percent in the first week of May versus April, and that helped support debt futures ahead of the close.
That touched off waves of short- covering by traders, forcing portfolio managers to extend the duration of their portfolios by buying longer maturities, First Albany Corporation's chief investment strategist, Hugh A. Johnson, said.
Another factor in the rally, he said, was the stability of the dollar, which led foreign investors to find their way back into the market.
The 30-year bond rose 16/32 , to a price of 10819/32 for a yield of 6.94 percent, down from 7.03 percent on Monday, and its lowest level since March 23, 1994, when it was 6.89 percent, the day the Fed raised interest rates for the second time in the current cycle.
Chris Moore, senior fixed-income analyst with Technical Data in Boston said, "Open interest on bond futures contracts continues to increase, which suggests that investors are holding onto their contracts and not selling because they see real value in fixed-income assets at these levels."
Traders at the end of the session began looking ahead to April inflation data tomorrow and Friday, which Mr. Moore predicts will meet expectations. "If they come out pretty much plain vanilla then the market will be O.K.," he said, but if the numbers are unexpectedly high, "you'll see people begin to take profits at the first opportunity."

HEADLINE: Productivity Has Only Small, 0.7% Gain

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 9

 BODY:
More signs of a slowdown in the economy emerged today as the Government reported that worker productivity rose just seven-tenths of 1 percent in the first quarter and that stocks of unsold goods on wholesalers' shelves grew in March for the ninth consecutive month.
The Labor Department said the rise in nonfarm productivity, or output per hours worked, was the smallest in nine months. 
 The gain followed a revised 4 percent jump in the fourth quarter of 1994 that was previously reported as a gain of 1.7 percent.
The modest rise last quarter reflected a 3.3 percent rise in total output, including farming, down from a 7.7 percent increase in the fourth quarter. It was the smallest gain since the second quarter of 1994.
"That's exactly what you'd expect to see with a slowing in the economy," said Richard Berner, an economist at the Mellon Bank.
Economists said productivity typically slackened as companies reined in output, which in turn pushed up labor costs associated with production.
Indeed, the Labor Department report showed that unit labor costs, which account for about two-thirds of the cost of a typical product, rose 3.4 percent in the first quarter, the largest increase since the first quarter of 1993. Unit labor costs fell six-tenths of 1 percent in the fourth quarter.
Hourly wages, when adjusted for inflation, rose 1 percent, down from 1.2 percent in the fourth quarter.
In a separate report, the Commerce Department said wholesale inventories in March rose 1.2 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $243.2 billion, after a revised gain of nine-tenths of 1 percent in February. Sales fell for the first time since last fall.
"We're seeing a slowing in demand and a buildup in inventories," Mr. Berner said. "That is consistent with the notion that production will continue to be cut back so inventories can be realigned with sales."
Stocks of both durable goods, which include hardware products and metals, and nondurable goods like chemicals and petroleum, increased in March.
Wholesale sales fell 1 percent in March, to a seasonally adjusted $183.1 billion, following a revised 1.2 percent increase in February. It was the first monthly decline in sales since a drop of six-tenths of 1 percent in September, and it was the biggest decline in any month since June 1993, when sales dropped 1.6 percent.
The department had previously said that inventories had grown 1.2 percent in February and that sales had risen by only 1 percent.
The largest buildup in March inventories was for nondurable goods, which increased 1.8 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $88.6 billion. Unsold stocks of everything from drugs and groceries to chemicals were higher than in February.
Economists said the economy was still fundamentally healthy despite the evidence of a slowdown. "It's not an economy going to pieces," said William Griggs of Griggs & Santow Inc.

HEADLINE: Fulton Crackdown Bill to Cover All Fish Markets

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
A bill before the City Council intended to rid the Fulton Fish Market of corruption has been modified to broaden the city's ability to regulate business owners and workers in other wholesale or retail fish markets in New York City.
The revisions to the bill, which were released yesterday, came after city officials determined that wholesale dealers at the Fulton Fish Market, in lower Manhattan, might move to other sites in the city rather than comply with a plan by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to raise their rents and subject them to tight regulation. 
 If the bill passes the Council, the city's Commissioner of Business Services will be able to require any concentration of fish sellers to register with the city and operate under strict regulation. The bill says the commissioner can call for such oversight if he believes "that an area has the potential for corrupt, dishonest or improper business practices."
Last week, the city reached an agreement with seven wholesale companies to remain at the Fulton Fish Market. In all, there are 40 wholesale dealers at the market, and most are still deciding whether to stay there or move. The new lease includes substantial rent increases.
The Giuliani administration, which contends that the Genovese crime family has been deeply entrenched at the Fulton market, had asked the Council for authority to license and regulate all the market's companies and employees. The Council is expected to approve the proposal later this month.
Jerome X. O'Donovan, the chairman of the Council's Economic Development Committee, said that the revisions made public yesterday had been drafted after meetings between Mr. Giuliani's aides and the Council staff.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
2 Retailers' Profits Down In Quarter

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, May 9

 BODY:
Two large clothing store chains, The Limited Inc. and the Ann Taylor Stores Corporation, posted weaker first-quarter profits today, citing the pressure of chilly spring weather and a spending pullback by consumers.
The Limited's earnings fell 17 percent, to $39 million, or 11 cents a share, from $47 million, or 13 cents a share, in the corresponding period last year. Sales rose 7.2 percent, to $1.6 billion. 
 "Our performance in the first quarter was at the lower end of our expectations," said Leslie Wexner. chairman and chief executive of the Limited, which is based in Columbus, Ohio. Analysts, however, had expected an additional penny or two per share. Still, the company's stock closed up 25 cents at $21.25 in New York Stock Exchange trading today.
Ann Taylor, based in New York, said that despite a 16 percent rise in sales, to $168 million, profits fell 56.7 percent, to $3.5 million, or 15 cents a share, from $8.1 million, or 36 cents a share, during the corresponding period last year. Analysts had been predicting 36 cents a share until last week, when the company warned that 15 cents a share was likely, and its stock slid several points. In New York Stock Exchange trading today, its shares closed down 37.5 cents at $20, well below its 52-week high of $44.875 set on Nov. 3.
Both companies were hit by generally sluggish sales of women's apparel, analysts said. In addition to cool spring weather, the analysts cited higher interest rates and stiff price competition among clothing retailers, and they predicted the negative trend would persist into summer.
"There's just continued poor retail business in general, across all categories," said Peter Schaeffer of Dillon, Read & Company. "We don't see any sort of a turnaround through this year."
At Limited, sales at the company's core women's apparel businesses overshadowed gains at its Victoria's Secret lingerie business and Bath and Body Works toiletries stores.
Same-store sales among Victoria's Secret stores open at least a year rose 2 percent in the quarter, Mr. Schaeffer said. But same-store sales at the women's apparel businesses, including the company's flagship Limited stores, fell about 3 percent.
"I was particularly pleased with the results of our intimate apparel and personal product businesses: Victoria's Secret Stores, Victoria's Secret Catalogue, and Bath and Body Works," Mr. Wexner of Limited said.
While Limited's results were disappointing, analysts said, investors remained upbeat about the company's plans to split the women's apparel divisions from the lingerie and personal care store chains. The company, which announced the plans in March, is set to sell 10 percent to 15 percent of each business to the public and retain the rest.
By breaking up the businesses, Limited hopes to heighten focus on some of its rapidly growing chains like Bath and Body Works and bolster the stock's value. The strengths in these newer chains have been hidden by Limited's larger and more visible women's clothing stores, such as Express.
"I think people will have to start to focus on the spinoffs" in coming weeks as opposed to near-term results of the women's businesses, said John Connolly, partner with Miller, Anderson & Sherrerd.

HEADLINE: Steelworkers Know About Job Retraining

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your May 3 news article describing the plight of displaced aerospace workers in California has a familiar ring to displaced steelworkers in Pennsylvania's Monongahela Valley. Steelworkers here experienced the very same problems after the steel mills shut down in the early 1980's, victims of the deindustrialization of America. 
 I am a former steelworker. I worked at the U.S. Steel Homestead Works for 21 years, until it closed in 1986. The mill shutdown left the Homestead steelworkers in the same situation as the California aerospace workers: how to find a decent new job? Many of us made a mistake. We chose job retraining. Job retraining, at that time, and to this day, is a joke. After job training, there were no jobs to fit the training.
The displaced steelworkers, who were looking for a full-time job to provide money, pride and self-esteem, found only bitter disappointment. Few workers have found jobs in their field of training. The majority are underemployed as part-time school bus drivers, security guards, bartenders, house painters or whatever menial jobs they can find. Their wages are far below what they earned in the mills.
Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich and other proponents of job retraining miss an important point: Job retraining doesn't work!
What good is job training if there are no decent jobs available when the training is completed? The long-term solution is the creation of well-paying jobs.
 
WILLIAM M. FIDEL
Pittsburgh, May 5, 1995

HEADLINE: Here Comes the Bill;
How Experts Cut the Costs But Keep The Magic

BYLINE: By BRYAN MILLER 

 BODY:
IN the next few months, guests at wedding receptions across the country will devour enough shrimp cocktail, veal loin, turned carrots and frilly layer cake to keep a moderate-size nation bunny-hopping till dawn.
The traditional wedding feast embraces both food and fantasy in equal parts, both of which can be frighteningly expensive. But wedding planners, caterers and banquet managers say that a wedding feast does not have to cost as much as a Ford Explorer to be memorable and that it is possible to curtail expenses by 20 percent or more without sacrificing quality or effect. 
 In New York, a top-of-the-line wedding can easily cost $400 a person -- or $60,000 for 150 people. The food alone, including gratuities, can count for about 80 percent of the total.
With more couples paying for part or all of their own weddings these days (especially in second weddings), cost control is on people's minds more than ever, party planners say. "Watching costs doesn't mean your dinner will be skimpy," said Ellen Eskenazi, a partner in Event of the Year Inc., wedding planners in Manhattan.
An economical but elegant wedding dinner is sort of like a good haircut: the trims should be so discreet that no one notices.
The first consideration for most couples is deciding when and where to hold the wedding reception.
No matter where it is held, wedding planners have uniform advice: if possible, avoid June, when space and labor are at a premium.
"The best time of year to get married if you are watching your money is from the end of July through August, or January and February," said Gail Perl of Perl & Berliner Inc., wedding planners in Fort Lee, N.J. In an off month, especially in winter, costs of the room and the food can be negotiated, whether one chooses a hotel or a party space.
"The discounts you can get vary greatly from hotel to hotel," said Nicholas Type, the director of catering at the Four Seasons Hotel on East 57th Street. "In July and August you can find some very good discounts, up to 25 percent."
The time of day also makes a difference. An afternoon function is generally less expensive than an evening one. "This is especially true if you have a hotel that is booked at night but has the room free during the day," Ms. Perl added. "You can negotiate a good price." Private party spaces, which in Manhattan rent for $1,000 to $3,000 and up for an event, are generally not as flexible.
But a Sunday brunch affair is still far less expensive than a Saturday night dinner. "It's very hard to book weddings at lunchtime, so if you can do that, most hotels are willing to offer substantial reductions," Mr. Type said..
Hotels are not necessarily more expensive than other sites. "If you go to an off-premise site, like a museum, and have a caterer, the food cost could be lower, about 40 percent," said Mary Dearborn, the vice president for catering at Restaurant Associates in New York. "But then the other items could be more expensive and in the end you wind up with a similar price."
When it comes to planning the menu, the smaller items, like reception hors d'oeuvres, count for a lot.
"We tell clients that if they have to put limited money somewhere, they should put it where guests are going to see it and remember it -- and that means the reception," Mrs. Eskenazi said. It seems to be a twist on the old axiom that hot dogs taste better at the ballpark: wedding guests are at their most ravenous -- and impressionable -- at the cocktail reception that precedes the dinner.
"We might advise clients to put money into the reception as opposed to the dinner by maybe adding an attractive pasta station or a carving board to the buffets," said Jackie Zirkman, Mrs. Eskenazi's partner at Event of the Year.
THAT is precisely what Tami Peskin and her fiance, David Nusim, plan to do at their Oct. 21 wedding at Bridgewaters, a party space at the South Street Seaport in Manhattan. The reason was not only financial, although they will save a little.
"We decided to do away with a first course at dinner and go right to the salad and entree," Miss Peskin said. "The reception will have three different stations -- cheeses, carving and pasta. I think guests will be impressed by the setup as soon as they get there."
Waiters will pass the hors d'oeuvres, a trend that wedding planners have seen in recent years.
"It is a fallacy to think that you need less help a for a buffet than passed hors d'oeuvres," said Ms. Perl in Fort Lee. "You still have to man the buffet and have backup help." Wedding planners say not only that it is more elegant to have appetizers passed by waiters, but also that people tend to consume less.
A relatively lavish cocktail reception takes some of the pressure off having a showpiece dinner, which is where the dollars add up. The cost of a formal wedding dinner alone, not including the cocktail reception, ranges from about $90 to $300 or more per person in the New York area. To that are added tax (8.25 percent in New York City) and gratuities of 18 to 20 percent.
There are several ways to trim the dinner. The most common is to eliminate the appetizer and serving a salad, main course and dessert. "The food price should be less," Miss Dearborn said, "and there will be one less setting of china."
If you do have an appetizer, the standard (and expensive) ones like smoked salmon, shrimp and lobster can be supplanted by equally compelling dishes that require more handiwork but are less expensive because the ingredients are cheaper.
"Things like California rolls, carved mushroom caps, beautifully presented vegetables -- these can be wonderful," said Diana Beattie, an independent wedding planner in Manhattan.
The dinner's cost can be further reduced by making the wedding cake the dessert, not just something to taste during a toast. But the cake must be large enough to serve every guest and it should be served soon after the main course.
"The wedding cake is considered part of the fantasy that all brides have," Ms. Perl said. "If you have a wonderful cake, people like to have it for dessert." A wedding cake can start at about $3 a person but can climb to $12 a person if it comes from a specialty baker on the outside.
Wedding planners say the main course is not something most people want to compromise on to save money. Traditional main courses -- beef, veal, lamb -- remain best-sellers, although preferences for one or the other go in fashions.
"Today I see a trend back toward beef," Ms. Perl said. "Young couples in particular are shying away from veal." Poultry, she added, which was equated with a low-budget wedding in the 1960's and 70's, had a resurgence in the 80's but has since fallen out of favor.
When it comes to service, most professional party planners insisted that one should not understaff to save money. Guests should not have to wave down waiters or run out of water or bread -- they get enough bad service in the outside world.
At most weddings today, dishes are served already plated, unlike French-style service in which waiters carry platters to the table. Neither system affects cost much.
"You can ask your caterer or hotel to design a menu that doesn't require a great deal of service staff," Miss Dearborn said. "Some dinners require two butlers per table of 10 guests, but you can tell the caterer that you would prefer a menu that requires only one to one and a half butlers per table." For example, a menu that calls for carving and saucing at the table requires more people.
Beverages can be controlled with few people noticing it. At receptions, for instance, champagne is sometimes served. That can be exceedingly expensive. Hotels charge around $7.50 for a glass of moderate-quality champagne. A bar with good-quality wine and standard liquors for mixed drinks is recommended, although more couples are eliminating mixed drinks.
"It's always nice to have a glass of champagne when the cake is cut," Ms. Perl said, "and by that time most guests are not inclined to drink more than one glass of it."
The bottom line in wedding meals, professionals say, is knowing what is essential and then bargaining over the marginal items.
"It's sort of like buying a car," Ms. Perl said. "You want something and the salesman wants something else. You go at it with him until the salesman hits his bottom line and can't budge. Then you have a new car."

GRAPHIC: Chart:
 
The Goal
 To have a top-of-the-line wedding reception adn dinner in Manhattan for 150 quests without paying top dollar. Good strategy can save about $20,000 of the total cost, which can reach about $50,000.
 
The Timing
 About $12,000 can be saved by holding the wedding in late summer or midwinter, rather than in June. Daytime is also cheaper than evening.
 
The Menu
About $3,750 can be saved by serving more food at the reception and shaving a course off the dinner.
 
The Cake
 About $1,875 can be saved by making the wedding cake the dessert course, not an addition to it.
 
The Drinks
 About $1,300, can be saved by serving champagne with the wedding cake only and not at the reception, where costs can quickly escalate (many hotels charge about $7.50 a glass for a moderate-quality champagne).
 
The Staff
 Avoiding dishes that require carving and saucing at the table will limit the number of servers, thereby saving salaries and tips.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Falling Interest Rates Could Lift the Economy
 Interest rates on long-term bonds fell sharply, dropping below 7 percent yesterday for the first time in 14 months, and the decline is starting to show up in lower rates for home mortgages. That may be just the jolt needed to revive the economy. But rates on other loans have not budged. 
 Most people look to the Federal Reserve to push down interest rates. But the Fed is standing pat, so bond traders are "easing rates for the Fed," as one trader put it, and their action might stimulate the economy. A1.
 More evidence of an economic slowdown emerged, as worker productivity rose just seven-tenths of 1 percent in the first quarter and wholesale inventories climbed a larger-than-expected 1.2 percent in March. D16.
 Silver prices plunged in reaction to the slower economy and lower interest rates. D6.
 
A Plan to Cut Federal Spending
 Republican Senators proposed cutting projected Government spending by nearly $1 trillion over the next seven years. Money would be saved in virtually every area of Government except Social Security and law enforcement. A1.
 
Senate Settles on Reduced Tort Bill
 The Senate settled on a bill that would limit the number of civil lawsuits, but the relatively narrow measure would limit punitive damages only for faulty products. A1.
 
Repeal of Glass-Steagall Advances
 The House Banking Committee approved a bill that would repeal the law barring mergers of banks and securities firms, but the bill would require holding companies to operate them as separate subsidiaries. Generally, the Fed would have regulatory responsibility. D2.
 
Ford Sees Lower Auto Sales
 Ford expects auto sales this year to fall to 15.1 million from 15.4 million in 1994. It was Ford's second cut in its forecast in a month. It said surprisingly slack results in April were responsible. D2.
 
Swiss-Warburg Deal Near
 Swiss Bank agreed in principle to buy S. G. Warburg, Britain's biggest investment firm, for $1.27 billion in cash, people close to negotiations in Basel said. Details are expected to be announced today. D5.
 
T.W.A. Drops Commission Cap
 Breaking ranks with other airlines, T.W.A. agreed to scrap a limit on travel agent commissions, at least through September. D5.
 
Net Falls at Limited and Ann Taylor
 The Limited and Ann Taylor Stores posted weaker quarterly profits, pressured by chilly spring weather and a spending pullback by consumers. Analysts predicted other retailers would also feel the pressure. D2.
 
Fountain Pens Popular Again
 The makers of fountain pens are reporting a growing boom in the market for premium pens, those costing more than $50. Although the traditional markets are the United States and Western Europe, demand has picked up in Asia, Eastern Europe and Russia. D3.
 
Mexican Crisis Hits Public Works
 Soaring interest rates in Mexico brought on by the economic crisis have made it impossible for states and local communities there to repay billions of dollars in loans used for public works projects. A13.
 
Ships Aim for Business Travelers
 Two new cruise ships, Legend of the Seas and Crystal Symphony, were built primarily for leisure travelers, but were also designed with the business traveler in mind.
 Edwin McDowell: Business Travel. D5.

HEADLINE: Contractors Put on Show to Save Their Subsidies

BYLINE: By JANE FRITSCH 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 9

 BODY:
This is the season of self-preservation, a fearful time when bureaucrats, businessmen and others who depend on Federal largess will do anything they can think of to fend off Congressional budget cutters.
That's why contractors rolled an electric-powered armored personnel carrier onto the Mall just beyond the Capitol today. They brought along an electric Humvee, too, and something that looked like an electric dune buggy to demonstrate to Congress that all their work had not been in vain. 
 But by day's end it was not clear that they had done much more than plow up the grass and possibly annoy the park police.
"Hey, Gordon, don't tear up the lawn," pleaded Michael J. Gage, the president of a California consortium that sponsored the event. But Gordon roared off in his machine, drowning out Mr. Gage's lament that "this will cost me the $2,000 bond."
The contractors, from consortiums around the country, put on the show because they are afraid they will lose $30 million in annual Defense Department subsidies to develop electric vehicles. Over the years, much of the money has been used to develop the vehicles, and now some in Congress are questioning whether the expense should be cut from the military budget.
"The budget gun has everything in its target, not just electric vehicles," said Winston K. Ashizawa, an official of the Sacramento Municipal Utility District, which is helping to build electric vehicles.
Mr. Ashizawa, who has been lobbying hard in recent weeks, said he had heard criticism that the electric vehicles project was essentially "drawing away defense dollars from their primary function."
With the electric-powered combat vehicles, the contractors hoped to prove otherwise. They peppered Congressional offices with leaflets inviting representatives and their staffs to the presentation, but only a few showed up during this overcast day on a forlorn patch of the Mall.
If they had, they could have chatted with Elliot L. Richardson, the attorney general who resigned over Watergate. Mr. Richardson provided an essential ingredient of any lobbying campaign: A Big Name.
Mr. Richardson, who is on an advisory board of a company that developed a high-speed flywheel, pronounced the invention "the most exciting technological breakthrough since the discovery of DNA."
Pressed for an explanation, he added, "This is the only battery that operates through the storage of kinetic energy."
The programs may be a target in part because they receive half their Government subsidies from the Advanced Research Projects Agency, a unit of the Defense Department that has come under attack by some Republicans in recent years. They have asserted that the agency's doling out of grants for research and development amounts to an industrial policy in which the Government picks winners and losers among companies that should be competing freely.
With Republicans in control of Congress and its budget-cutting committees for the first time in decades, the agency's contractors have found themselves among the newly vulnerable groups.
"When they hear 'electric vehicles,' they think that's not something the Department of Defense should be doing," said John H. Gully, a program manager for the agency. "These people staged this event to educate Congress."
The vehicles displayed today were prototypes and most are several years from completion, he said. All are hybrids that operate with both conventional gasoline-powered engines and electric power sources and provide three times the fuel economy of internal combustion engines operating alone.
For the military, Mr. Gully said, the hybrids have advantages over conventional vehicles. For instance, the personnel carriers could switch to electric power when it is important to move quietly. And use of electric power would foil heat-seeking missiles attracted to internal combustion engines, he added.
But without funding of additional years of research, the vehicles will be relatively useless.
It remains unclear how the research projects agency will fare in the weeks of budget slashing ahead. Some lobbyists said today that they have had some success in persuading Congressional opponents to leave the agency's budget intact.

LENGTH: 403 words

HEADLINE: China's Power Struggle

 BODY:
Chinese leaders have intensified an unpredictable power struggle that will determine not only the successors to Deng Xiaoping, but the pace of political and economic reform and perhaps the future of Communist rule itself.
President Jiang Zemin struck the first major blow with a wholesale purge of potential rivals in the Beijing city party organization. The Times's Patrick Tyler reported that it took a tense showdown, with police placed on alert, to convince the Beijing party boss, Chen Xitong, to step aside. 
 It is unsettling to see the fate of the world's most populous country, a nuclear power, being settled by the modern equivalent of medieval palace intrigue. But that is the price of a closed political system where the actions of a few well-placed party and military leaders count for more than majority opinion or formal institutions.
Jiang Zemin captured the inside track for succession through the personal endorsement several years ago of China's senior leader, Deng Xiaoping. Mr. Deng, now ill and enfeebled, appears no longer able to protect his political proteges. That leaves Mr. Jiang exposed to potential challenges. Another senior patron of President Jiang and Prime Minister Li Peng, Chen Yun, died last month.
Mr. Jiang's attack on the Beijing leadership seemed to be a pre-emptive move to demonstrate his own toughness. Mr. Jiang, who was not involved in the Tiananmen massacre, has also distanced himself somewhat from Prime Minister Li, who was. That has benefited the third-ranking member of the hierarchy, Qiao Shi, a former security chief who now heads China's nominal legislature.
Considerations of power, rather than ideology, appear to drive China's succession struggle. Nevertheless, it is worth noting that Qiao Shi, despite his security background, has recently emerged as a strong advocate of more pluralistic politics. If power were to pass to a Jiang-Qiao alliance, there could be an acceleration of political and economic reform.
Washington has only marginal influence over China's succession politics, exercised mainly through the prestige it can confer on contenders by treating them as world leaders. President Clinton made the right call when he decided to avoid meeting privately with Mr. Jiang while both are in Moscow this week. Scrupulous neutrality is the wisest policy for protecting American interests in a highly uncertain Chinese future.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Time for Hardball With Japan

BYLINE: By Patrick J. Buchanan 

 BODY:
McLEAN, Va.
With the collapse of U.S.-Japan trade talks, the hour of the economic nationalist may be at hand.
Demands that Japan open its market to more American autos and parts have been rudely rebuffed. Japan's top negotiator has virtually dared us to impose sanctions. We will haul you up before the world trade organization, Tokyo warns; there we will have you branded a violator of the free trade principles you so noisily preach -- before an international tribunal you yourselves set up. 
 Angry Clintonites reportedly intend to impose 100 percent tariffs on $1 billion of Japan's exports. This doesn't even qualify as a spanking. Americans are in a mood for action; and Republicans should demand more serious sanctions. Since 1970, Japan has purchased 400,000 U.S. cars, while selling us 40 million. Where Tokyo runs an annual trade surplus of $150 billion, our merchandise trade deficit has hit $166 billion. As this vast transfer of U.S. wealth was taking place, we were spending 6 percent of G.N.P. on defense, while Tokyo kept defense spending below 1 percent.
But now that Japan has given Mr. Clinton the wet mitten across the face, what is America to do? Free trade ideologues side with the Japanese. To them, trade deficits don't matter; U.S. consumers who swap dollars for quality Japanese goods are the real winners. But it is getting harder to convince the nation. As our share of world G.D.P. has fallen, the real income of Americans who work with their hands, tools and machines has fallen 20 percent in 20 years. Anecdotal evidence of a new two-tier economy is everywhere. College graduates come home to live with parents. Mothers leave children in day care to take jobs to maintain the family's standard of living.
Japan's negotiators hang tough because they're not ideologues; they're economic nationalists looking out for Japan first. And why should they abandon the protectionist policy that has worked splendidly for them to adopt a U.S.-style trade policy that has failed dismally for us? As for those U.S. officials who lecture them on free trade, Japan's envoys must have a special contempt. Many wind up on Tokyo's payroll as Washington lobbyists, parroting the Japanese line. But middle America is losing patience. Even establishment journalists are writing that we are being played for fools.
Congress, for once, should take unilateral action in the national interest. An across-the-board tariff of 10 percent on all Japanese goods entering the U.S. would net $12.5 billion. That shock would awaken Tokyo to the new reality that we Americans have begun looking out for America first. The revenue could be used to cut corporate taxes on small business, thus creating new American jobs, in addition to the new jobs created when Detroit recaptures its old markets.
If Japan retaliates, raise the tariff to 20 percent. Japan cannot win a trade war with America. It would be putting at risk $125 billion in exports to us, while we would risk but $60 billion in exports to Japan.Toward free traders like Canada and Europe, our policy should remain free trade. But toward predators like Japan and China, it is time for hardball.
Let us return to the trade policy created by Washington and Hamilton, pursued by Jefferson and Jackson, perfected by Lincoln and Theodore Roosevelt. Called the American system, it converted the U.S. from 13 rural colonies into the greatest industrial power the world had ever seen, producing 40 percent of the world's goods by World War II. After all, the powers that have lately embraced this system are today running the world's great trade surpluses.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Threats by Prosecutor Cited By Counsel on Leasing Deal

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON 

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., May 9

 BODY:
The Suffolk County District Attorney may have broken the law by threatening county legislators with grand jury inquiries, a special counsel hired by the Legislature said today.
Several legislators, including Presiding Officer Donald R. Blydenburgh, have said that the District Attorney, James M. Catterson, tried to intimidate them with threats of investigations if they continued to question a county car-leasing deal negotiated by his son, James Catterson Jr., a deputy county attorney. 
 Mr. Catterson appeared to be the primary target of the special counsel, Laura A. Brevetti, a former assistant United States Attorney retained by the County Legislature last December to investigate the lease and the allegations against Mr. Catterson.
Others, including the County Sheriff and the County Health Commissioner, have made similar allegations of intimidation against Mr. Catterson, who is a Republican like most of his accusers.
In a report on the findings of her six-month investigation, Ms. Brevetti said she found evidence of forgery, perjury and gross misuse of taxpayers' money by county officials.
Ms. Brevetti said that although Mr. Catterson had emphatically denied the allegations of intimidation, she recommended a "further investigation by an objective authority" into whether he had violated laws barring obstruction or attempted obstruction of governmental administration.
In fact, a special prosecutor -- Joseph W. Ryan Jr., a former president of the Nassau County Bar Association -- is already looking into Mr. Catterson's actions and is expected to conclude his investigation this summer.
Mr. Catterson today characterized Mrs. Brevetti's investigation as "a colossal witch hunt reminiscent of the McCarthy era."
"She has spent over $400,000 of the taxpayers' money selectively taking testimony without any public hearings, acting like a fact-finder, judge and jury," Mr. Catterson said. "She was hired by Mr. Blydenburgh to do a hatchet job, to smear people and bear no responsibility."
Ms. Brevetti spent more than four hours today making an oral presentation to the Legislature on her findings. She has scheduled two more sessions for Wednesday and Thursday and said a final printed report on her findings would be issued on May 17.
Questions concerning the car-leasing deal were first raised a year ago after the Suffolk County Executive, Robert J. Gaffney, a Republican, entered into a $17 million contract with PHH Vehicle Management Services of Maryland for up to 1,700 vehicles to replace the county's aging fleet. He won approval of the contract after a bitter power struggle with the County Legislature's Republican leadership.
Ms. Brevetti said the political power struggle generated a "lot of rumor and rhetoric and political expediency."
"While one would think the lease was intended to be a prudent and economical use of public money," she said, "it actually increased costs, decreased competition and was an imprudent use of taxpayers' money. In the end, the taxpayers did not get a good deal."
She said estimates indicated that had the car-lease deal not been subsequently revised by the Legislature, the lease would have cost the county $32 million over five years, while an outright purchase of the cars would have cost $23 million, financing included.
"I believe that the County Executive was not fully informed by his staff and others about the car-lease contract," she said, adding that Mr. Gaffney had been "extremely patient and cooperative" when he gave his sworn statements during two separate meetings in his office.
On the other hand, she said Mr. Catterson, while agreeing to be questioned on the matter, declined to give a sworn statement.
Mr. Catterson, in response, insisted that Ms. Brevetti had "no legal right to demand that anyone give a sworn statement."
"She's trying to be a special prosecutor, and she's not," he said.
"I met with her for five hours and I told her the intimidation incident never happened." he said. "I also gave her the names of two witnesses who were present when I met with Blydenburgh, but she has never questioned either of them.
"I told her I would be happy to speak under oath, but only before the full Legislature at a public hearing. I was the first to propose such a hearing a year ago, but they want no such hearings, only full control so they can blacken our names and leave us no recourse. It's an outrageous situation."
Ms. Brevetti told the Legislature's bipartisan ad hoc committee on car-leasing plans that she interviewed more than 60 people and compiled more than 4,500 pages of testimony in dispositions, all of them under oath except Mr. Catterson's.
While questioning the County Executive, Ms. Brevetti said she showed Mr. Gaffney a letter bearing what appeared to be his signature that was sent to Salvatore Alfano, president of the BGS Leasing Group, which was later hired by the county to advise it on the car leasing.
Mr. Gaffney, who is up for re-election this fall, said that the signature was not his and that he could not recall such a letter, which advised Mr. Alfano to discuss the car leasing with James M. Catterson Jr., the deputy county attorney. Mr. Alfano said he found the letter, which he said was a copy, in his files. No original copies of the letter were ever found, Ms. Brevetti said.
While the county's top elected Republican officials continued to squabble, Democrats looked on and smiled. "There was bombshell after bombshell today, and there will be more tomorrow," said one legislator, Steve Levy, a Democrat.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 16, 1995, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about an investigation of a car leasing deal in Suffolk County referred imprecisely to evidence of forgery, perjury and misuse of taxpayers' money. The County Legislature's special counsel did not indicate who might have been involved. The juxtaposition with a paragraph about District Attorney James M. Catterson was inadvertent.

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
Hotel construction is planned as part of growth at the Seattle-Tacoma International Airport.

BYLINE: By Harriet King 

DATELINE: SEATTLE

 BODY:
THE Seattle-Tacoma International Airport has been generating hotel construction and expansion as traffic at the airport grows.
The latest to announce plans is the Westin Hotels and Resorts. The chain, based here, plans to build a 364-room hotel with conference and meeting rooms connected by a skybridge to the terminal of the airport. 
 The Seattle Airport Hilton is also considering tearing down its 175-room hotel and replacing it with a midrise that would contain up to 500 rooms. "It's a matter of timing," said Peter Lynn, the general manager. "Development may be two to three years away."
Nine hotel chains currently have a total of 2,700 rooms close to the airport. In 1994, they had an occupancy rate of 72.8 percent, said Wolfgang Rood, president of the Pacific Hospitality Consulting Company, a concern in Bellvue, Wash.
The Seattle-Tacoma airport, which is 20 miles south of downtown Seattle, is the fifth-fastest-growing airport in the world. The airport handled 21 million passengers last year, and nearly 40 million travelers are expected by 2020.
More airlines will be flying out of the airport as well. The latest is Asiana Airlines, with flights beginning to Seoul, South Korea, on Monday. Chul Sung Kang, Asiana's general manager in Seattle, said demand was increasing for service because South Korea was the second- largest Asian market for Washington State exports, valued at $2.8 billion a year.
Terry Finn, an airport spokesman, said, "Any new international route such as Seoul is a big plum and brings $150 million a year to our local economy."
The activity stands in contrast to the situation in downtown Seattle, where no new hotels have been built in years. But the occupancy rate for existing hotels is strong at 75.4 percent, Mr. Rood said. Rates downtown average $110 a room, compared with $80 a night at the airport.
The Port of Seattle, the authority that operates the airport, had requested proposals from developers for an airport hotel last year. The Westin chain, which is owned by the Aoki Corporation of Japan, won the competition. Negotiations of the final terms of a 75-year ground lease are nearing completion.
The $40 million hotel, with 16 stories, will be the tallest building at the airport, where the tallest are now six stories. Rick Zieve, lead architect for NBBJ of Seattle, which designed the structure, said that a 200-foot sky bridge would take guests from the airport's main ticketing level across to the hotel lobby. The airport will eventually expand its terminal into the space under the sky bridge.
The hotel will have a 5,000-square-foot ballroom and a large meeting room that can be divided, a health club and board room-style meeting spaces at the 16th floor opening onto a terrace on the roof.
This summer a decision is to be made by the port, the Federal Aviation Administration and the Puget Sound Regional Council, a transportation planning board, on whether to build a third runway of up to 8,500 feet at the airport. The planning council a year ago gave up on its search for a new airport site after meeting resistance from residents.
Since 1992, the agency has spent $174 million to prepare for the future. It has upgraded concourses and doubled retail space to add shops.
The Federal Aviation Administration has said that even without a new runway, economic benefits from increasing activity at the airport would create 110,000 new aviation-related jobs, $17 billion in added business revenue each year and an increase of more than $400 million a year in state and local tax revenues over 25 years.
But Sam Uchello, general manager of the Seattle Marriott at the Seattle-Tacoma Airport, said he expected hotel development to move forward cautiously. He said Boeing's new 700,000-square-foot Spare Parts Center in the area was also drawing vendors and airline personnel and was helping hotel occupancies.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Investment Is A $2 Billion Bet on the Net

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
With its $2 billion investment in Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, the MCI Communications Corporation is making corporate America's biggest bet yet that the Internet is going to be a thriving business in a few years.
MCI is certainly not alone in the corporate rush onto the global computer network. In the last few years, an estimated 10,000 companies have erected their own electronic billboards on the World Wide Web, the multimedia part of the Internet. 
 Yet these are mostly inexpensive experiments to show that the companies behind the Web sites are in step with the high-tech times, not real money-making businesses.
By linking with Mr. Murdoch's newspapers-to-movies group, MCI hopes to add valuable services -- "content," in industry jargon -- to its telecommunications distribution network. That should result, the theory goes, in a profitable business.
"We just got a big-time content provider," said Tim Price, an executive vice president of MCI.
In Mr. Murdoch's view, the MCI-News Corporation linkup will be able to offer "new media services on a global scale" like no other company. While new media may someday mean interactive television, it now typically means transmitting text, audio or video over computer networks -- and the Internet is the biggest new arena.
"This deal underscores how the Internet is becoming the core of a fast, new world for business and information services," said Tony Rutkowski, executive director of the Internet Society, a nonprofit organization in Reston, Va. "It's amazing how quickly it has happened."
The potential market is enormous. An estimated six million computers are linked directly to the Internet, a threefold rise from a year ago, according to the Internet Society. The total number of people who can tap into the Internet from computer keyboards on any given day is estimated at more than 30 million worldwide.
In North America, roughly 47,000 companies have their own Internet mailboxes, or domain names, from which they can send and receive electronic mail. And more than 700 companies are registering domain names each week.
For all the size of the potential market, the amount of business done over the Internet remains quite modest. This year, the total Internet business -- including services, software and shopping -- will be less than $500 million, estimates Forrester Research Inc., a consulting firm.
But MCI and others hoping to profit from the Internet are looking at the future. By 2000, Forrester estimates that business on the Net will reach $10 billion or more.
MCI already has several Internet initiatives and a fast-growing, if modest, business in the field. MCI's revenue for supplying Internet access to companies and universities -- almost nil a year ago -- is now running at $1 million a month. The company's new Marketplace MCI service, where companies market their wares, now includes among its clients the specialty retailer Hammacher Schlemmer and Amtrak.
For its part, the News Corporation's commercial on-line service, the Delphi Internet Services Corporation, is a struggling fourth in the market with 160,000 subscribers in America. That places it far behind the leaders, America Online Inc., which has 2.5 million customers; the Compuserve unit of H& R Block with 1.9 million, and the Prodigy Services Company, a joint venture of I.B.M. and Sears, Roebuck & Company, with 1.6 million. Indeed Delphi is expected to be folded into MCI's information services business.
Many analysts said that the MCI-News Corporation linkup made sense, and that more such deals would follow. But analysts said much the same thing less than two years ago, when the Bell Atlantic Corporation and Tele-Communications Inc. planned to merge. When that plan fell apart, opinions were offered aplenty as to why it did not make much sense after all.
This time, analysts insist, both the rationale and profit prospects are stronger. The Bell Atlantic-Tele-Communications deal was devised when the thinking was that video-on-demand and interactive TV would be the big businesses on the so-called information highway.
But the technology for those services was -- and is -- years away. Internet technology is in place and affordable. What remains is to find a way to make money.
"They may not make a profit from this deal this year or next year," said Jonathan Yarmis, a vice president of the Gartner Group, a consulting firm in Stamford, Conn. "But the timing is right. The Internet is not a fad that is going to go away."

HEADLINE: Administration Rejects Plan As Based on False Promises

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 10

 BODY:
The White House locked horns with Congressional Republicans in the strongest terms yet today, denouncing their plans for balancing the Federal budget by the year 2002 as feckless and economically risky efforts to keep an "arbitrary campaign promise" and insisting that they drop their proposed tax cuts for the wealthy as a condition of negotiations.
With President Clinton away in Moscow, a parade of senior Administration officials appeared in the White House briefing room to accuse the Republicans of making "false promises" by pledging to cut taxes and spending so deeply. They warned that proposed cuts in the growth of the Medicare and Medicaid health care programs, could leave millions of children uninsured and impoverish the elderly and disabled. And they offered no hints of compromise or help. 
 "Look, this is the beginning of their process," Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff, declared. "They've got to drop this tax cut for the wealthy. They haven't done that." Instead, he said, "They are basically saying, you know, we're going to balance this budget on the backs of the elderly and on the backs of children."
Opening a newly explicit line of attack, the President's chief economic policy adviser, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, said the Republican goal of balancing the budget by 2002 was not only impractical but potentially unwise, because it risked prompting an economic slowdown.
Ms. Tyson, who heads the National Economic Council, said the Republicans were trying to balance the budget in seven years to keep "an arbitrary campaign promise" but "with no economic justification for why one wants to achieve that goal by that date." She asked: "Is that good for the macroeconomy? I think the answer is no. It exposes the macroeconomy to considerable downside risk."
Then, in the most pointed statement of a theme that has bubbled for weeks beneath the surface of the White House's arguments, Ms. Tyson argued that too much deficit reduction could be a bad thing.
"Any effort to reduce Government spending takes a dollar out of the economy, and when it takes a dollar out of the economy, that dollar means a dollar of reduction in demand in the economy, so it increases the contractionary risk on the economy," she said. "So if we hit a recession between now and 2002, the attempt to continue to balance the budget irrespective of the state of the economy exacerbates that risk and could aggravate the recession that the economy finds itself in."
On taking office in 1993, Mr. Clinton postponed his own campaign promise of tax relief for the middle class in favor of deeper deficit reduction. But after the Republican electoral sweep last fall, the White House forsook deeper deficit reduction in favor of new tax cuts for families with children and deductions for education.
Republicans have proposed tax cuts of $200 billion over five years, more than three times the amount in the White House plan, and Mr. Clinton contends that those tax cuts are fiscally irresponsible and unfairly skewed to the wealthy.
Mr. Panetta, Ms. Tyson and the officials who joined them -- the budget director Alice M. Rivlin and the Secretary of Health and Human Services, Donna E. Shalala -- made almost no mention of other Republican budget proposals, which would eliminate Cabinet departments, mass transit subsidies and Mr. Clinton's pet national service program, Amercorps, among many others.
Instead, Mr. Panetta saved his most withering fire for the Republicans' overall goals, dismissing them as deceptive and irreconcilable efforts to fulfill promises in the Contract With America. "I think it's clear from the budgets that they have presented that those were false promises to the American people," he said. "In trying to fulfill their contract, the Republicans have broken our nation's contract to working families and to their parents."
Couching their arguments in terms intended to alarm the nation's most powerful political constituencies, Mr. Panetta and Dr. Shalala both took pains to emphasize that two-thirds of the costs of Medicaid, the Federal health insurance program for the poor, supported long-term care for the elderly.
Last year, the Administration itself proposed reductions in projected Medicare spending as part of its unsuccessful health care plan, but Dr. Shalala noted that the intent was to provide more Americans with insurance, albeit in different form.
Mr. Panetta repeated the Administration's position that cuts in Medicare and Medicaid should only be made as part of broader efforts to reshape health care. Referring to Republican plans, he said: "We'll see what the budget committees do. We'll see what the floor does. And then we'll look and see whether or not they in fact backed away from the commitments that we think simply cannot be fulfilled."

HEADLINE: Clinton Chooses Coke in Russia's Cola War

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 10

 BODY:
When President Clinton decided to make one detour from his Moscow summit-meeting agenda to publicize a successful American business investment in Russia, he chose Coke.
The President plans to visit a $65 million Coca-Cola plant near here on Thursday morning. Pepsi, which has already been losing market share to Coca-Cola in the former Soviet Union, was not thrilled with the decision. 
 Now that the competition between the two superpowers has ebbed into an edgy partnership, the frenzied rivalry between the world's two largest soft-drink manufacturers is perhaps one of the more ardent of the post-Communist era. Mr. Clinton's choice was an example of the effectiveness of the aggressive marketing that has helped Coke break through its rival's Communist-era dominance in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe.
The Coke plant in the town of Solnovo, 17 miles from downtown Moscow, is wholly owned by the Coca-Cola Company and even boasts its own "Coca-Cola University," where Russian employees are drilled in the fine points of the American soft-drink business.
That is one reason Mr. Clinton chose to visit it. Joint ventures in Russia with foreign investors have suffered bad publicity of late, the consequence of myriad disputes between Russian and American partners.
Pepsico Inc. also has a bottling plant outside Moscow, but it is a joint venture with a Russian partner. Pepsi executives declined to comment on the Presidential visit to their rival's plant.
The Coca-Cola cause has also been helped by the company's ardent courting of Mr. Clinton's representatives in Moscow. The American Ambassador to Russia, Thomas R. Pickering, visited the plant earlier this year.
And it didn't hurt that the gleaming new Coke plant, with its happy Russian workers, provided an excellent photo opportunity for the President -- or that it was situated so conveniently on the route of his motorcade back to the airport.
Historical forces could also be at work in Mr. Clinton's decision. In popular lore, Coca-Cola has been the drink of the Democrats and Pepsi-Cola the beverage of the Republicans. In recent years Coke has contributed more to Democratic candidates than Pepsi and Pepsi has contributed more to Republicans.
In World War II, Franklin D. Roosevelt asked a Coca-Cola executive to help supply cola to the troops overseas, and before long Coke had set up bottling plants all over the world.
When the Communist state ran the Soviet economy, Pepsi developed a cozy relationship with the Kremlin, and by extension the Soviet bloc, after a visit to Moscow by Vice President Richard M. Nixon in 1959. During that visit, the chairman of Pepsi, Donald Kendall, met with Nikita S. Khrushchev.
In 1972, after Mr. Nixon had become President, Pepsi became the first foreign consumer product to be sold in the Soviet Union.
A few years later Coke found a champion in Jimmy Carter, who replaced Pepsi machines in the White House with Coke machines after he was elected President. The Carter connection may also have helped Coke to become one of the first foreign products sold in China after Chinese-American relations thawed in 1979.
"It's a great honor to have the President of the United States visit our company," said Michael A. O'Neill, head of the Coca-Cola operations in Russia. "And we will be bringing a certain amount of attention to that."
Coca-Cola has brought a great deal of attention to itself during the last four years, with splashy concert and sports promotions, ubiquitous nationwide television advertising and giant billboards and kiosks. Its red-and-white logo is plastered all over Moscow.
Pepsi is quite literally more underground. Pepsico made a deal with the Moscow city government in 1993 to put mobile food stands selling Pepsi, New York hot dogs and Taco Bell burritos in the busiest subway stations in Moscow.
Despite heavy marketing and advertising, Pepsi has lost ground to Coke throughout most of Eastern Europe and the rest of the former Communist world. In 1994 Coke took the lead in soft-drink sales in 10 of the 15 former republics of the Soviet Union, including Armenia, Lithuania and Georgia, breaking the lock that Pepsi held before the Communist bloc began to splinter in 1989.
Russia, with a population of more than 150 million, is where the competition is most acute. Pepsi still retains a strong lead, but Coca-Cola has narrowed the advantage of its rival to 2 to 1 last year, from 4 to 1 in 1993.
After Soviet Communism collapsed, Pepsi was left with a vast network of state-run bottling companies, most of which it kept. Coke, which introduced Fanta in Russia in 1979 and Coca-Cola in 1985, had only a limited presence before 1991. It moved far more quickly to cut its ties to state-run bottling companies and import its own manufacturing and marketing techniques than Pepsi.
When the Berlin wall fell in 1989, and people behind the Iron Curtain were suddenly infatuated with all things Western, Coke had the psychological advantage of seeming like an American soft drink. Pepsi had been around for so long that many Russian consumers saw it as a local beverage.
Pepsi has invested money in new equipment and advertising, but it has not invested nearly as much as Coke, which has poured $1.5 billion into Eastern Europe and $240 million into Russia alone.
But for all their money and energy, Pepsi and Coke combined have yet to overwhelm Russian consumers. American and European soft drinks have only captured 20 percent of the Russian market, and it is a pretty small market at that.
Rough industry estimates suggest that Russians drink 40 to 50 eight-ounce soft-drink servings per capita a year. In the United States, the figure for 1993 was 808 eight-ounce servings, said John Sicher, executive editor of Beverage Digest, a newsletter based in Greenwich, Conn.
And Russian consumers, and even soft-drink salespeople, can be cynical.
"Pepsi and Coke are about the same," said Nina Zikova, who is 48 and sells cigarettes and soft drinks from a cramped kiosk in Moscow, on which hangs a giant Coca-Cola logo. The company that owns her kiosk has an exclusive contract with Coca-Cola, but she said she was skeptical that there was a difference between her product and the rival one. She added with a shrug, "They all come from the same bottle."

HEADLINE: Clinton Rebuffs Senate on Letting Taiwan President Visit U.S.

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 11

 BODY:
The Administration today brushed aside a Senate vote on Tuesday that called on President Clinton to allow Taiwan's President to visit the United States.
State Department officials said that despite the Senate vote to lift the ban on his traveling here, the Administration would not grant a visa for Taiwan's leader, Lee Teng-hui, to attend a June ceremony in his honor at Cornell University, where he obtained a doctorate in agricultural economics in 1968. 
 Administration officials say allowing Mr. Lee to visit this country is not worth the price of touching off a major dispute with China, especially when the United States wants Beijing's backing as Washington presses North Korea to make good on an agreement to freeze its weapons-oriented nuclear program.
The dispute with Congress has put the Administration in a tight spot because while it is loath to offend Beijing, it does not want to appear to be ignoring the will of Congress.
Senator Frank H. Murkowski, the Alaska Republican, who sponsored the non-binding resolution, said, "This is unmistakable proof that the U.S. Congress believes it is in our nation's best interest to improve relations with Taiwan and to do so by permitting the leader of our fifth-largest trading partner to at least spend the night on U.S. soil."
The Senate approved the resolution 97 to 1, the only dissenter being J. Bennett Johnston, Democrat of Louisiana. On May 2, the House approved a nearly identical resolution, 360 to 0.
The Administration moved last year to upgrade unofficial relations with Taipei by allowing meetings between higher-level officials than before. Nonetheless, the Administration is still withholding diplomatic recognition of the island in deference to China, which considers Taiwan a breakaway republic.
In 1979, the United States adopted a policy that recognizes Beijing as the sole Chinese Government.
John Ohta, a State Department spokesman, said the Administration was not rethinking its position, adding that allowing him to visit "would have serious consequences for United States foreign policy."
He said that because Mr. Lee is President, China would not act kindly if the United States granted him a visa "because a visit by a person of President Lee's title, whether or not the visit were termed private, would unavoidably be seen by the People's Republic of China as removing an essential element of unofficiality in the U.S.-Taiwan relationship."
Mr. Ohta emphasized that this policy has nothing to do with the Administration's view of President Lee's accomplishments. Washington has frequently lavished praise on him for consolidating democracy in Taiwan.
Last week the Chinese Embassy issued a statement saying, "We are firmly opposed to any visit by Lee Teng-Hui to the United States in whatever capacity, under whatever pretext and in whatever form."
Albert Lin, spokesman for Taiwan's office in Washington, said his nation "certainly appreciates the friendship and support of members of Congress."
As part of a policy review conducted last year, the State Department decided that President Lee's aircraft could make brief transit stops in the United States "for safety, comfort and convenience." Under that policy, his plane refueled in Hawaii last year.
Christine D. Shelly, a State Department spokeswoman, said anything beyond a short stopover "would be inconsistent with the informal character of our relations with Taiwan."

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN MOSCOW: THE POLICY;
The Growth of NATO: Will Moscow Go Along?

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 10

 BODY:
The big question on the table in Moscow this week was not Chechnya or even the sale of nuclear equipment to Iran.
It was this: Will Russia cooperate in the establishment of a stable security system for central Europe, where this century's two world wars originated? Or will it resist the prescription favored by the United States and its allies, the eastward expansion of NATO, sulk if it takes place anyway, and worsen the tensions developing between President Clinton and President Boris N. Yeltsin and their Governments? 
 Mr. Clinton arrived in Moscow with no clear idea of the answer. He will leave with not much clearer an idea, but perhaps with a little more optimism.
The answer may ultimately depend as much on the dynamics of domestic politics as on considerations of foreign policy. The whole NATO issue shows every likelihood of becoming ensnared not only in the forthcoming Russian parliamentary and presidential elections but also in partisan skirmishing leading up to the American elections next year.
The political context in Russia, especially, is not encouraging.
"All the democrats in this country agree," said a European ambassador here, "that if NATO is alive as an issue when the elections come, it can only work to their great disadvantage. The black hats would use it to call the patriotism of the white hats into question. Can't you just see the debate on television?"
Today's meeting between the two leaders, each of whom felt deceived by the other at their last encounter in Budapest six months ago, produced expressions of good will all around. Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Clinton tried hard to put their mutual recriminations behind them, and the Russians agreed to participate in the Partnership for Peace, as they unexpectedly refused to do last December.
But in the main zone of contention -- the planned expansion of NATO to the east to include such former Soviet satellite states as Poland, which would bring it to the Russian border -- Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Clinton failed so completely to bridge their differences that they did what political leaders seldom do: they admitted it in plain language.
After "a never-ending meeting," the Russian leader said, it was clear that the two sides "still don't have answers to a number of questions -- our positions even remain unchanged."
More talk would be needed at the economic summit meeting in Halifax, Nova Scotia, in June, he said, "and we may not be able to agree there;" if not, NATO would come up yet again late this year at ceremonies marking the 50th anniversary of the United Nations.
President Clinton's task here, a ranking American official said beforehand, was to convince President Yeltsin that the United States sought NATO expansion not to isolate Moscow but to reassure the central Europeans, and that Russia would be brought into the post-cold-war security system on another track.
"Their willingness to keep talking is encouraging, I suppose," the same official said this evening when asked if he saw reason for optimism. "But we clearly didn't make a sale. It's going to be hard, though not impossible."
The United States is determined to press on, with or without Russian approval. To put the matter more baldly than American officials like to, they have decided that it is more urgent to deal with the worries of the central Europeans than to mollify the Russians -- a decision of fundamental strategic importance.
But what they hope, says Robert Legvold, an expert on Russia at Columbia University, is "to have their cake and eat it at the same time."
To that end, the Administration has been offering the Russians various forms of what it calls "compensation," such as closer linkage between NATO and Russia, a possible relaxation in the time schedule for expansion and greater importance for other European institutions and the Russian role in them.
In his remarks today, Mr. Clinton emphasized one of them, the Partnership for Peace. He said he would "encourage the beginning of the NATO-Russia dialogue" in the context of the Partnership. He added, "There must be a special relationship between NATO and Russia."
But Mr. Yeltsin emphasized another group, the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (as he had in an interview last week with Time magazine, when he said, "I think diplomats should focus their efforts on this, rather than discussing terms for the expansion of NATO"). In that group, Russia is on an equal footing with the other members, not in a junior role as in the Partnership.
"We hope that eventually we can just agree to disagree," another American official commented. "The Russians would say that they don't buy NATO expansion. We would say we don't grant Russia a veto on NATO expansion. But we wouldn't come to blows over it."
An open breach over NATO would have serious consequences. It could complicate efforts to win ratification of the second strategic arms reduction treaty, strengthen the hand of the Soviet military and weaken Mr. Yeltsin. Ultimately, if the Soviet Union became angry enough over expansion, it could conceivably lead to the division of Europe into two camps once again.
The Russian Defense Minister, Gen. Pavel Grachev, has already taken the position that NATO expansion would constitute a hostile act against Russia. Earlier this month, he announced that Russia would not carry out its obligation under the 1990 agreement on conventional forces in Europe if NATO expands.
Mr. Legvold, the Columbia scholar, said there was a real risk in the United States as well that "political forces will take over that are not looking for ways to manage the relationship as much as for ways to score points."
Threats have not materialized yet in Washington over the NATO issue. But several American officials have recently said a Russian nuclear sale to Iran could endanger Russian hopes to become a full member of the Group of Seven wealthy industrialized nations and other international economic institutions, and Representative Newt Gingrich, the Speaker of the House, has warned of a cutoff in various kinds of American assistance to Russian in the event of a nuclear sale.
Mr. Clinton urged that Americans and Russians both take a broader view.
"As with any sort of relationship, there will be difference of opinion," he said. "Occasionally, there will even be occasions when our interests are different. I think that we all know there may be consequences to having different positions and different actions.
"But I think we should be quite careful in using the language of threats in a relationship that in the last two years has made the world a safer place."

HEADLINE: A Double-Edged Sword for Detroit

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 10

 BODY:
High American tariffs on Japanese luxury cars would hit the Japanese auto makers in their tenderest spot.
But Japanese auto makers and their dealers could limit the impact of the tariffs, at least in the short term. The most effective step: accelerate imports to increase inventories before the United States Government imposes trade sanctions, as it said it would today. The Nissan Motor Company said it was considering that move. 
 Overstocking cars could give the Japanese companies more than two months' breathing room, perhaps enough time for trade negotiators to resolve their differences.
Once the tariffs bite, though, the Japanese will be caught in a terrible bind, without much freedom either to absorb the increased costs or to pass them on to their customers. Because of the surging yen, prices on Japanese luxury cars have already soared even higher than have prices on European imports.
As a result, the likely buyers of Japanese luxury cars are already turning to reinvigorated European auto makers in a slow migration that could become a stampede.
Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, said today that Washington would impose sanctions on Japan, although he would not describe how. Luxury cars are believed to be at the top of the list.
The Big Three auto makers and the United Automobile Workers union enthusiastically endorsed the Administration's strategy today. But in the short term, the Big Three would gain little from tariffs on Japanese luxury cars.
Instead, Mercedes-Benz, a unit of Daimler-Benz, and BMW, which have restyled their cars and lowered prices in response to Japanese competition, are poised to be the big winners.
The Japanese modeled their luxury cars on European sedans, and their buyers want the same kinds of performance, design and social cachet. Those buyers are generally in their mid-40's, at least 10 years younger than typical Cadillac or Lincoln buyers.
"I don't see the benefits flowing to Lincoln or Cadillac," said Susan Jacobs, president of Jacobs & Associates, an auto consultant in Rutherford, N.J. "It's a big opportunity for the Europeans to bring these people back."
Citing the loss of customers to European makes, dealers with Japanese luxury franchises were quick to predict doom. "Depending on the size of the tariff, we could go out of business," said B. F. Curry Jr., owner of Curry Acura in Scarsdale, N.Y. "Our employees would lose their jobs."
But dealerships generally make more money on parts and service and the sale of used cars than they do on new cars. Asked how long he could subsist on income from those other operations, Mr. Curry said, "not a year" -- a lifetime during such trade brinksmanship.
Still, quickly increasing inventories of Japanese cars could prevent wholesale defections of buyers. Even once the list of sanctions is announced, the companies have at least a 30-day comment period, and probably longer, to import cars unencumbered by the tariffs.
"We're looking at increasing inventory," said Don Spetner, vice president of corporate communications for Nissan North America. Dealers of Nissan's luxury line, Infiniti, have only 34 days' worth of inventory now, because of strong sales this spring after Infiniti announced special incentive programs to make room for a new car, the I30.
Acura, Honda Motor Company's luxury line, said today that it was not considering raising inventory. But at the end of March, its dealers' had on average almost three months' supply, according to the trade publication Automotive News.
Lexus has only a 42 days' supply, a spokesman said. And on Monday, Toshimi Onishi, an executive vice president of Toyota Motor and a member of its board, rejected the idea of bulking up inventories after a speech here.
"Customers would think it was not honorable," he said, speaking through an interpreter. For that reason, Toyota's board last month decided against raising inventories to prepare for tariffs, said James R. Olson, vice president for external affairs at Toyota's American sales arm.
Such honor could come at a high price, should the Japanese companies try to absorb the cost of the tariffs, which could be as much as 100 percent of the price of a vehicle. "You really can't pass the tariff on to the consumer, because you'd kill your dealer body," said Christopher W. Cedergren, senior vice president with the Autopacific Group, a California consultancy.
But Ms. Jacobs, of Jacobs & Associates, said the Japanese companies would have to pass the cost on. They have already drastically raised prices, she pointed out, a sign they could not afford to absorb the strengthening of the yen. "That's why I'm assuming the tariff would have to come through," she said.
