HEADLINE: Clinton Visit To Ukraine Is Welcome

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: KIEV, Ukraine

 BODY:
When the White House proposed that President Clinton stop here for a full day on his way home from the Moscow summit meeting, Ukrainian officials were flattered. But when the White House proposed that he spend a night in the capital, Ukrainian officials were slightly alarmed.
Foreign Minister Gennady Udovenko fretted publicly that Kiev did not have enough suitable hotel rooms to accommodate the American President and his entourage. 
 But the White House, eager to underscore its warm relations with the Ukrainians, accepted pot luck in a Government guest house for the President, his wife and top aides; the rest of the troupe will be in the hotels, living in a style to which they are unaccustomed.
The Clinton Administration views Ukraine as one of its big foreign policy successes. Under the leadership of President Leonid Kuchma, elected last July, the once isolated and economically ruined Ukraine has turned pro-Western and pro-economic-reform, and American officials expect Mr. Clinton's visit in Kiev to serve as a needed pick-me-up after a difficult summit meeting with President Boris N. Yeltsin.
"There are no outstanding differences between us," William G. Miller, the American Ambassador to Ukraine, said the other day. "President Kuchma and President Clinton will discuss how to enable the partnership to move onto an even more effective level."
Hopes for closer relations are high, especially in light of Ukraine's recent record.
Moscow has horrified Washington with its plan to sell nuclear reactors to Iran. Kiev heeded Washington and agreed to give up its nuclear weapons and sign the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty.
Russian economic reform is under siege from Mr. Yeltsin's restive opposition. This year, Mr. Kuchma pushed his radical economic reform package, crafted with the help of Western advisers, through a hostile but divided Parliament.
In contrast to Moscow's bloody, unpopular war in the rebellious region of Chechnya, Kiev is credited with managing a quiet, nonviolent clampdown on the separatist region of Crimea.
The blossoming romance between Kiev and Washington has infected ordinary Ukrainian citizens, who unlike their Russian neighbors are neither blase nor cynical about a state visit of an American President.
A recent public opinion survey of 600 Kiev residents showed that 85 percent of the respondents viewed the visit as "important."
"It's a huge deal for us to have President Clinton here," said Yuri Kravchenko, 28, an unemployed factory worker who was browsing in an outdoor market in Kiev. "And not just because we need foreign aid. He will see for himself that we are a real country now."
The Ukrainian economy, while still fragile, has improved slightly since the darkest days of free-falling productivity and hyperinflation. Signs of development are proliferating: several hard-currency supermarkets and restaurants have opened in the last year. The first tiny steps toward privatization of state property have begun.
The Ukrainian Government welcomes financial assistance, and even the advice that comes with it. Washington has pledged more than $900 million in aid and technical assistance to Ukraine for 1994 and 1995, making Ukraine the fourth-largest recipient of American foreign aid.
Western economic advisers are jubilant about Ukraine's embrace of radical reform. But average Ukrainians, facing rising prices as the Government seeks to obey International Monetary Fund requirements by reducing subsidies, say they are not yet feeling the improvement.
"I think things will get better," said Tatiana Kudriatseva, 57, whose pension pays her $13 a month, only a few dollars more than her monthly rent. "But it is going to take 30 years."
And despite its flirtation with Washington, Ukraine, which proclaimed independence in 1991, remains very much married to Russia in everything but name. With plenty of coal but no oil or gas of its own, Ukraine owes Russia more than $4 billion, mostly in energy bills.
Relations between Kiev and Moscow are particularly bitter these days as negotiations over Crimea and its ethnic Russian majority, and particularly over the division of the former Soviet fleet in the Black Sea, have bogged down.
Ukraine has hinted that it would like Mr. Clinton to exert pressure on Moscow to make concessions on those issues, though the United States is unlikely to risk further alienating Moscow.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Suggests Smaller Benefit Adjustments

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 10

 BODY:
As part of their plan to eliminate the Federal budget deficit, House Republicans today recommended a reduction in the annual cost-of-living adjustment for Social Security and other Government benefits, starting in 1999.
At the same time, Republicans on the House Budget Committee suggested vast changes in Medicare, which would increase costs for many elderly beneficiaries. 
 More than 43 million people receive Social Security, and 37 million are enrolled in Medicare. The annual cost-of-living adjustment in Social Security is based on changes in the Consumer Price Index. Republicans said their proposal was justified because the price index, in its current form, overstated inflation by as much as 1.5 percentage points. Many economists agree that there is some overstatement, but the amount is in dispute.
Lobbyists for the elderly said the proposals violated the Republicans' campaign pledge to make no changes in Social Security. Martin A. Corry, director of Federal affairs at the American Association of Retired Persons, said: "Prior to and after the elections, Republicans made unequivocal statements that Social Security was off the table. Today's proposal is a repudiation of that campaign promise." He predicted "a firestorm" of opposition to any reduction in the inflation adjustment.
The average Social Security benefit for retired workers is $698 a month. In recent years, the annual cost-of-living adjustment, or has been around 3 percent, and in the next decade it is expected to be 3 to 4 percent. The House Republicans would make a one-time permanent reduction of six-tenths of 1 percentage point in the Consumer Price Index, with a corresponding reduction in the inflation adjustment for 1999. This would reduce the basic amount on which future adjustments are calculated, and the cumulative effect could be substantial, totaling several hundred dollars a year for the average beneficiary over five years.
The Bureau of Labor Statistics, which computes the Consumer Price Index, was already planning a revision for 1998. But the Congressional Budget Office said this revision was likely to slow the growth of the index by just two-tenths of 1 percentage point.
The Medicare proposals unveiled today by Representative John R. Kasich, chairman of the House Budget Committee, are far more detailed and specific than those suggested by Senate Republicans, who called for a bipartisan commission to deal with the politically explosive issue.
Republicans on the House Budget Committee recommended three dozen ways to slow the growth of Federal Medicare costs. They include higher premiums, deductibles and co-payments for beneficiaries and strong new incentives for them to join health maintenance organizations, which provide comprehensive care in return for a fixed monthly fee.
Mr. Kasich said the Republican proposals would "expand health care choices for the elderly." But Mr. Corry said the Republicans were "creating a coercive environment in which Medicare beneficiaries will be herded into managed care and out of traditional fee-for-service arrangements."
Under one of the leading options, Medicare beneficiaries would receive Federal vouchers worth a fixed amount, around $5,100 a year, to enroll in an H.M.O. or other private health plan. They would have to use their own money to make up the difference if the cost exceeded the amount of the vouchers, but they could keep most of the savings if they chose less expensive plans.
The Republicans also recommend a stiff financial penalty for new Medicare beneficiaries who refuse to join H.M.O.'s. "Beginning in 1999, all new enrollees choosing Medicare fee-for-service would pay a premium $20 higher than that of current Medicare beneficiaries," one of the Republican recommendations says. The premium is now $46 a month.
The House Republicans would also reduce payments to doctors and hospitals, especially teaching hospitals and those that serve large numbers of low-income patients.
The Budget Committee recommendations are not binding on other committees. The Ways and Means Committee, for example, could choose other policies to achieve the savings required in the annual budget resolution.
But the options recommended today by Mr. Kasich were developed with House Republican leaders and are widely seen as a road map for the type of changes that will be endorsed by the full House and Senate as they try to shore up the finances of Medicare and revamp the program for millions of baby boomers who will retire in the next century.
Confidential documents from the House Budget Committee show that the Republicans are also recommending these changes:
*Double the amount that beneficiaries must pay for doctors' services before Medicare coverage begins. The annual deductible, now $100, would be raised to $200 and then increased automatically to keep pace with the growth of the program. The deductible has been raised only three times in the 30-year history of Medicare.
*Increase the monthly $46 premium by $5 in each of the next four years, then by $6 in 2000 and in each of the following two years.
*Charge higher premiums for beneficiaries with incomes exceeding $70,000 a year. The premium would more than triple, to $164 a month, for individuals with incomes of more than $95,000 a year and couples with more than $115,000.
*Charge patients for a portion of the cost of home health care provided to elderly people residing in their own homes. Republicans said such a charge would discourage overuse of home health services, but lobbyists for the elderly said it would be a tax on frail elderly people.
The House Republicans are proposing similar charges for the use of medical laboratories and skilled nursing homes.

HEADLINE: Black Executives Forming Group to Defend Minority Programs

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 10

 BODY:
A group of black business executives said today that they were forming a political action committee and hiring a lobbyist to fight efforts to eliminate or modify affirmative action programs, including those that set aside a percentage of Government contracts for minority-owned companies.
"Until now, the voice of black business has been largely silent on the twin issues of affirmative action and minority set asides," Earl G. Graves, publisher of Black Enterprise Magazine, said at a news conference. "Today, that changes." 
 Mr. Graves, who was joined by other black executives, said that the group was "drawing a line in the sand" and that there would be "no retreat" on affirmative action. The group is made up of the Black Enterprise 100, the largest black-owned companies in the country.
"Until we get to the point in this country where there is truly a level playing field," said Maceo Sloan, head of the Sloan Financial Group, "where a black business can go to a bank, for example, and be judged, in terms of loans, on the same basis that the majority business in this country are judged; where we have the same access to capital that they have and where there truly is a level playing field, we will very vigorously oppose the effort that is going on right to eliminate all the affirmative action programs."
The executives' effort comes at a time when affirmative action programs, especially the set-aside ones, are under increasing attack, mainly by Republicans. The White House is reviewing all Federal affirmative action efforts, and President Clinton is expected to announce the results of the review soon. Administration officials have privately said that Government set-aside programs have received the most critical look.
Earlier this year, Congress voted to end a tax break for companies that sell television stations and cable systems to minorities. The program came under intense criticism as a result of a proposed sale by Viacom Inc., a New York-based media giant, to a group of investors headed by Frank Washington, a black entrepreneur from California.
Critics of the sale said it was an affirmative action program intended to help minority millionaires.
But today the black executives said that such criticism reflected a double standard because there are several Federal programs like farm subsidies that help well-off individuals and businesses.
"What about all the thousands of millionaires who are majority business owners, and no one raises the issue of that being un-American?" Mr. Graves said. "When we start to do it, all of a sudden, let's change the rules."
Mr. Graves said the 100 largest black-owned companies had combined sales of about $11.7 billion last year and employed about 47,000 people, indicating that if the group could muster its financial resources, it could have significant political impact.
The executives said today that they had not yet solicited all the top black businesses to contribute to the political action committee, which will be called Mobilization for Economic Opportunity. But Mr. Graves said he did not think it would be difficult to persuade them to reach into their pockets.
"Whether you talk about L.A. or San Francisco, or Chicago, or Detroit, or Atlanta or New York, the issues are the same," he said. "It would seem to me we're not going to have a very hard selling point to push here."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Prices Retreat From Recent Highs

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities retreated yesterday, but not before testing recent highs.
Despite the setback, traders and analysts said bonds were still capable of going higher. The market, they said, was weighed down yesterday by a poor response to an auction of 10-year notes and by a Federal Reserve survey of business activity that was not as weak as had been hoped. Market participants were also hesitant to buy ahead of reports on producer prices today and consumer prices tomorrow, they said. 
 The price of the 30-year bond fell 22/32, to 107 26/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 7 percent, from 6.94 percent on Tuesday. Still, the yield is at its lowest point in more than a year.
Yesterday's auction of new 10-year notes "was one of the worst auctions in 10-year note history," said Theodore Ake, government trading manager at Kemper Securities Inc. in Chicago.
The average yield at the auction was 6.60 percent, down from 7.54 percent in February and the lowest since Feb. 9, 1994, when the yield was 5.92 percent.
But Mr. Ake cautioned against reading too much into the poor institutional and retail demand for the notes, noting that many dealers did not have customers lined up ahead of the auction.
"Prices have changed so rapidly over the past several days; few had bothered to book, or line up, customers for the 10-year auction," he said.
"The dealers have been fighting this market," Mr. Ake added. "The last thing they want to do is load up the boat and buy a bunch of securities ahead of important numbers," he said, referring to the producer prices and consumer prices data as well as today's report on April retail sales.
Some traders were also concerned that prices might have peaked, a view that was reinforced by a report that showed some pickup amid an otherwise sluggish economy. The Federal Reserve's quarterly survey of regional business activity, known as the beige book, largely confirmed a widespread slowdown although it did find some gains in the Cleveland, Chicago, Kansas City and Minneapolis areas.
Recent data showing that the economy is slowing at a pace that can stifle inflation, which erodes the value of bonds, has driven a powerful rally in the market. On Tuesday, rates fell below 7 percent for the first time in 14 months, and some traders and analysts expect the rally to resume soon.
"I don't think we have broken the market's bullish psychology today," Mr. Ake of Kemper Securities said. "There is still a positive spin on the data, so the funademental factors are still in play.
Some fund managers also noted that the bond rally was also feeding itself as declining interest rates prompted managers of portfolios with mortgage-backed bonds to buy long-term government debt. As a result of lower rates, more homeowners are expected to refinance their mortgages, which means there will be an increase in the number of redemptions of mortgages backing bonds. To offset the redemptions, the portfolio managers are buying Treasury bonds to maintain their presence in long maturities until the mortgage market settles down.
The market turns its attention today to the April Producer Price Index, which is exepcted to show a rise of three-tenths of 1 percent and a rise of two-tenths of 1 percent in its core rate, which excludes food and energy, according to Kathleen Stephansen, senior economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gasoline Prices Rise as Workers Strike Brazilian Oil Refineries

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Gasoline prices rose yesterday as a strike by oil workers in Brazil and refinery problems in Ohio and Louisiana threatened to reduce supplies.
On other commodity markets, silver prices continued their slide and cotton fell. The Commodity Research Bureau index gained 0.17 point, to 231.18. 
 Defying a court order, 42,000 oil workers stayed off the job in Brazil yesterday, vowing to further slow refinery output. About 7.5 percent of United States gasoline imports come from Brazil.
Meanwhile, a fire yesterday morning caused British Petroleum P.L.C. to slow operations at its 121,000-barrel-a-day refinery in Toledo, Ohio. Heavy rains are also threatening refineries in Louisiana.
Gasoline inventories in the United States are already 5 percent below a year ago, the American Petroleum Institute said after the market closed on Tuesday. Traders are forecasting stronger demand this summer than last year.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, unleaded gasoline for June delivery rose 0.73 cent, to 63.29 cents a gallon. Heating oil for June delivery rose 0.81 cent, to 49.95 cents a gallon. The gains raised June crude prices by 14 cents, to $19.75 a barrel.
Silver prices fell for a second day after a rally in the bond market indicated that investors were not concerned about inflation. Investors often buy silver and other precious metals when inflation threatens the value of other assets. Bond prices slipped back yesterday, but silver continued to decline.
"The rallies in the dollar, the stock market and the bond market imply inflation is not a problem," said Jim Steel, an analyst with Refco Inc. in New York. "When the paper assets are doing so well, silver is not what you want to own."
July silver fell 5.5 cents, to $5.445 an ounce on the Commodity Exchange of New York. Other precious metals also fell, with June gold falling 10 cents, to $384.20 an ounce. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, July platinum fell $1.50, to $431.90 an ounce.
Cotton for delivery in July, before this summer's crop is harvested, surged its 2-cent daily limit amid optimism that prices below $1 a pound would revive export sales.
After trading as high as $1.082 a pound on April 25, July cotton fell to less than $1 a pound on Monday for the first time in almost a month.
High prices have slowed sales to mills in South Korea and Indonesia, traditional buyers of American cotton. With the recent drops, analysts said, demand immediately grew.
The July cotton contract rose 2 cents, to $1.0029 a pound on the New York Cotton Exchange.

HEADLINE: The Fed Makes It Official: Slower Growth

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 10

 BODY:
A periodic Federal Reserve survey confirmed today what markets and economists had been saying in stages -- that the economy was slowing down, growing at a weaker pace than it did last year in most regions of the country.
The Fed released its survey of business activity, known as the beige book, which also indicated that inflation pressure was benign even though the price of goods in the early stages of production was rising. 
 The report was prepared for the next meeting on May 23 of the central bank's rate-setting Federal Open Market Committee. It covered conditions in March and April.
Analysts expect the Fed panel to leave key interest rates unchanged, with most evidence pointing to an economic slowdown -- the Fed's goal in increasing rates seven times from February 1994 through the beginning of February 1995.
Most of the 12 Federal Reserve banks said conditions in their regions reflected "continuing gains in economic activity from March through April, but at a somewhat slower pace."
The exceptions were in the Cleveland, Chicago, Kansas City and Minneapolis areas, where there were reports of solid gains.
The Fed's most recent previous survey had described economic activity as moderating over the winter.
The Federal Reserve survey cited widespread reports of rising commodity and industrial prices. But in most cases, the report said, the increases were "moderate or not accelerating," and were not being passed along to consumers.
The survey added that "despite tight labor markets in some sectors or regions, wage pressures were described as moderate in most areas."
The economy expanded at a 2.8 percent annual rate in the first three months this year, well below an annual rate of 5.1 percent in the last quarter of 1994.
The new Fed survey confirmed that consumer spending was slowing, with most districts reporting sluggish growth. Yet the Chicago and Minneapolis regions reported a pickup in sales and in New York, Cleveland and Atlanta, the overall pace of growth was brisker in April than in March. Manufacturing remained strong in many areas, propelled by business investment.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Huge Gas Rig Begins Journey in Norway

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: OSLO, May 10

 BODY:
Ten powerful tugs began towing the world's largest concrete drilling platform to deep water today, marking a turning point for Norwegian energy.
The giant platform is the centerpiece of the $5 billion Troll gas field on the Norwegian continental shelf. With several important oilfields beginning to run low, Norway is turning to natural gas. 
 "We'll be more than doubling our gas exports through the year 2005, and that is counting only volumes already contracted," said Jens Stoltenberg, Industry and Energy Minister. "We don't know exactly when Norway will begin to produce more gas than oil, but that can take place rather early in the next century."
Production in the Troll field is scheduled to begin next year. The platform under tow will eventually allow Norway to deliver one-third of the gas consumed in Germany, France and Belgium, and smaller amounts to Spain, the Netherlands and Austria, officials said.
Gas covered by the Troll contracts actually started flowing in October 1993 with completion of a 500-mile pipeline from the smaller Sleipner field to Zeebrugge, Belgium. Sleipner gas will continue supplementing the Troll deliveries once the Troll platform begins operation.
All told, Troll gas valued at $100 billion at current prices is to be delivered under European contracts through 2022. Eighty-five percent of the revenue will flow to the Norwegian state, helping maintain one of Europe's highest standards of living. A.S. Norske Shell, a subsidiary of Royal Dutch/Shell, spent four years building the Troll rig in a fjord near Stavanger. It stands 1,549 feet tall. By contrast, the world's tallest building, the Sears Tower in Chicago, is 1,454 feet tall.
"When the contracts were signed in 1986," said Simon Blakey of Cambridge Energy Research Associates in Paris, "this was known as the Norwegian Man on the Moon Project because of its 10-year time frame and the commitment of resources."
Today, 10 tugs generating 130,000 horsepower towed the rig north to the Troll field, 50 miles northwest of Bergen. The 200-mile trip is to take five to seven days at speeds of one to two knots, depending on weather. At a place where the North Sea is 994 feet deep, valves will be opened and water will pour into the rig's hollow concrete base. The ballasted weight of 1.2 million tons will push the structure 36 feet into the seabed.
Forty wells will radiate from the base of the platform, reaching more than 4,000 feet under the seabed. Norske Shell says Troll is the largest concrete-based platform and the heaviest object ever transported. The Shell Oil Company's steel Bullwinkle platform in the Gulf of Mexico is slightly taller, but at 75,000 tons spindly by comparison.
Norway says its oil production will peak next year. Natural gas production will increase yearly until 2005 and level off at six billion cubic feet a day, an extraction rate allowing at least 50 years' production. The Troll platform, to be operated by the state-owned company Statoil, will supply more than half the total.
In last year's referendum debate on joining the European Union, Prime Minister Gro Harlem Brundtland warned voters that Norway's oil age was ending and that membership in the union was needed to diversify the economy. Opponents prevailed in part by stressing the largely untapped gas reserves.
The Troll project had its origin in cold war tensions. When Western Europe planned a major increase in natural gas purchases from the Soviet Union in 1985, the Reagan Administration feared Soviet leverage over Europe. It banned the export of American equipment for pipelines. The eventual compromise was twofold: a ceiling on Soviet gas imports to Europe and the Troll gas agreements of 1986.
Western Europe's gas consumption is expected to increase 2 to 3 percent annually through 2010, Mr. Blakey, the consultant, said. In that period, he said, Norway is expected to surpass Algeria and the Netherlands to become the No. 2 gas supplier to Europe, behind Russia.

GRAPHIC: Photo: As several big oilfields begin to run low, Norway is turning to natural gas. A giant drilling platform is being towed in the North Sea. (Reuters)
 
Map shows the location of the Troll gas field.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains on U.S. Stance Against Japan Trading Practices

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the Japanese yen yesterday after the Clinton Administration said it would file a a broad legal challenge to Japan's trading practices.
The dollar also hit a 10-day high against the German mark, buoyed by a continued selloff of marks that traders stockpiled before France's election and by further indications that the Germany might cut interest rates. 
 "It was a really strong day for the dollar," said Steven Flanagan, vice president at Credit Agricole in New York. "It was really trading toward the top of its ranges."
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar rose to 83.80 yen from 83.35 yen on Tuesday.
The dollar rose after the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, announced that President Clinton had authorized the filing of a formal complaint against Japan with the newly formed World Trade Organization. That announcement followed last week's breakdown of talks between the two countries aimed at opening Japan's auto market.
Mr. Kantor also said the United States would soon publish a list of Japanese products that could be hit with punitive tariffs.
"The market has been waiting to see what Clinton's action will be and it liked the tough stance he seems to be taking," said Rick Porter, a vice president at Bank Brussels Lambert in New York.
In other currency trading, the dollar sustained its rally against the mark as traders continued to unload the German currency. In New York, the dollar rose to 1.3888 marks from 1.3805 marks.
Many foreign-exchange traders had purchased marks ahead of last week's election in France as a precautionary step because of questions about whether the new Government would be committed to a strong franc. But the victory of Jacques Chirac, the conservative Mayor of Paris, has satisfied the foreign-exchange markets. The dollar was further bolstered against the mark yesterday by comments from a German central banker, Hans-Jurgen Krupp, who said that another easing of official German interest rates was conceivable given the "improved monetary situation."
His comments followed similar remarks by two other Bundesbank council members on Tuesday. The Bundesbank's policy makers are to next meet on May 18.
Lower rates would weaken the mark, and thereby help the dollar, by making mark-denominated investments less attractive.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
One answer to overfishing: privatize the fisheries.

DATELINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
WILL fresh fish someday become a delicacy as rare and expensive as, say, truffles? Not likely: the most valuable species could always be cultivated on fish farms. But the collapse of fishing on the once-rich Georges Bank and last winter's near-war between Spain and Canada over the remaining crumbs suggest that the days of relying on the oceans as a primary source of food are numbered.
That was the buzz, if not the formal conclusion, from assorted economists, scientists and bureaucrats assembled last weekend at Columbia University to discuss what was billed as the "current crisis in commercial fisheries." For while fishing remains an enormous industry worldwide, fisheries are being decimated by a combination of politics, technological change and myopia. 
 The problem with commercial fishing is what the environmentalist Garrett Hardin labeled "the tragedy of the commons." The ocean, like the common pasture land in medieval villages, belongs to everyone -- and therefore to no one. Just as it paid peasants to let their animals eat grass down to the roots, it pays fishermen to catch as many fish as possible as quickly as possible,
But anyone with the job of telling peasants to stop doing what they had always done would have had it easy compared with today's custodians of the fisheries. In the last half century, technology has radically increased the capacity of fishing boats to vacuum everything and anything from the sea. And where fishermen lacked capital to buy such boats, they had the influence to persuade governments to subsidize their purchase.
The relentless drive to overfish stalled in the 1970's, when Ottawa and Washington asserted control of 200-mile coastal fishery zones to prevent East bloc trawlers from decimating the Georges Bank. But local fishermen quickly filled the breach. In 1992 Canada was forced to close the Newfoundland cod fishery in the face of collapsing harvests; New England followed two years later. Landings of Atlantic cod fell by two-thirds between 1970 and 1993.
This fiasco is a harbinger of more to come for an industry inclined to eat its seed corn. "Two dollars was spent for every dollar's worth of fish caught worldwide in 1993," said Suzanne Iudicello of the Center for Marine Conservation. Over all, a United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization report estimates that the industry is losing $50 billion a year.
Fishing capacity is now falling since many boat owners can barely buy diesel fuel, let alone replace aging equipment. But there is no hidden hand to lead this market to the promised land of maximum sustainable catches achieved with minimum effort. That is why economists have been so attracted by the idea of privatizing fishing rights.
If the right to catch a fixed percentage of the annual harvest were assigned to individual fishermen, the problem of the commons would be solved. Incentives to overfish would dissolve -- indeed, those with quotas would have a strong stake in sustaining the fishery, much the way owners of farmland have a stake in preventing erosion.
Privatization works, argues Lee Anderson, an economist who is chairman of the Mid-Atlantic Fishery Management Council -- and is quick to point out his views are his own. The Mid-Atlantic Council has privatized harvests of two species with great success, sustaining yields while cutting the number of boats needed by 90 percent. But privatization remains a fighting word for most fishermen, in part because it destroys their self-image as rugged individualists, but mostly because it means a lot of them would have to settle for jobs on shore.
Adding to the grief of those seeking rational management of fisheries is the difficulty of predicting sustainable harvests. For marine biologists now believe that nature as well as man can produce enormous fluctuations in fish populations. "A lot of people have lost sight of this great unknown," said Michael Sissenwine, the chief scientist for the National Marine Fisheries Service.
In a better world, suggests Bill Schrank, an economist at the Memorial University of Newfoundland, the size of permanent fishing fleets would be tied to very conservative estimates of sustainable harvests, and this would be very small. In good times, outsiders would be permitted to fish, too, presumably for a price. But in lean times, there would be no army of fishermen with overdue mortgage payments howling about their sacred right to catch every last fish in the ocean.
Is such a world possible? Richard Cooper, an economist at Harvard, is skeptical. "Fishermen have dug themselves into a very deep hole," he said.
But the conferees at Columbia were less pessimistic, if only because they believe that desperation is the mother of invention. "The current situation is so bad," concluded Giulio Pontecorvo, an economist at Columbia, "that the fishing industry may finally be ready for change."

HEADLINE: HOUSE COMMITTEE ISSUES 7-YEAR PLAN TO ERASE DEFICIT

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Thursday, May 11

 BODY:
The House Budget Committee voted largely along party lines early this morning to approve a seven-year blueprint for future Federal budgets that would wipe out the deficit by the year 2002, largely by reining in health care costs and abolishing hundreds of agencies.
In this morning's 24-to-17 vote, one Democrat, Representative Mike Parker of Mississippi, voted with the Republicans. The Republicans on the Senate Budget Committee released their own budget-balancing plan on Tuesday and debated it on Wednesday but quit before taking a vote. 
 While the House and Senate proposals reach the same end, the House blueprint outlines broader reductions in Federal programs and greater savings than does the Senate's. The House plan must dig deeper to pay for $340 billion in tax cuts that the representatives passed in April.
The size of the House spending reduction would be $1.1 trillion to $1.4 trillion, depending on which projection of future Federal spending it is measured against: President Clinton's own budget proposal, a projection by the Congressional Budget Office or a forecast of spending based on current law.
The tax cuts came in for the strongest denunciation yet from the White House, which insisted again on Wednesday that it would not seriously negotiate over spending reductions until Republicans abandon those parts of the tax package that benefit the wealthy. [Page B12.]
But the Republicans did not need Democratic help to move the House budget plan out of the committee, and they are not likely to need help to push a final compromise version through Congress later this month.
With President Clinton's budget a dead letter in a Republican Congress, the resolutions debated this week will be the foundation for the Federal budget that will take effect next Oct. 1 and for years beyond.
But much work lies between today's action and that budget. While the House panel endorsed the principle of the cuts and even suggested many, Republicans still must vote to make specific reductions, many in politically popular programs.
"We've gone a long way toward reversing the trend of higher taxes and bigger Government for most Americans," the panel's chairman, Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, said of his budget as his hearing opened. "It is a revolution. It is a bold plan. We will downsize Government, shift power away from this city, give Americans a tax cut."
The Democrat Mr. Kasich replaced as chairman, Representative Martin Olav Sabo of Minnesota, expressed admiration at Mr. Kasich's political feat of uniting Republicans behind a budget chock full of painful spending cuts. But he had no kind words for the budget itself.
Government must address society's central problem, the growing gulf between the very rich and the very poor, Mr. Sabo said. But "I frankly find that the basic, fundamental thrust of this document is one that escalates rather than solves the problem," he said. "This is a document that is moving us backwards."
Outside the chambers, lines of legislative aides and lobbyists snaked down halls, awaiting a chance to sit in on the conflict. Inside the hearing room, Republicans set the mood by hanging over the committee leaders' heads a digital "National Debt Clock," which ticked off a $38,158 increase in the nation's $4.7 trillion debt every four seconds. By the time, the 14-hour hearing finished around 1 A.M., the clock had added nearly $500 million.
Lobbyists for the elderly attacked one plan that would keep Medicare spending from rising as fast as projected and another that would have the effect of changing Social Security cost-of-living allowances. That, they said, broke a Republican pledge to exempt Social Security from cuts.
Democrats lustily joined them, condemning the reductions -- especially those in the politically sacred Medicare program -- as cruel assaults on the poor and elderly. In the Senate, they forced Republicans into difficult votes by offering amendments, all rejected, to scale back spending reductions in Medicare and other popular programs.
But the Democrats were badly hobbled by the fact that neither they nor the White House had any alternative proposal that would both erase the deficit and keep the programs they support intact.
For their part, Republicans repeatedly accused the Democrats of fiscal demagogy. They noted that while the House proposal would indeed spend about 15 percent less on projected Medicare spending through 2002, it would still allow spending to increase by 5.4 percent a year over current levels.
The House plan does make cuts from current levels in many programs and abolishes more than a few. Some parts make the budget offered by the Senate Budget Committee chairman, Pete Domenici of New Mexico, seem pallid.
The Senate plan would eliminate the Commerce Department; the House plan abolishes it and the Departments of Education and Energy, too. The Senate plan would pare $250 billion from projected spending on Medicare; the House plan ups the ante to $270 billion. The Senate would allot $100 billion to foreign affairs, a 20 percent reduction from what is envisioned under current law; the House would shave that by another $12 billion.
The Senate would reduce projected spending on space exploration. The House would take its shining jewel, the space shuttle, and sell as much as possible to investors.
The House proposal would reduce projected Medicaid spending by $184 billion through 2002, about $9 billion more than the Senate plan. On the other hand the House proposed increasing military spending more than $90 billion over current projections to $1.9 trillion over seven years.
All those are but recommendations; the actual shape of changes is up to appropriations committees that will have to tailor programs to meet the spending levels that the Budget Committee has proposed. But House Republicans indicated that many of the proposals have been cleared with their appropriations panel, and some -- like a proposal to return welfare to the states -- have already passed the House.
The House proposal would kill 13 Federal agencies. The Economic Development Administration, which dispenses grants to state and local governments seeking to attract new business, would go; so would the Federal Maritime Commission, the main Federal patron to the nation's shrunken domestic shipping and shipbuilding industries. The Legal Services Corporation, the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, the Federal Transit Administration, and the Travel and Tourism Administration would all bite the dust or, in the case of public television, lose their funding in stages.
The House proposes to eliminate 284 Federal programs, from the Education department's Goals 2000 initiative to an outreach program to socially disadvantaged farmers to the National Endowments for the Arts and Humanities. The Points of Light Foundation would lose its Federal aid; so would the volunteer Americorps program.
Representative Kasich said, "I've had Cabinet secretaries come to my office and tell me, 'There's one good thing about your coming to power: now we can get some reform.' "
Turning to his Democratic colleagues he said, "You only had 40 years to do this. You only had 40 years."
But the House budget also leans heavily in its deficit arithmetic on a series of economic assumptions that the more conservative Senate committee shunned as too speculative. Fully $170 billion of the savings in the House plan rest on an assumption that balancing the budget will lower interest rates and reduce Federal borrowing costs.

LENGTH: 675 words

HEADLINE: Republican Budget Extremes

 BODY:
Pete Domenici, chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, proposes to cut nearly one out of every three dollars that the Government spends on domestic programs. He proposes to slash tax credits for poor workers and subsidies for the arts and humanities. He proposes to eliminate the Commerce Department and scores of Federal programs. The Domenici plan would cut Medicare by 15 percent and Medicaid by about 30 percent.
Alarming? Outrageous? The frightening fact is that by current Washington standards, Mr. Domenici is the voice of budget moderation. His House counterpart, John Kasich, issued a seven-year plan yesterday that, by cutting taxes by $350 billion and raising defense by $70 billion, is more than $400 billion harsher on non-defense programs. 
 Mr. Kasich would gut the Legal Services Corporation -- which provides legal assistance to poor people, the Voice of America, and hundreds of other agencies and programs as well as massive cuts, beyond what Mr. Domenici proposes, in food stamps and other welfare programs.
Mr. Domenici deserves praise for holding the line against cutting taxes or boosting defense. But his budget would still victimize vulnerable families by, for example, stripping a $20 billion tax credit from some low-paid workers. Apparently tax hikes are dandy as long as they are aimed only at the needy.
The G.O.P. has vowed to eliminate the deficit by 2002 -- a politically seductive, but economically damaging timetable -- without raising taxes or nicking Social Security and defense. That requires slashing everything that is left over -- not only programs for the needy but also public investments in infrastructure and scientific research on which the long-term health of the economy partially depends. The "moderate" Mr. Domenici has proposed bad public policy.
The Republican drive to balance the budget is forcing irresponsibly hasty cuts in Medicare. The Medicare program is threatening to run a deficit of $100 billion or more each year by around 2005. It must be reduced, and the elderly should absorb much of the cut since they now enjoy huge subsidies that are unrelated to their need. Mr. Domenici and Mr. Kasich propose large cuts -- about a third of their deficit-reduction plans -- but leave unsettled who among doctors, hospitals and the elderly would cough up the savings. Once voters are told, the severe impact of the G.O.P. budget will finally emerge.
The mishandling of Medicare comes in counting on savings before figuring out what reform best protects the integrity of the program. Few experts believe Washington can save $250 billion or more without imposing excessive premiums and deductibles. The responsible way to go about saving money on Medicare is to open up the system to competition. That requires giving the elderly a choice of keeping the current fee-for-service coverage or else choosing a private plan that would offer lower premiums, better benefits, or both. Done properly -- which will require reform of the private insurance market also -- competition can eventually control costs and improve quality. But competition cannot work magic by 2002.
House Speaker Newt Gingrich says that the Medicare cuts are designed solely to save Medicare, not balance the budget. That pledge lacks candor. No one with a mind on health care would decide to whack 15 percent off the cost of a program in an impossibly short time before knowing what reform would work best.
The G.O.P. has fulfilled its campaign promise to propose a smaller Federal Government. The proposed budgets would beneficially eliminate wasteful bureaucracies and ill-deserved corporate handouts, such as subsidies for agriculture and export promotion.
But the G.O.P., which has now issued the outlines of its budget, has yet to tell voters who will win, who will lose and by how much. When that conversation takes place, the Republicans ought to loosen their supposedly ironclad promises. They should either raise taxes a bit to soften the spending cuts, or else let the seven-year timetable slip.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: No Matter How You Slice Vacancy Guidelines, Landlords Win;
Commercial Rent Tax

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Cutting the Rent Tax Generates Votes, Not Jobs" (letter, May 5): Stephen Kagann's criticism of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's proposal to reduce the commercial rent tax is not based on the facts and distorts the Mayor's economic agenda. 
 Mr. Kagann would have you believe that elimination of the commercial rent tax north of 96th Street in Manhattan and in the other boroughs is the only element in the Mayor's commercial rent tax reduction program. Not so. The executive budget also includes a 25 percent cut in the commercial rent tax in Manhattan's central business districts and in other areas south of 96th Street.
This would effectively bring down the commercial rent tax rate in midtown and downtown Manhattan from 6 percent to 4.5 percent. This proposal represents the first across-the-board commercial rent tax reduction in Manhattan since 1981, benefiting all of the city's major employers.
The Mayor is interested in making the entire city more competitive, thereby stimulating the creation of new private-sector jobs for our residents.
 
JOSEPH J. LHOTA
Commissioner of Finance
New York, May 8, 1995

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
Solving the Problems Of Public Education

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
Although "Reading, Writing and Rukeyser" begins with a look at a Baltimore school that has successes along with failures, tomorrow night's hourlong program is less a report than, in Louis Rukeyser's favorite image, an alarm bell. It is a chorus of interviews about what is wrong with the public schools and, sketchily, what should be done about it.
 Jeff Howard, the head of an organization called Efficacy Inc., which Mr. Rukeyser does not trouble to describe, paints a dire picture of an America divided between an educated minority and an uneducated, jobless, bothersome majority. Benno Schmidt Jr., the former president of Yale University, promises that his Edison Project's partnership with some public schools will revolutionize education for the better (a laptop in every lap!), but so far we have only his word for it. 
The hour has a conservative spin, appropriate to a venture paid for by investment companies and fronted by a man whose coiffure is the envy of Wall Street. The strongest voices are those of Milton Friedman, the free-market economist, and Lynne Cheney, the former head of the National Endowment for the Humanities, both of whom want Washington out of the schools.
 Opposed to that are Richard Riley, the Secretary of Education, whose department and job are at risk, and Albert Shanker, the president of the American Federation of Teachers, who offers an argument against school vouchers and other sorts of privatization that goes unanswered in this hour. He says that in any competitive system, private schools are likely to attract the cream of the student crop, leaving the hard cases to the public schools. Mr. Rukeyser, who repeatedly takes time to prompt his guests to criticize political correctness (nobody has a good word to say for it), does not find an opportunity to ask the champions of privatization about Mr. Shanker's concern.
 Higher standards and longer school days and years are urged from all sides. Left unexplored is what is to be done with disruptive or just plain stupid students, whom everyone agrees should not be permitted to keep teachers from teaching and other children from learning. Orphanages? Reform schools? Work houses? Mr. Rukeyser's resounding calls for change leave the problem children out of it, like the Baltimore truant last seen on the program sitting on a stoop, looking as bleak as his future.
 Alarm bells are in order, and it is unreasonable to expect a television program to tell how to overhaul as complicated and resistant an institution as public education. But the ringing slogans with which Mr. Rukeyser concludes ("Kick the bums out of the classroom!"), are not particularly illuminating. A little greater investment in posing questions to which he did not already have the answers might have yielded a more impressive return.
 
READING, WRITING AND RUKEYSER
PBS, tomorrow night at 9
(Channel 13 in New York)
 
Produced by Maryland Public Television; George Beneman and Dwight Phillips, directors; Stephen Reverand, producer; Rich Dubroff, executive producer; John Davis, senior executive producer.

HEADLINE: Clinton, Visiting Kiev, Celebrates Success

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: KIEV, Ukraine, May 11

 BODY:
President Clinton came to this capital today to begin a two-day celebration of Ukraine's striking new willingness to surrender its nuclear weapons and embrace a market economy.
With frictions between the United States and Ukraine over those issues now fading, the White House was unabashed in casting Mr. Clinton's visit as a tribute to the strides taken here by President Leonid Kuchma, who won election last July. 
 Yet even as Mr. Clinton applauded Mr. Kuchma, the President's aides were taking much of the credit today for prodding Ukraine toward better behavior. Mr. Kuchma has hurried the process of nuclear disarmament and pushed economic reforms in the former Soviet republic, a country the size of France that still holds world's third-largest number of nuclear weapons.
Mr. Clinton's top deputies were also moving aggressively to defend the summit meeting that the President just concluded in Moscow with President Boris N. Yeltsin from attacks by Congressional Republicans, underscoring the political dimension of Mr. Clinton's trip even 18 months before the next Presidential election.
While the Administration urged restraint upon critics it accused of making foreign policy into political fodder, its blunt response was bound to elevate the American-Russian relationship to new prominence.
At a news conference here this evening, Secretary of State Warren Christopher all but set diplomacy aside when asked about criticism from Senator Bob Dole, the Republican leader and presidential candidate. On Wednesday Mr. Dole criticized the summit meeting as having been "more successful in ceremony and atmospherics than in substantive results."
Mr. Christopher said: "It seems to me to be a relic of the cold war to think that every time the American President and the Russian President get together, their meeting has to be scored like a night baseball game with wins and losses and a box score. But if there is to be a box score, it seems to me very hard to put this in the loss column or the failure column."
Nicholas Burns, the State Department spokesman, was even more direct. "The summit was a success," Mr. Burns said. "The people who think it was a failure don't understand what happened."
In Washington on Wednesday, Mr. Dole said he was disappointed that Mr. Clinton had been unsuccessful in halting the sale of Russian nuclear reactors to Iran and that no progress had been made in ending the war in secessionist Chechnya. Calling the talks a "failure," Mr. Dole said Congress should reassess relations with Russia.
But Mr. Clinton's deputies labeled the complaint both mistaken and inappropriate.
"It's somewhat surprising that the Senate majority leader would criticize the President of the United States while he was on foreign soil," Michael D. McCurry, the White House spokesman, told reporters aboard Air Force One. "There used to be a tradition that members of Congress did not offer that type of criticism while the President was traveling abroad, but I guess like so many things these days, those traditions of amicability are thrown out the window when politics roll around."
Before Mr. Clinton flew here from Moscow this morning, he met with a cross-section of Russian political leaders and visited a Coca-Cola plant. He also joined Mr. Christopher and his national security adviser, Anthony Lake, in a meeting with the brother and son of Federick Cuny, the 50-year-old American relief worker who is missing in Chechnya.
Mr. Lake said that Mr. Clinton had told the Cunys that the Administration was determined to keep working to find Mr. Cuny, who was at work on a project for the Soros Foundation when he disappeared last month.
At a White House briefing in Kiev this evening, Mr. Lake expressed regret at signs that the fighting in Chechnya was increasing despite the cease-fire.
"I think that you would see the same pattern continuing," Mr. Lake said, speaking before reports emerged of intensive new shelling. "In our view, and as the President said very firmly in his televised address to the Russian people, we continue to see this as a tragedy, and we hope that there can be an indefinite extension of the cease-fire."
Mr. Lake went on to say that the continued fighting was "damaging reform within Russia and damaging Russia's relations with other nations."
The White House had said it expected that Mr. Clinton's talks here with Mr. Kuchma would not be marked by any of the strains in his meeting with Mr. Yeltsin, and all indications tonight were of American-Ukrainian conviviality.
Mr. Clinton and his aides have found much to cheer over the last year, as Ukraine ratified accords pledging a commitment to nuclear disarmament and Mr. Kuchma, who succeeded Leonid M. Kravchuk, rushed through changes that have opened the economy to market forces and encouraged foreign investment.
Today, as Mr. Kuchma greeted him outside Mariinsky Palace, the 18th-century Baroque structure now used by the Ukrainian President, Mr. Clinton was warm in his praise.
"Last year we had a very good year as Ukraine became a nonnuclear state and made dramatic economic reforms," Mr. Clinton said. "This nation is large, strong, committed to independence, committed to having cordial relations with all of its neighbors and with others who share its values. And I believe its strategic importance is very, very great."
The two leaders met privately for 90 minutes, and were joined later by their top aides for more talks.

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Rise as Retail Sales Fall

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 11

 BODY:
In what may prove remarkably good timing, a long-expected rise in inflation seems to be emerging just as the economy has decelerated enough to keep the increase in prices from climbing much further, Government figures suggested today.
The nation's producers managed to raise prices for finished goods by five-tenths of 1 percent in April, the biggest increase since November, while products at earlier stages of production resumed their pattern of hefty increases after a March pause, the Labor Department reported. 
 "You're getting signs that prices in the pipeline are starting to work their way up" toward the consumer, said William V. Sullivan Jr., senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds. "There's some challenge here to the rosy outlook."
At the same time, however, the Commerce Department's preliminary report on retail sales showed a drop of four-tenths of 1 percent in April as consumers spent markedly less for motor vehicles, furniture and other big-ticket items.
This tended to minimize nervousness about the price data since the consumer, whose retail spending alone accounts for one-third of economic activity, has become markedly more cautious this year.
One reason for the April decline in retail sales, according to Rosanne M. Cahn, chief equity research economist at CS First Boston, was "surging" final income-tax payments, which she estimated to have been $13.5 billion higher, netted against refunds, than in April 1994.
A third set of figures today showed that first-time claims for unemployment benefits fell 6,000, to 365,000, in the week ended last Saturday. The more reliable four-week moving average, however, climbed 5,250, to 357,000, the highest point since June.
While a few analysts have begun to call for a relaxation of monetary policy lest the economy skid into recession, most continue to believe the Federal Reserve will do nothing at its next scheduled policy meeting May 23. Among other factors, today's retail sales report was not as weak as it appeared since the Government revised upward the totals for both February and March.
Nor were the price figures so worrisome as to prompt the Fed to raise short-term interest rates again.
"Though disappointing, the April Producer Price Index advance will have no impact on Fed policy," Joseph Liro of S. G. Warburg advised clients. "The Fed has stated that it will tolerate some price pressure as long as the economy shows evidence of slowing to its long-run potential."
Brian M. Jones, economist at Salomon Brothers, concurred. "The thing you've got to focus on is growth," he said.
Still, the pressures were not confined to energy, which jumped 2.3 percent. The so-called core rate that excludes both food and energy rose three-tenths of 1 percent, which, except for a similar rise in February, was the largest since last May.
And producer indexes for goods at the intermediate and crude stages of production surged seven-tenths of 1 percent and 2.1 percent, respectively. This was the biggest jump for raw materials since October 1993.
Producer prices are the prices that manufacturers and farmers charge for the products they sell to retailers, distributors or other buyers.
The price of 36 finished items advanced by at least two-tenths of 1 percent, more than twice as many as declined, Mr. Liro found.
Some of the biggest changes were in food, which fell over all for the third time in four months, as the beef and veal category dropped 7.6 percent, the most in nearly 20 years. On the other hand, floods in California helped send the price of vegetables soaring 17.8 percent after a 5.7 percent rise in March. In intermediate goods, prices of nondurable factory materials, such as chemicals, accelerated 2.5 percent, quadruple the March increase. Durable factory items, such as metals, edged up two-tenths of 1 percent as increases for cement, silver, platinum and zinc more than offset declines for copper, aluminum, copper and brass mill shapes, plywood, hardwood lumber and building paper and board.
Among crude goods, the widely followed category of basic industrial materials climbed 1.2 percent, compared with five-tenths of 1 percent in March.
The Commerce Department report showed retail sales at $192.58 billion for the month, with a rise of three-tenths of 1 percent for nondurables, not enough to overcome a 1.5 percent drop for durables, goods designed to last at least three years. Excluding the automotive group, where dealers saw a 2 percent drop, total sales would have edged up one-tenth of 1 percent.
Merchants selling building materials, hardware, garden supplies and mobile homes suffered a 2.4 percent decline while those selling furniture and other equipment for the home had 1.3 percent less revenue than in March.
The figures are adjusted for recurring seasonal variation, for holidays and for differences in the number of trading days. No adjustment is made for changes in price.

HEADLINE: Stocks Rise, With Help From Dollar Gains

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The stock market, seemingly unmoved by a hint of inflation, rose to new highs yesterday, as the dollar improved.
"There was substantial institutional participation today," said William Rothe, managing director for Alex. Brown & Sons in Baltimore. "The participation was based on continued confidence in a) a soft economic landing, and b) moderate economic expansion" that benefits stocks. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 6.57 points to close at 4,411.19, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 index rose 0.01 point, to 524.37, barely ahead of the record set the day before. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 6.21 points, to 853.83, also a record.
And the bond market, which fell sharply in the morning, recovered in the afternoon, also helping stocks. The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond ended unchanged at 7 percent.
While stocks over all rose slightly, it was surprising that they rose at all. The Producer Price Index, a closely watched measure of inflation, indicated to some a renewal of inflationary pressure. Inflation, or the fear of inflation, hurts the prices of stocks and bonds.
The April index rose five-tenths of 1 percent, compared with Wall Street expectations of four-tenths of 1 percent. The so-called core rate, excluding fluctuating food and energy costs, rose three-tenths of 1 percent, compared with an expected two-tenths of 1 percent.
"But there are so many cross-currents going on today," said Kathleen Camilli, chief economist at Maria Fiorini Ramirez Inc., an investment advisory firm. She noted that April retail sales fell by a larger-than-expected four-tenths of 1 percent and that the Federal Reserve's beige book survey of regional business activity on Wednesday indicated a slowing economy.
What is more, she noted, the dollar demonstrated its biggest one-day gain in nearly four years against the Japanese yen and the German mark. Big institutional investors and traders, especially in Europe, "are now calling a bottom" to the dollar's slide in value, she said. "With the dollar reaching bottom, some foreign money is returning" to American financial markets, she said.
The sharp drop in the dollar has discouraged foreign investors from buying dollar-denominated assets because American profits can be reduced or wiped out when exchanged for strong currencies like the mark. The Dow, for example, has increased 15.04 percent in dollars so far this year, and fallen 1.06 percent in Japanese yen.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was above normal, with 341.4 million shares changing hands, about 2 percent above this year's daily average of 334 million shares.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.05 point, to 282.46, with advancing stocks thinly outnumbering declining stocks, 1,144 to 1,118. The American Stock Exchange market value index rose 2.44 points, to 486.32.
Among advancing stocks was CBT Group, a developer of computer software based in Ireland, whose American depository receipts rose $6, to 35 3/4, in Nasdaq trading. Each A.D.R. represents one share of CBT stock. The company has a development agreement with Microsoft for educational software.
Kellogg rose 3 1/2, to 66 1/8, after a Goldman, Sachs analyst raised her assessment of the stock.
Among declining stocks was the Hilton Hotels Company, which fell 6 1/2, to 71 1/4. Some investors were disappointed that Hilton chose to spin off its casino operations rather than sell the entire company. And some Japanese companies continued to fall in price as trade relations between the United States and Japan grew increasingly hostile. The A.D.R.'s of Canon Inc., each representing five shares, fell 5 1/8, to 73 7/8. The A.D.R.'s of Hitachi Ltd. dropped 2 3/4, to 98 1/4. A Hitachi A.D.R. represents 10 shares.
Of the 30 stocks that make up the Dow Jones industrials, 13 rose, led by United Technologies, up 1 7/8, to 76 3/8. Of the stocks that make up the S.& P. 500, 214 rose -- led by Wal-Mart Stores, up 7/8, to 24 3/8.
The most active Nasdaq stock, with 9.2 million shares traded, was MCI Communications. It rose 3/16 , to 20 3/4.

HEADLINE: Clinton Meets With Opponents of Yeltsin

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 11

 BODY:
In an effort to suggest that his Russia policy is not entirely focused on the politically battered Boris N. Yeltsin, President Clinton ended his two-day summit meeting in Moscow today by having breakfast with 10 leaders of the President's opposition.
At the American Ambassador's residence, Mr. Clinton met with alienated onetime supporters of Mr. Yeltsin like Yegor T. Gaidar, a former Deputy Prime Minister who drafted Russia's economic reform program. He also heard the views of longtime foes like Gennadi A. Zyuganov, head of the Communist Party. 
 But the ultranationalist Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky, who leads the largest opposition faction in the lower house of Parliament, was not included. The White House considers Mr. Zhirinovsky, a fiery and unpredictable politician given to making anti-Semitic remarks, outside the political mainstream.
Mr. Clinton gave a brief presentation, explaining the American two-party system, as well as the role of third-party candidates in his election. But he said he was mainly interested in discussing conditions in Russia. "I am here to listen and learn," he said.
All of his guests complained about the Yeltsin administration. Grigory A. Yavlinsky, leader of the democratic Yabloko faction and a future presidential candidate, said he had warned Mr. Clinton of the "growing authoritarianism" of the Government.
Mr. Gaidar, who leads the Russia's Choice faction, spoke of the rising tide of nationalism in Russia that was causing many Russians to mistrust the West and feel nostalgia for the cold war, when their country was a superpower.
Mr. Zyuganov described people's despair over rising crime, raising the specter that Russia could soon turn into "a big Colombia." He said the Communist Party prescribed "free and democratic elections."
The conversation did not dwell on issues that preoccupied the summit meeting, like the sale of nuclear reactors to Iran or the expansion of NATO, and instead focused on the burning domestic issues of the war in Chechnya, the next presidential elections and economic reform.
According to their political rivals around the table, the representatives of the Communists and the conservative Agrarian Party surprised them by expressing loyalty to economic and democratic reforms in Russia. "Had they spoken like this in the Duma and at public rallies," Mr. Gaidar commented drily, referring to the lower house of Parliament, "I would withdraw from politics."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Surges On New Plan To Cut Deficit

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
The dollar staged its biggest one-day rally in nearly four years, rebounding against the German mark and the Japanese yen on speculation that Washington might do more than in the past to cut the Federal budget deficit.
The dollar was also helped, analysts said, by a new mood among traders that the dollar had plunged too far too fast since the beginning of the year. There was also increasing hope that President Clinton's threat to impose sanctions on Japanese imports meant that the Administration was less likely to resort to trying to drive down the value of the dollar to help narrow the trade gap with Japan. 
 The surge in the dollar followed within hours of the House Budget Committee's vote early yesterday morning to cut spending sharply in a Republican plan to balance the budget within seven years.
The dollar ended the day of trading in New York yesterday at 1.4335 German marks, up 3.2 percent from 1.3888 marks on Wednesday. Against the Japanese yen, the dollar rose by 2.2 percent, to 85.68 yen versus 83.80 the previous day.
Meanwhile, further signs of a slowdown in the economy helped overcome any fears of higher inflation that might have been generated by a report yesterday that producer prices rose at a rate slightly greater than expected. [Page D2.] Stocks rose slightly, with the Dow Jones industrial average up 6.57, to 4,411.19. [Page D6.]
Despite the sharp increase yesterday, the dollar remains well below its level of just a few weeks ago against the world's other two big currencies.
"The market had become overly pessimistic about the dollar," said W. Wayne Grigull, director of foreign exchange at Merrill Lynch & Company. "The good news catalyst" that set off the rally, he added, was "people getting optimistic on prospects for cutting the budget deficit," and the sense that President Clinton was showing stronger leadership in his showdown with Japan over trade in automobiles.
The recent steep decline in the dollar has been caused by concern about the nation's budget deficit, about fears of higher inflation and by worries that the Federal Reserve was not prepared to increase interest rates simply to support the currency.
Looking forward, the dollar's prospects now appear to depend increasingly on perceptions among traders over whether Washington will follow through on vows by those in Congress to cut the budget deficit, analysts said. "One factor that's influencing the dollar is the budget plans released by the House and Senate," said Michael J. Moran, chief economist at Daiwa Securities America, the New York office of the Japanese brokerage firm. "That would be an enormously positive thing for the dollar." A big decline in the Federal budget deficit could help the dollar by reducing the Government's need to borrow from foreign and domestic investors, making more funds available for private investment that would help growth.
Congress's new resolve to cut the budget deficit seems to have caught some by surprise. "I personally was astounded by the House budget," said David Buchen, managing director of Citicorp's North American foreign exchange business.
Nonetheless, there is still a strong tide in the market against the dollar, which remains near its weakest levels in decades. "Deep in my heart, I don't think the dollar is going to become a strong currency with this President," Mr. Buchen said. Indeed, he added, many investors remain wary of the White House, fearing that it is much more concerned about resisting large spending cuts than in defending the currency.
One reason the dollar turned so sharply, analysts said, is because of increasing fears that the German mark is likely to weaken against other European currencies. Mr. Buchen cited recent reports in which, he said, "two members of the Bundesbank poor-mouthed" the German economy, suggesting that German interest rates would continue to fall.
With the dollar's gains, the markets also seemed to be responding to recent Federal Reserve policy. The Fed raised interest rates seven times from February 1994 to February 1995, contributing to a slowdown in the American economy that is helping to dampen fears of future inflation. Susan Phillips, a Fed governor, told reporters in Chicago yesterday that there was now "a good chance" that the economy was slowing to a sustainable pace. New York traders said her remarks helped buoy the dollar.
Slower growth has strengthened the arguments of those who believe that the economy can achieve a so-called soft landing in which it avoids a recession that would cause interest rates to fall sharply, making the United States a less attractive place to hold money.
The Business Council, a group of 100 business leaders meeting in Williamsburg, Va., forecast yesterday that the economy would slow without a recession. It predicted that modest economic growth would continue through 1996. A poll of the group showed that it expected the economy, adjusted for inflation, to expand at an annual rate of about 2.3 percent through the end of 1996. The group also forecast that inflation would remain relatively moderate at 3.2 percent this year and 3.6 percent in 1996.

HEADLINE: The Deficit Debate

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 11

 BODY:
Last summer, the Clinton White House credited the nation's economic expansion to its own deficit reduction efforts. Those same officials have spent the last two days attacking Republicans for risking serious harm with their plans to balance the budget through big cuts in spending.
Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff, said at a briefing last summer, "The fight we had on the economy was essentially a fight in which we were the party that led the charge to reduce the deficit and get the economy going." 
 But today, Mr. Panetta and other senior White House officials warned at another briefing of the dangers of trying to balance the budget by the year 2002, contending that it would limit the Government's flexibility in responding to any recession over the next seven years.
Economists from a variety of political positions expressed a great deal of skepticism today about these warnings. For starters, they said, it is unclear that the Republican budget resolutions announced this week would prove more enduring than legislation in 1985 that required a balanced budget by 1991.
"My guess is if were to adopt a plan such as the resolutions approach, the American people will ask halfway down that path for a correction," said Robert D. Reischauer, a former director of the Congressional Budget Office.
The Republican cuts may bring real hardships to millions of Americans who may lose Government jobs and benefits or pay more for services like Medicare. Yet, many economists believe that even if the Republicans succeed in enforcing the kinds of cuts they have in mind, the cuts by themselves will not slow overall economic growth significantly.
A trillion-dollar cut in spending seems like a lot, they note, until it is compared to the total output of the economy projected for that seven-year period: $54 trillion.
Even more important than spending to the pace of economic growth, at least in the short term, is the size of the deficit. But the Republican plans announced this week would cut the Federal budget deficit each year by an amount equal to less than eight weeks of growth in the nation's economy, even at the current subdued rate of economic growth. That strikes many economists as a fairly gradual pace of budget deficit cuts.
"If you're worried about avoiding a recession, maintaining economic stability and high employment, it doesn't make a heck of a lot of difference," said Charles L. Schultze, who was chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Jimmy Carter. "People who fight deficit reduction on the grounds that it's harmful to the economy are just wrong."
There is clearly a political as well as an economic component to the Clinton Administration's argument. For one thing, it provides justification for standing up for preserving spending that is popular with important constituent groups, as when President Clinton vowed in Iowa last month to defend farm subsidies. And if the economy sours during next year's election campaign, the attacks that the Administration is making now could prove useful in assigning blame.
There is only slightly more sympathy among economists to the Administration's fears about what might happen if the economy, after three years of strong growth, slips into a recession.
Alice M. Rivlin, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, warned in an interview this afternoon that the Republicans might worsen a future recession by locking the country into achieving a balanced budget by 2002.
Since the Depression, policy makers have blunted the effects of downturns in the business cycle by stimulating the economy with extra spending. The Republican goal of balancing the budget "increases the risk, and particularly it increases the risk when you're at a point in the cycle when you've been growing quite a long time," she said.
But even if the Republican Congress passes a seven-year deficit reduction plan this year, a future Congress could pass new legislation to replace it if the economy did run into a severe recession.
If Congress approves the current Republican budget they would be similar in their legal basis to the 1985 Gramm-Rudman legislation, which called for a balanced budget by 1991.
The budget targets were met for two years, but then a new Congress took office in 1987 and, even without a recession, found it too difficult to make the necessary spending cuts to continue meeting the targets. The balanced budget goal was extended, and later abandoned entirely.
Ms. Rivlin said that she nonetheless believed the current Republican plan might prove durable and lock in budget policy making. "It's a piece of legislation, but it's a piece of legislation that needs to be taken seriously, and we take the Republicans seriously," she said.
Mr. Schultze said that if budget cuts did slow economic growth unexpectedly, the Federal Reserve Board could compensate by reducing short-term interest rates to stimulate the economy. Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, strongly hinted that he would do so during Congressional testimony on Feb. 23.
But Laura D. Tyson, the head of the National Economic Council, warned on Wednesday against handcuffing budget policy and relying solely on interest-rate policy to guide the economy.
A more difficult question is whether the composition of spending cuts makes a difference. Ms. Rivlin said that if Congress cuts Government investment programs to reduce the deficit and Government borrowing, there would be a risk that the private sector would not invest the savings as efficiently. Most conservative economists disagree.
