HEADLINE: Budget Cuts Provoke Interest Groups' Fury

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 11

 BODY:
The dramatic spending reductions put forward this week by House and Senate Republicans have stirred up a hornet's nest among interest groups in Washington.
"I think there is no way to look at the current budget proposals and not see them as a drastic hit on environmental programs," said Gawain Kripke, director of the Friends of the Earth Appropriations Project. He was speaking of proposals to reduce financing for research on renewable energy sources and to open the Arctic Wildlife Refuge for oil and gas drilling. 
 "These cuts are so big that for a number of our hospitals, a substantial number, it's going to be very disruptive," Dick Davidson, president of the American Hospital Association said of the proposals to hold down projected increases in the Medicare and Medicaid health programs for the elderly, the disabled and the poor. "Ultimately it will affect quality, and a number of them are going to have to close."
While interest groups representing veterans, the elderly, farmers, mayors, children and the poor castigated the Republicans' proposals, the budget plans received high marks from business lobbyists who believe they will lead to lower interest rates, and from the conservative Christian Coalition, which supports the House's $500-per child tax credit.
"We love the overall thrust of the proposals," said Lonnie Taylor, vice president for Congressional Affairs for the United States Chamber of Commerce. "The chamber has been advocating a balanced budget for years. To have two proposals that are likely to make it to the floor of Congress is just wonderful."
Veteran lobbyists in Washington say there has not been so much concern, praise or protest over a budget proposal since 1981, when President Ronald Reagan and David A. Stockman, then director of the Office of Management and the Budget, sought significant spending reductions and hefty tax cuts.
But the proposals unveiled this week by House and Senate Republicans to pare in the range of $1 trillion from projected Federal spending increases over seven years, dwarf the budget cuts put forward by Mr. Reagan and Mr. Stockman.
"The last time there was this same sense of threat was during the Stockman, O.M.B. years, particularly the early 80's," said a lobbyist who asked that neither he nor his organization be identified. "At that point, those cuts were considered dramatic, if not worse, because we had not experienced anything like them before. But these are much larger."
As they begin to digest the scope of the Republicans' spending plans, representatives of some interest groups say that proposed reductions will play havoc with city budgets by reducing the Community Development Block Grant, will increase economic pressure on farmers by slashing farm price supports by $8 billion to $9 billion, will punish poor working families by reducing the earned income tax credit and will break a longstanding promise to the elderly not to mess with Social Security.
"At the end of this process we're going to learn just how much the public hates the Federal Government," said Thomas Mann, an analyst of government at the Brookings Institution, a research center here. "The Republicans have taken the public at their word that they want a smaller government."
Indeed, the National Taxpayers' Union said the wailing by many groups was in marked contrast to statements these organizations had previously made stating that they favored balancing the budget so long as the pain was spread around equitably.
Pete Sepp, a spokesman for the taxpayers' union, said, "These are the very same groups, when lobbying against the balanced budget amendments, that said, 'We know there have to be cuts in spending and we know we have to balance the budget, but this amendment is not the way to do it.' Now it's time for them to put up or shut up. If they can't come up with a better package, then they shouldn't complain."
Many critics of the Republicans' proposals insist that they support deficit reduction, and some even like some of the Republican cuts -- in other people's programs. "When we don't see cuts in other services such as Social Security, that has us greatly concerned," said Bill Smith, director of Public Affairs for the Veterans of Foreign Wars, who objected to reductions in funds for construction of Veterans hospitals.
When it comes to programs they favor, however, these critics tend to say the reductions go too far, or break longstanding promises.
Martin A. Corry, director of Federal Affairs at the American Association of Retired Persons, said his group was surprised to find that the House Republicans had recommended a change in inflation calculations that would effectively reduce Social Security and other Government benefits starting in 1999.
Under the House Republicans' plan, announced on Wednesday by Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, the chairman of the Budget Committee, the Consumer Price Index would be adjusted downward by six-tenths of 1 percent in 1999, on ground that it overstated the extent of inflation. The move would reduce the cost-of-living adjustments to Social Security payments, which are based on the index, which was already set to be adjusted downward in 1998.
"What was surprising," Mr. Corry said, "was that after all of the statements by leadership on both sides of the aisle, including the President, that they would leave it alone, Mr. Kasich has reached to beyond what the Congressional Budget Office has projected."
Pat Wolff, chief lobbyist for the American Farm Bureau, said agricultural subsidies had already been reduced by 50 percent from the projected spending levels since 1986. Now, she said, the Republicans were pushing for an actual reduction in price supports, rather than merely slowing their rate of growth.
"We believe that if you take a look at historic spending for agriculture, that you find that these cuts are just not equitable," she said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Are Lower Following Volatile Trading

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices were generally lower yesterday, after a volatile trading session.
The market was weighed down by a Government report on producer prices showing inflation at the high end of expectations. 
 With the dollar higher yesterday, there was also concern that foreign central banks would sell their large holdings of Treasury securities, traders and analysts said. More than a dozen central banks sold German marks, Japanese yen and other currencies for dollars in early March as part of a coordinated international effort to support the dollar and have since parked that money in Treasury securities. The recent rally in the Treasury market has realized profits for these banks, so some may have sold, traders speculated.
The price of the 30-year bond edged up 1/32 , to 10727/32 , leaving its yield unchanged at 7 percent. Rates on shorter-maturity bills rates were up 2 basis points on average. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
In addition, the Treasury sold $17 billion of 38-day cash management bills at an average rate at auction of 5.81 percent, with dealers saying demand was strong. Cash management bills are used to meet the Treasury's short-term borrowing needs beyond the money raised at the regularly scheduled auctions.
The report on producer prices helped keep inflation concerns alive in the market yesterday. The Labor Department said its Producer Price Index rose five-tenths of 1 percent in April, the biggest increase since November.
But the inflationary red flag raised by the producer prices report was tempered by a separate report on retail sales that showed an unexpected weakness.
The Commerce Department reported a preliminary estimate of retail sales that showed a drop of four-tenths of 1 percent in April. Retail sales had been expected to be flat.
"This morning's retail sales data support the view of a soft landing -- not a recession," said Marilyn Schaja, an economist for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
She said the latest weekly number of Americans filing unemployment claims for the first time continued to show a soft labor market. Initial jobless claims for the week ending May 6 showed a decline to 365,000, compared with 371,00 in the previous week.
"These data confirm very well to the impression that Fed policy will remain steady for a protracted period," Ms. Schaja said.
Some analysts say the market may be pausing to consolidate the strong gains of the last week. They do not think there is anything around near term that is likely to undermine Treasury securities.
George Mateyo, chief executive of Carnegie Capital Managment Company in Cleveland, said the recent economic news would make buying bonds safe at least for the next eight weeks.
But Carl Palash, chief economist at MCM Money Watch in New York, a market analysis and research firm, said, "Today's numbers fit well with the view that the market has overreacted to recent numbers, and that the extent of the slowdown is not as great as many have perceived."
"I believe that we are in fact at the low point of this slowdown, meaning that I think several factors will converge together to boost growth into the summer," he said. "These factors include a better housing market, in response to lower mortgage rates, better export growth, thanks to a lower dollar and the end of the inventory correction and a pickup in consumer spending, helped in part by the booming stock market."
Mr. Palash expects the Fed will maintain its monetary policy until August or September, "and than we'll see."

HEADLINE: House Action Dooms Plan For a Bridge to Ellis Island

BYLINE: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR 

 BODY:
Money for a bridge linking Ellis Island to New Jersey was removed from a Congressional spending bill yesterday, handing New York a victory in the two-year tussle between the states over the project.
Senator Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey had pushed for the $15 million bridge to improve access to the island and to lure tourists to New Jersey. 
 But the 1,400-foot bridge was opposed by New York and several historic preservation and environmental groups as an attempt at economic piracy that would mar a national landmark. New York gets over $1 million a year from the island in fees alone, while New Jersey gets about $150,000, according to park service officials.
Senator Lautenberg had reserved the money in last year's budget for the bridge, pending an environmental study, and an attempt by New York to kill it then failed. But this year New York prevailed in its attempt to shunt the money elsewhere in the National Park system.
"Today we slammed the door shut on New Jersey's attempt to steal Ellis Island," Representative Nita M. Lowey said in a statement. "Chalk one up for New York."
Although the House and the Senate are still haggling over the spending package, a formal vote is expected within the next two weeks. The bridge's defeat in conference after lobbying by both Democrats and Republicans from New York doomed the plan.
"That's the end of the road," said Bill M. Wise, the spokesman for Senator Lautenberg. The Senator, who had portrayed the bridge as an asset for all Americans rather than a struggle between the two states, issued a statement expressing disappointment at the rejection.
"The bridge to Ellis Island would have been a one-time investment in providing access to one of our nation's most important historic sites," the Senator said. "Now, tourists and the site itself will suffer."
He complained that the Statue of Liberty Ferry, a private New York company, would continue to hold a monopoly with its $7 fare for adults to the island. Ferry company owners could not be reached for comment.
Preservationists from both New York and New Jersey had fought the bridge, saying tourists should approach the island by boat to relive the arrival of their immigrant ancestors. Four in 10 Americans can trace their ancestry to the 12 million immigrants who arrived via Ellis Island between 1892 and 1954.
"From a preservationist point of view, the experience of Ellis Island is such that it must be approached by boat," said Bernadette Castro, Parks Commissioner for New York State. The New Jersey Department of Environmental Conservation had also questioned the need for a bridge, concerned that the extra traffic it generated would erode the quality of Liberty State Park, newly emerging from the decaying freightyards that existed along the shore for years.
A study recently conducted by the National Park Service estimated that Ellis Island, already one of the biggest draws in the country with over a million tourists annually, would get an additional 115,000 visitors if the bridge were built. Officials said that now that the bridge had been defeated, an attempt should be made to make the ferry ride free occasionally, or at least cheaper, as suggested in the study.
This fall the park service was planning to conduct public hearings on ways to improve access to Ellis Island, including the bridge, a tunnel and subsidized ferry rides. It was not clear whether those hearings would be held after the deletion of the money for the bridge.
New Yorkers also accused New Jersey of seeking to build the bridge to strengthen their lawsuit claiming the island, which lies off Jersey City. The United States Supreme Court is expected to hear arguments in that case this fall.
An existing bridge, for construction vehicles, connects the island to the shore, left over from the preservation work in the 1980's, but its permits are due to expire this year. Its open structure was deemed unsuitable for pedestrian traffic, butpreservationists said a sturdier bridge would not only waste taxpayer money but would also lead to tour buses.
The island, built mostly with landfill from the excavation of the New York subways at the turn of the century, still has 30 buildings that have not been restored. Proposals to use them as a combination convention center and hotel have all collapsed, but a bridge would probably be needed for any rehabilitation work.
"To keep the bridge up to be used for construction, I think it would need some additional structural work," Ann Belkov, superintendent of the park, said.
Ms. Castro said permits for the current bridge could be extended on a year-to-year basis, depending on construction plans for the island.
Citizens Against Government Waste, in a 1995 compilation of unnecessary government spending, had listed the proposed new bridge as an "Oinker," pork barrel spending.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Business as Usual in Kiev: By Taunt and Bribe

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: KIEV, Ukraine

 BODY:
When the Kiev city government began building a six-lane highway through the parking lot of a modern, Western-managed office complex last month, the South African Ambassador to Ukraine, whose embassy is in the building complex, blocked the city's bulldozers with his Mercedes-Benz.
The Ambassador, Deon van Schoor, said he was protesting the construction on principle -- city officials had ignored diplomatic agreements about embassies' rights to a security zone and, worse, had not bothered to give the building's tenants advance warning. 
 But he, like other Westerners working in Kiev, also saw the highway intrusion as business as usual; it was the city's way of taunting Maculan, the Austrian real estate development company that manages the building complex. Maculan's negotiations with the city to develop a larger property across the street have bogged down.
For the small cluster of foreign business people in Kiev, the episode is a stark illustration of the pitfalls in trying to start big investment projects in the former Soviet republic, where government corruption is rampant and where doing business means cutting through a Byzantine maze.
Even President Clinton's state visit to Ukraine today and tomorrow underscored the problems that have kept foreign investment at bay. As preparations were under way for the visit, one partly aimed at increasing the flow of investment capital here, Ukrainian officials publicly fretted that they were not sure Mr. Clinton could find proper space to spend the night. There are no Western-style hotel rooms to house the President and his entourage.
Referring to the war-ravaged capital of Georgia, Ambassador van Schoor said, "If they can build a four-star hotel with sauna and swimming pool and modern phones in Tbilisi, of all places, then what's wrong with Kiev?" He spoke of a Marco Polo luxury hotel recently opened there.
In Ukraine, though, the economy has been in a free fall since the republic declared its independence from the collapsing Soviet Union in 1991. Under President Leonid Kuchma, elected last July, the Government has embarked on a radical economic program of budget cutting and market pricing, propped up with hundreds of millions of dollars in foreign aid. Annual inflation, which the Government hopes to bring down to 250 percent by the end of 1995, ran in excess of 10,000 percent in 1993.
There are promising signs. In the last year, a few new joint-venture office complexes, hard-currency shops and fancy restaurants have opened in Kiev. Theme restaurants, many of which are joint ventures, are especially popular among the small but growing number of Ukrainian nouveau riche. Marilyn Monroe impersonators, for example, sashay around the pink and black Studio restaurant; waiters dressed as generals serve steak at a restaurant called the Napoleon.
Still, the rate of foreign investment in Ukraine still lags behind other former Soviet republics. And when it comes to construction of office space or hotels, foreign residents complain of the vagaries -- and worse -- in decisions by the Kiev city government.
"There have been dozens of legitimate offers to build hotels and offices, which are badly needed," said q Western resident, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "But they get blocked by the city. It seems pretty clear that the highway was built across Maculan because somebody didn't get paid off."
Paying bribes is an accepted, if undisclosed, part of business. But many company executives say that paying a bribe to a Kiev official is no guarantee of success; another can pop up demanding an even larger cut.
"One difference about doing business in Ukraine is that you never know who the real decision-maker is," said Boris Dackiw, a lawyer in the Kiev office of Baker & McKenzie. He said that Ukraine's civil laws, particularly in the previously unknown field of private property an real estate, were confused, at times contradictory and always unpredictable. "There is no confidence here that the deal you finally make won't be reversed the next day."
Three years ago, Maculan had secured a contract with the previous city government to put up Kiev's first modern hotel and business complex in an abandoned building in the old section of Kiev. Despite prolonged negotiations with the government elected last year, the project is stalled, the building remains boarded up, and Kiev has yet to see any modern hotel and business complex.
Maculan executives declined to discuss the stalemate. The Mayor of Kiev, Leonid G. Kosakivsky, said in an interview that the city had not demanded more money from Maculan. Its disagreement with Maculan, he said, was due to the company's failure to meet municipal architectural requirements.
"We are ready to sit down and negotiate with those foreign companies that want to really settle down to work, instead of being troublemakers," Mr. Kosakivsky said. "There are plenty of other firms ready to take over the site if the Maculan company can't abide by our rules."
Outsiders were mostly amused by the dispute. "I've never seen a road get built here so fast in all my time in Ukraine," said Philippe Pegorier, the commercial attache at the French Embassy, referring to the highway that sprang up next to the Maculan complex. "The Mayor's diligence was pretty impressive."
The South African Ambassador said he was proud that his well-publicized Mercedes-Benz protest had driven an embarrassed Ukrainian Government to apologize. The city was also obliged, he said, to reduce the highway from six to four lanes to leave room for a security zone in front of the building.
"It was fun," he said of his effort to stave off the city bulldozers. "But the Mayor was furious, and he still is."
Mr. Kosakivsky did not disagree. "I would like to know what the Mayor of New York City would do if some foreign ambassador tried to stop him from building a new road next to a United Nations mission," he said. "I can predict that he would act no differently than the Mayor of Kiev."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Promoting the new world order, and the new order of business, has many faces. President Clinton and the First Lady drank Cokes in Moscow early yesterday with Michael A. O'Neill, head of Coca-Cola's operations there. Then they flew to Kiev and applauded Ukraine's willingness to embrace a market economy. Not all is modern in Kiev business, and hotel space, even for a President, wasn't easy to find. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Wheat Reaches 2-Month High After Forecast of Smaller Crop

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Wheat prices rose yesterday to their highest levels in two months after the Government predicted that frost damage would cut the size of the winter wheat crop.
Another Government report, however, caused soybean prices to decline. Coffee, sugar and cocoa prices also fell, along with silver and oil. As a result, the Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities dropped 0.94 point, to 230.24. 
 Analysts had expected an increase in winter wheat production this year, but the lower estimate prompted buying. Wet weather, which has severely hampered planting of spring wheat in the northern Plains, was also a factor.
Before the start of trading, the Agriculture Department reported that winter wheat production would fall 1.4 percent, to 1.64 billion bushels, below traders' expectations of 1.68 billion.
Wheat for May delivery rose 2.25 cents at the Chicago Board of Trade, settling at $3.66 3/4 a bushel, the highest since March 7.
But Rod Engle, an analyst at Prudential Securities, said that while the wheat production figure was bullish, healthy crops in Texas and Oklahoma might offset much of the freeze losses in Kansas.
As for the spring wheat crop, delays in planting in North Dakota and South Dakota may continue, with the National Weather Service predicting above-normal rainfall in the next 10 days.
Soybean prices declined after the Agriculture Department said leftover supplies this fall would total 425 million bushels, higher than analysts had expected. May soybeans lost 4.25 cents, to $5.59 1/4 a bushel.
Elsewhere, coffee, sugar and cocoa prices fell sharply as speculators bailed out of the market. July coffee sank 4.9 cents, to 169.90 cents a pound, at the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York. July sugar dropped 0.38 cent, to 11.18 cents a pound, and July cocoa declined $24, to $1,276 a metric ton.
A rebounding dollar kept pressure on silver prices as it signaled that inflation could remain in check. July silver fell 7.3 cents, to $5.372 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange in New York.
Swings in energy prices set off a wave of sell orders, sending oil prices down sharply. June crude oil was down 34 cents, at $19.41 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. June heating oil lost 0.86 cent, to 49.09 cents a gallon, while June gasoline edged down 0.01 cent, to 63.28 cents a gallon.

HEADLINE: Rockefeller Center Forced to File For Bankruptcy by Tokyo Owner

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

 BODY:
Rockefeller Center, a symbol of wealth, commerce and power the world over, was forced yesterday to file for bankruptcy protection by the Japanese company that controls it.
The bankruptcy filing will have few, if any, tangible effects on the 12 Art Deco buildings that make up the center in midtown Manhattan, the home of bastions of American enterprise like NBC and its parent company, General Electric, the publisher Simon & Schuster and The Associated Press, as well as Radio City Music Hall. 
 But the filing is an embarrassment for the Rockefeller family, one of the world's richest and most storied, which owns a 20 percent interest in the center. Rockefeller Center, whose first building opened in 1932, was built by John D. Rockefeller Jr., the son of the founder of the family fortune. He decided to move ahead with the center when the economies of the United States and the rest of the world were at their nadir after the stock market crash of 1929.
By gaining protection under Chapter 11 of Federal bankruptcy laws, Rockefeller Center's owners are trying to win some breathing room from creditors.
But the bankruptcy filing is likely to incite a bitter legal fight over the buildings' ownership, as the Mitsubishi Estate Company, the Japanese real estate giant that bought an 80 percent stake for almost $1.4 billion from 1989 through 1991, squares off against the publicly held real estate investment trust, Rockefeller Center Properties Inc., that holds a $1.3 billion mortgage on the property.
The decision to file for bankruptcy has already led to harsh words between Mitsubishi and the Rockefeller family. For three years, the family has fought hard to keep the center out of bankruptcy. [Page D4.]
David Rockefeller, the current family patriarch, flew to Tokyo in February to negotiate a financial restructuring plan with Mitsubishi executives, but the two parties could not come to terms. "It came as a shock and a great disappointment when I heard that the Mitsubishi board in Tokyo has decided to go the bankruptcy route," Mr. Rockefeller said in an interview yesterday.
And in a statement, Richard M. Scarlata, president and chief executive of the real estate trust, described the filing as an "unconscionable attempt to take advantage of U.S. bankruptcy laws, in light of Mitsubishi Estate's significant assets."
Analysts said that the bankruptcy filing would almost certainly force the trust, which has more than 40,000 shareholders, many of whom are retirees and other individuals, to seek bankruptcy protection. The mortgage it holds is virtually its only source of income, and the partnerships will not be making payments while in bankruptcy.
But Stephanie Leggett Young, a spokeswoman for the real estate trust, said it had $50 million of collateral it could draw on to finance its operations. "We feel confident that we are solvent," she said.
The center is technically owned by the two partnerships that filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday: RCP Associates and Rockefeller Center Properties, which is a separate entity from Rockefeller Center Properties Inc., the real estate investment trust that holds the mortgage. The two partnerships, in turn, are owned by Mitsubishi Estate and the Rockefeller family.
In Tokyo early today, the president of Mitsubishi Estates, Takeshi Fukuzawa, said that despite the bankruptcy filing, his company was not now considering selling its 80 percent stake in the center.
The partnerships contend that the weak New York commercial real estate market, which had caused cash shortfalls at the center totaling $623 million as of March, made bankruptcy protection their only option.
But the real estate investment trust, Rockefeller Center Properties Inc., contended yesterday that Mitsubishi Estate has more than enough financial wherewithal to weather the slump in rents. Moreover, the trust said it intended to take ownership of the buildings itself, essentially repossessing them under the terms of the mortgage it holds.
"If Mitsubishi can't pay its bills, we want the keys," said Ms. Leggett Young of the trust.
Michael Claes, a spokesman for the partnerships, said the trust was deliberately trying to confuse issues by suggesting that Mitsubishi Estate was responsible for the partnerships' payments. "The partnerships have the very severe deficit that forced this action," he said. "Mitsubishi is not obligated to subsidize those deficits."
But by filing for protection under Chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code, the partnerships have frozen their assets -- namely Rockefeller Center -- putting them beyond the clutches of creditors like the trust. Bankruptcy protection gives the partnerships breathing room to negotiate a restructuring of the center's financial underpinnings with the creditors.
Among the partnerships' 20 largest unsecured creditors are the real estate investment trust as well as maintenance companies like the E. J. Electric Installation Company of Long Island City and tenants, including Lazard Freres & Company, that were promised improvements in their office space.
In the documents filed in court yesterday, the partnerships were careful not to assign a specific amount to their obligations to the trust.
And analysts and investors who specialize in distressed and bankrupt companies said a fight was sure to develop over how much the trust's bondholders and shareholders -- ultimately the partnerships' largest group of creditors -- are owed. That is the typical bone of contention in bankruptcy court.
Filing for bankruptcy protection has put the partnerships, and by extension, Mitsubishi Estate, into the driver's seat as the process begins. Bankruptcy laws give debtors the first opportunity to come up with a plan of reorganization. Bankruptcy judges in the Southern District of New York in Manhattan, where the partnerships' bankruptcies were filed, also have a reputation for being lenient with debtors.
Judge Prudence B. Abram will preside over the case, and she is scheduled to hold the first hearing at 3:30 P.M. today. The partnerships will seek her approval for a financing package for their use while they are in bankruptcy protection.
In addition to the power that goes to them as a normal part of the bankruptcy proceeding, the partnerships, backed by Mitsubishi's financial muscle, will have even greater sway than the average debtor, some analysts contend. "Mitsubishi is going to wear the pants in this one," said one analyst who has followed the situation for two years and whose firm owned shares of the trust that it eventually sold.
He and others suggested that the partnerships would try to disenfranchise the trust's management and negotiate directly with debt holders, mainly Japanese and European banks and Goldman, Sachs & Company, which own the trust's $775 million of debt. Mitsubishi could, for example, propose paying the debt holders the full value of their claims -- which would amount to roughly $800 million including interest -- in cash or in new debt, in exchange for ownership of Rockefeller Center.
Once creditors whose claims are secured by a debtor's assets are fully repaid, they no longer have a say in the bankruptcy process.
Holders of equity, however, are not so lucky, since their shares are not secured by assets. And the trust's shareholders, some analysts suggest, might end up with nothing, since their claims, unlike the claims of the debt holders, are not secured by any of the partnerships' assets.
As of December, two big banks, Wells Fargo and Bankers Trust, were the two largest shareholders of the trust. But most shareholders are individuals lured to the investment by the glamour of the Rockefeller name and a handsome dividend.
The trust is sure to argue that its shareholders are, in fact, secured by the mortgage, which is backed by Rockefeller Center. And it is unclear whether the partnerships could cut a deal with the trust's debt holders directly unless the trust itself filed for bankruptcy.
In February, Douglas Elliman & Company valued Rockefeller Center at $1.25 billion, and the trust is likely to contend that after paying debt holders, Mitsubishi should give its shareholders $450 million, or the difference between the secured claims and the property's estimated value.
At that value, shareholders would receive almost $12 for their shares, which were trading at $5.25 yesterday, up 25 cents from Wednesday, when the New York Stock Exchange stopped trading in anticipation of the bankruptcy filing.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Rockefeller Center Files For Chapter 11 Bankruptcy
 Rockefeller Center was forced to file for bankruptcy protection from its creditors by the Japanese company that controls it. The move is expected to have little effect on the center, which has long been a symbol of wealth, commerce and power the world over. 
 But the filing is likely to incite a legal fight over the buildings' ownership, as Mitsubishi Estate squares off against the real estate investment trust that holds the $1.3 billion mortgage on the property. A1.
 As recently as Monday, David Rockefeller thought there was a deal to avoid the bankruptcy, but then the deal fell through early Tuesday morning. D4.
What does the filing say about New York? Some real estate executives said the filing could affect perceptions about the New York property market. D4.
 
Committees Approve Budget Plan
 Budget committees in the House and Senate approved separate plans aimed at balancing the budget over seven years. A1.
 The White House has credited the economic expansion to its own efforts to cut the deficit, but has spent the last two days attacking Republicans for risking serious harm with their plans for big cuts in spending. A22.
 
Producer Prices Hint at Inflation
 Producer prices rose five-tenths of 1 percent in April, the biggest increase since November, as a rise in inflation seems to be emerging just as the economy has decelerated enough to keep the rise in prices from climbing much further. Retail sales fell. D2.
 
Cellular Phone Rules Rejected
 The F.C.C. rejected efforts by seven states, including New York and California, to regulate the prices of cellular telephone service. The ruling will let cellular telephone companies change their prices and offer new programs much more rapidly in some states. D6.
 
Disney in Times Square Venture
 The Disney Development Company and a New York developer will build a huge hotel, entertainment and retail complex on 42d Street at Eighth Avenue in Manhattan. B1
 
Silence Ordered After Implant Ad
 A judge in Reno has ordered Dow Corning and other parties to a pending breast-implant lawsuit not to talk to the public or news organizations in response to an ad placed by the company in several newspapers around the country. A14.
 
Big Airline Alliance in Eurpoe
 Lufthansa and S.A.S. agreed to forge an alliance, creating what they said would be the biggest air transport system in Europe. D3.
 
Foreign Investment Lags in Ukraine
 When President Clinton arrived to pay a state visit to Ukraine, his presence underscored the problems that have kept foreign investment at bay in that country. D3.
 
Boston Chicken in Manhattan
 Threatened by the prospect of stagnant same-store sales, Boston Chicken is betting its future on a new expanded menu and is opening its first store in New York City. The two-level restaurant is the very example of the company's new strategy. D2.
 
'Partner' New Trend in Advertising
 More ad agencies are being named or renamed to include or add the word "Partners." Stuart Elliott: Advertising. D5.
 
Brokers Limit Arbitration Options
 Securities lawyers say brokerage firms have been quietly limiting where investors can arbitrate disputes. A29.

HEADLINE: Disney and Developer Are Chosen To Build 42d Street Hotel Complex

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY 

 BODY:
In the first tangible sign that the long-awaited redevelopment of a tawdry stretch of Eighth Avenue is more than a pipe dream, the Disney Development Company and a large New York developer were chosen yesterday to build a huge hotel, entertainment and retail complex on 42d Street at Eighth Avenue.
The $303 million project is the centerpiece of state and city efforts to transform 42d Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues from a seedy strip with its ever-present hustlers and sex shops into a glitzy family-oriented entertainment center. 
 The developers, who still have to line up financing for the project, hope to break ground sometime in 1996 and complete the project in three to four years. The development will include a 680-room hotel, a multilevel entertainment and retail arcade and perhaps a 100-unit time-share hotel.
The city put up $35 million to condemn and acquire the site at the northeast corner of 42d Street and Eighth Avenue. In return, city officials said, the city and the state will receive about $56 million in taxes and leasing fees over a 20-year period. In addition, the project is expected to generate 3,000 construction jobs and 1,400 permanent jobs.
But perhaps of even more value is the Disney name. In its effort to turn around a neighborhood long synonymous with urban danger and degradation, the city now has a partner that is a symbol of wholesome entertainment worldwide.
While Disney has been pushed to the front of the stage as the star of the project, as a development partner it will serve as a supporting player.
Disney's partner, Tishman Urban Development Corporation, will build the hotel, raise funds for the project and operate the hotel or find a company to do so. Disney will be responsible for developing the retail and entertainment portion of the project.
Disney already has a growing presence in New York. In addition to the project announced yesterday, the company is close to completing a deal with the city to renovate the New Amsterdam Theater, just to the east of the hotel site. According to David L. Malmuth, vice president for corporate real estate at the Disney Development Company, the company is also developing a superstore on Fifth Avenue and 55th Street.
And of course the Disney musical "Beauty and the Beast" is still drawing crowds on Broadway.
The selection of the winning developers from several competitors was a closely guarded secret until the announcement yesterday, which itself had a theatrical air. In the presence of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Gov. George E. Pataki, state officials and executives from Tishman and Disney, smoke was blown across a darkened stage in the Academy Theater on 43d Street as a gold curtain was raised to reveal a spotlighted model of the planned hotel project.
Charles Gargano, the chairman of the State Urban Development Corporation, said the developers were selected for the spirit and sophistication of their design.
"Times Square represents the vibrancy, creativity and soul of New York and is worth preserving," Mr. Gargano said, "It is the town square of America and tourists come from all over the world to drink up the atmosphere."
Still to be arranged is the financing for the $303 million project. John L. Tishman, chairman and C.E.O. of Tishman, said that money for the retail property will probably come from a commercial bank after some leases have been signed. Financing for the hotel and time-share project, Mr. Tishman said, will likely come from several equity investors.
The Eighth Avenue hotel is only one part of the Times Square redevelopment project. Another key property in the 10-year-old effort to redevelop Times Square and 42d Street still in the works is the development of four office towers around the intersection of Seventh Avenue and 42d Street.
Last August, the developers of that property, the Prudential Insurance Company of America and Park Tower Realty, retained their stake in the project by agreeing to pay more than $20 million to refurbish storefronts in the buildings that have been condemned and emptied of tenants in preparation for redevelopment. In the meantime the space will be leased to interim tenants while the developers wait for the office market to rebound.
The design for the hotel and entertainment complex, which will replace a string of derelict buildings diagonally across the Port Authority Bus Terminal, is an eye-popping mix.
The 47-story hotel, designed by Arquitectonica, a Miami-based architectural firm, was designed to appear as if it split into two parts by a streak of light on its facade. The 615,000-square-foot hotel will have its main entrance on 43d Street.
The part of the project that will hold the proposed time-share units is a 10-story building with a glass-mosaic facade featuring postcard images of New York. At street level, running 400 feet along 42d Street, will be the retail and entertainment portion of the project, and it will include the renovation of the Case Building. Disney will be an anchor tenant of this part of the project and Sega, the entertainment company, has expressed an interest in leasing 28,000 square feet in the basement of one of the buildings.
There will also be a two-story, 12,000-square-foot restaurant on the Eighth Avenue corner of the project.
As required by the design guidelines for the project, there will be 10 to 12 huge signs scattered at various heights throughout the project.
The Tishman-Disney team won the right to develop the project over seven applicants that included two other finalists, Marriott International and Triarc Equities, and Milstein Properties and Weiler Arnow Management.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Disney Development Company and Tishman Urban Development Corporation were chosen to build a complex on 42d Street at Eighth Avenue. (Chang W. Lee/The New York Times)
 
Chart: "Disney's Inroads"
The announcement yesterday that Disney Development Company is part of the winning bid to develop a hotel project on Eighth Avenue, between 42d and 43d streets, is just the latest sign that the Walt Disney Company has set its sights on New York.
The hotel, to be developed by Dream Team Associates, an affiliate of Tishman Urban Development Corporation, will include an "entertainment component," to be developed by Disney Development Company.
 
ON BROADWAY -- More than 800,000 people have see "Beauty and the Beast" since it opened April 18, 1994, at the Palace Theater. Sarah Uriarte and Jeff McCarthy play the title roles in the Disney musical, which has an unlimited run.
 
ON FIFTH AVENUE -- Construction for a store, with merchandise related to Disney movies and characters, has begun. The two-level store, in the Coca-Cola Building at 711 Fifth Avenue, is expected to open next year.
 
ON 42d STREET -- Disney has signed a 49-year lease to the 92-year-old New Amsterdam Theater, though it can get out of the deal by July 15 if certain conditions are not met. When renovated, in about 18 months, be used to stage Disney shows. The city and state would be paid based on revnues.
 
IN CENTRAL PARK -- On June 10, Disney will take over the Great Lawn of Central Park for the premiere of its animated film "Pocahontas." Eight projectors will be used to show special 70-millimeter prints of the film, which will be projected onto four eight-story-tall screens.
 
IN TIMES SQUARE -- As part of the first anniversary of "Beauty and the Beast" on Broadway, Walt Disney Theatrical Productions provided banners for the Times Square Business Improvement District. They will remain up for about three months. ELLEN C. LESSER

HEADLINE: A Deal Brought Cachet, but Cash Is Another Matter

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

 BODY:
"Japanese Buy New York Cachet With Deal for Rockefeller Center," a headline in The New York Times proclaimed in 1989, when the Mitsubishi Estate Company bought a majority stake in one of the city's enduring symbols.
So when the Japanese company forced Rockefeller Center to file for bankruptcy protection yesterday, questions inevitably arose in the corridors of finance: 
 What does the filing say about New York? Or about the Japanese?
And could it be that cachet, like class, can be acquired but never bought? Or that Rockefeller Center, the towering Art Deco complex that sprawls over 22 acres, has a cachet that exists apart from the world of finance?
"This will hurt New York because of erroneous perceptions," said Meyer S. Frucher, executive vice president of the giant real estate company Olympia & York U.S.A., which itself has taken its blows in the New York real estate market. "It should not hurt New York, because this is a case of an investment gone awry rather than a city gone astray."
Similar views were expressed by William Tung, vice president for corporate real estate for the German media conglomerate Bertelsmann. "The Japanese are learning to behave more like Americans, which means they will explore the bankruptcy system," he said.
Mr. Tung said that in Japanese culture, one who does not pay his debts is dishonored. But he said he did not expect any Mitsubishi executives to fall "on their swords over this -- they're learning to deal with how business is done here."
Warren Wechsler, first senior vice president for the Real Estate Board of New York, resisted the temptation to make sweeping judgments about the Chapter 11 filing, or to see parables about greed of the 1980's sowing seeds of ruin in the 1990's.
"This is so complicated, it's a sui generis situation," he said. Acknowledging that, yes, some people will take pleasure in seeing the Japanese come up short, he suggested that troubles in Japan's economy might have led to some bad decisions. "I don't think it's fair to laugh," he said.
At Rockefeller Center yesterday, it was business as usual, or almost.
"Nothing is going to change as far as the life of the tenants and the operation of the buildings," said Michael Claes, a spokesman for the center's operating partnership. "In many ways, no one will notice the difference."
That seemed to be true, at least among some merchants. A worker in a candy store was asked whether the Chapter 11 filing meant anything to her. "Truthfully, sir, I have no idea what you're talking about," she said before ringing up a $1.26 sale for a raspberry truffle.
But M. Mizrahi, the manager of a watch shop on the Rockefeller Center concourse, was a bit concerned by the bankruptcy filing. "It means the proposals for betterment of the concourse might not happen," he said. And that, he said, could mean fewer customers.

HEADLINE: Man Is Charged in 7 Fires At Jewish Centers in Queens

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE 

 BODY:
A 39-year-old man whose father was Jewish was charged yesterday with having set a series of fires at synagogues, yeshivas and a Jewish center over the past year that have shaken Jews in the Far Rockaway area of Queens.
The fires had conjured up images of anti-Semitism, but the police said the arsonist's motive was anger at his mother, not bias. The man, Brian Bebeck, was arrested and charged yesterday with seven counts of arson and one count of attempted arson. 
 The police said Mr. Bebeck, an unemployed man whom they described as mentally unstable, had worn a yarmulke while setting some of the fires. He apparently set them after arguments with his mother, with whom he shares an apartment in the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn. Mr. Bebeck was reared as a Catholic by his mother, the police said. His father died in 1978.
Mr. Bebeck faces a maximum of 22 years in prison on the charges, the Queens District Attorney's Office said.
The first fire was set at Congregation Derech-Emunoh on July 14, 1994, and the most recent occurred last Saturday at Yeshiva of Belle Harbor.
The police said that Mr. Bebeck, after arguing with his mother, would typically take a bus to Far Rockaway. There, he had found rabbis and synagogue officials receptive to hard-luck stories he would tell them -- for instance, that he needed money for his sick mother.
The police said that Mr. Bebeck set the fires whether he was given money or not and that he received at least several hundred dollars a week panhandling at the synagogues.
Rabbis at Ohab-Tzedek Synagogue called the police when they suspected that Mr. Bebeck stole a donation box full of coins. On being questioned on Wednesday, Mr. Bebeck confessed to having set the fires, the authorities said.
Mr. Bebeck was also arrested in September 1989 for grand larceny, according to detectives at the 100th Precinct in Far Rockaway, who declined to reveal the outcome of that case.
But they did say he was not responsible for a dozen other fires at Jewish centers and businesses in the area. Those, they said, were the work of youths who had already been arrested and charged.
Mr. Bebeck has no history of mental illness, according to his mother, Alice Bebeck, 76, who talked about her son at a neighbor's house yesterday.
Mrs. Bebeck said that on learning her son was arrested, "I fell down the stairs -- I was in shock." Her ankle bore bruises, and a bump was visible on her head. She said her son had moved in with her less than a month ago after being evicted from his apartment two blocks away.
She described Brian as an attentive son who brought her gifts on her birthday and Mother's Day. She said he liked to go out dancing with friends in Bensonhurst nightclubs.
"Brian is very nervous, but he's a nice kid," she said. "We would get into arguments sometimes and he would fly off the handle."
She said he spoke a bit of Yiddish he had learned at the synagogues.
"It's not bias-related," said Charles G. Reuther, the Chief of Detectives, in describing the series of fires. "He had a great affinity for the Jewish community. We're dealing with an individual who is somewhat unstable."
Since the very first blaze was set, police detectives had ruled out bias as a motive, because no anti-Semitic messages were left. But after other Jewish sites in the area became targets, residents began to worry.
"It scared them terribly," said Antony Anisman, assistant director of the Anti-Defamation League. "They did not know where and when the next fire would be. With this arrest, the Jewish community breathed a sigh of relief."
Robert Wein, president of Congregation Derech-Emunoh, said yesterday, "I'm very glad that they caught him. Unfortunately for us, they caught him a few weeks too late."
The 90-year-old synagogue was set ablaze on April 30 for the second time in eight months. Mr. Bebeck is charged with having set both fires.
The second blaze was particularly distressing because repairs from the first had just been completed. Residents spent months raising money and working to repair the weatherbeaten neo-Georgian synagogue at 199 Beach 67th Street and Rockaway Beach Boulevard in the Arverne section of Queens.
Most of the fires were not severe, and were started in garbage cans behind the synagogues.
Mr. Bebeck is charged with having set fires at Yeshiva of Belle Harbor; Congregation Shaare Zedek of Edgemere; Young Israel of Far Rockaway; Glatt Mart Kosher Center, a community center; two fires at Congregation Derech-Emunoh, and one fire plus one attempt at a fire at Temple Beth El.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Brian Bebeck, who has been charged with arson at synagogues and yeshivas in Far Rockaway, Queens, outside the 100th Precinct station house yesterday. (Adam Fernandez for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Treaty Aimed at Halting Spread Of Nuclear Weapons Extended

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, May 11

 BODY:
More than 170 nations agreed today to extend in perpetuity a treaty that has limited the spread of nuclear arms for a quarter of a century.
The Treaty on the Nonproliferation of Nuclear Weapons, a bedrock agreement in Soviet-American relations that arose in the midst of the cold war, became permanent today by acclamation.
The original treaty, which went into effect in 1970, had to be reviewed this year, to decide whether it should be extended for a set period, ended, or prolonged indefinitely. The treaty basically limits nuclear weapons to the five states that had proclaimed them at the time -- the United States, Britain, France, China and the Soviet Union, now Russia. All other signers had to promise not to acquire them. 
 Today's announcement followed four weeks of sometimes bitter debate between those five declared nuclear powers, all of whom favored indefinite extension, and nations without nuclear arms, many of which were just emerging from colonialism when the treaty was written and were hesitant to see it extended in its present form indefinitely.
They argued that the treaty had allowed a small number of countries to have a monopoly over nuclear arms and that these nations were not providing nuclear technology for peaceful uses.
When the conference opened last month, the United States and its allies, among them Russia, faced formidable opposition to an indefinite and unconditional extension of the treaty, and did not have enough declared votes for a simple majority had there been a ballot, according to independent estimates.
Over the weeks, however, the opposition, led by larger developing nations -- among them Mexico, Venezuela, Egypt, Nigeria and Indonesia -- began to split.
The eventual collapse of the opposition to an indefinite extension was hastened by the decision of South Africa to back such a plan and propose a package of confidence-building documents that would meet some of the concerns of the non-nuclear-weapons nations. South Africa has said it abolished its nuclear weapons program, and signed the treaty in 1992.
That package became the basis for negotiations led by the conference's president, Jayantha Dhanapala of Sri Lanka, to find enough common ground for consensus on extending the treaty indefinitely.
In the last 48 hours, President Clinton personally campaigned for the indefinite extension, writing what a United States official called "tough messages" to Egypt and Mexico, emphasizing the importance of the issue to the United States. The official said that there were no threats implied, but that it was made clear that the United States would find it hard to understand why friendly nations that had received help from Washington would not be more cooperative.
Overnight Wednesday, Egypt changed course, abandoning a last-minute effort to name Israel as a violator of the treaty. Israel, India and Pakistan have not signed the treaty and have reportedly pursued nuclear weapons programs outside the safeguards of the International Atomic Energy Agency. Other nations who have not signed the treaty include Brazil, Chile, Cuba, Oman and the United Arab Emirates.
Another group of countries, including North Korea, Iran and Iraq, have signed the treaty but have in the past worked on nuclear weapons programs or are now believed to be doing so.
During the conference, which began on April 17, the Administration set up a 24-hour monitoring operation in Washington to keep track of the positions of key countries and a running tally of the nations that supported an indefinite extension.
"It has been a long hard road, but we have finally reached our destination," Madeleine K. Albright, the United States representative at the United Nations, said at a news conference after the treaty was extended indefinitely. "By reducing the risk that additional countries will become nuclear powers, this sterling success should make the world a safer place for all of us, for our children, and for their children."
Ms. Albright called the treaty "a very important legacy" and said President Clinton had made the treaty's extension "one of his highest foreign policy priorities."
Since January the Administration has made several conciliatory gestures on arms-control issues, most prominently by dropping the demand for an "easy out" clause in talks on a test-ban treaty now going on in Geneva. The Administration now pledges to get the second Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty with Russia, the so-called Start II treaty, ratified by the Senate, where it is languishing in a committee.
Thomas Graham, the Administration's special representative on arms control, traveled for more than a year promoting a permanent extension of the nonproliferation treaty, diplomats and administration officials say. Miguel Marin-Bosch, the deputy head of the Mexican delegation at the conference, said in an interview that the campaign had been impressive. He declined to comment, however, on persistent reports that the Administration had used its economic leverage with Mexico as a tool.
In the last few weeks, some envoys say, quiet diplomacy has turned to more forceful means of pressure by American ambassadors and Administration officials lobbying foreign embassies in Washington.
On Monday, the head of Venezuela's negotiating team, Adolfo Taylhardat, resigned after his Government suddenly changed its position from backing a limited and conditional extension to joining the United States in sponsoring a permanent renewal. In an interview, Mr. Taylhardat said this would not have happened if American pressure on Caracas had not been so intense.
The treaty created a global system that reserved to only five nations the legitimate possession of nuclear arms, a cause of dissent then and now. But as a compromise the accord, which went into force in 1970, gave itself a life of 25 years, after which it could be extended again for fixed periods or become permanent. In those intervening years, most nations -- though not all -- have apparently decided not to pursue the nuclear option.
The result of years of negotiations in the 1960's when the United States and the Soviet Union were locked in an arms race, a space race and intense competition for the loyalty of the newly independent nations, the nonproliferation treaty began the long, slow and still unfinished job of controlling and finally eliminating all weapons of mass destruction.
It formed the cornerstone on which other treaties were built, on missiles, chemical and biological weapons and atomic testing.
When the treaty was signed in 1968 in Washington, London and Moscow, there were fears that a dozen or more nations would soon possess the knowledge and fuel for atomic bombs. Presidents Truman, Eisenhower and Kennedy had sought to control nuclear weapons.
"People were much closer to nuclear devastation as seen in Hiroshima and Nagasaki," said Joseph Ciricione, the executive director of the Campaign for the Nonproliferation Treaty, a coalition of independent arms control research organizations. "Read what Eisenhower said, or Kennedy: 'The weapons of war must be abolished before they abolish us.' "
President Johnson signed the treaty on July 1, 1968, and President Nixon put it into effect two years later. To date, 178 nations have signed the accord.
Today the treaty was extended indefinitely as part of a package with companion documents calling for more progress in disarmament and a strengthened system of monitoring compliance with the pact.
The conference also adopted by consensus a separate, rewritten resolution on the situation in the Middle East that had delayed final action on the nonproliferation treaty for a day.
Today's crucial session was delayed by a last-minute dissent from Iran and Syria to the Middle East resolution, which as originally submitted by 14 Arab nations was intended to draw attention to Israel's undeclared nuclear program. That resolution was resubmitted today by the United States, Britain and Russia with specific references to Israel removed but including other language linking moves toward regional disarmament to the Middle East peace talks.
Syria, which has not concluded a peace agreement with Israel, and Iran, an Islamic but not an Arab nation and thus not an original sponsor of the resolution, finally agreed to new wording that mentioned the peace effort as one of several roads toward making the region safer and free of nuclear weapons.
The negotiations, which went on in a corner of the General Assembly hall as delegates milled around, held up the start of the meeting by about two hours.
Although the treaty was adopted by consensus to avoid a vote, which most delegations here feared would weaken it if the tally fell short of unanimity, more than a dozen nations gave critical speeches after the decision to make the treaty permanent.
Malaysia's delegate to the conference, Hasmy bin Agam, reflected the view of a number of other developing nations when he said the treaty provided a carte blanche to the nuclear powers. He said the accord could be interpreted as "justifying nuclear weapons states for eternity."
In the Statement of Principles and Objectives for Nuclear Nonproliferation and Disarmament, one of the documents that was adopted today, the nuclear powers pledged to reduce and ultimately move toward elimination of their arms.
The statement calls for "the determined pursuit by nuclear-weapon states of systematic and progressive efforts to reduce nuclear weapons globally, with the ultimate goal of eliminating those weapons."
Nuclear-weapon nations also committed themselves to concluding a comprehensive ban on nuclear testing in 1996.
In extending the treaty, the signers also strengthened the process of reviewing compliance by introducing yearly assessments beginning in 1997. Substantive issues concerning the treaty could also be raised in those meetings, as well as in more extensive five-year reviews.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 13, 1995, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about an accord for indefinite extension of the Treaty on the Nonproliferation of Nuclear Weapons misstated the options facing the conference at which the accord was reached. The gathering was to choose among three options -- indefinite extension, extension for a fixed period and extensions for a series of fixed periods. Ending the treaty was not an option.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Market Ignores Inflation As Stocks Continue Surge
Stocks pushed higher, with the Dow Jones industrials rising 19.37 to a record 4,430.56, as traders ignored the strong hints of inflation in the Consumer Price Index for April and instead expressed confidence that the Federal Reserve would not need to raise interest rates again.
Capping a week of small but steady advances, the broader Standard & Poor's 500 rose 1.18 point to 525.55, also a record, and the Nasdaq composite index rose 5.11 points to 858.94, another high. For the week, the Dow advanced more than 87 points. Page 37.
A calm bond market helped lift stocks. Bond prices rose modestly, pushing the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond down to 6.99 percent, from 7 percent on Thursday. 36.
The dollar extended its rally, gaining 1 percent against both the German mark and the Japanese yen. 32.
 
Religious Leaders to Seek Ban on Genetic Patents
Many leaders from virtually every major religion in the United States plan to ask the Government next week to prohibit the current patenting practices for genetic engineering, contending that being able to patent a human gene violates the sanctity of human life and reduces what some call the "blueprint of evolution" to a marketable commodity.
The petition has been endorsed by roughly 100 Catholic bishops, Protestant and Jewish leaders and groups of American Muslims, Hindus and Buddhists. The industry says patents are crucial to commercial biotechnology, and that in seeking to cure diseases it is playing doctor, not God. 1.
 
First-Quarter Loss for T.C.I.
Tele-Communications Inc. posted a loss of 8 cents a share, countering Wall Street's expectations of earnings of about a penny a share. The giant cable operator said its revenues rose 44 percent, partly because of its merger with Liberty Media. 35.
 
Judge Lifts Ad Ban in Implant Case
A state judge in Reno ruled that Dow Corning has a right to publish advertisements in newspapers despite its forthcoming trial involving a breast implant patient. The ruling came two days after the judge ordered the company and other parties involved in the pending lawsuit not to speak to the public or media. The judge had imposed the emergency order in response to a full-page advertisement discussing implants that Dow Corning placed in several newspapers. 7.
 
Merger of Movie Chains Called Off
The proposed merger between Cineplex Odeon and Cinemark USA, which would have created the world's largest movie-theater chain, has been called off. The deal fell apart amid a series of unforeseen changes in the world economy and shifts in corporate power, Wall Street analysts said. The companies said that even without a merger, they have not ruled out cooperating on ventures in the future. 35.
 
Unions Agree to Combine
The governing board of the United Rubber Workers union approved a proposal to merge with the United Steelworkers in a move to shore up the sagging strength of organized labor. The board of the Steelworkers' union is to vote on the matter on Monday. 37.
 
Budget Chief Focused on Deficit
Senator Pete Domenici enjoys a universal reputation as one of the Senate's hardest- working and most intelligent members. As chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, he is also the acknowledged master of the nuances of the Federal budget. But his single-minded pursuit of lowering the deficit has sometimes left him in the political wilderness on Capitol Hill and possibly cost him higher standing within the Republican Party. 1.
 
Cuba Considering Layoffs
The Cuban Government is renouncing the guarantee of lifetime employment in an effort to make Cuba's sagging economy more efficient, and it has begun layoffs that are expected to affect 800,000 people. Officials say the cuts are essential if Cuba is to emerge from the economic crisis brought on by the collapse of the Soviet bloc. 1.
 
Wheat Prices Rise on Midwest Rain
Wheat prices continued to surge, reaching their highest levels in three months as rains forecast for the Midwest threatened to delay spring planting. 32.

HEADLINE: Arthur Hill, Finance Executive And Ex-Ginnie Mae Chief, 46

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Arthur J. Hill, a prominent Florida banker and securities executive who was one of the highest-ranking African-American officials in the Bush Administration, was found dead on Wednesday morning in his hotel room at the Airport Hilton in Elizabeth, N.J., where he had attended a dinner of the Republican Governors Association the night before. He was 46 and lived in Miami.
The office of the Union County Medical Examiner said the cause of death was a heart attack. 
 Mr. Hill managed the public financing branch of New York-based Prudential Securities in Boca Raton, Fla. He had held a number of banking positions in that state, including chairman and president of the Peoples National Bank of Commerce, Miami's only black-owned bank.
In 1989, President George Bush called him to Washington, where he first headed the Government National Mortgage Association and later became Commissioner of Housing at the Department of Housing and Urban Development. His responsibilities during his years in Washington included the management of more than 40 Government-backed mortgage insurance programs totaling $400 billion, the preservation and rehabilitation of housing, and the management of HUD's foreclosed properties.
Mr. Hill, who grew up in Jacksonville, Fla., was a graduate of Florida Memorial College in Miami and of Southern Methodist University's Graduate School of Banking. He also earned a master's degree in agriculture economics at the University of Florida.
He is survived by his wife, Licia Green-Hill; two daughters, Lolita Hill of Washington and 1-year-old Maria; a sister, Clatties Dawkins; and two brothers, Dr. Charmie L. Hill and the Rev. Kenneth Hill.

HEADLINE: Thousands Turn Out to Cheer Clinton in Ukraine

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: KIEV, Ukraine, May 12

 BODY:
President Clinton stood before an enormous outdoor rally in this capital today to pay another tribute to the course Ukraine has chosen since the Soviet Union's collapse.
As more than 15,000 Ukrainians packed into a wooded plaza of the city's premier university, Mr. Clinton left no doubt that his sentiments were very different than those voiced here by President George Bush in 1991, in a speech that was seen as a caution that Ukraine should not stray from the Soviet fold. 
 "God bless America," Mr. Clinton said, then switched to Ukrainian to add, "Glory to Ukraine."
As Mr. Clinton headed home to Washington after four days here in and Moscow, the White House pointed to what it called Ukraine's "stunning turnaround" as evidence that American foreign policy was paying dividends even if this trip did not produce a major success.
This morning's pushing, surging crowd was so vast that hundreds of Ukrainian troops had to be rushed to the scene to reinforce barricades. And while most of those in the crowd showed little reaction as a translator rendered Mr. Clinton's 30-minute address, a throaty cheer broke out as the President hailed a country that the Administration regards as a warm friend.
"I commend you for taking the hard road, for putting the needs of your future and your nation above immediate personal concerns," Mr. Clinton said. "Your efforts will be repaid, for your independent country has a better chance to create freedom and prosperity than it has had in centuries."
A day after more than 170 nations agreed to extend in perpetuity the treaty limiting the spread of nuclear weapons, the President said Ukraine deserved credit for forsaking the nuclear arsenal it inherited from the Soviet Union. And he praised the "bold and farsighted leadership" of President Leonid Kuchma, who since being elected last July has set about reforming Ukraine's economy.
Michael D. McCurry, the White House spokesman, said Ukraine's nuclear disarmament, which is to be completed next year, along with Russia's agreement this week to cancel part of a nuclear accord with Iran, had made Americans more secure. He also defended the modest achievements of Mr. Clinton's meeting this week with President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia.
"The President set out for Russia and Ukraine with fairly limited objectives, and he is satisfied that those objectives have been met," Mr. McCurry said. Asked how the White House intended to counter criticism from Republican opponents about its foreign policy record, Mr. McCurry said it would "engage in that debate vigorously because this Administration believes it has a very good record to defend."
Today, Mr. Clinton made only an oblique reference to the visit that Mr. Bush made here four years ago, when his warning against "suicidal nationalism" was taken by many Ukrainians as an affront.
"I am deeply honored to be the first American President to appear before the people of a free and independent Ukraine," Mr. Clinton said, standing before the crowd at Schevchenko University.
As did Mr. Bush, Mr. Clinton made a solemn pilgrimage to Babi Yar, a ravine that is the site of a mass grave of more than 100,000 victims, many of them Jews, who were killed by special squads of Nazi soldiers during the German occupation of this capital from 1941-1943.
Mr. Clinton visited both a memorial built by the Soviet Government in 1976, which does not mention that a large number of those killed were Jews, and a 10-foot-high menorah erected by Jewish organizations since Mr. Bush's visit to call attention to the Jewish tragedy.
"In the quiet of this place, the victims of Babi Yar cry out to us still," Mr. Clinton said. "Never forget, they tell us, that humanitiy is capable of the worst, just as it is capable of the best."

Clinton Claims Success
 ABOARD AIR FORCE ONE, May 12 (AP) -- President Clinton said today that his summit meeting with President Boris N. Yeltsin went better than most people had expected and that the Russian leader was "cordial, clearheaded and very direct" about Iran and Chechnya.
"I felt quite good about this trip," Mr. Clinton told reporters aboard Air Force One on his way home from Russia and Ukraine.
Citing progress on arms control, he said his overall Russian policy is "clearly a success."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Rockefeller Center Filing May Mean Big Tax Bill

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
While the bankruptcy-law filing by Rockefeller Center saved the Mitsubishi Estate Company from pumping more money into the cash-short property, it could cost the Japanese company as much as $190 million in taxes, accountants and analysts said yesterday.
Initial consideration of the fate of the landmark 12-building center was put off yesterday until a hearing in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan on June 11. But Judge Prudence B. Abram approved a plan for as much as $50 million in interim financing so the center can pay its bills for the next month. 
 Representatives of Mitsubishi, the 80 percent owner of the center, and the Rockefeller family, which owns the remaining 20 percent, yesterday accused each other of negotiating in bad faith during the last few weeks as they tried to forge a bailout plan that would avoid a bankruptcy filing and the associated tax bill.
Rockefeller Center has been in a financial squeeze because the payments on its $1.3 billion mortgage are greater than its income from rent. The two parties were close to a plan that would have substantially reduced the center's annual debt payments by buying outright the mortgage lender: a special-purpose real estate trust called Rockefeller Center Properties.
They were preparing to offer to buy the mortgage lender's stock for $7.50 a share. The offer would also have given the mortgage lender's stockholders the right to participate in future profits from the center, according to people involved with the deal. Its stock had been trading between $5 and $6, but was suspended from trading yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange.
The deal broke down over how the two parties would allocate the approximately $270 million cost of the mortgage lender's stock. The Rockefellers originally proposed contributing their 20 percent share, about $54 million. But Mitsubishi wanted the Rockefellers to put up another $38 million, as a token recognition of the family's enormous gain from the sale.
"The money we were going to put up was on top of our enormous losses, while they were just going to reinvest some of their huge profits," an adviser to Mitsubishi said, speaking on the condition that he not be named. The Rockefellers eventually agreed to put up the $38 million, but they insisted on receiving interest of 12 percent and repayment in five years.
William G. Bowen, chairman of the Rockefeller Trust Committee, said, "We were willing to do more than our pro rata share, but the terms of that additional investment had to make business sense."
The Rockefellers eventually agreed to somewhat more relaxed terms, but they did not offer enough soon enough to satisfy Mitsubishi, advisers to the Japanese company said.
The few million dollars a year in interest that the Rockefellers asked for would be a far lower cost to Mitsubishi than the huge tax bill and other consequences of the bankruptcy filing, but its adviser said that was not its only motivation.
"The tax consequences of the bankruptcy will be far more than the $38 million," the adviser said. "But we were not making decisions purely as a matter of economics. We wanted a gesture from the Rockefeller family on concessionary terms."
The tax bill is likely to be high because when debt is restructured, as it often is in bankruptcy negotiations, the amount of the principal forgiven is treated as taxable income. Even worse, from a tax point of view, if the mortgage lender repossesses the property, which would be the most extreme outcome of the bankruptcy filing, the entire amount of the mortgage is treated as income.
Under that worst-case sequence of events, Rockefeller Group, the owner of the center in which Mitsubishi has an 80 percent stake, would record income of $1.3 billion -- the mortgage amount. It would deduct its cost, minus depreciation on the building and property, which is listed in the bankruptcy-law filing at $713 million.
Federal and local taxes on the nearly $600 million gain would be about $240 million, although the center's accumulated operating losses could be deducted from the gain.
This would nonetheless be a significant financial blow to the Rockefeller Group and Mitsubishi's $1.4 billion investment in the group. The group owns several valuable properties -- including the McGraw-Hill building and the real estate company of Cushman & Wakefield -- in addition to its more problematic holding of Rockefeller Center proper.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The bankruptcy filing by Rockefeller Center provides relief from creditors but creates tax obligations, tax experts say. The center's 30 Rockefeller Plaza is flanked by some of the other 11 buildings in the complex. (Associated Press)(pg. 35)
