HEADLINE: San Miguel's Cosmopolitan Charm

BYLINE: By MARY CANTWELL; MARY CANTWELL is a member of the editorial board of The Times.

 BODY:
EVEN if I hadn't seen the sign I would have known this was the bus for San Miguel de Allende. In a sea of Mexicans stood a small island of gringos: an oldish couple wearing the kind of gear, and attitude, that proclaims Provincetown or Woodstock, several backpackers and two tall, stringy women in their 30's who, it turned out, would talk New York publishing nonstop while the rest of us attempted sleep. San Miguel, four hours north of Mexico City, is 75 percent Mexican but its air is that which is breathed in every arts colony in every part of the world. Here conversation is purer than it is elsewhere, having been filtered (at least for a while) of both commerce and critics.
The roadways are cobblestone and the sidewalks too narrow for two, and this New Year's Eve when I was in San Miguel and going to a party I was reminded of the movie "Don't Look Now." Slowed by high-heeled shoes, I couldn't keep up with my companion, who kept appearing and disappearing along the abruptly cornered, shadowed streets. Sometimes I glimpsed glories -- courtyards and fountains behind somber doors -- but mostly I walked through a darkness and secrecy that was far more Old World than New. 
 The pre-Hispanic population of San Miguel was nomadic, according to the town's visitor's guide, which costs about $15 and is worth it. Eventually it developed into small agricultural communities linked to two great metropolises, Teotihuacan and Tula, and fell to Cortes in the early 16th century.
Today it's a jumble of baroque churches and grand plazas; the rural poor and the Mexico City rich; tourists, mostly middle-aged Americans, who come for the sights, and tourists, mostly young Mexicans, who come for a weekend of dancing at Pancho and Lefty's, possibly the loudest disco on earth. There is also what the tourist guide calls a "new crossbreeding" of Mexicans and Americans who started arriving in the 1950's, whose lives are centered to some extent on the town's two distinguished art schools, Bellas Artes and Instituto Allende, and who are passionately interested in preserving its curiously cosmopolitan charm from halogen street lights, asphalt paving and suffocation by automobile exhaust. San Miguel is also a good place from which to mount an excursion. One can spend a day in any number of interesting towns and ruins and be back in time for a rather more worldly evening than is usually available in Mexico's central highlands.
The best way to see San Miguel is to walk its streets (although the town itself is beginning to sprawl, and its population has reached 110,000, its old center is compact), on all of which I managed to get lost -- mostly because I was forever detouring into a church, a shop or a marketplace. If I am unable to describe the altarpieces of any of the churches it is because they were, without exception, devoted to enormous Christmas creches, my favorite of which had a canvas backdrop painted with the fierce piety of a Giotto. Actually, fierce piety seemed the hallmark of all San Miguel's churches, that and an esthetic impulse that made a marvelously gaudy marriage of 18th-century stonework and 20th-century stars and tinsel.
At one church, Las Monjas, I walked in on a double wedding, sisters in white satin, one of whom was marrying a stiff, shy young man in a white shirt and white trousers, the other of whom was marrying a stiff, shy young man in a white shirt and black trousers. The two bridegrooms never cracked a smile, not even while being serenaded by a brass band or, with their male friends, climbing into the back of the pickup truck that was to take them to the reception. The brides, accompanied by their female friends, were in a separate pickup and grinning from ear to ear.
AT a second church, La Parroquia, on New Year's Eve, the town firefighters, were being celebrated with a procession and, again, a brass band. Brass bands are always within earshot in San Miguel, along with church bells and, on Sunday afternoons, political speeches so amplified as to pound every ear in town.
At the Sanctuary of Atotonilco, however, all is quiet, even desolate. The sanctuary is about nine miles outside San Miguel, but I recommend it for its remarkable frescoes, one chapel's stenciled lace walls, a Virgin Mary in full bridal fig and a life-size Christ in a glass case. His face is tortured, his back scourged, he is carrying the cross and he is wearing what looks like a pink macrame skirt edged with gold fringe. Touring churches can be a dull business, but never in Mexico. The images, however clumsy, have the force of a clenched fist.
Shopping is another of San Miguel's pleasures, even for someone like myself, who usually hates it. The area is known for its crafts, but don't bother looking for them up some obscure street in some obscure outlying village. The best of them are in town. My favorite shops were Zarco Artesanias; Veryka, where I bought a small, elaborately carved wooden church, and Izcuinapan San Miguel. I also liked the antiques shops and especially El Atico where, swamped in San Miguel's omnipresent sanctity, I succumbed to a framed print of the Nino de Atocha, a young prison visitor whose bread and water miraculously multiplied in the manner of the loaves and fishes.
San Miguel is hilly, so after a brisk walk through the Jardin Principal or the Parque Benito Juarez I'd catch my breath in the local library, which has a big, shady courtyard, or in the courtyard of Bellas Artes, where one can get a light lunch. I also stopped for coffee rather often, in little restaurants with irresistible patios, and once (for a margarita) in the pretty courtyard of the Hotel de Sierra Nevada, which is said to be the best in town.
A friend who lives in San Miguel also recommends the much cheaper Hotel Sautto, which gets a lot of art students and has a kitchenette in every room, and the Villa Santa Monica. Since I was staying in a private house I seldom dined out in San Miguel, but restaurants are easy to find. Many are advertised in Atencion, San Miguel's English-language newspaper, which, though lighter on local gossip than I would like, is heavy on local events.
Early one morning I took a bus through an arid, desertlike landscape (passing Dolores Hidalgo, a good place for tiles and old furniture, especially fanciful iron beds) to Guanajuato, the capital of the state of Guanajuato. Buses are cheap, and the most sensible way to get around this part of the world.
GUANAJUATO, in a silver-mining district, gave a lot of money to the Spanish crown during the 18th century. Judging by its great colonial buildings, it appears to have spent quite a bit on itself as well. But what I found most interesting about the city, which is also the site of a university, was its steep, sharply angled streets and huge, glass-roofed marketplace. Diego Rivera was born in Guanajuato, in a house that is now a museum. As a house it is boring, being clumsily renovated and dully furnished; as a record of his evolution as a painter it is fascinating, since it tracks Rivera from the time he was painting like virtually every other artist around to when, finally, he was painting only like himself. The state Museum of History and Archeology is fascinating, too, and presumably exhaustive, but I wished there, as I wished almost everywhere I went, that there had been more information about the exhibits and the city printed in English.
On the whole, though, it is a pity to stay indoors in Guanajuato, when there are all those narrow, vertiginous streets (reminiscent of Toledo and Lisbon's Alfama) to walk, and all those little plazas to sit in. Most of my sitting was done at the sidewalk cafe at the Hotel Museo Posada de Santa Fe, the home of the Prussian consulate during the reign of the unfortunate Maximilian. It faces a park with a charming Edwardian bandstand, is just down the street from the Juarez Theater, which would have done well as the set for the opening of "The Age of Innocence," and is within strolling distance of most of the best of Guanajuato.
Guanajuato is one bus trip to the north of San Miguel. Patzcuaro, which is about 100 miles to the southwest, takes three buses and is something else entirely. Where the faces are Spanish in Guanajuato, they are Indian in Patzcuaro, and on Fridays Tarascan Indians sell their pottery in the Plaza Vasco de Quiroga. Even so, the town itself evokes the Europe of 150 or so years ago. One can imagine Emma Bovary immured there, in one of its shuttered, secretive houses, running up a bill at the local dressmaker's and restlessly pacing its shaded squares.
Go up any street -- Patzcuaro is hilly -- and you will arrive at the Basilica, across from which is the Hotel Posada de la Basilica. My room had flowers painted on its white stucco walls, a balcony, and a much-needed fireplace (the nights are chilly) wedged in one corner. The view from the terrace was spectacular: the town tumbled at one's feet, and off to the right was a lake over which hovered a strange persistent mist and out of which come the tiny silver fish one sees for sale all over town.
Patzcuaro is known for its crafts, but nothing I saw in the shops, many of which are housed in a haunting, quite beautiful old convent and hospital near the Basilica, compared with the displays in the Museum of Popular Art. It is as charming a provincial museum as I have ever seen, and disarmingly homey.
A resident of San Miguel who is forever fantasizing about real estate says she would love to have a house in Patzcuaro. But who, she asks rhetorically, would ever visit her in so remote a spot?
I would, in a minute, and this time I would take the boat across that mysteriously misted lake to its largest island, Janitzco. I would also return to the restaurant facing the Plaza Vasco de Quiroga where I had smoked trout, and the little shop nearby where I bought an embroidered tablecloth and napkins. And I would do it just as I did in January: in buses that took me through a countryside whose beauty is rooted in its bleakness.
 
 
 
Shopping, eating, hotels and side trips
Getting There
 Buses to San Miguel de Allende from Mexico City leave from the northern bus terminal. E.T.N., Primera Plus, Flecha Amarilla and Heradura de Plata all have service between Mexico City and San Miguel. Prices range from $13 on E.T.N. (executive service) to $7.40 on Flecha Amarilla (second class). A direct trip takes about four and a half hours.
Buses that run from Guanajuato to Dolores Hidalgo can drop off passengers near the sanctuary of Atotonilco, on Route 51 about nine miles north of San Miguel; be sure to tell the driver you are going there. Buses leave for Dolores Hidalgo about every half hour from San Miguel's main bus terminal. Price: $1.75. The sanctuary is open from 7 A.M. to noon and from 4 P.M. to 8:30.
The trip from San Miguel to Guanajuato takes about an hour and 15 minutes. San Miguel's bus station sits about one mile outside town on the Calzada de la Estacion. Primera Plus has service twice daily for 18 pesos, and Flecha Amarilla has second-class service about every two hours from 6:45 A.M. to 5:00 P.M for 14.50 pesos. Telephone for both services: (465) 200-84. (The country code for Mexico is 52.)
There are several ways to make the bus trip from San Miguel to Patzcuaro, all involving multiple transfers.
 
Where to Stay
SAN MIGUEL: Casa de Sierra Nevada, 35 Calle Hospicio, telephone (465) 204-15, is housed in a former archbishop's residence. All 24 rooms are suites with stone walls and Spanish style furniture; they range in price from $120 to $200, depending on size.
Villa Santa Monica, 22 Calle Baeza, (465) 204-27. One of San Miguel's quaintest inns. The 10 rooms are spread over a number of gardens and courtyards. There is a small swimming pool. A double room costs $72, and includes a continental breakfast.
GUANAJUATO: Hotel Museo Posada Santa Fe, 12 Jardin de la Union, (473) 200-84. This 50-room hotel was the Prussian consulate during the reign of Maximilian. A double room costs $50.
PATZCUARO:Hotel Posada de la Basilica, 6 Arciga; (434) 211-08. Eleven rooms in a Spanish-style building across the street from the main cathedral. A double room costs $22.
 
Where to Eat
SAN MIGUEL: Bugambilia, 42 Calle Hidalgo; (465) 201-27. Typical Mexican food. Specialties include chiles en nogada (stuffed peppers in white walnut sauce) and chicken with mole. A meal for two with a bottle of wine costs about $30. It's a good idea to reserve in advance.
Antigua Trattoria Italiana, 9 Codo; (465) 237-90. Italian food. Specialities include eggplant with parmesan cheese and a mixed sea food plate. A meal for two with wine costs about $43.
The restaurant of the Villa Santa Monica serves international cuisine, including grilled sea bass and breast of chicken roasted in chili sauce. A meal for two with wine costs about $70.
GUANAJUATO: The restaurant of the Hotel Museo Posada Santa Fe serves international and Mexican food, including steaks and enchiladas. A meal for two with wine costs about $30.
 
Shops in San Miguel
Most stores are open from 10 A.M. to 2 P.M. and 4 P.M. to 6 P.M; many are closed on Sunday.
 Zarco, 24 Sollano, (465) 203-23, sells ceramics, colorful tin figures and handmade glassware.
El Atico, 24 Calle Correo, (465) 205-86, has a variety of antiques, Mexican religious paintings, reta blos and oriental rugs.
Izcuinapan San Miguel, 42 Canal, (465) 205-94, has folk art, paper cuttings, wooden furniture and other crafts.
 
What to See
GUANAJUATO: Diego Rivera Museum, 47 Positos; (473) 211-97. Tuesday to Saturday, 10 A.M. to 1:30 P.M. and 4:00 P.M. to 6:30 P.M.; Sunday, 10 A.M. to 2:30 P.M. Admission fee: 85 cents.
Museum of Guanajuato, 7 Positos. Tuesday to Saturday 10 A.M. to 1:30 P.M. and 4:00 P.M. to 6:30 P.M.; Sunday, 10 A.M. to 2:30 P.M. Admission: 85 cents.
PATZCUARO: Museum of Popular and Regional Art, at the corner of Ensenanza and Alcantarilla. Tuesday to Saturday, 9 A.M. to 7 P.M.; Sunday, 9 A.M. to 3 P.M.
 Casa de las Artesanias de Michoacan (originally the House of the Eleven Patios, an 18th-century convent), between Jose Maria Cos and Ensenanza, near the cathedral. Usually open daily from 9 A.M. to 2 P.M. and 4:00 P.M. to 7:00 P.M.
 PAUL SHERMAN
 
 
 
Paying in pesos
 Figuring the consequences of a currency devaluation is a complicated business, but the bottom line in Mexico is that five months after the peso lost more than 40 percent of its value, converting dollars to pesos still generally benefits travelers. The advantages are fewer in cities and major resorts that are pegged to the dollar. Big hotels setrates in dollars, so no saving there.
In early May, the exchange rate stood at about 5.8 pesos to the dollar, meaning that whatever costs 1 peso in Mexico -- like a box of Chiclets -- costs a traveler about 17 cents, versus 29 cents before devaluation.
The advantages are tempered by inflation that could top 50 percent this year, along with a jump in the national value-added sales tax from 10 to 15 percent. Gasoline prices have shot up almost 40 percent. Even tortillas cost about 25 percent more now than they did in December.
 ANTHONY DePALMA

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
2 New Projects Enhance a South Norwalk Recovery

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

DATELINE: NORWALK

 BODY:
TWO new projects costing a total of $6 million are scheduled to open in South Norwalk in July, signaling a recovery from four years of recession-hobbled growth in an area the city has counted on to seed future development and spark tourism.
In an effort to assure the recovery, Mayor Frank Esposito is now trying to rid adjacent neighborhoods of drug dealing, panhandling and prostitution. 
 The projects are the Crown SoNo Regent, an eight-screen, $4 million movie theater under construction on Main Street, and the New England Brewery, a $2 million microbrewery and 180-seat restaurant that will open half a block away on Marshall Street.
Daniel M. Crown, president of Crown Theaters, said he would move his headquarters from Manhattan into the theater building, while maintaining his present office. He added that the bulk of his theater operations would be brought to Norwalk. The theater is expected to draw patrons from New Canaan, Darien and Westport, fueling business for South Norwalk's shops and restaurants.
Valus & Carpenter Associates, Westport architects, have designed the 50,000-square-foot theater, conforming to the city's request that it reflect the area's prevailing Victorian architectural style. Some 5,500 feet of retail space will occupy the ground floor.
Crown, which owns and operates 10 theaters in New York and Connecticut, has an application pending for a six-screen theater in Norwalk on Route 1 at the Westport line.
The pub-microbrewery, local manifestation of a nationwide appetite for such establishments, is being converted from what was once a decrepit, vacant warehouse. Marcia and Richard King, the owners, have moved their brewery on Commerce Street to the new location after two years of renovations paid for with their own money. "We took no loans," said Mrs. King.
In 1993, they won a gold medal at Denver's National Great American Beer Festival for their signature product, Atlantic Amber. Seeking to provide equally good food, the Kings have hired Joseph Cizynski, former chef-owner of Le Bec Fin in Greenwich, as their chef.
Adding to the climate of improvement is the imminent restoration of the city's premier eyesore -- the vacant, deteriorated old City Hall, across the street from the movie theater. In foreclosure after a failed attempt to turn it into an inn, it is to be resurrected at a cost of $1.5 million as the Museum of Norwalk.
The architectural firm of Beinfield Wagner Associates formed a private partnership with other investors to buy the 15,000-square-foot building for $248,000. In addition to the museum, it is to contain a 3,000 square foot ballroom for weddings and bar mitzvahs, and 5,000 square feet of commercial rental space.
The three buildings complete a circle of diversions that will be marketed as a walking tour starting at the Maritime Center on North Water Street, where cruise boats are available for tours of the Norwalk Islands. Visitors will be able to walk to Marshall Street, to Main Street and on to the shops and restaurants of Washington Street and back to the Maritime Center.
AFTER a rocky start in 1988, the Maritime Center has succeeded to the point where it is one of Connecticut's major regional tourist attractions. It is now planning a $2.4 million expansion.
Washington Street is the heart of the SoNo (South Norwalk) Historic District. Carved out of the depressed south end of the city in the early 80's, it is considered a model restoration of 19th century brick buildings. But the recession left many stores vacant, condominiums unsold and the developer, Arthur Collins Enterprises of Greenwich, in bankruptcy. A reorganization plan for the company is under review in Federal Court in Bridgeport.
Today most of the condominiums are rented and there are few retail vacancies. But the mix of businesses is changing. Out of the 27 stores that the Collins company owns, 12 are restaurants, and most of the original upscale art galleries, craft shops and boutiques are gone.
"Some businesses came in without a lot of experience, committed to rents they couldn't afford," said Mr. Collins. Rents have been lowered and tenants, once carefully screened for esthetic rather than fiscal qualifications, are signed up to meet an economic need rather than enhance a concept. A general store, dress shop and shoe store are among the new tenants. paying rents around $12 to $16.50 a square foot, according to Bardwell Jones of Avery-Emerson Realty.
Residential condominium rentals range from $750 for efficiencies to $1,000 for 2-bedroom, 2-bath units with fireplaces, decks and water views. "Some are leased for only six months," said Patsy Brescia, broker with William Pitt, "while owners wait for buyers."
Even though condominium resale prices are down to a range of $40,000 to $100,000 from highs of $60,000 to $140,000, they are not moving, said Kate Johnson of the William Raveis Real Estate office here.
The Brookfield Craft Center moved out of its Washington Street branch last summer, retreating to its headquarters buildings in the Town of Brookfield that were built in 1790.
"Our 10-year lease was up," said John I. Russell, the executive director, "and our income wasn't enough to meet the $10-a-foot rent we were paying. When we opened in SoNo our goal was to help generate an arts-driven neighborhood, but over the years the arts component declined."
MICHAEL NISCHAN, owner of Miche Mache, an upscale French restaurant that was situated at the edge of SoNo on South Main Street, moved to Stamford a year ago for a reason that has plagued SoNo since its inception.
"Our customers were constantly being harrassed at night by panhandlers who demanded $5 in the free parking lot," he said. "Some of them would walk into the restaurant trying to sell stolen goods, or urinate on our windows. When our sous chef was held up at gunpoint while emptying some garbage out back, that was the last straw."
Drug-dealing, prostitution and petty crime in the adjacent neighborhoods are persistent concerns and a deterrent for tourists who come to the area by train and must walk through three blocks of urban decay before reaching SoNo and the Maritime Center.
According to Mayor Esposito, police schedules are being reviewed and altered to include night patrols that he hopes will eliminate complaints like Mr. Nischan's. He also said that he expected that the rehabilitation of the notorious New City Hotel opposite the Miche Mache site would remove a prime source of crime.
An additional measure to attract tourists, said the Mayor, is "the cleaning up of the Monroe Street area." A renovation of the entire neighborhood between the railroad station on Monroe Street and along South Main Street into SoNo is now under way. The city plans to float $1.5 million in bonds to buy the mostly vacant and substandard properties along the route, which it hopes to then sell to developers.
"We would like to see a combination of housing and retail extending from SoNo to the station," said Mayor Esposito.
The westbound side of a new $8 million station -- the eastbound side was completed last year -- and its 725-car parking structure are due for completion in October. The eastbound station house contains a police substation serving the surrounding unstable neighborhoods.
"SoNo is still a bit fragile," said Brechin Morgan, artist and owner of the Morgan Sign Company, a business that has survived in SoNo since 1976.
"Artists are often the vanguard of development," said Mr. Russell of the Brookield Craft Center, "but they can rarely afford the rent to remain as senior citizens when the area prospers."

HEADLINE: Where Have All The Doctors Gone?

BYLINE: By JULIE MILLER 

 BODY:
FOR Loretta Cullen of Waterford, who has been hospitalized many times over the past few years, finding a doctor proved to be almost as big a challenge as her illnesses.
"A patient's problem is not just with the insurance companies. It starts with finding a doctor, period," Ms. Cullen wrote recently in a letter to a newspaper. "Our community has too few physicians, and all are overbooked or not taking new patients. If you're fortunate enough to receive an appointment, it will be for a month or two later, even though your problem is now." 
 New London County will need as many as 100 more primary-care physicians -- family doctors, internists and pediatricians -- by the turn of the century, according to the New London County Health Care Task Force. In fact, the shortage of primary-care physicians is among the most serious health issues facing the region, the task force stated in a report last year.
Several factors combined have created a greater demand for primary care, doctors in New London County said. Managed-care plans, which control the delivery of health services and the amount of reimbursement, require patients to see a primary-care physician before going to a specialist, since a primary-care physician's fee is lower. In addition, newly trained doctors seeking the advantages of joining a group practice are bypassing New London County, where doctors traditionally have worked alone or with a partner, and fees and insurance reimbursements are lower than they are in other parts of the state.
The great majority of primary-care practices are closed to new patients, the president of the New London County Medical Association, Dr. Robert J. Keltner, said. Dr. Keltner is a lung specialist who also received training in internal medicine. "About 10 percent of my patients don't have respiratory problems," he said. "I treat them for hypertension, diabetes and cardiac disease. They can't find another doctor who can take on their care. It's a real, day-to-day problem. I probably don't treat people as well as an internist would."
Besieged by increasingly complex insurance plans and government regulations, physicians find time constraints tighter than ever, Dr. Robert J. Bundy, who has offices in Willimantic and Norwich, said. "I don't think it's a matter of doctors turning patients away. Their practices are full," Dr. Bundy said. "For them to take on new patients is an excess burden. It just doesn't pay anymore."
Thirty-six out of an estimated 150 primary-care physicians are accepting new patients, the director of the New London County Medical Association, Amy Snider, said. Ms. Snider added that there may be some open practices not listed with the association. The shortage in New London County reflects a national trend, according to figures from the American Medical Association. Over the last eight years, the number of family physicians and general practitioners in the United States has grown more slowly than the groups of internists, pediatricians and obstetrician-gynecologists. The largest increase was in the number of internists, which jumped by 24 percent.
Dr. Louis Buckley, vice chairman of the department of medicine at Lawrence and Memorial Hospital in New London, said the shortage is an artificial situation created by managed care. "They want everybody to turn to primary care first," Dr. Buckley said. "There are plenty of doctors around."
Managed care will fail when people realize it limits their ability to choose the physicians they want, Dr. Buckley said. He added that managed care is expensive to operate. "We need to do something simpler, like rationing some care. We have to become more realistic about dying."
A bill before the state Legislature would designate obstetricians and gynecologists as primary-care physicians under managed care plans. Representative Lenny Winkler, a Republican of Groton, who sponsored the bill, charged that the state is attempting to set up a Medicaid managed-care system, which would leave 200,000 people uninsured.
"Without the designation, we fall short of the number of primary-care doctors we need," Ms. Winkler said. Opponents of the bill argue that obstetrician-gynecologists are not trained to treat the variety of medical problems handled by primary-care physicians.
Local health professionals are working on ways to attract more primary-care physicians to New London County. They are seeking Federal and state funds to establish an Area Health Education Center, defined as a partnership between community health services and the University of Connecticut's medical school in Farmington. Under the plan, medical students, residents and students in other health professions would practice in the community under the supervision of established physicians, said Marta Medaris Smith, director of the Area Health Education Center Development Office in Norwich. "The center is a bridge between the private practice and academic programs," Ms. Smith added.
Scheduled for completion within the next three years, the center would encourage physicians to enter primary care and offer opportunities for medical training, Ms. Smith said. In addition, newly trained physicians would be available to fill in for local practitioners who need time off. Included in the plan are housing for medical students and residents and library resources.
Area health education centers were conceived by the Federal Government in the early 1970's and are operating in 35 states, Ms. Smith said. North Carolina's nine centers, for example, are affiliated with the state's four university medical schools. Students in medicine, dentistry, nursing, public health, pharmacy and other areas receive part of their training in local hospitals, physicians' offices and public health departments.
North Carolina's centers were started in 1972 with Federal funding but have been supported since 1974 with money from state and local budgets. The centers have built up the supply of primary-care physicians in the state, according to the program's administrative office in Chapel Hill. Since 1977, 61 percent of the family practice residents trained at the centers have remained in North Carolina. Nearly half the residents who set up practices in the state settled in towns with populations under 10,000.
Dr. Keltner said New London County, economically depressed, has less to offer young physicians. "Doctors coming out of school with a lot of debts may earn $40,000 to $50,000 less here than they would anywhere else," he said. It is hard to compete with big health maintenance organizations, which offer better salaries and benefits, he said.
And Dr. Keltner was not optimistic about the economic future. "Everybody sees more and more jobs lost," he said. "There may also be a shortage of patients who are well insured. Things are not that rosy."

HEADLINE: A Growing Taste for the Fruit of the Vinyl

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
FOR most of the quarter century that it has been on the market vinyl siding got no respect. While less tinny and more damage-resistant than aluminum siding, it served the same purpose -- covering unsightly, low- to mid-priced older homes.
But in the last five years it has become something of a Cinderella of the siding industry, swept from its humble beginnings by consumer demand for maintenance-free living. Manufacturers have created an ever-widening variety of sidings and trims in period and contemporary styles. And vinyl, once synonymous with modest homes, is increasingly being used in upscale housing, even for homes with price tags over $1 million. 
 "Vinyl has become the product of choice," said Lisa Macchi, district manager in the new homes division of Coldwell Banker Schlott in New Jersey. "It's a maintenance issue. We carry 150 new home projects in the tri-state area, in price ranges from $150,000 to $2 million, and its not the building community choosing vinyl for economic reasons, its a customer-driven success."
"People today," she added, "don't have the time to paint their houses as they did generations ago and they don't want the constantly escalating expense of repainting every few years, whether it's a new house or a resale."
Still, caution is the watchword when dealing with home buyers, according to some brokers.
"I don't tell people that a house is sided in vinyl at first," said Ron Molloy, an agent with Coldwell Banker Schlott in Greenwich, Conn. "Once they have fallen in love with the house and I do tell them, it doesn't matter."
Vera Blendermann, manager of Houlihan/Lawrence Real Estate in Bronxville, N.Y., said that "it's still not people's favorite thing."
"The size and location sets the price," she said, "but if the house has everything else they want, they overlook the vinyl."
An environmental measure that inadvertently boosted vinyl's popularity occurred in 1979, when the Federal Consumer Products Safety Commission ordered the removal of lead from all over-the-counter paints, and followed that action by removing mercury in 1990.
Lead in amounts up to 50 percent at the turn of the century had been reduced to 30 percent in the 40's and .05 percent in the 60's, but even the smaller amounts, combined with other additives, made paint nicely opaque, completely covering and clinging to the surface. Mercury, in proportions of around 200 parts per million, helped to prevent mildewing of surfaces and deterioration of paint in the can.
After the two elements were removed, painted houses began to deteriorate faster, emphasizing vinyl's most touted advantage -- the saving of many thousands of dollars for frequent repainting, stripping or sandblasting wood houses.
Homes that are finished with the better grades of vinyl are almost impossible to distinguish from the real thing -- various wood finishes and cuts. Vinyl can be molded to look like custom-milled clapboards, shiplap, cedar shakes, pediments, trellises, columns, railings, beading, Victorian and Carpenter Gothic decorative work, shutters and window and door frames.
Research by Alcoa, a major producer of vinyl building products, indicates that 53 percent of the homes using vinyl siding throughout the country today are priced from $100,000 up, an 11 percent increase from 1990. In addition, 48 percent of all re-siding in 1994 was done with vinyl. Plywood is next in popularity with 13 percent.
Vinyl's ability to withstand extreme climatic conditions for decades, and the fact that it is manufactured and delivered to the builder's exact specifications -- no warps, no knots, no surprises -- have made it the first choice of many developers.
"Every house we build is 100 percent vinyl or vinyl combined with brick or stone," said Robert Allen, senior vice president of Beazer Homes, based in Atlanta. In the company's subdivisions of 60 to 300 homes in several states, warranties of 50 years are offered on 1,200- to 4,500-square-foot houses priced from $100,000 to $300,000.
Jon Fleming, a partner in Vinylume, a family-owned business in Greenwich, has been working with vinyl since 1968. To date the company has vinyl-sided about 1,050 renovated or new Greenwich homes, and hundreds more in southwestern Connecticut and Westchester County. "We do 150 to 175 houses a year, primarily as an alternative to painting," said Mr. Fleming, "or to alter the style of a house," a project that can be prohibitively expensive in wood. "Vinyl accessories," he said, "produce excellent results in transforming a ranch into a colonial, or a colonial into a Greek Revival."
Libby and Thomas Hollahan chose vinyl for another reason. They bought their 1929 home in White Plains four years ago and last fall decided to have it painted. "There was a very high lead content in the existing paint," said Mrs. Hollahan, "and when we looked at vinyl siding as an alternative it turned out to be the most cost effective way of taking care of lead abatement."
The New York State Health Department agrees that vinyl can be useful in solving a lead problem. "Peeling paint should be removed," said Thomas Carroll, the department's senior sanitarian. "Then, as long as the siding is done properly, covering everything, any paint that falls off will be sealed inside, causing no harm."
The cost of sanding and repainting over old lead-based paint on a typical four-bedroom, two-story colonial of 3,000 square feet is around $12,000. Stripping down to the wood, priming, repainting and disposing of the lead debris in a toxic waste dump can be two to two and one-half times the $18,000 cost of vinyl siding.
But that does not mean that vinyl will never need painting. "All vinyl siding is expected to weather," said Kim Lenz, spokeswoman for Alcoa. So-called limited lifetime guarantees cover the siding itself, particularly the better Alcoa grades that are between .044 and .048 inches thick. They are guaranteed not to wave or bow, while thicknesses of .040 to .043 might. Certainteed, of Valley Forge, Pa., produces vinyls of .040 to .044 that it says will not bow. The minimum standard for the industry, set by the American Society for Testing and Materials, in Philadelphia, is .035 inches. .
Various manufacturer's warranties against fading expire between 5 and 10 years. Anyone planning to add to a vinyl house had better do it before the sixth year or be prepared to paint, because the addition will not match the original color.
Vinyl colors last years longer than paint because the color permeates the material and higher-quality vinyls retain deep tones longer than cheaper grades. "Scratches are not noticeable," said Rich Gottwald, technical director of the Vinyl Siding Institute in Bowie, Md.. "It's impervious to termites and manufactured with weep holes that allow the house to breathe. It can be cleaned with a garden hose and a household detergent. Damaged sections can be replaced and it flexes back to normal after being hit."
In response to consumer requests, Carl Minchew, chief chemist at the Benjamin Moore Paint Company in Montvale, N.J., has been developing paints specifically to remedy vinyl's fading and chalking. A product called Moore's Acrylic Latex Siding Paint is being test-marketed in the New York City and Chicago areas in white. Local dealers can produce any color by adding some of the 2,000 compatible tints.
"Vinyl is a great surface to paint on," said Mr. Minchew, noting that he preferred it to moisture-absorbing wood. "Latex is better than oil because mildew's favorite diet is the linseed in oil paint, and an arsenal of mildicides and additives is available to inhibit mildew, which affects all materials."
"Chalking," he explained, "occurs when the resin that holds vinyl together erodes and air enters, much like snow, which is clear water until it's turned white by air."
Another environmental measure that increased vinyl's desirability went into effect in 1989, when Federal restrictions on logging in 12 Western states were imposed to protect the spotted owl, salmon, grizzly bear and other endangered species. Wood became more expensive and less available.
Peak lumber production in 1987, according to the Western Wood Products Association in Portland, Ore., was 23.9 billion board feet. It dropped to 17.4 billion board feet in 1994, a 27 percent reduction.
"Twenty years ago we didn't use vinyl," said Mr. Allen of Beazer Homes. "We used wood, but warranty problems became atrocious and kept increasing."
DAVID MACKES, a custom builder of homes priced from $175,000 to $1.5 million in Salisbury, Md., complains that "there is less old-growth timber.
"What we are getting has a higher moisture content," he said, "so it tends to twist and have more nail pops." He said that rejections of shipments and parts of shipments were becoming more common.
But Jeff Santozzi, spokesman for the Western Wood Products Association, called such complaints exaggerated.
"Wood has its own characteristics," he said. "It's a natural product; that's what people like about it."
Research on pricing of vinyl compared with other materials was undertaken by Alcoa in 1994. The resulting figures showed that a square foot of installed, regular grade vinyl was about $1.45 compared with $2, $3 and $3.50 a square foot for pine, cedar and stucco, respectively, and $6.75 for brick. Top of the line vinyls cost no less than high-grade cedar, but labor costs are considerably lower for installing vinyl and it requires no initial painting or staining.
Many architects whose clients insist on using it have found the experience to be gratifying, but many others won't even consider it. Alan Shope, for example, of Shope Reno Wharton Associates, Greenwich architects, said: "I have designed large homes from Maine to Florida. People have asked for vinyl and we have said no. I'm not comfortable with fake plastic material. You can't beat tried and true wood shingles and stone. And I don't like the ticking sound that vinyl emanates in the sun."
As a self-described "lover of lead paint," he found ways of circumventing problems of mildew and peeling paint exacerbated by the absence of lead and mercury. He uses stains rather than paint, dipping the shingles in a preservative and weathering oil, covering all four surfaces with stain and sealing the ends -- "where most moisture accumulates," he said. He said that the treatment would last for 10 years.
In spite of such resistance, vinyl statistics are continuing to be pumped upwards by people who spend anywhere from $70,000 to $3 million or more on their houses. "In 1987 the United States produced 15.6 million squares, or 100 square-foot units, of vinyl," said Mr. Gottwald. "In 1993 we produced 24.2 million squares."
"Since the beginning of the 90's our business has grown by 35 percent," said Robert Long, marketing manager for Certainteed, which manufactures vinyl products at 100 sites around the country.
Melissa Keenan, architect for Megill Construction, custom builders in West Chester, Pa., used Certainteed materials in a $1.2 million, 4,000-square-foot, vinyl-sided summer home for her boss, Wayne Megill. It overlooks the ocean at Sea Isle City, N.J. "The third summer is coming up and it looks as good as new," said Mr. Megill. "With cedar I would have had to repaint at least once."
"On the shore a cedar house discolors badly within three years and the grout on a brick house comes apart," said Ms. Keenan. As recent converts to vinyl, the Megill company now uses it for 20 percent of its homes, occasionally running into resistance by local architectural review boards. "Vinyl has a long way to go with some of the people sitting on these boards," said Ms. Keenan.
Not all municipalities have architectural review boards, and not all that do maintain total oversight on the use of vinyl siding. In Greenwich, "it's not encouraged," said James Sandy, the Town Planner, "but the board doesn't get into reviewing single family homes." But in Bellport, L.I., "the architectural review board discusses every house, and it will allow vinyl siding only if it is satisfied with the detail and quality of construction," said Robert A. W. Heins, a local architect who has designed vinyl homes priced up to $3 million.
Vinyl is even gaining limited acceptance in historic preservation. The Vinyl Siding Institute and the Preservation Assistance Division of the National Park Service in Washington have been working together for some time on appropriateness and specifications for vinyl on historic renovations. The Park Service designates historic landmark buildings nationwide and acts as an advisory and technical assistance agency to local historic preservation organizations.
"We are in the business of retaining the historic character of buildings through repairing and reproducing elements of the original structure," said Kay Weeks, technical writer and editor for the division. "Although we would never recommend synthetic materials, under very special circumstances they can be used, to replace extremely deteriorated wood, for example, on a building that needs to be maintenance-free." A detailed set of 10 standards for architectural preservation is available through her department. "If there is a Federal tax incentive for rehabilitating a historic building and the criteria are not met," she said, "the tax credit will be withdrawn."
No legal action can be taken against people who destroy the architectural integrity of a building in violation of guidelines set by local historical societies or the Federal Government. But public pressure to preserve significant architecture usually prevails.
LIKE the National Parks Service, the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission generally will not approve the use of vinyl siding on principal visible facades of historic buildings, said Deborah Sacks, spokeswoman for the commission. "But there are some exceptions," she said.
In St. George, on Staten Island, there were houses that already had vinyl siding before the area was designated a historic district. "We did not require its removal," she said. The same situation was found in the Riverdale section of the Bronx and handled in the same way. "We look at each case individually," said Ms. Sacks. "If vinyl siding is to be used on the back of a historic house, where it can't be seen, and it would alleviate a mildew problem, we may make an exception."
A few years ago, before building a large waterfront home in Annapolis, Md., Katherine and Michael Stalker attended a vinyl seminar, seeking a more satisfactory material than cedar. "We had watched very expensive three-year-old wood houses turn green and brown from moisture," said Mrs. Stalker, "and the bills for repainting were astronomical. A house of 7,000 square feet can cost $30,000."
Drawing on information from the seminar they chose a Wolverine vinyl for their $1.5 million house, completed in 1989 and still "looking fabulous," said Mrs. Stalker, "and we didn't cut down trees or dump paint residues into the water table." To maintain the siding they have it power-washed once in a while for $300.
"Some people," she said, "have difficulty in making the jump from wood to vinyl, but in another 15 years I think that they are going to turn up their noses at wood the way they do now at vinyl."

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By Hubert Herring 

 BODY:

CONGRESS
Budget-Cutters on the March
Like it or not, Congress is inching steadily closer to dismantling Government as we know it. When House and Senate budget panels approved plans last week to balance the budget in seven years, the main sticking point was tax cuts -- the House wants $350 billion in cuts, the Senate none. They'll have to hash that out if, as expected, the bills pass this week. But then would come the messy part: figuring out specific cuts, not just simple numbers. How bad will the pain be? It's a numbers game. Some estimates put it at 7 percent or more from overall spending. But since Social Security and the military are off limits, cuts in things like education and the environment could be more like 30 percent. That's pain.
 
COMMUNICATIONS
MCI Joins Murdoch's Team
Rupert Murdoch is on a roll. He just got the F.C.C. off his back on the thorny issue of foreign ownership of American TV stations. Then last week MCI said it would invest up to $2 billion in his News Corporation. The new partners' talk was full of grand global plans, of "synergies" -- and these two companies do indeed have a history of rattling all sorts of cages. But analysts saw a coup for Mr. Murdoch, questioning those vaunted synergies. After all, even if MCI eventually owns 13.5 percent of the company, the deal gives it no true voting power. And on the news, MCI's stock fell and the News Corporation's rose. So what's in it for MCI? Clearly, a possibility of fulfilling global dreams that go beyond long distance.
 
REAL ESTATE
What Went Bankrupt?
It really comes down to two questions: 1) Come on, how could Rockefeller Center possibly be bankrupt? 2) Oh, does it really matter? To tackle No. 2 first, it was best summed up by a candy-store worker, right in the belly of the Midtown beast, who responded to a query about last week's Chapter 11 filing this way: "Truthfully, sir, I have no idea what you're talking about." As for No. 1, let's see: The family took out a huge mortgage. A Japanese company bought 80 percent of the center, paying too much. Rents fell when they were supposed to rise. And somehow, with all sorts of overlapping companies called Rockefeller Group, Rockefeller Center Properties, RCP Associates, things just stopped adding up. Is that clear now?
 
WORK FORCE
Women Pay Their Way
Not long ago, if a woman had a job, it was often for little extras -- not the meat of a family budget. Well, in case you hadn't noticed, that world is long gone. If any doubts persisted, they were dispelled by a survey released last week that showed that more than half of employed women provided at least half of their household income. The study "challenges the persistent notion that women's earnings are supplemental," said Arlene Johnson of the Families and Work Institute, co-sponsor of the survey. Not that all women want to be breadwinners -- 31 percent said that if money were abundant, they'd be tending to their families, while just 21 percent of men stated that preference. And some women, of course, have no choice -- the men aren't around.
 
MARKETS
Emerging Is as Emerging Does
It was a noble idea, fairly oozing with pioneer spirit. Three years ago the American Stock Exchange decided to give a break to some little companies that didn't quite fit the mold but that, it hoped, had boundless futures. Last week the Amex ended the experiment, called the Emerging Company Marketplace, saying no new companies would be added. Not only did some of the companies fail to emerge, but nearly a quarter of them are now worthless. The tales behind the companies range from the blatant (one's largest shareholder was a convicted arsonist) to the bizarre (another's chairman had been sued by the S.E.C., but had since had a sex-change operation). But the lesson seemed to be that there is, after all, a reason for an exchange to have rigorous rules for membership. Or simply this: Emerge first, then apply.
 
ANNUAL REPORTS
The Pepsi Investor Next Door
Pity the designers of annual reports. They're duty-bound to put heavy machinery or cereal boxes on the covers -- but don't want to make them so dull-looking that stockholders will quickly toss them. Why, they must wonder occasionally, can't they put some glamorous model on the cover? No, what a silly idea, they surely say, as they switch off their daydreams and try to think good thoughts about tractors. But apparently someone at Pepsi had that very daydream -- and forgot to wake up. And so it is that Pepsi's just-released annual report could easily be mistaken for Glamour or Vogue -- there's Cindy Crawford gazing seductively out at you -- without a soda can in sight. The cover line: "A typical investor looks us over." Sure, Pepsi, sure.
 
RIVALRIES
From Cold War to Cola War
Who says there are no superpower rivalries left? Even with the cold war over, Coke and Pepsi are still engaged in their mythic battle for the gullets of the masses. And even if Pepsi scored one for having the sexiest annual report, Coke caught the Presidential eye in Russia last week. Mr. Clinton, picking an American investment to publicize by bestowing a visit, chose a Coke plant near Moscow. There was a reasonable political explanation: Coke owns its Russian plant, while Pepsi's is a joint venture. But could it be because Coke has contributed more to Democrats lately? Or maybe Mr. Clinton, weary of vodka, craved a soda -- and figured the Coke plant was the nearest place to get a free one. It was, after all, right on the way to the airport.
 
TRANSPORTATION
You Could Always Walk
In a single century, a historical speck, we've gotten used to the odd notion that if we want to be 30 miles away in half an hour, we should be able to do it -- no matter what damage is done to the environment. Now, as the world struggles to retain that luxury, someone had the bright idea of mandating a certain number of electric cars by 1998 -- a down payment on a pristine new world of travel. But is it possible? Practical hurdles still loom, of course -- but there's more: now comes a study saying that emissions from mining and smelting the lead needed for batteries might cause their own nasty threats to public health. But what of the argument that at least pollution would be shifted away from cities? Not so, said one toxicologist; "lead particles can move long distances."
 
SOUVENIRS
23! 45! 23! Oh, Never Mind
Does Michael Jordan realize he is tampering with some basic elements of our economic system? A basketball uniform is merely a piece of cloth, but with a star's number on it, it becomes a glowing -- and pricey -- symbol of all that's glamorous. So when he picked No. 45 for his comeback, a huge industry instantly took shape -- caps, T-shirts, banners, you name it. So when he abandoned that number last week for his old 23, he demolished the value of all that stuff. It was as if Calvin Klein decided to change his name to, say, Oliver North. All those people strutting around town in their Calvin underwear would feel, well, a bit cheated. No wonder the N.B.A. fined Jordan's team for the switch; Jordan upset a delicate balance of capitalism.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Stalking the Elusive Tax-Free Bond Price Quotation

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

 BODY:
FOR investors in municipal bonds, it is now getting easier to find something that has long been hard to come by: bond prices.
A new program features newspaper publication of benchmark bond yields as well as an "800" number -- to begin tomorrow -- for obtaining prices for many specific issues. The initiative, the result of Federal pressure on the industry, is sponsored by the Public Securities Association, the municipal bond dealers' trade group. 
 In the stock market, prices are listed daily in the newspaper. The same is true for corporate bonds and foreign currency. And on computer screens, current prices for such investments are sometimes listed minute by minute.
But the $1.5 trillion market for tax-free municipal bonds is a strange bazaar, far more akin to the 19th century than the 20th. There is no central marketplace. Buying and selling take place among a babble of dealers, each quoting different prices. And the market's great variety makes things worse. While only about 15,000 different stocks trade in the equity markets, there are about 1.5 million separate tax-free bonds.
The result is chaos.
"Right now, it is virtually impossible to see at what prices bonds trade in the municipal market," said Robert L. D. Colby, deputy director of the division of market regulation at the Securities and Exchange Commission.
For investors, this confusion can be costly. Unless an investor shops around, it is difficult to know whether the price being quoted is the best one.
The solution is an independent source of price data. "We hope that things like the '800' number will help people get a sense of how bonds are priced, other than only through a dealer," said Mr. Colby.
Under the telephone program, a caller will pay a flat $9.95 for price and credit data on 25 different bonds. People who do not need 25 quotations at once will be assigned an account number and can obtain the additional quotes later for no extra payment.
The "800" number, operated by Kenny-Standard & Poor's, will be especially helpful for those who invest in smaller issues sold by minor cities or obscure projects. While bonds from big issuers like New York City trade daily and their prices can be easy to find, rarer bonds present difficulties.
But there is so little trading in some small issues that even the most recent price data can be woefully out-of-date. For these issues, the bond prices on the "800" number (it will be 1-800-BOND INFO) will be estimates based on trades and current interest rates. For actual prices, bond buyers must still shop around -- but at least they will have an estimated price to compare to dealers' offers.
Besides the telephone service, the program includes newspaper publication of a "yield table" for the municipal bond that has the largest market share -- the 10-year, Triple-A, insured revenue bond.
This table, similar to a yield curve, provides yield data for this bond at varying dates of maturity, along with tax-equivalent yields and historical yields. The table, marketed by Bloomberg Financial Markets, will join similar yield tables for Treasury bonds and corporate bonds that now appear in the press.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST VILLAGE;
Avenue A Safari: Natives Are Restless

BYLINE: By MONTE WILLIAMS 

 BODY:
Anyone who is looking for proof that Avenue A is in the midst of a bona fide economic resurgence need not look any further than the red double-decker tour buses regularly wending their way down the street. Last month, New York Apple Tours added this once derelict street, now bustling with trendy sidewalk cafes and boutiques, to its itinerary, which includes fabled tourist attractions like the Empire State Building, Chinatown and Little Italy.
But not everyone in Alphabet City appreciates the attention. 
 "It's annoying," said Michael Farrin, a freelance book editor who lives on Avenue A and St. Mark's Place.
"I basically resent the Busch Gardens, Wild Kingdom connotation," he said. "I was sitting in my friend's second-floor apartment, and when we looked up, the tourists were looking in at us. They were eye level. It's basically very intrusive. They're trying to make the neighborhood seem exotic."
Hayim Grant, the 26-year-old president of New York Apple Tours, said he had not heard any complaints about the addition to the tour.
"We haven't had any feedback from the community," Mr. Grant said. "We're in New York to please the public and the tourists. All we're doing is trying to generate tourist dollars. I haven't heard from residents, but I wouldn't think the reaction would be negative."
Avenue A was included in the $25 tour of Manhattan because it is "an exciting" part of town, Mr. Grant said. "There are restaurants, cafes, music clubs," he said. "It's a culturally rich area."
The presence of tour buses does not surprise Tom Vesely, manager of Two Boots restaurant, at 37 Avenue A. "It's been an up-and-coming area for a few years," he said. "People are finding out it's O.K. to come to the neighborhood. My sister from Scarsdale even eats on Avenue A now."
Founded in 1992, New York Apple Tours encourages visitors to get off the bus and shop, eat or sightsee at any or all of its 48 stops. Tourists can resume the tour on another Apple bus. Buses operate between 9 A.M. and 11 P.M. daily. On Avenue A, buses stop between 8th and 9th Streets, at Tompkins Square Park, every 10 to 15 minutes.
Mr. Grant said tour guides do not inform out-of-towners that Tompkins Square Park was the site of a violent clash between police and demonstrators in 1989. "We point out Tompkins Square Park," he said, "but we try to avoid saying anything negative about New York."
Mr. Grant declined to say how many tourists had hopped off on Avenue A. But residents and merchants say they have yet to see anyone disembark.
"We'd like some of them to stop and get out and eat," said Joseph Gilbert, the chef at Zitella, an Avenue A restaurant that serves California-style Italian food. "But they're probably too leery." MONTE WILLIAMS

HEADLINE: EARNING IT:;
For Many, a Slower Climb Up the Payroll Pecking Order

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
LAWYERS are famous for being in oversupply. Any labor expert will tell you that. Yet, somehow, they are the best paid workers in America today. Obviously, lawyers who do get work don't discount their fees.
There are other surprises in the pecking order of pay for 49 occupations and professions. Elementary school teachers, thought to be greatly underpaid, are not as far down the list as widely believed. Their median weekly wage last year was $624, which means that half the teachers earned less than that amount and half more. That is better than accountants and journalists, machinists and members of the clergy. 
 The pay scales shown here are compiled by the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics from monthly surveys of 65,000 households that represent all sorts of workers. Top corporate executives, of course, make more than lawyers. But as a group, top executives are too few in number to measure accurately. And while there are people who earn less than child care workers, most are working illegally or at less than the minimum wage and do not show up in the surveys.
Even without these extremes, however, the spread between the chart's highest- and lowest-paid workers -- the lawyers at $1,116 a week before taxes and the child care workers at $158 -- is several times greater than in any other large industrial country.
Other trends are evident in the data. Pay increases for many groups have been less in the 1990's than they were in the 1980's, despite a low unemployment rate during much of this decade.
"Things have changed enough so that a low unemployment rate no longer means shortages of workers and pressure to raise wages," said Frank Levy, a labor economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, referring particularly to layoffs, weak unions and the great worry among many job holders that they could be dismissed. "This is no longer a phenomenon limited to the poorly educated and semiskilled."
Pay increases for doctors and nurses have slowed for a different reason: cost cutting in health care. There is one caveat, however. Pay seemed to fall in 1994 for both groups, but that may reflect a revamping of the survey last year. While the revamping probably produced more accurate data for 1994 than for previous years, comparisons of pay levels before and after the change may be skewed, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
The pay picture is clearer for government workers. Whatever the job -- police officer, , mail carrier or official -- public employees remain among the best-paid workers, suggesting they have not yet suffered as much wage stagnation as those in the private sector.
Pay for the less skilled and less educated has risen more slowly since 1983 than for others. But there are exceptions. Architects, highly educated, have not seen a rise in their median pay since 1990. And some workers have struck gold. Dietitians in this food-conscious nation have more than doubled their median pay since 1983, landing them just ahead of the clergy, by $1 a week.

GRAPHIC: Graphs: "A Sampling of American Paychecks" shows median weekly wages each year for selected occupations from 1983 to 1994. (Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics from Census Bureau Data)

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: JAMAICA;
Forecast of Downturn?: 1,000 Jobs May Move

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
Beginning in the late 1970's, the fortunes of downtown Jamaica sank as several major local employers -- Macy's, The Long Island Press, Ideal Toys, two banks and the flagship Gertz department store -- folded or moved. But a turning point came a decade ago when the Gertz family turned the eight-story department store into an office and retail complex called Gertz Plaza.
The state, seeking an anchor for the area, moved 1,000 workers from two agencies into the Plaza. Then York College built its campus nearby, and a large Social Security office moved to the neighborhood. Finally, the E, J and Z subway lines were extended and a major terminal was built at Parsons Boulevard and Archer Avenue. Next on the drawing board are a Queens Civil Courthouse and a large office for the Federal Food and Drug Administration. 
 But local officials fear Jamaica faces a new reversal because the Pataki administration is considering moving the state employees out of Gertz Plaza.
In March, Queens Borough President Claire Shulman wrote to Gov. George E. Pataki, pleading that the state offices stay where they are. "This disastrous loss of jobs and local revenue will have a very serious negative effect on the South Jamaica Economic Development Zone," Ms. Shulman wrote. "These jobs have played a major role in the resurgence of Jamaica." Aides said they have not received a reply.
A spokesman for the Governor, Christopher Chichester, said: "No decision has been made yet on a move. The administration is looking at the most cost-effective options."
A spokesman for the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, which employs about 550 people at Gertz Plaza, confirmed that the agency is considering a consolidation of offices now scattered in Manhattan, the Bronx and Queens.
"We are currently examining ways to relocate all facilities under one roof for economies of scale," said the spokesman, Harry Ryttenberg. Officials of the State Social Services Department, which employs about 450 people at Gertz Plaza, did not return phone calls.
Gertz Plaza occupies most of the block bounded by Jamaica and Archer Avenues, Union Hall Street and Guy R. Brewer Boulevard, opposite York College. Its tenants also include retailers and city offices.
"The secret of Jamaica's recovery has been targeted public investment," said F. Carlisle Towery, president of the Greater Jamaica Development Corporation. "We took huge hits in the 70's. The state agencies that moved to Gertz Plaza were the pioneers, and it made a major difference." That strategy helped Jamaica to thrive as a black middle-class community, he said.
Manhattan already has about 80 percent of all government jobs in the city, Mr. Towery said. Queens has only 6 percent of the government workers, he said.
"Millions of dollars of city, state and Federal money was put into revitalizing Jamaica," said Dan Andrews, an aide to Ms. Shulman, "so what sense does it make to pull 1,000 jobs out of there?"
 BRUCE LAMBERT

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS: FUNDS WATCH;
Managers Developing Team Spirit

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
TO help mutual fund investors make educated decisions, the Securities and Exchange Commission told fund companies a year ago to disclose the name of their managers in the primary fund document, the prospectus. Fund companies are reluctant to do so, however, fearing investors might follow the managers if they leave the company. So more and more fund companies are taking advantage of the exemption allowed for funds run by teams. A search of the data base of Morningstar Inc., the fund tracking service in Chicago, showed that 35.5 percent of all funds were listed with "team management" at the end of April, up from 30 percent a year ago and 26 percent at the end of 1992.
 
Pay Practices
 The Securities and Exchange Commission released a report recommending that brokerage firms stop paying bigger commissions on sales of the firm's own products. The report, prepared by industry leaders at the agency's request, included several other suggestions on broker compensation. Among them is a ban on sales incentives for specific products -- something proposed by the National Association of Securities Dealers earlier this year and awaiting S.E.C. action. 
 The recommendations reflect a movement in the industry away from pushing products to professional techniques like asset allocation, said Dan Jamieson, who edits Registered Representative, an industry magazine published in Irvine, Calif. At least brokers offer a wide range of products from more than one source, Mr. Jamieson said, whereas many insurance brokers still sell only one company's products.
 
Sun and Funds
 Cruises around the world offer opportunities to learn about far more than ancient history and architecture. Several fund companies and other groups are providing investment seminars along the way for people intent on developing a financial edge as well as a golden tan.
T. Rowe Price, the Baltimore fund company, started doing cruises three years ago. Now available is a cruise of the "Great Capitals of Europe" aboard Royal Cruise Lines' Crown Odyssey. It departs on Sept. 3 from London. T. Rowe Price will offer seminars on such subjects as diversified investment strategies, asset allocation for retirees and preretirees and international investing. Royal is offering Price shareholders discounted rates and free air travel (800 945-7462). For summer cruises to Alaska, the Eastern Mediteranean and the Black Sea, identify yourself as a Price shareholder and call (800) 926-3775.
In conjuction with Royal Cruise and American Express, Scudder, Stevens & Clark will offer seminars on a 12-day cruise to Portugal, France, Britain and Ireland, departing May 17. The trip, a first for the fund company, is already sold out, though Scudder may consider others in the future.
 
The Morality Index
 Investors can do just as well with a portfolio of "socially responsible" stocks as with other stocks, concludes J. David Diltz, associcate professor of finance at the University of Texas at Arlington. Mr. Diltz examined 159 common stocks, primarily of large United States companies.
All the stocks were rated by the Council on Economic Priorities for their environmental and nuclear policies, diversity and community outreach, among other criteria. For example, the Dial Corporation got a high ranking because it makes skin products without any animal testing. Heinz also got high marks for reusable packaging and recyling programs. Among the problem companies were Dole Foods, cited for heavy pesticide use, and Dow Chemical, which participates in the nuclear arms industry.
Mr. Diltz created 14 diversified portfolios, broadly pitting socially responsible companies against others, and found little difference in performance from 1989 through 1991. He concluded that equity markets were sufficiently large, liquid and efficient to make social screening irrelevant to the performance.
 
Fund Reopenings
 T. Rowe Price Small Cap Value, which closed to new investors in March 1993, has reopened. To deter short-term trading, a 1 percent redemption fee applies to shares held less than one year.
Montgomery Micro Cap, which closed on Jan. 28, is scheduled to reopen on June 1, now that manager Roger Honour has invested the fund's cash hoard.
 
In Brief
 Matthew Weatherbie resigned as lead manager of the Putnam Voyager fund, which will fall into the hands of Roland Gillis, who worked for eight years at Keystone Custodian Funds, and Daniel L. Miller.
Scott Lucas has joined AIM Capital Management as chief equity officer.
