HEADLINE: Japan Won't Take a Trade Back Seat Anymore

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I read with interest your May 8 Business Day news analysis on auto issues, and wish to respond specifically to the comment by Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, on Japan's "hypocritical" attitude on managed trade. 
 Mr. Kantor said that by rejecting the United States demands to have Japanese automakers commit to increasing their purchase of imported auto parts, the Japanese negotiators "are not only being hypocritical." But they are also "being inconsistently hypocritical" because Japan in the past agreed to restrict exports to the United States and Europe.
Despite much talk about a new phase in our bilateral economic relations, this statement suggests the United States still prefers its traditional approach to Japan. It wants Japan, and its Ministry of International Trade and Industry in particular, to go back to the bad old days of voluntary restraint arrangements.
Voluntary restraint arrangements were often the deus ex machina in the final phase of past Japan-United States trade negotiations, such as on textiles, color television sets, steel, machine tools, semiconductors, as well as on automobiles. But we now think voluntary restraint arrangements were a bad idea and have no place in the trading system.
Countries of the world have expended great effort to move toward freer trade through the Uruguay Round and the establishment of the World Trade Organization. Voluntary restraint arrangements and other "gray area" measures are explicitly prohibited under the new W.T.O. rules on safeguards, because they are nothing but efforts to manage trade by regulating trade flows.
Mr. Kantor just does not seem to realize how far Japan has come into fully embracing the principle of free trade based on multilateral rules and disciplines. If "the centerpiece of Mr. Clinton's economic strategy has been encouraging free trade with the world's biggest emerging markets," Mr. Kantor and his colleagues should immediately terminate their futile effort to turn back the clock.
 
ICHIRO ARAKI
Dep. Director, Intl. Communications
Ministry of Intl. Trade & Industry
Tokyo, May 11, 1995

HEADLINE: Japan Won't Take a Trade Back Seat Anymore;
Buchanan's Doctrine

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Patrick J. Buchanan's eloquent call (Op-Ed, May 10) for closing United States markets to Japan because of our bilateral trade deficit is a clear statement of his doctrine of "economic nationalism." This is the new label for classical protectionism. The opinion pollster Frank Luntz has discovered that most Americans disapprove of protectionism, but nationalism is still popular, and not just among conservatives. 
 The central concept of economic nationalism is the belief that there is only one American national interest in trade. The expression of this error is always associated with the words "we," or "our" national interest.
This idea of "one national interest" sometimes takes the form of "exports are good, and imports are bad." Although only some Americans sell products to foreigners, those are "our exports." Sometimes it takes the form, "Americans ought to buy from other Americans instead of from foreigners." Mr. Buchanan cites our trade deficit to justify protecting us from "imports."
In a country of more than 100 million working families, there are 100 million different manifestations of America's economic national interest. The belief that our interest is definable in a singular way is destructive of the principles on which our free market system is built, because that would justify regulating the economy in ways that bestow privileges on some Americans at the expense of other Americans.
Political leaders should not sell themselves to some Americans and hope most other Americans will not understand the logical fallacies they so eloquently employ.
 
JOE COBB
Olin Senior Fellow in Political
Economy, Heritage Foundation
Washington, May 10, 1995

HEADLINE: Have You Hugged Your Computer Today?

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
MY NAME is David. I am afraid of my computer.
When people talk about Unix accounts, web sites and bulletin board chats, I need an interpreter. When people talk about surfing, downloading and upgrading, I pine for gerunds like reading, writing and talking. 
 But when my mom, a children's librarian, receives an invitation to a conference on "Internet: Highway to Cities of Multimedia and Chinese Resources," I want to say: "Time out! What about me?"
It's a woolly world out there, this global electronic village populated by preschoolers who can navigate computers with their eyes closed and on-line fanatics who spend eight hours a day chatting with people they've never seen.
Me, I just cling to an imaginary security blanket to allay my electronic anxieties. Clearly I need some help.
"For some reason, new technology produces this irrational fear that everybody knows it but you," said Dr. Trudy Williams, a consultant in technical writing and developmental psychology at Nynex Science and Technology in White Plains, N.Y.
"Maybe you're a 56-year-old executive and suddenly you're not as good as the 18-year-old down the block," she explained. "You feel that after investing some time in building self-esteem and gaining equality, you are thrown back to that isolated peak in the middle of the ocean that you have so diligently swum away from."
There are, of course, those who say that all this "information superhighway" talk will turn out to be a lot of bunkum, or at least that it's possible to lead a perfectly rewarding life without even the occasional day trip to cyberspace. But even so, Dr. Williams and others in the computer community try to assure me, going on line really doesn't have to be scary or difficult. The World Wide Web may sound like nothing more than a place to get hopelessly lost, but, for starters, there are all manner of places to go that are quintessentially local, whose world is the web of everyday life right here in New Jersey.
"Remember that a human being put this together, therefore a human being can learn it by doing it one step at a time," counseled Dr. Williams.
Still, can that really include me, David the technophobe, who shunned math and science classes in college except for ones with nicknames like "Physics for Poets" and "Rocks for Jocks"? Who worked for a couple of years in Silicon Valley and stared blankly as people talked high-tech and E-mail? Who once called the people at America Online to report that something was wrong with their trial software -- only to be told that I had failed to connect the modem to a phone line?
But I'm willing to try again. After all, as many as 40 million people have electronic mail access globally, 90 percent of them in North America, said Jill Ellsworth, author of a book called "Marketing on the Internet." In New Jersey, she and others estimated, perhaps a million people are wired.
To get going, I checked out a weekend computer show at William Paterson College in Wayne. Maybe it wasn't the best idea for me; there were too many products and too many people. I found a kindred spirit, however, in Frank Pondelick, a retired gentleman from Paterson who, like me, was staring at computer disks with arms folded and eyebrows furrowed.
"I'd like to get involved with the Internet just to keep up with the world, but this is too confusing for me, the whole mass of everything," he said. "If you want to learn it, you really got to sit down and learn it."
I asked some friends for help. Eventually, I found Fred LaParo, who runs an Internet access provider in Stanhope. His advice? "Make sure you make nice with your PC geek buddy for a week to help you get connected."
Simple enough. I asked Fred and two more of a growing corps of on-line entrepreneurs -- who aren't geeks, by the way -- to guide me on my way. Here's what I found.
 
John Kelley
I.D. System operator of MicroFone InfoService, a bulletin board system, in Metuchen.
BEGINNINGS Mr. Kelley, who is 52 years old, taught himself computers as a release after the death of his first wife in 1981. He has operated MicroFone since 1982, and now teaches computers at John Adams Middle School in Edison.
Bulletin boards, by and large, are the slow lane of the on-line world, typically small, local operations with features like electronic mail, discussion groups, file transfers and games. Many bulletin boards are the province of teen-agers; they are also a good place for novices like me to start.
Like most bulletin board system operators (known as sys-ops), John Kelley runs MicroFone InfoService out of his basement. Calling it crowded is an understatement: The room is filled with four computers, 32 phone lines, a scanner, modems, CD-ROM's and shelves of books and software packages.
"For your basic user, you only need a computer, a modem, a phone line, bulletin board software and the phone number of a local bulletin board so you don't have to pay long-distance charges," he said. "Get someone to help you set up, if you need that."
I sat down at the main computer and dialed Mr. Kelley's own bulletin board, which he describes as "a family, G-rated board" that offers everything from computer games to the weather to information about goings on at Rutgers. The instructions were pretty simple: Basically, the program asked my name, phone number and other personal details.
I typed in my name, and the entry was promptly rejected. Could it be me?
"Oops. There's another user named David Chen," Mr. Kelley said, taking control of the keyboard for a second. "He's in Plainfield. Well, I'll be. We'll just have to use another name."
It worked the second time under DW Chen. I was in; I was psyched.
From there, Mr. Kelley guided me to various chat groups and games. It really wasn't that hard; I just followed the directions. Later, I dialed the New JerseyLand board in Neptune. It was similar to Mr. Kelley's in that it asked several preliminary questions and offered message groups, games and personal ads, real estate listings and a teen-age chat forum featuring the latest in juvenile macho posturing.
Mr. Kelley compiles a monthly list of the state's bulletin boards for New Jersey Computer User magazine. He estimates that there are 60,000 boards in the country, 500 of them in New Jersey.
His own bulletin board holds a monthly on-line auction. Once, someone tried to sell his wife for two cents. "I knocked that one out of the system," he said in disgust. But another time, Mr. Kelley and other MicroFone subscribers raised money for a fellow sys-op's bone-marrow transplant.
 
Fred LaParo
I.D. Senior partner, Planet Access Networks.
BEGINNINGS Mr. LaParo, 40, worked in telecommunications and information services for about 15 years. He became interested in the Internet a few years ago because, he says, he was fascinated with its possibilities.
I felt pretty good after leaving Mr. Kelley's house. It didn't seem that difficult to dial in to a local bulletin board, get on line and start sending messages or playing games. But what about the Internet, and the vaunted World Wide Web?
For this I turned back to Mr. LaParo, who co-founded Planet Access Networks in March 1994. It is an Internet access provider, or a link between your computer and the Internet, the world's largest collection of computer networks. Many people tap into the on-line world through the national services -- America Online, CompuServe, Prodigy, Delphi and Netcom. But around the country, there are also hundreds of smaller, local providers like Planet Access, which are somewhat harder to use but promise greater freedom to explore the Internet.
Mr. LaParo first instructed me to get the appropriate software. Packages like "Internet in a Box" or the "Internet Starter Kit" work just fine, for example. He then walked me through the basic steps of configuring the computer -- setting the right modem speed and other technical details to insure that everything is in synch. This part can be tricky, so it's best to make sure your access provider has dependable customer service.
I logged onto Mr. LaParo's computer and found myself staring at icons named Netscape and Eudora. Eudora is the gateway for electronic mail; Netscape searches for files on the World Wide Web, a major chunk of the Internet. I clicked on Netscape, and found myself at Planet Access's home page -- the welcome mat to the Internet.
As with the bulletin boards, the instructions were fairly self-explanatory; I basically moved the mouse around to click on text highlighted in blue, called hypertext, to get more information. Point, click, point, click. That's all.
"The surfing aspect is you hit one place and it takes you someplace else," he said. "You find one thing and you find 100 things behind that."
You can also search for information by using tools that cross-reference words and phrases. Searching for the combination of "Jersey" and "sushi," for example, produces a web page on the state's best sushi bars.
It may take me awhile to figure things out. After all, the web is expanding at a ridiculous pace, according to Howard Funk, an Internet consultant who participated in a seminar on New Jersey and the Internet at Kean College last week. In 1993, there were only 50 web addresses worldwide; in January 1995, there were 27,000.
Planet Access's web site, for example, provides on-line access to certain newspapers, as well as Internet updates, stock quotes, weather forecasts, entertainment news, even a daily comic. And on June, it will offer the Jersey Mall, a directory of businesses around the state.
To Mr. LaParo, going on line seems like a very New Jersey thing to do. "It's the mentality of the suburbs," he said. "People nest out here, and the net is the ultimate nesting place. You cocoon down in the evening with your PC and your modem."
That way, if I flounder, at least I'll flounder alone.
 
Karen Schneider
I.D. Proprietor of Blue Highways Internet Services, a home-office consulting business, in Wayne.
BEGINNINGS Ms. Schneider, 37, became computer literate only a few years ago during graduate school at the University of Illinois. She worked in electronic resources at the Queens and Newark Public Libraries before starting her own business last August.
Next up, a talk with Karen Schneider about what I could do with these tools to find New Jersey information.
Ms. Schneider calls herself a "cybrarian," an on-line librarian who helps individuals, businesses and non-profit organizations connect to and learn about the Internet. She runs Blue Highway off a Macintosh Powerbook in a spare bedroom in her home.
Her own web page, "Welcome to Karen's Kitchen: A Virtual Cafe in Wayne, N.J.," is essentially a cyberspace hangout, divided into categories (marked by coffee mugs) like NJ Delicacies, Librarian Stuff and The Intellectual Freedom Page. Oh, and I can't forget Darcy the Cat, which lets you hear the lovely meow of Ms. Schneider's 17-year-old pet.
Under NJ Delicacies, I found listings for the Amateur Computer Group of New Jersey, the Prototype Home Page for the Episcopal Diocese of Newark and a list of New Jersey internet providers. So far, so good.
Ms. Schneider said I could also use a popular web index called Yahoo to look for discussion groups, called newsgroups, about New Jersey (or any other topic, like "Melrose Place" or the N.B.A. playoffs). And she directed me to a couple of new sites still being tested, NJ On-Line and IN Jersey. The former is run by Newhouse Newspapers, the parent company of The Star-Ledger; the latter by The Asbury Park Press. Both are designed to feature local news.
Ms. Schneider is a member of a discussion group called Spiderwoman, women who maintain web pages; she sees herself as something of a crusader for an underrepresented minority. Eighty to 90 percent of Internet users are men, she estimates; hence, she points out, the problem of sexual harassment -- she received a vulgar E-mail message recently and has tracked its writer to a school "west of the Mississippi."
Right now, I'm struggling with the jargon. Try to make sense of this: "I'm surfing the web and browsing some hot links from somebody's home page so I find some cool HTMLs."
"Just go ahead and ask," said Ms. Schneider. "With the net, don't expect to learn it all in one day. Have patience and persevere and log-on late at night."
I was on my own, not exactly confident, but pride-bound to press on. Borrowing the computer of a colleague, I relied on the Yahoo index to find something called the Unofficial Home Page of New Jersey, put out by someone at Ohio State University. It contained information about each of New Jersey's 21 counties, and more. In the Hoboken area, for instance, I found restaurant listings, complete with addresses, phone numbers and recommendations.
I then used Yahoo to see how many New Jersey discussion groups there were. I counted about a dozen, including ones about politics, for-sale items, weather and events. Digging deeper into each newsgroup, I found people discussing speeding tickets, meetings for young Jewish singles and the absence of self-serve gas stations.
One thing I didn't find was anything offered by the state government. Indeed, on-line users have long complained about the state as being behind the curve on providing on-line data. The state has promised to do so soon, but I haven't found it yet.
There's more to come, including NJPIX (North Jersey Public Information Exchange), a nonprofit organization that is connecting schools and libraries in North Jersey. The idea is to provide local information for people in places like Newark and Elizabeth "to provide opportunities for economic and social empowerment," said Paul Pattwell, chairman of NJPIX.
It all sounded good, but I still wasn't sure. So I checked with Adam C. Engst, author of "The Internet Starter Kit," to see if he could offer a little sympathy, or, at least, understanding. I even E-mailed the man.
His response: "Fear is silly. If you don't want to get on the net, don't. But if you do, just do it -- you have to experience the net for what it is and make up your own mind about whether or not you like it," he typed. "Hope this helps. Cheers."
It did, Mr. Engst, and thanks. I'm still intimidated, but I think I can safely say that I am no longer paralyzed. Check back with me in a few months, though.

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
Can the Republicans Really Help the Cities?

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON; Iver Peterson is Trenton bureau chief of The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
One of the jokes told at the annual dinner of the Legislative Correspondents Club Wednesday night went like this: "If Governor Whitman put a few more dollars into her urban program, it would cost as much as her house."
The line hardly stretches the truth: Governor Whitman said she would put up all of $2 million in state seed money for urban neighborhood improvement when she disclosed her urban self-help strategy in March, which is about enough money for an entry-level estate in the horse country, where the Governor lives. It is a measure of how desperate some of New Jersey's cities are that many mayors acted grateful for the Governor's idea. 
 Few states have contrived as well as New Jersey has to disconnect the lives of most residents from the problems of the cities. We have no urban giants, like New York City or Philadelphia, with the population and the votes to throw their weight around in the Legislature.
Instead there are a half-dozen old medium-size factory towns and two dozen small pockets of decay scattered around the state. For most New Jerseyans, the problems these places have -- unemployment, rotten housing, crime, awful schools -- exist as abstractions, except for the attendance checkers suburban school districts post at the curb each day to monitor the license plates of cars dropping off kids, lest some city dweller manage to sneak a child across the line.
So it is interesting that some of the boldest ideas percolating to the surface of the urban policy debate these days are coming from Republicans, in a state where "city" has meant "Democrat" since Paterson dipped its first bolt of silk in a vat of dye.
Brett Schundler, the youthful and Republican Mayor of Jersey City, is trying to apply free market theory to school choice on the principle that the cities will live and die on the quality of their schools. After first backing him on an experimental free-choice voucher program, Mrs. Whitman backed off, for a year at least, to give the subject more reflection.
Mr. Schundler felt betrayed but hardly defeated, and last Thursday he was back in Trenton, touting a plan for charter schools, which operate independently and with specialized curriculums. It is at least something he can do without permission from Trenton.
The other Republican urban theoretician is Senator Dick LaRossa, whose 15th District includes Trenton. A one-time lottery announcer, Mr. LaRossa is not, admittedly, old-line G.O.P. He chose his party the day of the filing deadline in 1991, and has been something of a loose cannon in the tidy ranks of New Jersey's Republicans ever since.
But when you represent one third of the Republicans' three-vote majority in the Senate, even a nonconformist can find an audience, and Mr. LaRossa is trying to get his to listen to him about the cities. In a state that already has committees for veterans and for women's issues, Mr. LaRossa prevailed on Senate leadership to create the Legislature's first committee on urban policy and planning, and had himself installed as chairman.
"We're getting hammered on this question, this idea that the Republican Party doesn't care about the citiies," Mr. La Rossa said the other day, as he sat in his district office in Ewing, outside of Trenton. "We're allowing the other party to run away with the cities because we let people think we don't care."
To be fair, Mrs. Whitman is something of a softie when it comes to spending money directly on people who live in the cities, as opposed to bricks and mortar. Under pressure from the courts, she increased state aid to urban schools by $30 million this year and proposes to add another $100 million in the coming fiscal year, and she has refused to follow some of her fellow Republican governors in cutting welfare programs.
But the Governor's urban policy is essentially one of atmospherics, getting neighborhoods to improve themselves enough to attract private investment. Mr. LaRossa's take on the cities is fundamentally different, and focuses on employment first and uplift later.
"If we can lower the barriers to investment in the cities, and if we can show that investment will be profitable, we can do something besides talk about the problem," Mr. LaRossa said. "It's not like a field of dreams, if we build another industrial park, they will come. But if we can show businesses they can be profitable, they will come. The bottom line is still the bottom line."
Mr. LaRossa's Urban Redevelopment Act would empower a new state agency to force owners of closed city factories to get back into business or sell their properties to someone else. Besides the usual tax abatements for start-up industries, he wants a newly created Urban Development Authority to issue bonds to help new businesses start up, along with faster approval of the necessary licenses to operate factories.
There are still plenty of gaps in all this. Aren't many old factories so heavily polluted that businesses won't touch them, for fear of getting stuck with cleanup costs? Mr. LaRossa will offer technical help to make them touchable. Isn't one of the reasons businesses settle in the suburbs their aversion to the crime and despair of the cities? New jobs will lift the pall and pathology of poverty. And aren't factory jobs vanishing nationwide? Mr. LaRossa breathes the prayer of economic development gurus everywhere: "High tech."
The plan has picked up considerable attention among free-market strategists in Washington, and Governor Whitman's staff is working with the Senator on some of the plan's details. In a state that has made the cities and the cities' problems almost invisible, Mr. LaRossa is at least spinning ideas, including his strategy for selling his plan to the suburban-dominated Legislature: appeal to self-interest.
"The suburbs are already paying for the cities' problems, for education, for Medicaid, for welfare," he said recently. "And the cities' problems are already moving outwards. Crime was never an issue when it was a city issues, but now it's coming out to the suburbs. That's what's got people's attention."

HEADLINE: Big Utility Tax Is Suddenly Shrinking, And State Scrambles to Make Up for It

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
As the state government and its cities and towns scramble to make do with less in the aftermath of Governor Whitman's income tax cuts, another major source of revenue is shrinking much more quietly but almost as fast: the taxes paid by the seven big utility companies that supply most of the state's electricity and natural gas. And that drop, in turn, is stirring a debate about how -- and whether -- to prop up the revenue.
Treasury officials are predicting that next year the state will lose at least $85 million in revenue from the gross receipts and franchise tax, which is collected from the seven companies regulated by the State Board of Public Utilities. The tax, which amounts to more than $1 billion this year, is second only to property taxes as a source of revenue for municipal budgets. As recently as 1992, it brought in $1.5 billion. 
 The seven major utilities pay the 13.5 percent tax instead of local property taxes, to compensate for the use of public land for water mains, power and gas lines and other purposes. The revenue is shrinking because more and more businesses are buying electricity and gas from the utilities' competitors, which don't have to pay the utility tax: out-of-state companies and alternative energy producers, called co-generators because they generate steam and power as a byproduct of industrial processes.
By law, the state keeps about $250 million and passes $685 million to the municipalities. If there is extra revenue, it goes to the municipalities, and this year that figure is $85 million. But because of increased competition from the other suppliers, treasury officials have warned that the municipalities should not expect such a surplus next year. As more commercial and industrial customers buy energy from the alternative suppliers, the utilities say they are losing millions of dollars a year and therefore paying less in taxes to the municipalities. And they say their competitors get a built-in advantage because they don't have to pay the 13.5 percent tax.
"The large utilities don't mind paying the tax, but from a competitive standpoint they're getting killed," said William Dressel, assistant executive director of the League of Municipalities, the umbrella group of local governments. "It's only fair that these other companies get taxed, too."
But those suppliers point out that they pay a corporate business tax that the utilities are exempt from. They provide about 12 percent of the state's electricity and gas.
Sarah Beavers, a spokeswoman for the Board of Public Utilities, says the more substantial loss of revenue is to out-of-state gas companies that do not pay the utilities tax. The deregulation of the gas industry several years ago enabled commercial customers to buy their gas out of state. The board will soon consider whether to deregulate the electricity industry as well, which leaves some politicians worrying that the loss of tax revenue will get far worse.
"You don't have to look far in your crystal ball to see the same thing happening with electricity," said Senator Jack Sinagra, a Republican from Middlesex County who has been studying the deregulation issue since 1988. "This is just the beginning of a problem that's going to escalate unless we address it right away."
Donald Linky, president of the Public Affairs Research Institute of New Jersey, which studies tax policy, said the deregulation of the energy industry begged the question of whether the tax should continue to exist at all. "In my view, the tax has been a deterrent to economic development in New Jersey," he said.
Last month, the Treasury Department and Board of Public Utilities heard from politicians and officials from the energy suppliers at three public hearings. The Treasury Department has said that it will make a decision by the end of June about whether to recommend changes in the tax.
"If we don't plug that leak, it's going to hit everyone's pocketbook," said Mr. Dressel, of the League of Municipalities. "The worst-case scenario is right around the corner."

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
Thank You for Not Smoking (as if You Had a Choice)

BYLINE: By Herbert Muschamp

 BODY:
FORGET "STAR TREK," "STAR Wars," "2001." No outer-space adventure is as fascinating as the spatial dramas that take place right here on earth. New York City's tough new anti-smoking laws are a case in point. Push comes to shove a million times a minute in New York, but a new kind of territorial dispute doesn't come along every day. And the anti-smoking laws have made dining out an excellent refresher course in the dynamics of the territorial impulse and its impact on urban space.
The first day the laws went into effect, April 10, I had dinner at a downtown Manhattan restaurant that has always attracted a lot of smokers. It was shocking to see the room without smoke. You could actually see the ceiling, which, it turned out, had benefited from that low cloud cover. The paint was blotchy. You could also see the faces of diners halfway across the room in clear, seemingly magnified detail. Some of them had blotchy make-up. People looked uncomfortably exposed without their pale wrapper of haze. Smoke kills, but it can also lend enchantment. 
 As I was sitting there it occurred to me that smokers could argue that this is a freedom of religion issue. It has been proved that secondhand smoke is a health hazard, so in this sense the anti-smoking laws are based on science. But they also reveal the extent to which science can invite the projection of religious attitudes. In this case, it projects a good cover for Puritan morality.
Perhaps, like the American Indians who have received special exemption from drug laws because their sacred rites include the ingestion of hallucinogenic cactus buttons, smokers should start a cult, something like the First Church of Nights Out on the Town. Many of them are already devout worshipers at the altar of urban sophistication. Select restaurants could be their temples. Cigarettes could be marketed as incense sticks, to be brandished aloft over hot gossip and frosty Ketel One vodka martinis.
And if the ruse works, the concept could be expanded to include multinational corporations. Industries could fight air quality regulations on the grounds that they're not really belching pollution: they're conducting the solemn ritual of economic growth. Or polluters could claim exemption on esthetic grounds. They're creating atmosphere. Think how barren nocturnal New York would be without the steam that comes hissing from the manhole covers. As a friend once commented, with more than a touch of civic pride, the streets steam in New York because the city is so close to hell.
Besides compelling some restaurateurs to install partitions between the dining room and the bar, the anti-smoking law won't have much impact on architecture. Still, as an assertion of territoriality -- the right of some people to control a space and to let other people know that they don't -- the smoking ban is a good illustration of the social displacement that defines the city today.
Saskia Sassen, a professor of urban planning at Columbia University, has used the phrase "culture of eviction" to describe the reigning dynamic in the city now. The term doesn't refer only to the homeless. It refers to suburban children who know that they'll never be able to afford a house as nice as the one they grew up in. It refers to the struggling artist who discovers that the city no longer offers marginal living conditions to creative people. It refers even to the middle-class family working just to hold onto a little space and their dignity. Beyond that, it refers to the global migration from poor countries into large American cities and to the social displacement of those left out of the global-information economy.
Architecture doesn't drive the culture of eviction, but it plays a big role within it. Architects not only put up edifices; they also create images that conceal the magnitude of the displacement that is occurring. This is probably the big story of architecture in the 1980's. This was a decade when real-estate developers discovered the virtues of quality architecture, when architects learned to be sensitive to the urban context, when post-modernists showed themselves willing to accommodate tradition and popular taste.
AT THE SAME TIME, THIS WAS A period when housing costs skyrocketed, when homelessness became the new term for destitution, when the middle class could no longer take for granted the dream-house incarnation of the American dream. While architecture was promoting continuity with the past, society was experiencing a rupture with it. New housing developments began to simulate their surroundings esthetically while transforming them socially. While buildings appealed to popular taste, fewer people could afford them. Architecture, in other words, functioned as a smokescreen, an enchanting facade of stability that masked our rapid transformation into a society of virtual nomads.
The situation had those who write about architecture in a bind. We write about the look of buildings because it's expected of us and because we like it; we think form matters. Who were we to criticize real-estate developers for becoming more sophisticated about design? Yet at a certain point it became imperative to look further upstream toward the social and economic forces that bring buildings into being. Perhaps that point arrived with the end of the cold war, and the pressure it created to reexamine a society in which some people enjoyed park views while others slept in the park.
Architects have no choice but to work within the culture of eviction. Their livelihood depends on keeping it going. But they do have the capacity to decide how best to reckon with it. They can choose to mask it, substituting symbols of stability for the real thing. They can devise new forms that celebrate nomadism as a liberating force of contemporary life. Or (like Frank LLoyd Wright) they can respond to the creative challenge of mediating between these extremes.
No one has proposed legislation outlawing free enterprise. On the contrary, the political climate today favors the further relaxation of regulations that try to compensate for its defects. Nonetheless, the economic slump of the past few years has clarified the options architects face. It has cleared away a lot of smoke.

HEADLINE: Fostering Clean Air Through Environmental Law

BYLINE: By ERIKA DUNCAN 

 BODY:
I THINK everyone is born with a curiosity about nonhuman creatures," Charles Wurster said. "If it isn't an ant or a spider, it might be an elephant in the zoo. Everyone is born without fear of snakes and spiders."
It was Easter Sunday, which seemed an appropriate time for two strangers to meet, so that I could learn about the sequence of events that led to the banning of DDT nationwide and the founding of the Environmental Defense Fund. 
 Now the story is 30 years old, the "fearsome foursome," the young scientists who began it all, are three and their hair is very white. They are just as impatient about the plight of the natural world as they were 30 years ago, just as unable to wait, although their organization now has a membership of 300,000, a $25 million budget, and is still steadily growing.
The words echo: "What? You don't have a plan? No five-year plan?" the early trustees used to say. "You haven't chosen priorities?"
"We knew what our goal was." But the route remained flexible, as it still does today, despite the organization's large size. "New people would pop up, or the situation would change. We went up many blind alleys, and then backed off and went in a different direction.
"People think of things a government can't think of. Not having a plan leaves the way open for a great deal of innovation among all of the participants, even, often, for those on the other side."
He was speaking about how the Clean Air Act of 1990 exemplified this, specifying an amount and a time frame for cutting sulphur dioxide emissions without giving mandates about how it might be accomplished, so that those who were able to cut their pollution easily by 75 percent were able to sell their rights to those who could only cut it by 25 percent. Here, the goal, the 50 percent cut, was clearly more important to Charles Wurster than an arbitrary and even distribution.
He was speaking of the "win/win" situation with the McDonald's hamburger chain, how the staff of his organization worked flipping hamburgers, predicting that waste could be cut by 80 percent. Waste already has been cut by 75 percent and McDonald's has become an active collaborator.
As birds -- the best adapted to our earth as it is meant to be because they exist equally in land and sea and sky -- became the best barometer for the ills of the environment, so the successful banning of DDT, first in 1966 in Suffolk County and then later in Michigan (where dieldrin and aldrin were added) and then in Wisconsin, became the catalyst that broke through the "standing barrier" in which an individual was unable to press charges in court on behalf of a bird or a whale or the sky.
It brought into being a way of approaching environmental issues that would herald results more immediate than those of the most eloquent editorials and scientific reports, a collaboration of scientists and lawyers that inaugurated the now well-accepted entire field of environmental law.
There was a clear feeling of renewal outside, and although we were sitting indoors I felt that there was no distinction between dining room table and forest outside. The forest was just gathering its green, and beyond it one could see onto and over the salt marsh and onto and over the bay, to the tan of a sand bar, and then in the distance still farther the hills around Bridgeport, Conn.
Silhouetted against the glass that made up the front wall was a single dark telescope on a tripod. For Charles Wurster was starting to lead eco-tours in his approaching retirement and he found that, for the inexperienced, binoculars were tricky; they wasted all of their time focussing, instead of enjoying the birds.
And it seemed that the birds, still invisible to me in the forest, were in waiting on that day.
A man in a red and black flannel shirt, sitting at a slight diagonal against the floor-to-ceiling glass. You notice the little things when a person talks to you. The first thing I noticed was that Charles Wurster hardly ever said "I." He always said "we."
A week and a half later there would be a conference hosted by the Marine Sciences Research Center at Stony Brook, honoring "Charlie" on his retirement and celebrating the return of the osprey to Long Island, even naming that day, the 25th of April, in his honor. Needless to say, already he was fretting about being singled out in what was so clearly a collaborative story.
It was only when he was talking about boyhood beginnings before the life-long collaboration began that he was willing to use the word "I."
"When I was 6 and lived outside Philadelphia I came across a snake," he said, returning to inborn curiosity about the nonhuman world."Now I know it was a garter. I killed it. This was the enemy, but it fascinated me. Gradually my interest spread to turtles. I remember going out in row boats and catching them. By the age of 10 or 11, I was catching rattlesnakes and copperheads."
At the age of 16 he went to Germantown Friends' School "where," he said, "the naturalist Joseph Cadbury taught little kids all about birds and bees and the natural world."
"We would drive all night down to Florida and would camp in the Everglades. I would bring back the snakes that I caught in bags, and I would give them to the Philadelphia zoo. Most of the others were interested in birds, and after a while I would notice that if they saw 100 species of birds in a day, I would see two snakes. Somewhere along the line I made a checklist from memory of the birds I knew up to the point, and I found that I knew 200 species. It's been birds ever since."
A lot of forces converged so that he majored in chemistry -- "At the time biology didn't seem to be as serious a field. This was before DNA was discovered, don't forget" -- continuing until he came to Dartmouth to do his first biochemical work.
It was there that he was told by an elderly woman that the DDT that the town of Hanover was using to combat Dutch Elm disease was killing the birds.
"I saw the dead birds on the campus. And then we started to see some that were alive, with tremors. At first we didn't know what we were doing, but we sent petitions and we went to the town fathers who said: 'We are careful. We read the labels. We are very responsible. We do not want to kill birds.'
"We began to conduct a survey. There were four of us, who met during lunch. Two weeks after the spraying of DDT there would be a dead robin, and then another, and another. By the end of the semester in June we had 100 dead robins in our freezer.
"A small grant from the Fish and Wildlife Service enabled us to amass enough evidence to say to the town fathers, 'Now look what you did!' And they changed to another chemical."
In the fall of 1965, Charles Wurster moved to Stony Brook where he met the biologist Bob Smolker and the adventurer/naturalist explorer Dennis Puleston. He met Art Cooley, a high school biology teacher who still seems to him the soul of the movement.
Along with a number of friends and even a few of Art Cooley's brighter students, they started the Brookhaven Town Natural Resources Committee, whose main concern was such things as protection of seals, the dredging of swamps and the crushing of terns' nests by careless beach buggies.
They would meet at various homes once a month, and between meetings wrote letters to politicians. "Then a lawyer came into our midst," he said. It is with affection that Charlie describes Victor Yannacone, whose wife Carol had become upset when she saw some men from the Suffolk County Mosquito Commission cleaning their truck and then emptying the DDT washings into Yaphank Lake, killing the fish.
In a fortunate confluence of circumstances, Victor Yannacone saw a letter that Charlie had published in a local newspaper.
"Already, by the time that he called me, he had filed a suit in Carol's name. He had recognized the problem. But he didn't have the scientific evidence.
"He was an absolute believer in the court system, and that was his strength. We in turn needed what he had. We didn't have any idea how to get the system to move. If you kept knocking on the door, he was to teach us, eventually someone would make a mistake. You would be able to get in the court and stay there."
Although the presiding judge was unable to allow Carol, legally, to stand in for a lake or a fish, he was able to call an emergency halt to the commission's use of DDT until more conclusive evidence could be amassed.
While the judge was convinced from the onset, he did eventually have to throw the case out of court after the 18-month period of the injunction was over -- there was no place yet in the law for Carol's sort of claim -- but not before the Legislature was convinced to permanently outlaw the chemical.
The interval had provided politicians and public alike the chance for a serious hearing of the scientists' arguments that no previous editorial writing had accomplished. The case gave birth also to the strategy of "winning by losing," vital to a generation of environmentalists to come.
The story moves first into Michigan, and then into Wisconsin. In Michigan, the chemical is dieldrin, and again it is a case of winning by losing, although the circumstances, this time, are different. And already there are many more players.
Charlie had managed to convince me that I could not get the full story by talking to him alone, and so it is now 10 days later, the day that has been named for his celebration at Stony Brook. In the big and bare room where the podium and slide projector sit, one wall sports a map of the earth as seen from outer space, the other a black and white topographical representation of Long Island, whose crustacean-like texture seems to give the earth-world a strange almost prehistoric aura, half of insect and half of the dinosaur world.
Although it is broad daylight outside, the fluorescent lights vie with the incandescent. Most of the scientists are older, in their 60's and 70's, and are wearing formal suits, so that little belies their more anarchist beginnings.
Suddenly a woman comes in, dressed in red from head to toe, a long red gypsy skirt, much embroidered, and a flaming red jacket that falls more like a cape. The room seems to bow in deference, and surprise. Lorrie Otto has come to this conference from Wisconsin, along with Fred Ott.
An excitement with the history -- so shared -- is spoken more in this moment of entrance than in all of the words.
It is as if suddenly all stories are joined in a strange medley of choral voices. I am asking:"But why you. Surely others also saw them? What made you in particular devote your whole life to this?"
Lorrie Otto and Fred Ott are both talking at once. It is the same dying robins: how they put a dying bird into the hands of Fred's daughter who said: "To watch that robin trembling in my hand; I knew that I was going to be a scientist!" -- and she did become one, testifying in behalf of the environment; how the people who loved the elms and the people who loved the birds were at loggerheads, over what they should be saving.
By that time Charlie and his friends knew that DDT was no longer working. They were able, as would be their way whenever possible, to offer more effective alternatives.
Within days of Lorrie Otto's phone call to Charlie, scientists from all over the country, and even one from Canada and one from Sweden, had moved into her house to establish a center for studying the case.
One by one the speakers rose to tell their parts. Often, Ian Nisbet, an environmental consultant pointed out, the first note of changes came not from those interested in ecology but rather from unlikely places. Thus it was the falconer who noticed the gradual disappearance of peregrine falcons and bald eagles. Illegal collectors of birds' eggs held evidence of shell thinning over time. Part of the work of the organizers was always in extending the circle of collaborators.
Had the making of the group into a nationwide organization lessened the fervor of the earliest participants? had it resulted in compromise, in a weakening of resolve? Those whom I met all would argue it had not. Rather there was something rather heartening in the endurance.
"I like to think of it as a bit like the evolutionary process itself," Charlie said. "We kept more people than different circumstances would have predicted."
In the course of our conversations he would return very often to the idea of "win/win." Of course there are some situations where this is impossible. With the oil and coal companies, as with Montrose Chemical (the manufacturer of DDT), there was no way that you wanted them to win.
He would speak of the fact that he firmly believes that environmental change is possible within our present market economy; he does not feel that the system has to change, but rather that we have made the mistake of assigning zero value "let us say to the elephant, available to the ivory hunter for nothing."
"While the hunter gets the full profit, the world loses an elephant. It is the same with the whale and the air and the right to pollute it. We must think very differently about assigning a price to what should not be free.
"With each administration our relationship has been different. Right now, with the new Congress, our main concern is with maintenance, with not losing ground."
At the end of the evening, William Ruckelshaus, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency in 1972 who delivered the historic decision to ban DDT nationwide, gave a speech in which he begged environmentalists not to see government as the enemy.
My mind traveled back to the rather delightfully anarchist notion of the "one man committee" that Charlie Wurster had mentioned in passing.
"If responsibility for what is going to happen is in one place and everybody knows it, then it usually works out. If two people are supposed to write a letter to the editor, or get something moving, it is far less effective."
He had told me of an organization he knew of "that was beautifully organized, only it didn't yet know what it was going to do."
"When you aren't that well organized, when circumstances keep changing, you too are free to change. You are not stuck in a course that might be obsolete. And the focus becomes the job itself.
I thought about the moral meaning of respect for biodiversity, concern for all species, including the seemingly unimportant ones, in relationship to a whole whose secrets might never be known."For, years ago, who could have forseen that a certain mold would become instrumental in making penicillin; who would have wanted to save that particular mold?"
Was it possible that even thinking of such things would breed less competition? more interest in relationship?
In the beginning, for Charlie Wurster, it was very much a front-line struggle. While Rachel Carson's "Silent Spring" had moved a generation and paved the way for public sympathy, it was not until scientists and lawyers came together that real change could occur.
Did he miss being in that front line place? I had asked on the afternoon of that first Easter Sunday visit.
Yes, in a way he did, he said, as he spoke of how he felt his training wouldn't allow him to make the kind of contribution that is needed in the major scientific areas that preoccupy him now: those of population expansion, preservation of the world's forests and energy use, how he is reading in all of those areas, even as he pursues his plans to lead eco-tours in Africa and New Guinea.
Then he seemed to grow thoughtful for a moment. "I guess if I were to involve myself in anything in that same way again, it would be in the area of how pollutants can function as hormones. Way back even in the 40's, I noticed some papers about how roosters who had been exposed to DDT were no longer crowing properly. They didn't have proper combs and they would function as if they were semi-males. And then there were other pollutants enhancing femininity, decreasing masculinity. Over a 50-year period, human sperm counts had decreased by about half. There were alligators in Florida being born with half-length penises. On the west coast, where Montrose Chemical Company was situated, this hormonal chaos could be seen."
As day deepened, Charlie told me the story of the Montrose vicinity's lesbian gulls, how when it came to be breeding time there were five times as many females as males, so that the females paired up, laying their eggs and then sitting on them. They had made double clutches of eggs, but of course they were sterile.
"The males didn't even bother to come to the breeding grounds, so that the issue was really their absence," he repeated as he mused over whether there was anything he could personally do to explore the strange gradual "feminization of the planet."
"With DDT I was one of the troops," he repeated. "DDT involved many things -- birds and fish and cancer -- and they all fitted together. I knew what I wanted. Do you know that old saying, you can't go home."
Day deepened, and the forest outside grew even more beautiful.
It would be romantic to say that the birds began to sing, but that day, to my notice, they didn't.

HEADLINE: Connecticut Q&A: Drew M. Crandall;
A Minister Goes to the Marketplace

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
DREW M. CRANDALL, 39, is the founder and president of Keep In Touch, a sales and marketing company in Vernon, and the head of the New England chapters of Fellowship of Companies for Christ Inc.
The fellowship began meeting in Connecticut in February 1991, and has since grown to include nearly 100 active members -- business owners and chief executives from sole proprietorships to large corporations. The group meets regularly to pray, study Biblical principles for business and share experiences. 
 Mr. Crandall was born in Bridgeport and grew up in Connecticut, New Jersey and Long Island, attending Congregational and Methodist churches, then went to the University of Connecticut where he majored in sociology with a minor in economics. A career in sales and advertising followed.
Mr. Crandall discussed the fellowship during an interview recently at his office in Vernon. Following are excerpts from that conversation.
 Q. If you're interested in serving Christ, why not enter the ministry?
A. More than anything else, I know that God has called me to be here, to be a minister in the marketplace. If I had the title pastor, I think a lot of doors would be closed to me. But having a business card that says "president" opens a lot of doors.
If we say we believe on Sunday mornings and we don't show it the rest of the week, we're hypocrites. We really strive to demonstrate in the daily operation of our businesses that the Lord really is our Lord.
 Q. Why are members presidents and C.E.O.'s? Why not employees?
A. There are a number of business-oriented ministries.
I was saved -- that's the term, I trusted the Lord as my Savior -- at a Full Gospel Businessmen's Fellowship breakfast. That's an international organization aimed at a broader spectrum of business people, employees or middle managers or owners. There's another ministry I'm involved with in Hartford, the Connecticut Christian Business and Professional Association, which is also broad. You have the Gideons, who are businesspeople whose ministry is primarily distributing Bibles.
When the founders of the Fellowships of Companies for Christ organized in Atlanta in the late 1970's, they realized when it came to strong Bible teachings on how to run a business, they couldn't find a source.
I find I need encouragement from other C.E.O.'s, because the buck stops with you on every single thing. The degree of accountability and responsibility is enormous. Unless you walk in similar shoes, it's hard to understand that.
 Q. Is it predominantly any one denomination?
A. No, there are at least 12 to 15 denominations represented in Connecticut. It's not the label on your church that saves you, it's the Lord that saves you. There are three criteria to become a member. You must be a born-again Christian. Next, you must occupy the office of chief executive officer, president or owner of a for-profit business. Third, you must be active in a local church, giving of your time and talents.
 Q. Does the organization require that members close on Sundays or not use certain advertising techniques?
A. It doesn't have a guidebook that says, "This is what you shall do and this is what you shall not do," because the ministry trusts that if you know Christ as your Lord and Savior and the Holy Spirit is in you, you'll do right. There's no perfect business. If you were to look at my business with a magnifying glass you'd see things that aren't perfect. But as you are taught the Word and talk to other Christian C.E.O.'s, the Lord will gradually impress upon you what you should do or not do.
Q. Is there anything a member could do that would cause you to ask them to leave?
A. I can't remember a case where someone was chastised or booted out.
If you chose not to be really zealous about serving the Lord in your business you'd probably drift away, because you wouldn't want to hang around people who are on fire for the Lord.
But how do you deal with people who may have crossed the line? If that person comes back and asks for forgiveness, I say give him a hug and move forward.
 Q. Are there any types of businesses that would not be welcome?
A. There are real obvious ones -- if the C.E.O. of a pornography company came, the decision would be easy.
But there are others that are not so easy. I would have to plead with the Lord to give me wisdom, to know what to do. The company that makes those killer bullets, for instance, or gambling.
But I don't think those issues lend themselves to a list that says, "These industries are in and these industries are out." You have to handle it on a case-by-case basis.
Q. What are some of the Biblical principles for business?
A. The top one comes from First Timothy: "For the love of money is the root of all evil." We have to be very cognizant of the enticement of material wealth.
Another would be that to the best of your ability, you have to honor your financial commitments. If you use bankruptcy to hold off your creditors to give you time to organize your finances and honor your debts, there's nothing wrong with that. But from a Scriptural and moral standpoint, to file for bankruptcy and stiff your vendors . . . it may be legal technically, but not before the Lord.
Q. Are there situations where business really benefited from following Christian principles?
A. Yes, from one in particular -- the Golden Rule: "Do unto others as you would have them do unto you." If you love your customers and your employees and vendors, and treat them as you want to be treated, you will benefit. People gravitate toward people who love them. Nobody wants to go where they're not welcome, and if you make it clear you don't care about your customer, what kind of business are you going to have?
 Q. Are there situations where businesses have been hurt by not following Christian principles?
A. Five, 10 years ago, we had a few pillars of the state economy: defense, insurance and financial services, and real estate. We've seen those three pillars shake; they came down crumbling.
You look at the real causes for that trouble, and you can point to Scriptural principles that were broken, greed being one of them, lack of wisdom being another.
There were some worldwide political factors that played a role in it, but I think if we're honest with ourselves, much of the recession in Connecticut was self-inflicted.
 Q. Do you risk offending non-Christian customers by promoting Christianity?
A. I set out to be a Christian company, right from the start, and my brochure makes it clear where I stand with the Lord.
However, we do live in a pluralistic world, and not everybody believes in the Bible, not everyone believes in Christ, not everyone is as zealous in their faith as myself.
There have been occasions where I've lost business, or haven't gotten business, because of my Christian faith. That's the price I pay for being who God has called me to be.
By the same token, though, there has been business we've gotten because of our Christian faith.
 Q. Do you expect your customers to be Christians?
A. No. I do not have the fortress mentality, where we have to deal only with Christians. That's the monastery approach. We're out in the highways and byways of life, dealing with real world issues and real people.
 Q. Do most companies have a moral basis?
A. I think they do. I serve on the board of the Better Business Bureau, and the Tolland County Chamber of Commerce. I think, fundamentally, most business owners have a heart to do right. Perhaps they have more of a sensitivity to customers because that's where their bread and butter comes from.
 Q. What do you find most discouraging about today's business climate?
A. It does seem, at times, you're punished for trying to do what's right. I've had some experiences where I've done what I think my conscience and God have told me to do, but I'm beat up for trying to be a Christian. Yet I see so many ungodly people out there raping and pillaging, and everyone seems to be applauding them.
But you know, King David, when he wrote the Psalms, saw some of that too. But the Lord gave him the wisdom to have a more eternal perspective. He used to cry out, "I see the wicked prosper," and the Psalmist said, "but then I saw the end of their ways."
We're dealing with eternity here, and my life is just a vapor, that's what the Bible says.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Drew M. Crandall, entrepreneur and dedicated Christian leader, draws inspiration from a family Bible. (Steve Miller for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section A; Page 16; Column 5; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 271 words

HEADLINE: Welfare Rules Imperil Battered Women

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your May 8 news article on migration of welfare recipients from Chicago to Wisconsin draws the reader to simple and unfair conclusions. The poor cite a variety of reasons for moving that mirror those of the wealthy. And yes, for those subsisting on low grants, extra money doesn't hurt. What hurts are residency requirements designed to discourage relocations based on an assumed pursuit of higher benefits. 
 The two-tier concept, which restricts newcomers to benefit levels of their former states, punishes fleeing domestic-violence victims and their children. Abusers typically escalate abuse when they sense control slipping, so miles provide added protection. Victims who have left behind all assets for a chance at safety are welcomed with assured poverty.
While benefits are higher in Wisconsin than in Illinois, you don't report that Wisconsin's $617 grant for a family of four is hardly sufficient for housing, child care and other costs.
Punitive welfare reforms bent on reducing the rolls threaten to cut off a vital bridge to independence and safety. Rigid work requirements designed to punish or modify "lazy" behavior ignore the reality that recipients' good-faith efforts to work are often met with beatings.
It is vexing when legislators who purport to be tough on crime are the same ones who endorse policies that make it harder for women to break the cycle of violence. Women may be forced to choose economic security and abuse over poverty and homelessness.
 
MARCI BERNSTEIN
Housing Coordinator, Wisconsin
Coalition Against Domestic Violence
Madison, Wis., May 12, 1995

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Old Soldier May Take Deng's Mantle

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: GUANGZHOU, China

 BODY:
Of the six old men likely to remain as revolutionary elders of China after Deng Xiaoping dies, only one has commanded the 3.2-million-member People's Liberation Army, a key institution during the coming political succession.
Only one has made a state visit to Washington, talks frequently about the importance of strong relations with the United States and counts George Bush among his friends. 
 Only one was at Mr. Deng's side both when the paramount leader began China's economic reforms here in the prosperous south and when he had to rescue the reforms from a hard-line backlash that followed the Tiananmen Square violence in June 1989.
His name is Yang Shangkun, a military man who has often backed reformers. And among the octogenarian elders -- Mr. Yang is 88 -- he poses the biggest threat to upend the political order that Mr. Deng, his lifelong friend, has bequeathed to a restless nation of 1.2 billion.
Although China's political succession is apparently complete with the elevation of Jiang Zemin as head of state, general secretary of the Communist Party and chief of the military, the revolutionary elders who survive Mr. Deng -- who is 90 and in poor health -- will continue to wield enormous influence, Chinese and Western officials say.
The most influential conservative among the elders, Chen Yun, died at the age of 89 on April 10, but he is survived by Peng Zhen, 92, Mr. Yang, Song Renqiong, 85, Bo Yibo, 86, Wan Li, 78, and Song Ping, 78.
It was these leaders who elevated Mr. Jiang after Zhao Ziyang, now 76, was deposed as party boss during the Tiananmen Square crisis.
While Mr. Yang's age makes it doubtful that he will dominate Chinese succession over a number of years, his influence after Mr. Deng's death could tip the factional balance that has swung between Marxist conservatives and liberal reformers for nearly two decades.
"Yang Shangkun is making a serious bid to come back, and he has a tremendous network inside the country," said Douglas Paal, a White House specialist on China during the Bush Administration.
Even as the Communist Party leadership in Beijing projects an image of unity and stability to the world, Mr. Yang has been politicking among the regional party and military leaders who have shown growing disaffection with the increasingly conservative policy from Beijing.
Even though he is nominally out of power now, just three summers ago it seemed that Mr. Yang could succeed Mr. Deng as China's paramount leader.
Mr. Yang was the only member of the group of Chinese elders who had the same combination of longstanding military and political connections as Mr. Deng and, of equal importance, he was committed to Mr. Deng's economic reforms.
"Yang Shangkun goes along with Deng and always has," said James R. Lilley, a former United States Ambassador to China. "If you go back and look at his career, there is a consistent pattern of his coming down on the side of the reformers."
Mr. Deng's sudden decision in the summer of 1992 to drop Mr. Yang and purge the military of his influence, and that of his younger half-brother, Gen. Yang Baibing, has been one of the enduring mysteries of China's succession struggle.
Now, from the accounts of former Communist Party insiders, Chinese observers and Western diplomats, the dimensions of Mr. Yang's assault on the political status quo are becoming clearer.
According to these people, Mr. Yang was stripped of his offices after he tried to remove President Jiang Zemin and Prime Minister Li Peng in early 1992. In their place, he promoted the idea of elevating more centrist and reform-minded party leaders.
Western diplomats say they believe that in 1992, Mr. Yang sought to broker the return of Zhao Ziyang, the Communist Party leader ousted in 1989 over his refusal to send the tanks and machine gunners against unarmed democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square.
Many Chinese find it paradoxical that Mr. Yang, who carried out Mr. Deng's assault orders against the students in 1989, has been working behind the scenes to rehabilitate Mr. Zhao.
For a man who is supposed to be out of power, Mr. Yang gets remarkable attention when he demonstrates his influence, as he did this winter here in Guangdong, China's richest province.
One newspaper in Shenzhen, the contained capitalist economic zone across from Hong Kong, published Mr. Yang's picture on the front page as if he were visiting royalty.
In Zhuhai, which borders Macao, the city fathers feted Mr. Yang aboard a yacht. After all, one city resident said, it was Mr. Yang's influence in the Chinese military that got Zhuhai permission to build an international airport, putting the sleepy port town on Asia's map.
It was said that Mr. Yang was retracing the steps of Mr. Deng's southern crusade of 1992, which signaled China's economic boom. For Mr. Yang to have made this pilgrimage speaks volumes about his political intention to play a kingmaker role in the post-Deng era.
The survivor of numerous internecine party struggles, Mr. Yang cuts the figure of a self-assured Chinese warlord. Gone are the dress greens he wore like a marshal of the Red Army. Now, in forced retirement, he wears conservative business suits, which render him slightly rotund, Buddha-like.
Amazingly spry at 88, Mr. Yang moved nimbly through Shenzhen's botanical gardens in January, even visiting the trees that he and Mr. Deng planted in 1992. His public speeches are spare and politically correct.
In Shenzhen, Mr. Yang praised Mr. Deng for his "foresight" in creating "special economic zones" where China could experiment with foreign investment and free-market economics that are now transforming the country. By working in Shenzhen, he said, a whole generation of Communist Party cadres have become committed reformers. "They are its wealth," he said.
In the culture of the Communist Party, this is the gospel of reform, and that is why here, among the gleaming towers of southern China's richest province, Mr. Yang's name still commands Deng-like respect.
If the political succession Mr. Deng has put in place suddenly collapsed, it would not be a first.
Mao selected and purged three potential heirs before he finally settled on Hua Guofeng, whom he anointed by uttering from his deathbed, "With you in charge, I am content."
After Mao died in September 1976, two years passed before Mr. Deng emerged from a bloodless but intense political struggle to become first among equals in the circle of revolutionary elders.
Today, as Mr. Deng's death approaches, China's enfeebled paramount leader has uttered to a daughter that with Mr. Jiang in charge, "I am content."
Many Chinese believe that this prescription, too, will not endure. Mr. Jiang was always a compromise, a choice least offensive to China's hard-liners, whom Mr. Deng was forced to placate after the democratic uprising in June 1989.

HEADLINE: An Economic Ghost: Stagflation;
G.O.P. Revives a 70's Bugaboo, Hoping to Spread Any Blame

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 14

 BODY:
For months, economists have been using the cheery term "soft landing" to describe an American economy that seems to be gliding to a slower but steady rate of growth after several boom years.
But now an uglier word is making the rounds: stagflation, a combination of paltry growth, rising unemployment and spiraling inflation. 
 The Republican majority on the Joint Economic Committee of Congress cried stagflation in an economic analysis issued Friday. The analysis followed a Government report saying that consumer prices climbed in April at the fastest rate in eight months, as well as earlier reports that producer prices had risen faster in April while unemployment jumped.
The politics of crying stagflation are clear. Republicans are nervous that if the economy goes into a recession during next year's Presidential campaign, some of the blame may be heaped on their budget cuts instead of the policies of the Clinton Administration. So they are striking early by pointing out that the economy has already had problems, and by trying to link these problems to the White House.
"With both the producer and consumer price indices rising at 3 to 4 percent annual rates, and data on the economy showing weakness, the recent economic performance continues to resemble that of the 'stagflation' of the late 1970's," the G.O.P.-driven analysis said. "This is largely the result of easy money in 1992 and 1993 that masked the Clinton tax increases. Now that the easy-money stimulus is wearing off, the slowdown effects of those tax increases are showing up."
White House officials are no different in trying to manipulate perceptions of the economy for political gain. Leon Panetta, the President's chief of staff, led a succession of top officials in daily briefings last week warning that Republican budget proposals could turn an economic slowdown into a recession.
Economists tend to be skeptical of both sides' assertions. They dismiss the idea that modest tax-policy changes in 1993 could have seriously changed the course of a $6 trillion to $7 trillion economy. They also dismiss the notion of serious economic harm from a Republican blueprint to balance the budget by reducing the deficit by less than $30 billion a year in each of the next seven years.
With few exceptions, economists also doubt that the United States also faces stagflation now. Instead, most expect that the country will avoid steeply rising inflation, but may pay a price that could prove just as painful in higher unemployment and a further widening of the gap between rich and poor. They forecast growth slowing to 2 or 3 percent this year, from 4 percent last year. Most economists consider slowing growth, as well as an actual decline in business activity, to be an ingredient of stagflation.
And while rising prices and unemployment may mean that April qualified as a single month of stagflation in a narrow and technical sense, the overall structure of the economy has changed so much since the late 1970's that a return to the problems of those years seems unlikely.
"In some literal sense, the month was a month of stagflation, but that does not capture the spirit of the times," said Neal M. Soss, an economic consultant and money manager in New York.
In 1979 unemployment averaged 5.8 percent, the same rate as in April 1995. But consumer prices were then rising at an annual rate of 13.3 percent. Consumer prices increased four-tenths of 1 percent in April, and at an annual rate of only 3.1 percent for the first four months of this year.
The first use of the term "stagflation," in 1965, has been attributed to Iain Macleod, a leading British Conservative politician, who would become Chancellor of the Exchequer. In the United States, it has been used to describe adverse economic conditions at times during the Nixon, Ford and Carter administrations.
There are powerful forces at work now that could slow price rises in the coming months. Commodity prices, which soared in 1994, have fallen this year for a wide range of products from iron and steel scrap to cattle hides. That will eventually mean a little less pressure to raise prices for everyone from steelmakers to producers of shoes.
At the same time, the Federal Reserve's seven increases in interest rates in the last 15 months have eroded demand, and with it, long-term inflation pressure on the prices of cars and other products. New homes may be the exception, as falling mortgage rates have made them more affordable, and this could lead to more construction this summer.
But as overall demand for goods and services fades as the economy slows, companies are facing a difficult choice between raising prices or cutting back on labor, typically by laying off workers or cutting wages. With companies still encountering strong customer resistance to price increases, the result seems to be the sort of aggressive action such as that by Mobil, which announced on May 1 the layoff of nearly 10 percent of its work force a week after posting a big rise in first-quarter profit.
With national unemployment increasing three-tenths of a percentage point in April, to 5.8 percent, businesses may retain the ability to forestall at least the inflation side of stagflation, though possibly at the expense of their employees.
Darwin L. Beck, an economist at the First Boston Corporation, said, "They're certainly going to try that, and if the labor market is as weak as April's data indicates, labor is not going to have much leverage."
