HEADLINE: Two States, Two Gatherings and a Lot of Anti-Government Sentiment;
At Michigan Rally, Unyielding Anger At the Brady Bill

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: STERLING HEIGHTS, Mich., May 13

 BODY:
At Gunstock '95, held beneath hazy skies at Freedom Hill County Park here, a Doberman pinscher named Brutus wore a collar made from a bandoleer.
Compared with the sentiment at Woodstock in 1969, the anti-authoritarian spirit at this gun rights rally had a steely edge. Among the two thousand or three thousand people who browsed through booths run by chapters of the Michigan Militia, the John Birch Society and other right-wing groups, tastes ran to camouflage and the words of Patrick Henry rather than tie-dye and the lyrics of Arlo Guthrie. 
 The only live music was a rendition of the national anthem, the only chanting a recitation of the Pledge of Allegiance, and the only controlled substance on everybody's minds the ammunition they had left at home.
"Adolf Hitler was the first one who supported gun registration!" thundered Dave Jaye, a Republican state representative, in one speech to the crowd. Mr. Jaye is sponsoring legislation to permit residents of Michigan to carry concealed firearms.
At the booths, literature warned of a one-world government and of threats posed by "pro-animal extremists" and the complex financial instruments known as derivatives. Ball caps for sale condemned to hell Sarah Brady, the wife of the Brady Bill namesake, James Brady. T-shirts called President Clinton a "Socialist-Marxist Commu-Nazi."
"Where is Lee Harvey Oswald when his country needs him?" asked one bumper sticker, for sale at a booth run by a local Libertarian Party. Other stands sold waffle cones, pizza and Italian sausage.
"We don't want our children to lose their freedom," said Susan Timko, explaining why she had brought Catherine, 13, and Matthew, 10, to picnic in this blue-collar Detroit suburb and listen to five hours of speeches about Waco, the Los Angeles riots and theories about a government link to the Oklahoma City bombing. "When they're our age, I don't want to see them living under suppression."
This was the second annual Gunstock, which is sponsored by the Gun Owners of Macomb County and the Macomb Coalition of Republicans. About 3,000 to 3,500 people paid $5 each to attend, organizers said, down from the 10,000 they claimed last year. Police estimates for this year were closer to 2,500.
After last fall's elections, "I don't think people feel their rights are under the same assault they were last year," said Joseph Munem, an organizer. Some attendees said the boat show drew people away; others said people feared that undercover Government agents would be attending this year.
Mr. Munem said he had named the event Gunstock because "it just has sort of a festive atmosphere."
"It's not a gun rally: it's like Woodstock," Mr. Munem said.
Aside from a revulsion to gun control, attendees -- engineers, police officers, United Automobile Workers union members and others -- seemed to share deep fears of Government conspiracies and a thirst for information confirming them.
"You read a book like this, and you start to see what's going on," Tom Lightbody, a World War II veteran and a member of the John Birch Society, said as he raised his copy of "Global Tyranny, Step by Step: The United Nations and the Emerging World Order." "In the schools, they're teaching kids that they're world citizens. They're not learning about America."
The Oklahoma City bombing and its political fallout were not far from Mr. Lightbody's thoughts. "It was horrible," he said of the attack. But he said the Government was using it as an excuse to crack down on groups who were not involved. "The same broad brush they're applying to the militia movement I saw applied to the John Birch Society in 1961," he said.
Fear may have brought the people together, but even those with the darkest views of the future seemed able to relax and have fun. Dale Orthner, for example, described burying food, medical supplies and ammunition to prepare for the coming chaos. He had also bought two handguns, two rifles and a shotgun. "I really don't like to hunt," he said, "but in a post-economically collapsed society, I'm going to have to."
Mr. Orthner, 25, a member of the Michigan Constitutional State Militia, was concerned that widespread use of derivatives would destroy the world's economy. "It's designed to fail by the oligarchs," he said. He identified "the oligarchs" as the Rockefellers, the Morgans, the Rothschilds, the House of Windsor and others. "They'll let us wallow in the mire of our apparently self-inflicted depravity for a couple of months, and then come in and say, 'We can help,' " he said. They could then "depopulate the planet," he said.
But, even as he described the apocalypse at a mile a minute, Mr. Orthner, a real estate agent, grinned and waved as he caught sight of clients in the passing crowd.
Where Mr. Orthner railed against derivatives, hunters' rights advocates worried that people were forgetting that human beings were predators by nature, and Libertarians complained that the Government had given the United Nations the moon.
One man, who would identify himself only as George, seemed most concerned about the Federal Emergency Management Agency. He said FEMA was running concentration camps in the United States. "They're international police," said George, who was wearing red, white and blue suspenders over his blue oxford cloth shirt.
Despite his fear of the Government, George said he was a member of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, although he would not say at what level of government he worked or in what capacity. "It's a job, sir," he said.
Many attendees wore "patriot awareness" ribbons, camouflage bows pinned to their chests.
Among the speakers, the star attraction was Mark Scott, host of a talk show on WXYT Radio here. Standing before a giant American flag, he suggested that the Central Intelligence Agency was involved in the Oklahoma City bombing. "It was committed by C.I.A. contractors," he said, adding that the Government hoped to disarm "the American patriot movement." Like other speakers, he urged his listeners to vote and to obey the law.
"We should remember to be law-abiding," Mr. Scott said. "But we will remember that what they won't allow us at the ballot box can be won at the bullet box.
"Keep your powder dry," he added.

HEADLINE: REPUBLICANS FACE AN INTERNAL FIGHT ON CUTTING TAXES

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 14

 BODY:
As the House and Senate prepare to debate watershed plans to balance the Federal budget, the authors of the Republican plans differed today over whether the final version of the proposal should include a huge tax cut that would almost certainly draw a Presidential veto.
In broadcast interviews today, the chairmen of the two budget committees that wrote and approved the measures appeared to be at loggerheads over the tax question. The House budget plan includes a $340 billion tax cut for businesses and individuals, while the Senate plan leaves taxes at their current level. 
 "The debate about whether we ought to have tax relief in the budget" is over, Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, the House chairman, said on the CBS News program "Face the Nation." Critics had contended that it would be almost impossible to cut taxes and erase the deficit. But with the approval of the House budget plan, he said that as far as he was concerned "that argument has been laid to rest."
Mr. Kasich's counterpart, Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, said he was sticking by his position. "We don't have a tax cut until we balance the budget," he said on the same program.
The politics are straightforward enough. Republicans probably have enough votes in both chambers to enact any budget package they choose, but they lack enough Democratic support to assemble the two-thirds vote required to override a Presidential veto. And their prospects of getting it are fairly slim.
That means they must either produce a final budget this summer with enough concessions to persuade Democrats that it is not worth a messy political battle, or push something close to their current proposals and brace for a fight that could briefly shut down the entire Government.
The route they take depends on how Republicans in the House and Senate handle the current debates over their respective budget proposals, which are but frameworks for the actual budget that will be written in a few months. One way or the other, the two chambers must produce a single budget framework late this month that will set the course for the rest of the year.
Today Mr. Domenici and Mr. Kasich both said they were confident that the House and Senate would approve their proposals largely unchanged.
Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut, the general chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said the two parties could work together to balance the budget if both the Republicans and the Clinton Administration dropped tax cut proposals and found common ground on health-care reform.
"If we can do that, then I think frankly we can come to an agreement," Mr. Dodd said on NBC's "Meet the Press." "That's what we ought to be doing, not trying to one-up each other."
The full House, its Republican majority unified under Speaker Newt Gingrich, is expected to rubber-stamp its version of the deficit-reduction plan in a vote this week. The more fragmented Republican bloc in the Senate is most likely to take longer to approve its budget measure, haggling over amendments that would increase spending on the military and over other areas of Republican concern.
The White House proposed its own far more modest tax cut, totaling $63 billion over five years, in the budget that President Clinton sent to Congress in February. That plan included tax breaks for middle income families with children and for whom household income is less than $75,000 a year, deductions for college tuition and an expanded individual retirement account. Mr. Clinton's budget is considered dead in the Republican Congress, but that $63 billion is seen by many as at least the low end of what the White House might consider spending on tax cuts in a final budget.
The Republicans who dominate the House favor deep tax and spending reductions as a matter of ideology. Among other things, the $340 billion tax cut in the House budget resolution would grant credits to all taxpaying families earning less than $250,000 a year and sharply reduce the capital-gains tax rate.
At this early stage, no one was ready to suggest how the bitterly partisan budget fight that seems certain to erupt over a deficit-reduction package will play out. Nor does anyone really know what the Republican budget will eventually do about tax cuts. But the Senate's budget outline approved last week does set aside $170 billion that Congressional analysts say might be saved if a balanced budget lowers interest rates and therefore the cost of the Government's debt. House leaders have suggested that that figure might be a starting point in any talks.
The tax issue is easily the most pressing question facing the Republican majority in Congress as the budget debates begin.
The struggle will unfold on the House and Senate floors over the next two weeks. And the outcome, political strategists say, will shape not just the final battle between Republicans and Democrats over the 1996 budget this fall, but the 1996 Presidential race as well.
"That's the showdown," a top aide to House Republican leaders said in an interview. "It's going to be one of the defining moments of this year."
A sprinkling of Republicans in Congress began over the weekend to question specifics of the House and Senate plans, especially the Senate's proposal to hold military spending basically at current levels.
The two proposals, called resolutions, each seek to save more than $1 trillion from Federal spending that is currently projected in the 1996 fiscal year and the succeeding six years. They are essentially frameworks for the all budgets through 2002, setting overall spending levels for major parts of the Federal Government. The fates of individual programs will be decided by appropriations committees in separate bills this summer.
Once the two chambers ratify the proposals, which is a foregone conclusion in most experts' minds, Mr. Domenici, Mr. Kasich and other House and Senate leaders will try to meld the plans into a compromise version that should come to a final vote in both houses later this month.
Private budget analysts said the two committees had performed a historic feat but cautioned that the resolutions did not reduce projected spending in actual programs, but only instructed other committees to make reductions later this summer.
"These are serious numbers," Stanley Collender, the Federal budget expert at the accounting firm Price-Waterhouse in Washington, said of the Republican plans. "These are not based on rosy economic assumptions."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Television;
A castoff show may come back to haunt CBS from its lofty new perch on NBC's schedule.

BYLINE: By Bill Carter 

 BODY:
FOR Andy Hill, these are days of highly mixed emotions. On the one hand, he is elated because as president of CBS Entertainment Productions he will see a show developed by his company placed in a promising position on the fall television schedule, a position where it stands an excellent chance of becoming, as he puts it, "a monster hit."
On the other hand, Mr. Hill is feeling "some real awkwardness." If the show, a half-hour comedy called "Caroline in the City," does become the success Mr. Hill expects, CBS -- which needs hit comedies like the Titanic needed lifeboats -- will not be the beneficiary of its hearty ratings. NBC will. 
 The prospect of a CBS-produced show becoming a hit for NBC is the latest example of how far the networks are willing to go to become suppliers of programs as well as their distributors. In this case, CBS's programming department passed on the opportunity to place "Caroline" on its own schedule. But the network's production division, acting like any other studio in Hollywood, sought out other buyers for the series -- and found one in a competing network.
NBC thinks so much of "Caroline," which revolves around a young woman cartoonist living in Manhattan, that the network is expected to announce today that it will give the comedy the 9:30 P.M. time slot on Thursdays. That is the most highly coveted time period for a new show in television because it is sandwiched between the two highest-rated shows in the business, "Seinfeld" and "E.R."
Warren Littlefield, president of NBC Entertainment, says "Caroline" has a chance to follow in the tradition of NBC hits that have thrived on Thursdays, among them "Seinfeld," "Cheers" and "Frasier."
 If "Caroline" does become a success of that magnitude, CBS will certainly benefit financially because reruns of hit comedies often bring their owners $100 million or more in syndication profits. "CBS Productions would have a tremendous asset," Mr. Hill said. "That would be great news for CBS corporately."
Still, it would be far better economically for CBS if the show was part of its own ailing prime-time schedule. Instead, "Caroline" has a chance to do even more damage to the CBS lineup by pulling more viewers to NBC.
Executives at all the networks say this kind of arrangement will be repeated more often as increasingly tangled alliances between networks, producers and writers create situations in which traditional rivals become partners. Last fall, for example, CBS had high hopes for a comedy called "The Boys Are Back," a show owned by ABC Productions. (It failed.)
"With the earth moving and shifting constantly in this business, with networks being bought or sold and new alliances being made every day, there are no rules to the competition any more," said Brad Grey, co-chairman of Brillstein-Grey Entertainment, a production company that has a partnership agreement with ABC. That partnership has produced one comedy, "News Radio," which is now on the air and doing quite well. But it's on NBC, not ABC.
Mr. Grey said "News Radio" was simply a more appropriate show for NBC. "Creatively, it just fit NBC," Mr. Grey said, referring to NBC's enviable track record in scheduling youthful, adult-oriented, urban-based romantic comedies.
Ted Harbert, president of ABC Entertainment and the man who selects the shows that play on the network's prime-time schedule, said much the same thing when NBC picked up "News Radio." NBC had the right place to put the comedy, he said, and had other shows that were compatible with it.
Similarly, Mr. Hill said, "Caroline in the City" simply works better as a NBC show.
For one thing, the comedy would have been substantially different had it remained at CBS, especially at the top of the bill.
The actress Lea Thompson, who plays Caroline, had a contract with NBC. "Warren Littlefield delivered Lea Thompson," Mr. Hill said, "and he deserves all the credit for that."
Indeed, Mr. Littlefield had been looking for the right project for Ms. Thompson, one of the stars of the "Back to the Future" movies. He said that Ms. Thompson was leaning toward starring in a one-hour drama being developed by NBC but that he steered her instead toward "Caroline" because the show seemed so right for her.
As Mr. Hill explained it, NBC had a surer sense of how to turn "Caroline" into a hit. When first presented to CBS, the show centered on the romantic relationship between an older woman and a younger man. Program executives at CBS passed on the idea, Mr. Hill said, "because they felt they had similar shows in development that they liked better."
Still convinced that "we had a hit show in this script," Mr. Hill went across the street to NBC, where he thought the show might get a warm reception. It did.
Two NBC development executives, Jamie McDermott and Bob Levy, found the main character and comedic voice promising, though they thought the show should be substantially changed. "They gave us very smart notes," Mr. Hill said.
The writers revised the comedy to include NBC's suggestions, making it more a romantic triangle among three characters. Ms. Thompson was added to the project, along with the director James Burrows, who has a special deal with NBC.
The show was essentially retailored to fit NBC's prime-time comedy style and was no longer the series that CBS had rejected. "It is a considerably different show," Mr. Hill said.
That distinction was important, he said, because it undercut the notion that CBS passed on a show it clearly could use. "The show would not have been the same if it had stayed on CBS," Mr. Hill said.
Still, it is likely to be a point of some embarrassment for CBS if "Caroline" goes on to become another NBC hit; CBS has not had a break-through comedy hit since "Murphy Brown" seven years ago.
Asked whether any CBS executives had expressed some regret about "Caroline" winding up as the most highly anticipated new show on NBC's schedule, Mr. Hill said, "I'll pass on that."
But, he added: "If we're not going to be aggressive, we shouldn't be in this business. People have had a problem in the past viewing CBS Productions as a major program supplier, even though we've put on shows like 'Dr. Quinn, Medicine Woman,' 'Walker, Texas Ranger' and 'Dave's World' on CBS."
"Getting 'Caroline' on NBC is by far the most important statement CBS Productions has ever made about our legitimacy in this business," he added.

HEADLINE: Commencements;
Upsala Ceremony Is a Last Hurrah

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

DATELINE: EAST ORANGE, N.J., May 14

 BODY:
The band played "Pomp and Circumstance," honorary degrees were conferred and the alma mater, "Hail, Hail, Upsala," was sung.
But for Upsala College, it was the last time these traditions will be observed. Yesterday, the school graduated its final class of seniors, as 200 students received degrees from a college that is closing its doors forever. 
 For many, the day carried a bittersweet flavor. Several undergraduates had yet to complete transfers to other schools, alumni wept over memories rendered suddenly unreturnable and the professors said they planned to file for unemployment this morning.
"It's like a party and a funeral at the same time," said Darnell Grant, the student body president, who was among those who graduated. College buildings were covered with graffiti but surrounded by lovely dogwood and lilacs, as if to illustrate his point.
The commencement ended an academic year in which the college teetered on the brink of financial collapse, then pinned its hopes on a South Korean industrialist, only to be drowned in red ink and the loss of its accreditation. The day culminated with a small service in the college chapel in which the Upsala seal and official mace were ceremoniously returned to the Evangelical Lutheran Church of America, which founded the college in Brooklyn in 1893.
In a prayer, the Rev. Charles R. Leonard, the college pastor, said graduation day added up to the answer to a collective question, often repeated over the past nine months: "How do we get to the end of the year with all this?"
The answer, he said, was "people working out of faith, people working out of commitment."
Professors took a 40-percent pay cut this year, and also worked without pay as administrators to help keep the school running. Students accepted fewer course choices. The rating agency, the Middle States Association of Colleges and Schools, agreed to delay pulling the plug until May 31.
Then in March, Upsala saw its last hope dashed. The benefactor, In Tae Kim, who was elected to the board of trustees, was barred by the South Korean government from giving the school $10 million to $15 million over a five-year period. The Korean Government restricts transfers of money to nonprofit institutions outside the country.
A week later, the Essex County Improvement Authority, seeking to recover a $4.2 million loan, began foreclosure proceedings on five college buildings.
The net effect was to leave many in the college community very, very weary. "I'm just empty," said Andrea Tschemplik, a classical philosophy instructor. "I have nothing left."
David Bishop, Upsala's acting director of development, said the college's slide began with plummeting enrollments in the 1980's. An increase in students in the early 1990's was not enough to make up for debt taken on in the previous decade, he said. Then the gathering financial storm caused enrollments to begin to fall again, from 1,000 in 1993 to 650 last September to 420 this spring semester.
At the same time, the school was accepting an increasing proportion of minority students, many of whom needed financial and academic help. "We need learning laboratories to sustain what I suppose one can call the American Experiment," Warren Funk, provost and dean of the faculty, said.
But this mission was a surprise to many who had known the school as a conservative Lutheran liberal arts college.
"Some of the constituents of the college saw the place changing dramatically from the place they recognized," Dr. Funk said.
David Milgrone, an art history professor at Upsala since 1967, said the strain of going from what he calls "a classic hilltop college" to an activist institution involved in local urban issues was a tough task on limited cash.
"It was done more on a hope and a shoestring than any real resources," he said. "The tactically unfortunate error was not to work on an endowment during the years it might have been easy to do."
The ones most immediately hurt by the school's closing are undergraduates who must transfer, often losing credits. Edward Perez, 21, who has just finished his junior year, is transferring to Trenton State University, where he expects to have to repeat at least a semester's worth of courses. "I feel heartbroken inside," he said, adding that he does not expect to find the same sense of camaraderie in Trenton.
Alumni also returned yesterday to see the physical remnants of their memories. One woman came back to see the chapel where she had rehearsed thousands of times with Upsala's respected choir. The piano has already been sold, but not the organ.
John Biel, a history major from the class of 1968, was watching the commencement in an Upsala T-shirt. They are no longer sold.
"My wife says we can have an Upsala Homecoming in our backyard this fall," he said. "But I don't think that will be quite the same."

HEADLINE: Crossing Party Lines on Pollution Bill Clouds Future of Environment Issues

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: KENNEDYVILLE, Md., May 13

 BODY:
Wayne T. Gilchrest knows the tidal patterns around the mouth of the Sassafras River well enough to point out, as he walked along a marshy promontory, where the currents and the shoreline had recently shifted.
As a Republican Congressman, he is also caught up in shifting political tides as the House of Representatives debates a bill that would relax the pollution controls of the Clean Water Act. 
 Unlike most in his party, Mr. Gilchrest opposes the proposed legislation, saying that it would reverse decades of progress in cleaning up the nation's waters. Votes like his are being closely watched as the House nears its final decision on the water pollution bill, one of the country's most important environmental laws and the first to be considered by the new Congress.
Mr. Gilchrest's outspoken opposition to the bill has made him part of an unusual crosscurrent that is showing up in the debate over the measure, which the House is expected to pass as early as Tuesday. Indeed, dozens of moderate Republicans -- including people who, like Mr. Gilchrest, generally vote a fiscally tight, conservative line -- have spoken out against the bill and voted against some of its major provisions.
At the same time, an even greater number of conservative Democrats have swung the other way, and the bill is expected to prevail.
"I don't necessarily have any science background," said Mr. Gilchrest, gazing out over Chesapeake Bay, which thrusts its tentacles deep into his district and holds the region's economy in its watery grasp. "I just think this is a nice place, and I am fighting for it."
Before his election to the House in 1990, he fought in Vietnam with the Marines, taught high school social studies, lived in a wilderness cabin as a volunteer forest ranger and painted houses.
On Monday evening, when the House debates the wetlands provisions of the Clean Water Act, Mr. Gilchrest will be urging changes to the bill's language to conform to the recommendations of the National Academy of Sciences, which issued a report on May 8 sharply critical of its approach to wetlands.
Because wetlands are crucial to water quality in the Chesapeake, the state of Maryland has echoed Mr. Gilchrest's objections to the House bill -- as have the local fishing industry and conservation groups. That makes his opposition relatively painless, as does his refusal to take campaign contributions from political action committees, which form the political muscle of the property developers who want the law changed.
To be sure, the conservative Democrats can argue just as passionately about wetlands as Mr. Gilchrest can. Some who want to end Federal protection over most of the nation's remaining wetlands, as the bill would do, are from states like Louisiana, where the bayous are as cherished as Chesapeake Bay is here.
"The folks who live there are special to me," said Representative Jimmy Hayes, a Democrat of Louisiana who helped write the wetlands provision. "The folks who vote there, and send me to Congress to be their voice, want somebody to say, 'Enough is enough!' and there is a difference between the waterfowl lands that we know and hunt and the lands in individual residential subdivisions that are already, for years before, of no more ecological value, but are very important, as are property rights, to the individuals who now own them."
The bill, after redefining wetlands to eliminate Federal authority over vast areas, would rank what is left according to the land's ecological value, giving the strongest protection only to wetlands of the most valued rank, like those that provide critical habitat for birds and fish.
But to limit development of these most valuable wetlands, the Government would have to compensate landowners for the resulting decline in property values, a proposition that could cost billions of dollars.
It is not the only part of the bill that Mr. Gilchrest opposes. He is also upset about changes that would ease existing requirements for cities to clean up polluted sewage that surges into streams after heavy rains, provisions that would grant waivers for industrial pollution permits, and a proposal to reduce the enforcement of limits on polluted runoff in coastal zones.
In general, the bill would add flexibility to state and local governments in meeting clean water goals, and would grant major concessions long sought by industry and agriculture.
Although many local governments and most major business groups support it, President Clinton has promised to veto it and it is unlikely to pass the Senate unless it is substantially changed.
Because of the different rules of debate in the Senate, where the loss of a few moderate Republicans makes any bill prone to a filibuster, and because it takes two-thirds of each house to override a veto, the crossover votes like those of Mr. Gilchrest and Mr. Hayes are being closely watched as signals of the emerging Congressional balance of power on environmental issues, including the Superfund bill and the Endangered Species Act.
It is not unusual in the 104th Congress -- the first in a generation to be controlled by Republicans -- for conservative Democrats to join with Republicans in voting on environmental or other social issues. But there have been few votes in which so many Republicans have defected as the preliminary votes on the Clean Water Act. Mr. Gilchrest says he believes that at least 30 Republicans have serious concerns with the bill, and that after the debate on coastal issues on Monday and Tuesday it will pass, but not by much.
The voting so far on provisions involving coastal pollution showed how powerfully local economic interests can draw Republican votes toward stronger environmental protections than those in the bill.
On May 10, 61 Republicans, including Mr. Gilchrest, voted to support Sherwood Boehlert, a Republican from upstate New York, on an amendment to strike provisions that would repeal the Coastal Zone Management Act and fold its antipollution requirements into other state programs. Republicans from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut spoke of the vote's importance for protecting the area's beaches and the tourism industry they support. Only three of the region's Republicans voted against the amendment.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

EVEN CALM, RIKERS IS ON THE RAZOR'S EDGE
The inmates on Rikers Island readied for battle last November by scouring for weapons: plexiglass broken from light fixtures, razor blades attached to toothbrushes, metal wrenched from radiators. Thousands refused meals to protest cuts in services. Correction officers went on high alert. The nation's largest jail complex braced for a riot. But the explosion of New York City's nearly 20,000 inmates never happened. This year, slashings and stabbings by inmates have declined sharply as jail officials herald an era of relative peace. A1.
 
HANGING 10 COLD ONES ON LONG ISLAND
Forget Malibu. Forget about Hawaii's renowned Banzai Pipeline. The national surfing circuit has discovered Long Island. This weekend, at what its organizers billed as the first professional surfing contest around New York, dozens of surfers came to Lido Beach, on Long Island's south shore, to try to capture a share of $5,000 in prize money. The problem was that the waves didn't quite follow them. A1.
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
THE LATEST FEUD: GIULIANI-MCCALL
In his 16 months in office, Mayor Giuliani has had no shortage of high-profile skirmishes, whether with the Schools Chancellor, the Public Advocate or with fiscal monitors. But his current rift with the State Comptroller, H. Carl McCall, stands apart for its intensity, drawing some of the harshest criticism by -- and of -- the Mayor. The feud came to a boil after Mr. Giuliani suggested that the city stop financing the section of the State Comptroller's office that monitors and comments on New York City's finances. B3.
 
TALKING TRASH, AND TALKING MONEY
Why is New York City so dirty? That question was posed in this space five weeks ago, in an article with photographs of some of the city's filthiest places. In response, several readers and city officials have tried to explain why New York is not as clean as, say, Paris. As they see it, money is, as usual, the largest part of the problem: People flout rules to economize, and budget cuts impede government's efforts to stop them. That is not to say that nothing can be done. Metro Matters by Joyce Purnick, B3.
 
REGION

AGE AND SANITY CATCH UP WITH A KILLER
Since his mother died a decade ago, only a few people have continued to visit Howard Unruh, the most infamous of the 303 criminally insane patients held in New Jersey mental hospitals. One visitor is his lawyer, James H. Klein, the public defender who has represented him since 1976. Mr. Klein describes his 73-year-old client as a timid man who could be mistaken for someone's grandfather. B5.
 
2 DIE OF PNEUMONIA AT NURSING HOME
Two people have died of pneumonia and 12 others have developed pneumonialike symptoms at the Nathaniel Witherell Home, a municipal nursing home in Greenwich, Conn. Plans for some Mother's Day visits were canceled, and the 35 residents living on the home's fourth floor were quarantined to prevent the further spread of the disease. During the last two weeks, 14 residents on the floor have suffered respiratory illnesses with symptoms including fever and congestion. B6.

HEADLINE: Where Violence Reigns: A special report.;
Even at a Time of Relative Calm, Rikers Stands on the Razor's Edge

BYLINE: By MATTHEW PURDY 

 BODY:
The inmates on Rikers Island readied for battle last November by scouring for weapons: plexiglass broken from light fixtures, razor blades attached to toothbrushes, metal wrenched from radiators. Thousands refused meals to protest cuts in services. Correction officers went on high alert. The nation's largest jail complex braced for a riot.
But the explosion of New York City's nearly 20,000 inmates never happened. The coalition of inmates weakened. The tension dissipated, like a fog lifting. This year, slashings and stabbings by inmates have declined sharply as jail officials herald an era of relative peace and control. 
 Just as last fall's prediction of an uprising was overstated, however, this season's calm masks the daily drumbeat of violence on Rikers. The same volatile ingredients that nearly boiled over six months ago still exist. The number of inmates is rising, the number of officers is declining, and inmate services, including counseling and classes, have been sharply cut. The Giuliani administration's anti-crime drive and its push for austerity are colliding at the jails.
"It's a touch and go situation," said Sal F. Albanese, a member of the City Council's Public Safety Committee. "I'm sure the hierarchy of the department gets up every morning and prays that there's no problems."
The mundane daily catalogue of violent incidents is jarring: slicing fights between inmates who store razor blades in their mouths; vicious, seemingly unprovoked attacks on correction officers by inmates; officers subduing inmates with their fists.
It is a gauge of the gulf between jail and the free world that such violence persists in an atmosphere touted by officials, and some inmates, as dramatically improved.
"Before you couldn't live in jail," said Efaim Torres, a prisoner in a crowded dormitory of metal beds and cold-eyed inmates. "Now you can go to sleep and not worry."
But even with this year's drop in slashings and stabbings -- 251 for the first quarter compared with 324 for the last three months of 1994 -- the level of violence is considerably higher than in 1992, when there were 737 such incidents in the entire year.
This year's trend, said Eric M. Taylor, the jails' top officer, is the result of clamping down hard on the inmates -- more frequent weapons searches, computer analyses for pinpointing violence-prone areas, and added restraints on the most dangerous.
Yet the long-term trend continues. The inmates are more violent and better armed, reflecting the tenor of the street. The jails are increasingly strapped for resources, reflecting the state of the city government.
 
Logging the Violence
Single-Edge Razor: Weapon of Choice
 The internal daily logs of the city's jails read like a script of violence that ebbs and flows between seasons and sometimes between days.
Two weeks ago, in a seemingly typical incident, a correction officer at the James A. Thomas Center was punched by an inmate, "knocked to the floor and rendered unconscious," according to an internal report. When officers tried to strip-search the inmate he attacked again. "Officers exchanged punches with the inmate," the report said. During the fight the inmate "pulled a razor from his pants pocket."
"Inmate refused to comply with the orders to release the weapon," the report said, "so the captain kicked at the inmate's hand until the inmate released the razor blade."
The previous day, three inmates at the Thomas jail had been stabbed by four fellow inmates.
"We're just a reflection of the street," said Ralph McGrane, an assistant chief of the Department of Correction. "People get into fights over basketball and softball games on the street. It's no different here."
In that same jail, officers conducted a search on Jan. 20 and within three and a half hours found 59 razors and 11 homemade knives. Two months later, an inmate directed officers to a telephone where they unscrewed the mouthpiece and found a stash of 40 razors. During February and March, officers recovered 1,436 weapons from all of the city's jails.
"The single-edged razor, that's the 9-millimeter of jail," said Norman Seabrook, a security officer on Rikers Island. "It'll cut you open like a hot knife going through butter. These guys have more weapons than they do on the street."
To catch smuggled weapons, visitors are searched before entering the jails and employees pass through metal detectors, or magnometers. But in October, when Correction Department investigators conducted a surprise check of the staff entrances at nine Rikers jails, they found the magnometers were not on at three of the jails, according to a report on the examination. At six of the jails, investigators noted, the staff members were not accustomed to regular searches. Officers have since been retrained in security procedures, an official said.
Only the inmates have the weapons in the jails, but the aggression on Rikers goes both ways, and beyond.
The department is investigating a March 25 incident in which a Rikers pharmacy assistant, Vincent James, was apparently mistaken for an inmate on the grounds of the island as he arrived for work. He was detained by three officers and a correction captain. In a statement released by Local 1199 of the National Health and Human Services Employees Union, Mr. James said the captain "took her nightstick from her belt and struck me three times perpendicularly directly into my abdomen."
Even after Mr. James identified himself, the statement said, one officer "put a thick glove on his right hand and forcibly held my face with his gloved hand. He pressed my face in a downward position. I felt as though my head was about to be pushed through my chest cavity." Mr. James was eventually released but told by the officers to remain silent about the incident, the statement said.
The logs report daily conflicts between inmates and officers. Often officers respond by punching inmates.
On April 4, an inmate assaulted a correction officer and the officer "responded with several punches to the face and body."
On April 5, two inmates "refused to cease fighting" and when officers "employed body holds, the noted inmates resisted, and staff employed punches terminating the incident."
On April 8, when an officer told an inmate to hang up a telephone "the inmate refused and pushed the officer in the chest area."
"The officer responded with one punch to the facial area" and then put the inmate in a cell with the help of other officers.
Jonathan Chasan, a Legal Aid Society lawyer, who has brought several successful lawsuits charging brutality by officers at Rikers, said officers are supposed to use the least injurious form of restraint necessary, but the guideline is often ignored. He said the department lacks adequate internal monitors on staff actions.
 
A 6th Borough
 A Neighborhood Of Jails
 Rikers Island is like the city's sixth borough, an island between the Bronx and Queens, populated by the accused and the convicted.
The majority are detainees, legally innocent and awaiting trial, some locked up for lack of a few hundred dollars in bail money. There are parole violators serving short sentences, and others are recently convicted, awaiting bus trips to more permanent addresses in upstate prisons. About 15,000 city inmates are at Rikers, with an additional 400 to 500 at borough detention centers. The island is a haphazard collection of 10 jails, each its own neighborhood.
The Rose M. Singer Center, the women's jail, for example, is such a cheery version of incarceration that one wonders if the metal mesh on the windows is meant to keep people in or out. Women march to lunch singing about bettering their lives. Searches for contraband turn up "basically excessive clothing," said the warden, Jannie Poullard.
More places are like the James A. Thomas Center, which looks every inch a jail. Its long, narrow cell blocks with 75 cells apiece stacked three tiers high reverberate with the dull murmurs of idle inmates and the sharp clang of metal gates. On a crisp spring day, the air inside stings from a morning shower of disinfectant.
The inmate traffic across the sloping bridge from Queens to Rikers Island is reaching record proportions -- up 20,000, to 130,000 this year -- even as the ranks of officers, counselors and teachers on the island grows thinner.
With the crush of prisoners and cuts in resources, the Giuliani administration is trying to rally its corps of correction officers.
On a recent tour of the jails, arranged for The New York Times after six months of requests, signs of morale boosters were evident. They range from the substantive -- a new emphasis on cleanliness -- to the symbolic -- Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani now visits injured officers in the hospital -- to the simplistic -- the staff entrance of the Otis Bantum Correctional Center displays the "11 Commandments for an Enthusiastic Team."
Commandment 5: "Speak positively about each other and about your organization at every opportunity." Commandment 11: "Have fun."
 
Budget Squeeze
Economy Moves Anger Inmates
 Just as violence is an immediate threat to inmates and staff, the continual budget squeeze threatens the equilibrium of the jails.
Last fall's food strikes were prompted by reports of planned reductions in classes, counseling service and drug treatment and a change in the nightly "lock in" time to 9 P.M. from 11 P.M., all changes driven by the city's budget crisis. Only the change in the lock-in time, a volatile issue among inmates, was dropped.
For next year, the mayor's budget proposal calls for a $56 million decrease in the department's current $761 million budget and cuts of 749 officers and 228 civilian employees.
No correction officers have been hired since 1991, and the number has fallen by more than 1,000 in the last two years, to 9,529. Meanwhile, annual admission to city jails is rising, 18 percent in the last year.
With the officer-to-inmate ratio diminished, said Stan Israel, the president of the Correction Officers Benevolent Association, inmates, and particularly leaders of jailhouse gangs, have become more powerful. "The price of peace is to let the gangs flourish, and I think one day they are going to pay the price," Mr. Israel said.
The strain is obvious. The city is only able to staff its jails with officers working overtime. The overtime budget last year was $88 million and this year is $89 million, with a planned decline to $72 million next year.
"These are guys who are doing a thankless job," said William Booth, the chairman of the Board of Correction, which oversees the department. "When they have to work double and triple shifts their efficiency goes down. They can't be as alert or effective."
Inmate services have been cut sharply. About 900 drug treatment beds were eliminated by the Giuliani administration in the last year, although some are now being restored, and even larger jails, with more than 1,000 inmates, have just one inmate counselor each.
At the Anna M. Kross jail, inmates in a crowded dormitory said that other than one hour of outdoor recreation early each morning, they are locked in the dorm and the adjacent television room all day, sleeping, listening to cassette players, talking. They said they even eat meals on their beds.
At the George R. Vierno Center, an inmate, Mark Lee, in jail on weapons charges, lives with a group of inmates on a clean, sunny cell block that has regular meetings to discuss substance abuse and self-esteem problems. The inmates set rules for the living area and even vote before switching the television channel. While his cell block is peaceful and productive, he knows much of the jail is not and that idleness can breed unrest.
"We understand that a lot of the cuts are for budget reasons," Mr. Lee said, "but you can't just lock up a lot of people and not give them anything to do."
 
More With Less
Seeking Ways To Cut Expenses
 The correction problem has fallen to Michael P. Jacobson, who was appointed acting commissioner in January, after Anthony J. Schembri resigned during an inquiry into whether he met the city's residency requirement.
It's among the most difficult budgeting tasks in city government. The department has little say over the size of its population. The Police Department controls the flow into jails by making arrests, and those numbers are rising. The courts and district attorneys control the flow out of the jails by disposing of cases.
But to meet its tight budget for next year, the department is counting on the city to cut the average time in jail for accused criminals by 6 days, to 40 days.
Speeding up the city's criminal case system has long been a concern of various agencies, and there has been some success at doing so in recent years. But without significant success soon to reduce the jails' average daily population, the department could face even deeper cuts in staff. Mr. Jacobson fears that could threaten security.
"I don't think we can afford to lose much more uniform staff with the current population," said Mr. Jacobson, who is also the probation commissioner and a former Dinkins administration budget official.
The department is reviewing all of its operations, searching for ways to save money. Paradoxically, that may mean restoring some inmate services, like drug treatment, and hiring several hundred more correction officers as a way of reducing overtime costs, Mr. Jacobson said.
He said the department will use 600 new jail beds, due to open in the summer, as drug treatment centers, replacing two-thirds of the treatment beds cut over the last year. Mr. Jacobson said running the new jail units as drug treatment centers requires fewer officers, and will save money.
Some changes save money and reduce violence. For example, a new telephone system ends inmate calls after six minutes, cutting down on fights over phones and saving a projected $2 million in telephone bills.
In making some changes, the department is likely to face a fight from inmate advocates. Officials want relief from court orders and consent decrees that govern all aspects of jail life, from the schedule for window washing to the time inmates are locked in for the night.
"My concern is they might attempt to undo 15 or 20 years of work aimed at insuring the humane treatment of inmates in city jails," said John Boston, the director of the Legal Aid Society's prisoner rights project. "People who are incarcerated should be treated humanely. If the city says it doesn't have enough money to treat them humanely, they should have less people in jail."
One challenge is expected to come when the department seeks to increase jail space by housing sentenced inmates in a part of an old jail that a judge has already found unfit for detainees awaiting trial.
Another court ruling likely to be challenged requires a full medical exam, including chest X-rays, on any new inmate, even if the inmate is re-entering jail after having left a few days before.
But rules more basic to the operation of the jails are to be reviewed, including staffing levels and other security matters.
Mr. Jacobson said the city is not trying to evade constitutional responsibilities, but it simply wants to operate the jails within its means.
"We're not saying that's it, we're just going to feed them corn dogs," Mr. Jacobson said.
Yet others, like Mr. Booth, the Board of Correction chairman, fear that a new round of cuts and adjustments could revive unrest, threatening what he called Rikers Island's "relative quiet."
"I hope it continues," Mr. Booth said, "but I don't think it will."

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
If You're Talking Trash, It's Usually About Money

BYLINE: By Joyce Purnick 

 BODY:
WHY is New York City so dirty?
That question was posed in this space five weeks ago, in an article with photographs of some of the city's filthiest places. In response, several readers and city officials have tried to explain why New York is not as clean as, say, Paris. 
 As they see it, money is, as usual, the largest part of the problem: people flout rules to economize, and budget cuts impede government's efforts to stop them. "You've got greed and avarice at the forefront," said Emory N. Jackson, president of We Care About New York, a citizens' group that combats graffiti and litter.
That is not to say that nothing can be done. Most of the sites pictured in the article on April 10 have been cleaned up, and so have many of the city's highways.
But a larger problem remains: chronic and illegal dumping. The city picks up residential trash, but businesses are supposed to hire licensed carters to collect their trash. That can be expensive. So many businesses, explained Mr. Jackson, "hire Joe-from-the-neighborhood, who will collect the trash and dump in out-of-the-way places."
Many of those unlicensed, freelance carters, building contractors and illicit automobile "chop shops" routinely turn vacant lots and isolated streets into garbage dumps. Why not take the rubbish to a legal dump? In part because the city charges so much for dumping at its last remaining landfill, Fresh Kills on Staten Island -- $40 per cubic yard.
That is double what most other landfills charge. Fresh Kills is running out of space, so a few years ago the city decided to raise its rate to encourage carters to take their rubbish out of town. For instance, it costs up to $320 to dump the contents of a typical Econoline van at Fresh Kills. So the vacant lot around the corner often becomes a junkyard.
"WE find oil cans, tires, paper, dogs, refrigerators, everything," says Charles Diaz, a supervisor of the city's Special Cleaning Squad. Mr. Diaz and his crew of nine sanitation workers were cleaning out the detritus of illegal dumping last Thursday just north of the Riverside Drive exit of the West Side Highway.
The crew belongs to a squad of 21 special cleaners assigned to the city's worst messes. "We go where the trouble is," Fredric Ciena, a 10-year veteran, said. But the rubbish inevitably returns, and now, because of budget cuts, the squad visits each of the city's 59 sanitation districts just once a year instead of two or three times, as it once did.
Cumulative budget cuts have decimated the district crews that used to supplement the special cleanups. Lucian Chalfen, spokesman for the Sanitation Department, said that in 1987 the city had 8,748 district cleaners. Today it has 2,202.
Still, it is apparent that when the city wants to clean up its act, it can. A return visit to the places that were such a mess five weeks ago proved that. Many had been improved, including an abandoned exit off the Henry Hudson Parkway, still littered but no longer a pile of rusting cars, and some park land behind a ball field between Linden Boulevard and South Conduit Avenue in Queens.
THE Queens site had been piled high with dumped tires. Last Thursday, it still had construction junk on it, but the tires were gone. "Usually, if the media calls attention to something, somehow or other it manages to get cleaned up," said Anne Grossberg, district manager of Community Board 10 in Queens.
A park on the Lower East Side, next to the annex of Seward Park High School, was cleaned out after this reporter telephoned Henry Stern, the Parks Commissioner, in connection with last month's article. He checked it out and ordered it cleared. "It was a total mess," he conceded.
Should it take media attention to clean up a park or a lot or a highway? Elliot G. Sander, the Transportation Commissioner, said that the Giuliani administration's highway cleanup was planned independently of the article in The Times or a subsequent article about highways in The Daily News. "We have a ways to go," Mr. Sander said. "But we're making progress."
Others readily concede that press attention can have a direct bearing on which problem gets attention and when. "There's a kind of rough triage," Mr. Stern said.
Mr. Chalfen asked, "Does it take media attention? It takes some attention. It's a big city."
The tire dump behind the ball field in Queens is a case in point. It's a favorite dump site for contractors and chop shops and is periodically cleaned out. Then the site fills up again because the city doesn't have enough money to patrol it, Ms. Grossberg said.
"When were you there last?" she asked. "Yesterday? Try it again today."

HEADLINE: CHRONICLE

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON 

 BODY:
Sweaty palms and stage fright? No problem. A word-for-word text and a Teleprompter to read it from? No need. Slides on the big screen above the stage? Now the architectural historian VINCENT SCULLY is worried.
Mr. Scully is scheduled to give a speech tonight in the Concert Hall at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington. Not just any speech, but the 24th Jefferson Lecture in the Humanities, the Government's highest recognition of intellectual achievement in the humanities. Mr. Scully, the Sterling Professor of Art History Emeritus at Yale University, was chosen by the National Council on the Humanities, the 26-member advisory board of the National Endowment for the Humanities. He will also receive an honorarium of $10,000. 
 "I don't write speeches," Mr. Scully said. "If I read a talk, it's terrible. And if I tape a talk and try to transcribe it, it sounds like Gertrude Stein on a bad morning. The slides are my notes."
But "they use very hot bulbs" in the projector, he said. The bulbs are so hot that the slides could melt before the audience's eyes, leaving him -- there really is no other word here -- speechless. To prevent that, technicians have mounted them in heat-resistant glass carriers.
Even though it is the Jefferson Lecture, Mr. Scully is not going to talk about Thomas Jefferson, who dabbled in architecture. "I thought the lecture to give here is about contemporary problems," Mr. Scully said.
Still, Jefferson's Virginia will figure in Mr. Scully's talk. He has slides of urban renewal in Roanoke, Va. A reporter for The Roanoke Times and World News sent him articles describing how urban renewal had uprooted Roanoke's black residents. "In the 50's and 60's, when architects and planners and politicians did this, we didn't know what a neighborhood was," Mr. Scully said. "It's amazing how much anthropology had been done in the South Seas, and yet we didn't know what happens when inner-city communities are destroyed."

HEADLINE: INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY;
Study Says Japan's Executives Are Behind in Computing

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
Only a few years ago, Japan was supposedly ready to leap past the United States as a technological superpower. That assumption now appears exaggerated, and a new study provides a possible explanation: Many of Japan's executives are technological illiterates.
Japanese executives are less likely than their American counterparts to use a computer, and they are less satisfied with the results they get from information technology, according to the study by the Fujitsu Research Institute in Tokyo and Fuld & Company in Cambridge, Mass. 
 The study, "Information Technology's Role: A U.S.-Japan Competitiveness Gap," was released today. Its results are based on questionnaires answered last fall by 373 senior executives at large companies in Japan and the United States.
Japanese companies, of course, are world leaders in the production of consumer electronics and many technologically advanced components for the computer industry, like color screens for notebook computers.
"But what really surprised me was the gap between what the Japanese make and what Japanese executives use," said Leonard Fuld, president of Fuld & Company, a research firm. "There seems to be technological illiteracy in the executive suites in Japan."
While 64 percent of the American executives said they must use computers in their jobs, only 8 percent of the Japanese executives replied that computer use was essential for them.
"American executives are lugging laptop computers with them wherever they go," Mr. Fuld noted. "Japanese executives, by and large, do not."
American executives were also more likely than Japanese executives to be directly involved in the setup and management of information systems in their companies. Sixty-eight percent of the Americans said they were involved in the planning and use of information technology in their businesses, compared with 36 percent of the Japanese.
In Japan, Mr. Fuld said, information technology seems to be regarded as "a glorified bookkeeping tool." By contrast, he said, in American companies the technology is used much more to gather, analyze and distribute marketing information and as an aid in making management decisions.
Perhaps the most debatable aspect of the Fujitsu-Fuld study is its assumption that the resistance among Japanese executives to using new technology has much to do with changes in competitiveness. Economists say the attitudes of Japanese managers toward technology have changed little in recent years, but the yen has strengthened sharply, making Japanese exports more costly abroad.

HEADLINE: Apple Offering Newton Rebates

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: CUPERTINO, Calif., May 14

 BODY:
Apple Computer Inc. is offering rebates of as much as $100 to buyers of its miniature computer, the Newton Messagepad.
The rebates on the hand-held computers, which sell for about $600, run through July 31. Customers who buy just the Messagepad are eligible for a $50 rebate. Those who buy extra storage, a fax modem or other "qualified" accessories can get a $100 rebate, the company said. 
 The company said it hoped to increase sales of the latest version of its paperback-sized computer, which was introduced on Jan. 27. The machines store telephone numbers, appointment calendars and notes.
Last week, the market researcher Dataquest Inc. reported that Apple sold about 60,000 Newtons in 1994, giving it a 15 percent share of the market for hand-held computers. The Hewlett-Packard Company leads the market for hand-held computers with a 27 percent share, Dataquest said.

HEADLINE: Essay;
The G.O.P. Delivers

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Republicans may play a mean, low-down political trick on Democrats still railing at proposals to stem the tide of red ink: to put the budget submitted to Congress a few months ago by President Clinton up for a vote.
You may remember his punt-and-pray, you-go-first budget -- not only was it "dead on arrival"; it was dead before sending. 
 That was because Clinton made few choices needed to slow the growth of the deficit. Instead, he projected another trillion dollars in debt over the next five years (even assuming steady growth and low interest rates, which won't happen if such Government borrowing continues apace).
Everyone knew the Clinton budget was not to be taken seriously; it was his way of saying "you won the election; you balance the budget." Rarely do Presidents so completely abdicate their economic responsibility. He changed "the President proposes, the Congress disposes" to "the Congress proposes and disposes while the President treads water."
However, to ingratiate himself with the voters who rejected his party, he included a me-too tax cut in that budget. That compounded his mistake.
Now we are engaged in a great budgetary war. Contrary to Clinton's expectations, the feisty G.O.P. House and the sobersided G.O.P. Senate met his challenge and came up with what Democrats considered impossible: seven years to budget balance. Nor do the G.O.P. proposals "cut" actual spending; they follow the precept of the Civil War general to a gunner to "elevate them sights a little lower."
But it is undoubtedly a Mort Sahl budget. ("Is there anybody I haven't offended?") The lobbies of geezers and greens, of veterans and farmers, of root casuists at Justice and corporate welfare queens of Commerce are stunned.
You can feel the moral high ground move. Having smugly asked "what's your specific alternative?" -- and having received a serious answer -- Democrats now find themselves embarrassed at being asked the same question.
All they have in the way of an answer is the old Clinton budget, which won't do. If Bob Dole and Newt Gingrich bring the coagulated Pablum of that Panetta-Rivlin compromise to a vote, Congressional Democrats will be forced to desert Clinton, lest they go on record as deficit doves.
That's why you can sense a Democratic fallback position in preparation. Farewell to Clinton's long-promised "middle-class tax cut," now seen by Congressional Democrats as a wrongheaded response to the electoral debacle.
Those unreturned billions will be proposed to be sprinkled over endangered liberal programs -- national service's subsidized volunteers, public broadcasting, education under Federal standards, the arts, another veterans' hospital, etc. -- to shore up core constituencies and show Democrats resisting this year's sanhedrin of skinflints.
This means the debate is no longer between budget balancers and the defenders of debt. It is now between balancers including a tax cut (with spending restraints in the near years) and balancers without a tax cut (with a slowing of spending back-end-loaded). That's a huge shift in argument, as borrowing is no longer seen as a gift to our old but as a theft from our young.
The best way to redirect our nation is with the stronger Government spending restraint plus tax rate reduction; as Napoleon advised a temporizing general, "If you are going to take Vienna, take Vienna." However, with the veto power still in Democratic hands, conservatives may have to settle for spending restraint first, tax cuts later -- in effect, taking the suburbs now and the citadel in 1997.
What is the immediate political effect of this rightward shift in the debate?
It means Perot voters no longer need a third party to express their disgust with the unwillingness of major parties to come to grips with the deficit. Of five United-we-standers, three are likely to go Republican, one Democratic, one home.
Smart Democrats understand this, which is why Bill Clinton keeps taking credit for having reduced the deficit last year. It is why Democrats are now abandoning the "deficit as percentage of G.N.P." weaseling and are scrambling to get aboard the anti-deficit bandwagon. And it is why Republicans are so eager to make certain you know the impetus for budget balance comes from them.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: The Brownstone Storytellers;
A Colony of Writers Is Growing in Park Slope

BYLINE: By JANNY SCOTT 

 BODY:
Colin Harrison, author and editor, lives with his wife, Kathryn Harrison, novelist, in a brownstone a block from Thomas Boyle, writer of thrillers, who lives in a brownstone a block from Luc Sante, writer, and his wife, Melissa Holbrook Pierson, the same.
Mary Morris, novelist and travel writer, lives with her husband, Larry O'Connor, editor and writer, in a brownstone across the street from Penny Kaganoff, senior editor, not far from Paul Auster, novelist, and his wife, Siri Hustvedt, ditto. 
 Ms. Kaganoff found her dry cleaner in Park Slope through Mr. Harrison's last book. Jennie Fields's block in Park Slope is the hero of her new novel. Gail Hochman, literary agent, says one in every 20 book proposals she is sent these days hails from the same place: Her neighborhood, Park Slope. "I think I'm the only person in Park Slope who hasn't published a novel with a major publishing house," mused David Ravel, who, as manager of the Community Bookstore on Seventh Avenue in the heart of "the Slope," is in a position to know.
Park Slope, the tidy trapezoid that sweeps gently northwestward from the westernmost reaches of Prospect Park, is becoming New York's Left Bank, home to a conflux of writers, editors, publishers and literary types.
Most have rolled in over the past 15 years, with the pace seeming to pick up over the last five. Many are emigres from Manhattan's Upper West Side, lured by affordable brownstones, space for families, wisteria in spring.
They say they have found there the kind of neighborhood that Manhattan no longer seems to offer -- unpretentious, but with great physical charm, a true community, cohesive but tolerant, and just an F train ride away.
For a few, their adoptive home has also become their Muse. Park Slope is surfacing now in their books -- as a symbol of domesticity or of continuity, a kind of urban idyll, perhaps a celebration of life.
"I find the Slope to be heart-breakingly beautiful," said Mr. Harrison, who set much of his last novel, "Bodies Electric" (Crown, 1993), there. "If you walk along some of the streets at dusk, when kids are out on the stoops and people are walking home, there's a marvelous sense of civilization.
"Life feels organized and perceptible again in an otherwise chaotic, information-rotted world. People love that," he said. "And I think writers in particular are very sensitive to the chaos of the world. It's their job to order it. Maybe being in the Slope is somehow a balm."
Like much of Brooklyn, Park Slope has inspired writers before. Pete Hamill grew up there in the 1940's, but it was a different place -- a place he described in "A Drinking Life" (Back Bay/Little, Brown, 1994) as one of Irish bars and steel-wheeled trolleys squealing along Seventh Avenue into the night.
The roots of the current reincarnation reach back to the late 1960's, when Manhattan real-estate prices seemed to shoot through the roof. Writers and artists ventured into Brooklyn, stumbled upon Park Slope and discovered a mother lode of Victorian brownstones, available and cheap.
The houses had been built for prosperous members of the upper bourgeoisie. Some had been converted into rooming houses when the neighborhood declined with suburban flight, but many had remained in the same family for generations -- one of the largest, best-preserved, Victorian-row-house neighborhoods in the city.
They appealed especially to younger people and writers, for whom "the suburbs seemed to hold a special horror," Mr. Hamill wrote in a magazine article in the early 1970's. Houses began selling for as little as $14,000. Prices have risen steadily -- to $40,000, then $200,0000, and now, $450,000 and above.
"The New People, as they are called, saw Brooklyn fresh," Mr. Hamill wrote back then, and the observation seems no less true today. "They saw Brooklyn in a way that we had not seen it when we were young, and they saw it in a way that Brooklyn had not seen itself, perhaps . . . "
By the late 1970's, hardware stores were selling polyurethane varnish by the drum. When the neighborhood's second bookstore opened in 1985, publishing industry people remember how it shrewdly began placing home-renovation books so they could be seen through the front window.
"Suddenly, every time I walked out on the street I would see another face from a company where I was working," said Barbara Grossman, senior vice president and publisher of Viking, a 15-year resident. "Suddenly, it was like the Hamptons in Brooklyn."
Now Mary Morris bumps into Donald Antrim, who wrote "Elect Mr. Robinson for a Better World" (Viking, 1993), under the ceiling fans at Ozzie's, one of the neighborhood's many coffeehouses. Or she runs into Ian Frazier, whose most recent book is "Family" (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, 1994), in the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.
Ann Rittenberg, a literary agent, counts seven writers on her block, as well as two agents and "something like 40 kids under age 7." Kathryn Cullen-DuPont, a poet who also writes about women's history, met her agent at a Parent-Teacher Association gathering because their daughters were best friends.
When the two women ended up writing a book together, "Women's Suffrage in America: An Eyewitness History" (Facts on File, 1992), they dedicated it to their daughters, who had served as messengers, carting drafts and notes to and from school in their backpacks, swapping them at lunch.
Their school, the Berkeley Carroll School, has so many students with writer parents that its annual holiday book fair to raise money for its library has turned into a miniature Frankfurt Book Fair, with more than a dozen well-known parent authors lined up at tables signing their books.
And when one parent's novel, "Crossing Brooklyn Ferry," by Jennie Fields, was recently being considered for publication, two other parents at Berkeley Carroll, a private school, were doing the considering: Michelle Sidrane, president and publisher of the Crown Publishing Group, and Ms. Grossman of Viking.
There are now four bookstores in a 15-block stretch of Seventh Avenue in the Slope. The Community Bookstore holds standing-room-only readings at a rate of two or three a month. Even the stoop sales are remarkably literate. "I've seen things like bound galleys," said Mr. Sante, the writer.
Writers' reasons for choosing Park Slope seem to be a mix of economic, aesthetic and intellectual. They find it affordable, beautiful and historically interesting. They also find it user friendly for people who work at home.
A spare room for a studio is not out of the question. The Brooklyn Public Library and the Brooklyn Museum are a short walk away. The coffeehouses don't mind campers with portable computers. And streets are alive during the day.
Asked to describe why they live there, people talk about their houses and their gardens and walking their children to school. They mention dogwood trees, original door knobs, barbecues, the woodpecker in the maple tree out front.
Some resisted at first. When the moving van pulled up outside Ms. Morris's Manhattan apartment, she told her husband it was dirty, send it away. It seemed inconceivable, she now says, to leave behind Manhattan's energy and life.
It took her two years to come to love living in Park Slope. She dates her change of heart to a snowstorm in late 1991. The cash machines had broken, she had dinner guests coming and so she went with her checkbook from store to store.
"I had to get fish, cheese, wine, dessert, whatever," she remembered. "Nobody would take my check. They said, 'What do you want? No problem. When you come back, you pay us.' "
What Ms. Morris appreciates most now is the mix of bucolic and urban: She can descend into the subway and roam the city, then spend hours in the botanic garden and "walk quietly home to check my tomato plants."
"I can be contemplative and not feel that I'm off in the country, and then feel that I can go out in the world," she said. "That blend is very satisfactory for a writer. Because you need that inner quiet."
William Malloy and his wife, Claire Zion, both publishing executives, were sharing a Manhattan tenement with a kitchen shower back in 1984 when a publishing friend of Ms. Zion's vacated an apartment in Park Slope.
Mr. Malloy's sole experience with Brooklyn had been a jaunt over the Brooklyn Bridge, just to say he had done it. But the couple went out to see the apartment anyway, one spring day when the cherry trees were in bloom.
"We walked up from Ninth Street to Garfield Place," said Mr. Malloy, now editor in chief for The Mysterious Press. "I remember looking around with my jaw hanging slack and saying, 'How come I didn't know about this?' "
They took the apartment, five times the size of their last one. It had a porcelain bathtub, with clawed feet, the size of a small pool. Mr. Malloy took to spending two hours every Saturday and Sunday wallowing with a book.
In recent years, Park Slope has turned up increasingly in people's writing -- in Thomas Boyle's trilogy of Brooklyn-based thrillers, in Ms. Morris's short stories, in works by Paul Auster, Richard Cohen and Ms. Fields.
In Mr. Boyle's books, gentrification is a backdrop. One character is a serial killer of mixed race who was driven crazy by a childhood spent fleeing from one neighborhood to the next each time writers moved in.
In Ms. Morris's stories, Park Slope symbolizes what she called in an interview "domesticity and a certain tedium of domestic life." Among other things, she has explored the ambivalent bonds between neighbors.
Ms. Fields's novel, coming out next spring, is about two people who fall in love in adjoining brownstones. It is set on her block on Eighth Street, the history of which has captured her imagination ever since she moved in.
Like Colin Harrison, Ms. Fields chose a title that echoes Walt Whitman. In his poem, "Crossing Brooklyn Ferry," Mr. Whitman pondered the ebb and flow of people between Manhattan and Brooklyn over decades and decades of time.
"To me, those brownstones represent the flow of life," Ms. Fields said in an interview. "I think it's really appealing for a writer to see that. It's a celebration of life, that life goes on, no matter what, through 100 years."
Park Slope is even the setting of a movie, "Smoke," due out next month. It was shot in and around the neighborhood and is based on a story by Mr. Auster, who describes the film as "an homage to this neighborhood."
"I think it celebrates a sense of community and a sense of tolerance," said Mr. Auster, who moved to Park Slope in the late 1980's. "And also the wonderful verbal gifts of everybody around me."

HEADLINE: Trouble for Teaching Hospitals

 BODY:
The quality of American health care -- unarguably the best in the world -- is under siege. Republicans released budget plans last week that would cut subsidies to teaching hospitals that train doctors and perform clinical research. Meanwhile, the private market, whose reform Congress bungled last year, has been doing the same. The two-pronged assault is alarming.
American physicians provide innovative, technically advanced care whose quality can be traced in part to generous subsidies for basic research that Congress has provided through the National Institutes for Health. The N.I.H. estimates that the Senate budget plan could reduce these subsidies for non-AIDS research over the next seven years by as much as 25 percent; the cut is deeper if inflation is taken into account. 
 The proposed N.I.H. cuts are easily identified and will be subject to public scrutiny. Two other threats are harder to spot.
The Federal Government, when reimbursing hospitals for treating Medicare patients, pays an average of 30 percent extra if treatment is provided in a teaching hospital. The extra payments cover costs associated with training doctors and translating basic research into clinical practice -- to develop, for example, innovative surgical procedures or drug therapies. Under the G.O.P. budgets, these payments could fall by between 30 and 60 percent.
The other dagger aimed at teaching hospitals comes from the private sector. Private insurers have also paid more for patients treated in teaching hospitals. That practice is ending. Wielding new-found market power, health maintenance organizations and other managed-care groups are driving down hospital rates. They refuse to pay for training or research that does not directly benefit their enrollees. Private markets will not pay for public goods, like research, that will eventually benefit everyone but not necessarily anyone in particular.
The assault on training and clinical research is especially grave for New York City, whose teaching hospitals train about 15 percent of the nation's medical residents. When the Democrats controlled Congress, and Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York was chairman of the powerful Finance Committee, these teaching hospitals were well protected. But New York's Republican Senator, Alfonse D'Amato, is chairman of an unrelated committee.
The solution to the problem is surely not to stymie the growth of competitive managed-care plans. They remain the best way to insure high-quality, affordable care. But Congress does need to attend to the special needs of teaching hospitals, a national resource worth preserving.
One way is to impose a tax on health insurance premiums, and direct the money to training and research programs. This would require the G.O.P. to admit that not every tax is evil. A less costly approach might be to subsidize doctors-in-training directly. Congress could fund N.I.H. to distribute fellowships to medical school graduates to help pay for their residency programs. Congress could also reduce subsidies for low-priority clinical research by requiring hospitals to submit proposals to the N.I.H. for funding on a competitive basis.
The Republicans are right that teaching hospitals are riddled with waste and turn out the wrong mix of doctors -- too many specialists and too few primary care doctors. Many such hospitals, in New York and elsewhere, ought to shrink, if not close. But these truths do not justify a mindless assault that threatens to bury the programs that turn out the best-trained physicians in the world.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
