HEADLINE: INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY: Information by the Gallon;
As Desktop Video Approaches, Is the Office Ready?

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
On Chase Manhattan Bank's new trading floor in Manhattan, the desk of Paul G. Farrell, managing director of foreign exchange trading, is an information arsenal.
There's a two-foot-wide telephone console; a microphone and video camera for communicating with other traders on the vast floor, and an array of five video monitors for, among many other things, Chase's interoffice E-mail, real-time prices on dozens of currencies, text from four news wires and the cable television channels CNBC and Cable News Network. 
 It isn't enough.
Mr. Farrell and his lieutenants recently began testing a new video service from Reuters that delivers speeches, news conferences and other potentially market-moving events directly to their computer monitors. Rather than waiting for the news services to tap out the first headlines, Mr. Farrell reasons, his traders will be able to interpret events as they unfold. And without even taking their eyes off their trading screens, Mr. Farrell hopes, his currency team can respond to world developments before its competitors have time to react.
"In this business, time is money," Mr. Farrell said one recent trading day, as the screens flickered around him. "It always has been."
And that is precisely the premise behind Reuters Financial Television and a handful of other new video services promising to turn the computer screens of Wall Street into picture windows on the world. The services come not only from financial specialists like Reuters, Bloomberg Financial Markets and Dow Jones, but also from mass-market generalists like the CNN network of Turner Broadcasting System and NBC.
For Mr. Farrell and his counterparts at other financial houses, only time and testing will tell whether these new services -- roughly the video equivalents of business news wires -- actually pay off.
Some skeptical managers argue that turning a portion of the computer screen into a television set, even for specialized financial information, will be a time-wasting distraction. And, others wonder, even if the services bring incremental benefits, will they justify prices that can run hundreds of dollars a month per desktop?
Mr. Farrell, for whom millions of dollars can ride on every uptick or downtick of the currency market, is an eager member of this new television audience. "The more information the better," he said.
Right now, most of these offerings do little more than transmit live video feeds because of technical limitations, whether within the services themselves or in the customers' office computer networks. But the idea is to enable users eventually to select video business reports from a menu, similar to the way that text-based news wires now offer articles from data bases that often have several months or more of archival material.
Such services represent the news industry's most aggressive test yet of a basic thesis of the so-called interactive media: that people want the same control over television news that they have come to enjoy for all the information streaming into their computers.
The media companies pursuing this business sense that the wealthy news hounds of the financial world may represent the first big market for customized video news. But for now, the services are so new, and the customers still so few, the market remains largely theoretical.
"As in any news service, we don't expect major penetration until years down the road," said Thomas S. Rogers, executive vice president in charge of business development at NBC, which has two entries in the field: NBC Professional and PFN/ First Call.
Neither of the NBC services has more than a handful of large corporate customers yet. But since NBC's desktop video operation is primarily a repackaging of financially relevant news that has been gathered by NBC's broadcast affiliates, the CNBC cable channel and NBC's new entertainment and news networks in Asia and Europe, Mr. Rogers added, the operating costs are bearable now and can only get more so.
 "It's the same cost to reach the first subscriber as to reach the one- millionth subscriber," he said.
Video news is nothing new to financial firms, of course. Ever since CNN started broadcasting world crises live in the early 1980's, television sets have been as much a staple of trading floors as pizza and off-color jokes. Most of the sets are now tuned to either CNN or to CNBC, acable business-and-finance channel.
But typically, unless there is a big story, the sound is turned down and the picture is ignored. The new desktop video services take a more direct approach.
In October, CNN teamed up with the Intel Corporation to offer a version of its cable news programming for delivery to personal computers. Subscribers can watch CNN in a window in a corner of their monitor's screen.
Or they can program their computers to capture and store a half-hour of "CNN Headline News," and selectively view it later by calling up a menu of the individual news stories and use the mouse to click on the headlines of the items they want to view.
In contrast, Dow Jones, NBC and Reuters are hoping eventually to reinvent video news as a computer software tool as valuable to the financial community as spreadsheets and stock quotes.
The three companies offer coverage of specific events selected for their presumed relevance to the financial community, like Congressional testimony by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan. These and other potentially market-moving events are broadcast live, while news conferences or reports of lesser import might be tape-delayed. Between events, the screen is blank.
But Dow Jones, Reuters and NBC Desktop Video are all still feeling their way, technologically. So far, only NBC gives customers access to any sort of archive.
 A "server" computer furnished by NBC at each site can store all the items broadcast in the most recent two weeks. Because the capacity of most corporate computer networks is already overextended, however, subscribers do not see full-motion video when they search this archive. Instead, they are able only to listen to the stories, which are accompanied by still pictures.
That same limited story-and-picture feature has been available for more than a year, along with some of the text-based news articles distributed by Bloomberg Financial Markets, the fast-growing data and news company that provides a wide variety of information services to the financial community.
Bloomberg is spending $250 million to upgrade all 48,000 of its subscribers' specially designed Bloomberg computer terminals to receive Bloomberg Information Television, a satellite-delivered video news channel that started 10 months ago and is vying to win over viewers of CNN and CNBC.
Michael Bloomberg, founder and chief executive of the company, contends that the costs of video production favor his company's general-news approach to the financial world, with conventional text-based services still being the most efficient way to cover events of interest to a relatively narrow audience.
Given the expense of fielding camera crews, "the economics are such that you can't afford to do many stories," Mr. Bloomberg said. As a result, he predicts, the narrow-focus news-gathering operations like Dow Jones and NBC will end up sending their cameras where they know there will be news -- the very events already being widely covered, he added.
But NBC and Dow Jones insist that they feature exclusive programming that their subscribers cannot get elsewhere. NBC said it had more than 270 exclusive interviews in the last month -- although some of these, like the first interview in the United States with the visiting President of Brazil, Fernando Henrique Cardoso, may have had scant market-moving impact.
Still, when there is news being made, customers say they like the fact that they can view speeches and events themselves, without having to depend on journalists' interpretations.
Referring to "luminaries" like Mr. Greenspan, Glenn Havlicek, a managing director in the domestic treasury division of Chemical Bank, said: "As financial luminaries become more like movie stars, we are getting more and more sound bites. A lot of it is out of context, so when we can see it ourselves it gives us a fuller and fairer view of what someone had to say." Chemical Bank is trying out the services of both Reuters and NBC.
 Moreover, money managers at firms outside big cities say the services can save them time and money. "We're a small organization," said Paul Secord, equity portfolio manager at Independent Capital Management in Horsham, Pa., an hour outside Philadelphia.
"We don't have the luxury of having people to cover every investment conference," said Mr. Secord, who subscribes to PFN/First Call, an NBC desktop service that concentrates on live and taped coverage of industry conferences, exclusive interviews with chief executives and company announcements.
But as much as they say they like the new services, few customers who were interviewed were able to cite specific examples of how any of these had played a significant role in a decision to buy or sell.
And while Charles Schwab & Company, the San Francisco-based discount brokerage firm, is considering outfitting 350 of its top brokers with NBC Professional, so they will be on top of the news when their clients call, executives at other investment companies see the services as a potential distraction.
At Legg Mason Inc., a regional brokerage firm in Baltimore, the Dow Jones video service is available on only three computers in the firm's research department. "I think there would be a natural reluctance from management to put the service on each broker's desk," said Richard Cripps, Legg Mason's director of equity marketing. "They want them on the phone. They don't want them watching TV."

A chart in Business Day on Monday with an article about the use of desktop video services by traders at financial houses referred incorrectly to the service offered by Dow Jones & Company. It is the Dow Jones Investor Network, not the Dow Jones Information Network.

Chart: "Coming Soon to a Desktop Near Yours"
 Bringing live video to the desktop is the latest rage among media companies. The five services currently available take distinctive approaches.
 Reuters Financial Television concentrates on foreign exchange trading, closely following the movements of finance ministers and central bankers in 13 countries, mostly in Europe.
The Dow Jones Information Network and NBC's PFN/First Call focus more on industry conferences, exclusive interviews with chief executives and company announcements. A second NBC service, called NBC Professional, mostly covers breaking news.
NBC is also offering access to an archive containing all the stories broadcast by its two services in the previous two weeks. The stories are stored on a computer that "serves" them to each desktop computer on command. But because the capacity of most corporate computer networks is already stretched thin, subscribers do not see full-motion video. Instead, they are only able to listen to the stories, which are accompanied by a still image.
Bloomberg terminals are already equipped with a similar function, and later this year Dow Jones is planning to introduce an interactive service that will incorporate its TV service. Reuters is still in the development stage. LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN

HEADLINE: Menem's Victory in Argentina Seen as Endorsement of Free Market

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, May 15

 BODY:
The overwhelming victory of President Carlos Saul Menem in elections on Sunday was seen today as an endorsement of the free-market reforms that have slowed inflation andled to economic growth in Argentina. But it raised questions about the balance of power in this young democracy.
Most of the reaction to Mr. Menem's re-election was positive, particularly among economists, investors and foreign diplomats. Many saw his substantial margin of victory as a ringing endorsement for his economic agenda, which has been to restructure Argentina's economy through privatization and an ironclad currency exchange system that links the peso to the dollar. 
 With more than 90 percent of the vote counted, Mr. Menem, a Peronist, was elected to four more years in office with 49.7 percent of the vote, compared with 29.5 percent for Senator Jose Bordon of the center-left Frepaso coalition, the national election service announced today. Mr. Menem needed at least 45 percent to avoid a runoff.
The century-old Radical Party, which had been the Peronists' main rival until a recent surge of support for Mr. Bordon's coalition, had its worst showing ever, at 17 percent.
Some political analysts expressed concern that Mr. Menem's victory, and his party's victory in both houses of Congress, might give the Peronists too much power in a country that returned to democracy only 12 years ago after a brutal military dictatorship. But others said that the strong showing by Mr. Bordon's coalition, which was formed several months ago by defectors from the Peronists, was a growing counterbalance to Mr. Menem's power.
Mr. Bordon, who won a majority of the votes in Buenos Aires, the capital, is widely expected to be a viable contender for the 1999 presidential elections.
A number of brokers and bankers said that based on their conversations with large and small investors, local and foreign, Mr. Menem's re-election had increased their confidence in Argentina and was likely to bring a return of the foreign capital that fled the country after the Mexican peso's devaluation in December.
"There was a big collective sigh of relief by Argentines and foreign businessmen that there will be a continuity of the economic policies," said the United States Ambassador, James Cheek. "The businessmen have to be really pleased with this outcome, even though everybody acknowledges that the country still has to come through the crisis of confidence."
Larry Goodman, an economist for Salomon Brothers, a New York investment bank, said that Argentina's economic indicators remained strong and that with the return of foreign investment, the economy should increase at about 3 percent this year, although many economists and analysts had earlier predicted zero growth.
The victory of Mr. Menem's Peronist party in Congress appeared to give him a legislative mandate to continue his reforms. The Peronists gained a majority of seats in the Chamber of Deputies, where they had been a few votes short of a majority, and maintained their leadership in the upper house.
But some political analysts also expressed concern about the one-party control. Throughout his first term, Mr. Menem was criticized for his control of the judiciary, through his appointment of judges, and of his influence with the Congress.
"This drive toward supremacy by Menem is detrimental in a modern democracy because it weakens the system of parties, as it places men above institutions," said Natalio Botana, a political scientist at the Di Tella Institute.
The showing by Mr. Bordon's coalition was considered an encouraging sign, though. The coalition, which is composed of disaffected Peronists, Socialists and Christian Democrats, ran on a platform that promised to halt corruption, which was widespread in Mr. Menem's administration, and to create jobs in the face of unemployment of 12.2 percent.
"The people liked Menem's policies and Bordon's style of governance, but unfortunately they could only vote for one," said Felipe Noguera, a political analyst for Mora y Araujo, Noguera and Associates, a polling concern.
"But Bordon has been elected in some sense, although not to any real post -- but to speak out on the things that he stood for in the campaign."

HEADLINE: The Religious Right Readies Agenda for Second 100 Days

BYLINE: By GUSTAV NIEBUHR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 14

 BODY:
For months, religious conservatives watched, and many applauded, as the new Republican majority in Congress wielded its political muscle against Government spending. Now, they are urging those same Republicans to take up moral issues as well and push for restricting access to abortion, reducing Federal influence in education and, most important, creating a Constitutional protection for student-led school prayer.
"It's not that we're showing up, saying, 'O.K., guys, it's our turn,' " said the Rev. Louis P. Sheldon, chairman of the Traditional Values Coalition, an organization based in Anaheim, Calif., that says it represents 31,000 churches nationwide. After all, he said, the organization has supported spending cuts on the ground that national financial and spiritual stability are linked. 
 But in the second 100 days, Mr. Sheldon said, he expects to see moral issues on Congress's agenda. "There's a lot of social legislation we're going to work on and support, but our main thrust is going to be the Religious Equality Amendment," he said.
Indeed, some form of constitutional protection for student-led school prayer seems to be at or near the top of just about every agenda among religious conservatives.
The call for such an amendment will be featured in the Contract With the American Family that the Christian Coalition is scheduled to unveil at a news conference on Capitol Hill on Wednesday. The 10-point document will also call for turning over much of the Department of Education's budget to local schools, imposing new restrictions on abortion and making Federal prisoners pay restitution to victims of their crimes, said Ralph Reed, executive director of the Christian Coalition, the nation's largest group of religious conservatives, with 1.5 million members.
The news conference will start a new phase in the Republican-led Congress, one that some analysts say is fraught with peril for the Republican Party. The relative harmony of the first 100 days reflected, in part, the understanding that the more divisive social issues, like abortion and prayer in schools, would be deferred. Now, with that cease-fire over, conservative Christians are eager to move forward.
But the Republican Party has a painful history on this agenda. Abortion has long divided the party between conservative Christians and less ideological members; the issue has bubbled up in state races and in struggles over the party's platform, which since the Reagan ascendancy has called for a constitutional amendment to outlaw abortion.
Moreover, the 1992 party convention, with explicit appeals to traditional values, was considered by many analysts to have backfired. A speech by the conservative commentator Patrick J. Buchanan, declaring that a "religious and cultural war" had begun, was widely denounced as polarizing and counterproductive to a party whose electoral fortunes depend on casting a wide net.
Already, the backlash to this newest offensive by conservative Christians has begun.
An alliance of some 50 religious, civil liberties and educational organizations has denounced the proposed Religious Equality Amendment as a breach of the principle of separation of church and state. The Coalition to Preserve Religious Liberty, as the alliance is called, is lobbying Congress and trying to rally popular opposition to the proposal, said its co-chairman, J. Brent Walker, who is also general counsel for the Baptist Joint Committee on Public Affairs.
The American Civil Liberties Union today sent a letter to President Clinton, Congress and the 50 governors in which it called the Christian Coalition's plans an assault on constitutional freedoms.
"Religious expression in public schools is already protected by the First Amendment," said Ira Glasser, executive director of the A.C.L.U. "The Christian Coalition's real agenda is to impose its own religious beliefs and ceremonies on all students."
The Contract With the American Family follows in title and form the House Republicans' Contract With America, the political manifesto introduced in the election campaign last fall and taken up by the new Congress, and which the Christian Coalition supported.
"The economic and the cultural issues are a seamless web," Mr. Reed said. "And part of our broad agenda of limiting government is to turn power back to parents and families and local schools."
If the coalition stands in a position to make such recommendations, it is because religious conservatives claim credit for helping transform Congress in a conservative Republican direction. "In November, evangelicals turned out in record numbers," said James Dobson, president of Focus on the Family, a conservative Christian organization with a daily nationwide radio broadcast on social issues.
An exit poll survey conducted by Mitofsky International of 5,200 voters in that election found that just over 20 percent of voters identified themselves as Protestants who were evangelicals or born-again Christians. And 3 out of 4 of those Protestants reported voting for Republicans, said John Green, a political science professor at the University of Akron and director of its Ray Bliss Institute, a research center.
"It was the largest single voting bloc among Republican voters," said Professor Green, an expert on voting patterns among religious groups. "It represents just about a third of the Republican vote."
With this political potency in mind, religious conservatives have watched Republican decisions with a keen and critical eye. Dr. Dobson said he had been disturbed when Republican leaders chose Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey to deliver the party's response to President Clinton's State of the Union Message in January. Given her support of abortion rights, he said, Governor Whitman represented the "antithesis" of what religious conservatives value.
But Dr. Dobson said he had since met with Speaker Newt Gingrich and come away with assurances that Congress would soon begin to address moral concerns. "He did say that by the end of the second 100 days, we'd be more pleased with the outcome in respect to family values than we have been in the past," Dr. Dobson said.
As Speaker, Mr. Gingrich has not specifically endorsed a school prayer amendment. Rather, he has spoken in general terms about "religious freedom" legislation that would "create a legal framework that allows us to recognize that this is a profoundly religious country, but there is no state church."
A widely circulated version of the Religious Equality Amendment would bar Federal and state authorities from preventing anyone from engaging in "prayer or other religious expression" in situations, like graduation ceremonies, where "expression of a nonreligious character" would be allowed.
That wording represents a break with how religious conservatives approached school prayer in the past. Absent is any mention of teacher-led classroom prayer, which was declared unconstitutional by the Supreme Court 33 years ago.
Instead, the emphasis is on public expression of religious belief. The amendment would forbid the authorities to cite constitutional grounds to block "ceremonial" expression of religion, a clause that could allow Christmas creches on courthouse lawns.
The Christian Coalition, Mr. Reed said, wants the measure to guarantee "student-initiated" prayer, allowing students, for example, to bring in a minister, priest or rabbi for an invocation at graduation.
Lawyers with the American Center for Law and Justice, an organization founded in 1991 by Pat Robertson, the religious broadcaster and founder of the Christian Coalition, have played a major role in drafting the amendment. Jay Sekulow, the center's general counsel, said the measure "gives those who have been concerned about morality in schools and the role of religion in public life a reason to hope that they will not be isolated or marginalized."
But Mr. Walker of the Coalition to Preserve Religious Liberty said the amendment "involves a drastic reordering of church and state."
He recently wrote a memorandum warning, for example, that the amendment could allow a public school teacher to "evangelize kindergarten students," a minister to preach "a hell-fire sermon" at a graduation ceremony or the Government "to fund religious schools in the same way it funds other, nonreligious schools."
Religious conservatives assert that the measure is popular with their constituencies, many of whom believe that an aggressive secularism in courts and city halls threatens to undercut religious liberties. They cite startling stories -- a pupil reprimanded for saying grace or for wanting to write about Jesus in a classroom essay -- as evidence that the religious are being shoved to the margins of society.
The proposed amendment, Dr. Dobson said, would "put it specifically in the Constitution that children and adults have a right to express their faith."
By casting the proposed amendment as a religious liberty measure, religious conservatives think they have a legislative winner.
But the measure is not their only hope. Mr. Sheldon, for example, said the Traditional Values Coalition was working with the office of Representative Philip M. Crane, Republican of Illinois, for a "clarification" of what Federal tax laws say about how much time, money and labor that religious groups can spend on influencing legislation.
His group, Mr. Sheldon said, wants to see the limit for time, money and labor set at 19 percent. Currently, there is no specified limit other than it should be "insignificant," he said. "Churches across America would like to be more active in the influencing of public policy and that's what this would do," he said.
And in its Contract With the American Family, the Christian Coalition expects to call for new regulations on abortion, like limiting late-term abortions, Mr. Reed said.
Some action against abortion is vital to religious conservatives, Mr. Sekulow said, adding, "To ignore the life issue is to ignore the ongoing culture clash in our society."

HEADLINE: Tomb of Ramses II's Many Sons Is Found in Egypt

BYLINE: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD 

 BODY:
Ramses II, one of ancient Egypt's greatest pharaohs, is said to have fathered more than 100 children, including 52 sons. Archeologists have now discovered an enormous mausoleum with at least 67 chambers, the largest tomb ever explored in the Valley of the Kings, and they think this was the resting place for most of those royal sons.
Working their way through a narrow entrance in the limestone hillside, archeologists were astonished to find a central hall with 16 pillars, a passageway to a statue of the god Osiris and other corridors leading away to many separate chambers. In the dim light they could glimpse wall decorations and alabaster fragments carrying inscriptions with the names of four sons of Ramses, and sarcophagus pieces, mummy fragments and statuary strongly suggesting that the tomb was used for their burials. 
 The sons never attained the power of their father, whose reign lasted 66 years, and their elaborate burial place is not likely to yield treasures similar to those in the tomb of Tutankhamen, the young King Tut. But the newly explored tomb, archeologists said, promised invaluable insights into Egypt's royal family at a crucial period in ancient history.
The discovery was described yesterday by Dr. Kent R. Weeks, a professor of Egyptology at the American University in Cairo who directs a project to map the monuments at the ancient Egyptian capital of Thebes, 300 miles south of Cairo. The tomb is part of the necropolis, known as the Valley of the Kings, where monarchs and nobles were buried from 1600 B.C. to 1000 B.C. The site is on the west side of the Nile, across from the ruins of Karnak and Luxor.
"It's like no other tomb I know of anywhere in Egypt," Dr. Weeks said in a telephone interview.
Most ancient Egyptian tombs consist of only a few chambers, and these are small and laid out along a single axis. Tomb 5, as the new find is designated, not only has at least 67 chambers arrayed in a complex plan, but stairs and sloping corridors -- yet to be explored -- apparently lead to even more rooms on a lower level. These lower rooms may be the actual burial chambers, Dr. Weeks said, and the total number of chambers could be more than 100.
Dr. Peter Dorman, an archeologist from the University of Chicago who works across the river at Luxor and has visited the site, praised the discovery as "a very significant find, very impressive and certain to give us a much clearer picture of the family of Ramses II." He also noted that the tomb's architecture was "completely unlike any other tomb" in Egypt.
Dr. David O'Connor, an Egyptologist at the University of Pennsylvania's University Museum, said the grandeur of the tomb complex "seems to say something important about the status of royal princes during the Ramses reign." Princes usually rated much more modest burial places.
Dr. Weeks wondered if there could be other multiple burials for the families of other pharaohs that have gone undetected.
"Tomb 5 raises many questions about what else the Valley of the Kings and other areas at Thebes may have to offer," Dr. Weeks said in a statement issued by the American University of Cairo. "It is an entirely new type of New Kingdom burial structure."
Egypt and a large part of the known world in the 13th century B.C. were dominated by the long reign of Ramses II. He was one of the most powerful rulers in antiquity and a prolific builder of monumental architecture. His empire extended from Libya east to the valleys of the Tigris and Euphrates rivers, from Turkey south to the Sudan. His charioteers fought many battles against the Hittites, arch-enemies in what is now Turkey and Syria. Tradition has it that Ramses was pharaoh at the time of the Exodus of the Israelites from Egypt.
According to the Book of Exodus, the first son of the pharaoh was killed by God. In Chapter 11, Verse 5, it says, "And all the firstborn in the land of Egypt shall die, from the firstborn of Pharaoh that sitteth upon his throne, even unto the firstborn of the maidservant." The eldest son of Ramses II was named Amon-her-khepeshef. He is one of the sons whose names are inscribed on the walls of Tomb 5.
The tomb occupies a prominent place in the necropolis, 100 feet from the tomb of Ramses II himself and not far from King Tut's. In fact, when the English archeologist Howard Carter excavated Tut's tomb, he unknowingly piled dirt and debris over Tomb 5's entrance, further obscuring it.
That entrance was discovered once in 1820 by an English traveler, but he explored no farther than the three outermost chambers, which were unprepossessing and damaged by floodwaters. In the 1980's, Dr. Weeks and other archeologists rediscovered the hidden entrance by studying the diaries of the 19th century travelers. They also followed the lead of an ancient papyrus now in a museum in Turin, Italy. It described the trial of a thief in 1150 B.C. who was caught trying to rob the tomb of Ramses II and also one "across the path," presumably the one now called Tomb 5.
Cutting test trenches on the slopes near the Ramses tomb, they uncovered the narrow entrance and did some preliminary investigation. But debris washed in by floods hampered exploration. Only in February were Dr. Weeks and his team able to remove debris blocking the door leading off the grand hall with 16 pillars.
Once through the door, they found less water damage and one surprise after another. They followed the passageway leading past 20 doors of smaller chambers and ending at the statue of Osiris, god of the underworld. Two branching corridors each had 20 doors to other rooms. The smallest rooms were about 10 by 10 feet; the largest was 60 by 60 feet.
This was when Dr. Weeks realized he had entered, as he said, "the largest tomb in the Valley of the Kings and maybe the largest ever found in all Egypt." It was certainly more complex and extensive than the standard royal tombs, which are simple structures with a single corridor leading to a main burial chamber.
In an interview with the Reuters news agency in Cairo, Abdelhalim Nourredin, head of Egypt's Supreme Council for Antiquities, described the structure and the many chambers as magnificent, even if some of the rooms were badly damaged by water, and important because of its "unique design and size from a crucial period in ancient history." The Egyptian Government worked with Dr. Weeks in the explorations.
Dr. Weeks speculated that the rooms on this main level were used for religious ceremonies and making offerings to the dead, with the lower rooms set aside for the burials.
The floors were littered with thousands of pieces of pottery, statue fragments, jewelry and beads, pieces of wooden furniture, stone sarcophagus fragments, inscribed stone vessels, bones from offerings of cooked meat and pieces of mummified human bodies. Dr. Weeks said there was no indication that looters had ever penetrated the back chambers, or been anywhere in the tomb since antiquity.
Close examination revealed the inscribed names of four sons of Ramses. Decorations in the small entrance rooms included the names of Amon-her-khepeshef, the firstborn, and the second son whose name was, in effect, Ramses Junior. A piece of alabaster jar bore the name and titles of another son, Sety, and outside the entrance archeologists found a piece of limestone on which was written the name of Mery-amon, the 15th son.
Historians know the names of all 52 sons, but little else about them. They had previously been able to identify the burial sites of only two of Ramses' sons. Mernepteh, the 13th son, succeeded his father as pharaoh and so built his own tomb in the Valley of the Kings. The fifth son, Khaemwase, is thought to be buried at Saqqara, south of the Pyramids of Giza.
It is entirely possible, Dr. Weeks and other archeologists said, that all 50 of Ramses' other sons were laid to rest in Tomb 5. Explorations are scheduled to be resumed in July.

HEADLINE: Tobacco Suit's Plaintiffs Suffer A Court Setback

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
In a setback for plaintiffs in a giant class-action suit against American tobacco companies, a Federal district judge in New Orleans agreed to allow his class-action certification of the case to be taken to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
An appeal, which could take six months to a year, would have the effect of stopping the momentum of a consortium of lawyers from close to 60 plaintiffs' law firms who have gathered in New Orleans to mount the largest class-action suit in history. The plaintiffs contend that the seven companies, their related units and the Tobacco Institute, an industry group, had concealed knowledge that nicotine was addictive and had manipulated nicotine levels in cigarettes to keep customers addicted. 
 In his order yesterday, the judge, Okla B. Jones 2d, stayed all trial action in the case, halting the plaintiffs' discovery procedure, in which the consortium had hoped to find documents incriminating to the tobacco companies.
Also halted is the largest notification effort ever initiated in a court of law, a plan to use newspaper, magazine and television advertisements to inform as many as 90 million smokers and former smokers that they may be included in the class action.
Although the judge's order made an appeal possible, only the Fifth Circuit, which is in New Orleans, can decide whether to take the case. However, analysts and lawyers for both sides said an appeal was highly likely, given the magnitude of the case.
The order "is definitely a temporary victory for the tobacco companies," said Prof. Kenneth Abraham, a specialist in insurance and tort law at the University of Virginia. "It gives the companies an opportunity to get the class decertified, and to possibly save some of the enormous resources that they would have had to invest in this trial."
The plaintiffs' lawyers acknowledged that they felt "a little disappointment that we can't move ahead rapidly," said John P. Coale, one of the lawyers, who is also their spokesman. "The tobacco companies will buy some time with this, but that's all they'll buy," he said, adding, "We hope we'll win on appeal because we tightly followed Fifth Circuit law."
But some analysts speculated that the ruling, and the resulting delay, would cause disarray in the plaintiffs' camp. "I wonder if the coalition of law firms can stay together," said Gary Black, a tobacco analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company.
Mr. Coale said the plaintiffs were "in this for the duration," adding that "the good news is that Judge Jones's order keeps us from going on for years and spending trillions of dollars on the case, and then having the court of appeals say we shouldn't have got certification."
Charles Wall, senior vice president and associate general counsel at the Philip Morris Companies, applauded the judge's decision and denied that the tobacco companies were using delaying tactics. "We had the right to appeal an adverse decision, and I feel that our chances of prevailing in the appeal are very good because we're right -- on the law," he said.
Daniel W. Donahue, senior vice president and deputy general counsel for the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, a unit of RJR Nabisco, said he thought it was "likely that the Fifth Circuit will in fact review this case on the merits," because it contains "novel, untested and previously unapplied legal theories," he added.
The plaintiffs' lawsuit was filed in March 1994 in the United States Eastern District of Louisiana on behalf of Dianne Castano, who is the widow of a smoker, and three other plaintiffs.
In yesterday's order, Judge Jones wrote that "the system of law is not designed to have one court control the economies and lives of so many in a case of such legal importance." He added that though he had "a firm belief of having made the right decision in certifying this matter as a limited class action," he agreed to the tobacco companies' request for an appeal.
Wall Street has followed the case closely for its potential to cost the tobacco companies billions in liability damages. Word of the judge's order began circulating about a half-hour before the close of the New York Stock Exchange, "but it's hard to say that it moved the tobacco stocks," said Emanuel Goldman, a securities analyst for Paine Webber. "It should have a somewhat positive effect in the future."
Shares of Philip Morris climbed 62.5 cents, to $70.875, while shares of the Loews Corporation, parent of Lorillard Inc., were up $1.50, to $115.375.
In his order, Judge Jones mentioned a March decision by the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit in Chicago, which reversed a lower-court decision permitting a class action by 10,000 hemophilia patients -- or their surviving families -- who had been infected by H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. They were suing five international drug companies that had supplied the patients with blood-clotting medicine, asserting that the companies knowingly distributed clotting products contaminated with H.I.V.
At the time of that decision, the tobacco companies said it provided a precedent to invalidate the legal assault brought by the plaintiffs' lawyers. But the plaintiffs' lawyers said that the issues were substantially different and that the ruling, by a three-judge appeals panel, was an aberration.
The companies named in the tobacco suit are the American Tobacco Company, a unit of American Brands; the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company; the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation, a unit of B.A.T. Industries P.L.C.; Philip Morris Inc.; Liggett & Myers Inc., a unit of Brooke Group Ltd.; the Lorillard Tobacco Company; and the United States Tobacco Company, a unit of UST Inc.

HEADLINE: Iranian Leader Says U.S. Move on Oil Deal Wrecked Chance to Improve Ties

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: TEHERAN, Iran, May 15

 BODY:
President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran tried to appeal directly to the American people today, asserting that the United States missed a chance to improve relations when it forced the cancellation in March of a $1 billion deal Teheran had made with an American oil company, and urging Washington to lift its recent trade embargo against his country.
But the Iranian leader also exhibited his long-held antipathy to the United States. In a 75-minute interview with ABC News, he said the Clinton Administration owed Iran "a thousand apologies" for what he called efforts to weaken the 16-year-old revolutionary Government with "lies" and "bullying." He repeatedly asserted that Washington owes Iran billions of dollars from the time of the Shah. 
 Mr. Rafsanjani, who has virtually no contact with the Americans and seldom grants interviews to American news organizations, was unable to hide his curiosity about American policy. He more than once asked Peter Jennings, the ABC anchor who interviewed him, whether the Clinton Administration's characterization of his country as an outlaw state spreading global terror and desperately seeking nuclear weapons was justified.
"We invited an American firm and entered into a deal for $1 billion," Mr. Rafsanjani said of the agreement with a Dutch subsidiary of Conoco, the Houston-based oil company, to develop two off-shore oil fields. "This was a message to the United States, which was not correctly understood. We had a lot of difficulty in this country by inviting an American company to come here with such a project because of public opinion."
The Conoco deal would have represented the first major American investment in Iran since the 1979 revolution and therefore would have sent an important signal to other investors at a time of huge inflation, an increase of capital flight and a lack of investor confidence among both Iranians and foreigners.
The Clinton Administration's cancellation of the deal and the trade ban that followed this month has contributed to a quiet panic on the streets of Teheran and a sense that things can only get worse.
The embargo itself will have only a minimal effect on Iran's economy. The United States sold Iran only $330 million worth of goods last year, the most important of which were for equipment for the country's aging oil fields. American oil companies bought upwards of $3.5 billion of Iran's oil last year.
The official reaction in Teheran to the American trade ban is that it does not aggravate Iran's economic problems and enjoys no support from Iran's other trading partners.
But even Mr. Rafsanjani acknowledged today that it would have a psychological effect. "This provocation could provide some anxiety," he said, although he added, "In practice it would not have much effect."
But Mr. Rafsanjani urged the United States to rethink its policy. "My suggestion to your Government is not to do these immature things it's doing," he said, adding, "We are not asking the United States to have relations with us. What we are asking the United States is to stop its hostility against us."
The dollar may not get much respect in Tokyo or Bonn, but in Teheran, it is the only currency that counts. Even before President Clinton's executive order banning trade with Iran, the country's national currency was in steady decline.
But in the last week, the rial plunged to its lowest level against the dollar since the Iranian revolution, sparking widespread buying of dollars on the black market and much-publicized arrests of money changers from their informal headquarters on a strip near the Central Bank in central Teheran. Mr. Rafsanjani, who had once tried to allow the Iranian rial to rise and fall freely on the open market, threatened executions of the "economic terrorists."
Curiously, independent, but more established money changers are still allowed to change dollars, and customers lined up today outside the shops in central Teheran to change dollars at more than twice the official rate.
Even as Mr. Rafsanjani said the American embargo would have no practical effect, he blamed the United States and Israel for wreaking havoc on Iran's currency.
Mr. Rafsanjani said of the independent money changers: "We gave them too much of a free hand. They have acted in full harmony and synchronized their actions with the trade ban of the United States and the actions of the Israelis."
Mr. Rafsanjani also repeated denials that Iran is trying to develop a nuclear weapon.

HEADLINE: MEDICARE TARGET COULD BE ELUSIVE, MANY EXPERTS SAY

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 15

 BODY:
As Congress rolls toward a vote this week on more than $250 billion in Medicare savings, a variety of health policy experts say there is no magic formula for extracting that much money from the program by 2002, the Republicans' self-imposed deadline for balancing the Federal budget.
Slowing spending that much in that short a time almost certainly would mean charging beneficiaries more while squeezing payments to hospitals and other health care providers, these experts say. 
 "There's no way to do this without imposing real sacrifice and real pain," said Robert D. Reischauer, former director of the Congressional Budget Office and now a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, "and both beneficiaries and providers will feel it. The notion that this can be squeezed out of the system with greater efficiencies is wishful thinking."
So far, the debate on Capitol Hill has been stuck on generalities and sound bites. From Sunday talk shows to weekday committee rooms, Republican leaders have maintained that they can wring that money from the system while "preserving, protecting and improving" Medicare, which serves 37 million elderly or disabled Americans. They have talked about "new technologies, new management and new approaches."
Many health policy analysts agree that over the long haul, a basic restructuring of Medicare to encourage greater use of managed care may produce some of the painless savings the Republicans promise.
Moreover, few experts dismiss the idea that the Federal Government ought to try to get control of the upward spiral of Medicare expenditures in areas like home health care. There is also considerable support for charging affluent beneficiaries more of the true cost of Medicare benefits. There have been proposals from both Democrats and Republicans over the years, for example, that would require upper-income elderly to pay higher premiums for the insurance that covers doctors' fees, which is now heavily subsidized by general tax revenue.
But the sheer amount that the Republicans seek to save in Medicare means they will have to go well beyond such narrowly targeted proposals, many experts say.
And as is often the case with health policy, the decisions made on Medicare could ripple through the health care system with far-reaching and unintended consequences. For example, many planners say that new spending controls could be particularly hard on rural and inner city hospitals, which often serve a disproportionate share of elderly and low-income patients.
The Medicare revisions will also come at a time of immense change in the private health care marketplace, where employers are being more aggressive in their efforts to control costs. Many hospitals, some policy analysts say, could be caught in a vise, squeezed on one side by Medicare and the Medicaid program for the poor, and on the other side by private payers.
Gail R. Wilensky, a health policy expert in the Bush Administration and a longtime advocate of many of the Republican proposals, acknowledged that hospitals are in for a tumultuous time.
"You'll have pressure to find different ways of providing services, and some of the providers will probably not survive the pressure coming from the private and public sectors," Ms. Wilensky said. Such a shakeout, she added, happens from time to time. "It happened in defense, it happened in corporate America, but nobody expected it to happen in health care," she said.
Republicans assert, of course, that reining in spending is essential to ease the strain on the Medicare trust fund as well as to balance the budget by 2002. They bitterly dispute the notion that their proposals, reported out by the House and Senate Budget Committees last week, even qualify as cuts. Overall spending on the program, which cost $162 billion in the 1994 fiscal year, would still rise, they note, just not as fast as projected. The Senate proposal says it would reduce the growth rate from about 10 percent a year to about 7.1 percent a year; the House version would peg it at about 5.4 percent a year.
But Bruce C. Vladeck, administrator of the Health Care Financing Administration, which oversees Medicare, scoffs at the idea that spending reductions of that magnitude are necessary to save the trust fund. "It's necessary to save some political rear ends, but it's not necessary to save the trust fund," he said.
And representatives of the hospital industry and the elderly portray the Republican proposals as out and out cuts that would do everything but "preserve, protect and improve" the 30-year-old insurance program. They note that Medicare spending grows not only because of medical inflation, but also because of increases in the size of the beneficiary population and increases in the services being provided.
The Republican proposals, they argue, would simply shift more costs to the elderly, to health care providers and, eventually, to other health care consumers, concerns also cited by Democrats. Vice President Al Gore, in an interview today, argued, "It is wrong to pretend for the purposes of a political shell game that this phenomenon doesn't occur; it does occur."
The Catholic Health Association, representing nearly 900 hospitals and institutions offering long-term care, has described the Republican budget targets as "unprecedented and devastating." Dick Davidson, president of the American Hospital Association, used a similar characterization in a letter last week to Republican leaders.
"Do these spending reductions avert the trust fund's insolvency?" he wrote. "No, only postpone it. Meanwhile, will access to and quality of medical care for seniors deteriorate? Without question."
The debate has an edge of the surreal because, so far, it is largely over a number, not a detailed set of policies. The Senate's proposal sets a $256 billion target for seven-year savings and calls for a bipartisan commission to figure out how to get there. The House calls for $282 billion in savings, and a Budget Committee working group outlines assorted options to achieve it, including new charges for beneficiaries and controls on payments to providers. But the House plan leaves the details to other committees.
"As was the case with health care reform, one needs to look at the details before one can make an assessment that this is a disaster or a complicated and difficult program that could work," said Stuart Altman, a health policy expert at Brandeis University and a member of a Medicare advisory board. "I would like to know how we would get there before I would vote on the dollars."
Still, the votes will certainly be cast this week in the House, with debate beginning in the Senate. And once these votes are cast and the resolutions approved, Republicans will inevitably have to look in a few basic spots for the money to carry them out.
Down the road, they hope to achieve big savings by injecting more competition and cost-consciousness into the Medicare system, by such mechanisms as giving the elderly vouchers that they could use to buy their own coverage. But in the meantime, experts predict and the House working group's proposal clearly suggests, lawmakers will look to higher premiums, deductibles and co-payments for beneficiaries, and for ways to tighten payments to providers.
The premium paid by the elderly for the insurance that covers doctor and outpatient services, known as Medicare Part B, is now $46.10 a month. Conservatives say that when Medicare was created, the intent was that beneficiaries would pay a premium covering half of the program cost; now, they pay about 25 percent. Both houses are almost certain to raise that monthly premium -- the House plan suggests an increase of $5 to $7 each year -- as well as the deductible for the Part B program, which now stands at $100 a year.
One of the House options would also charge new Medicare beneficiaries an additional $20 a month for Part B insurance, beginning in 1999, if they want to have traditional fee-for-service coverage instead of joining a health maintenance organization. That would be a way of speeding the movement of Medicare beneficiaries into managed care, promoting more savings in the long run.
New co-payments are also likely, particularly a 20 percent co-payment for users of home health care services. That may turn out to be one of the most controversial of the Medicare proposals, because many advocates and planners say such a co-payment would fall on the sickest and oldest of Americans. The American Association of Retired Persons says the co-payment would be a "sick tax" that would cost the average home health care user an additional $900 in 1996.
Advocates of the co-payment note that home health care costs have been soaring and argue that the payment could help "discourage over-utilization," as one House Budget Committee document put it. Low-income elderly people could be cushioned from the charge, they add.
But advocates for the elderly maintain that out-of-pocket costs for health care are already a burden on Medicare beneficiaries. The American Association of Retired Persons said last week that Republican budget committee proposals could mean more than $3,000 in additional out-of-pocket expenses for the average beneficiary over the next seven years.
There are any number of ways to restrict payments to providers, with any number of potential consequences, ranging from negligible to wrenching, health planners say. Medicare is an integral part of the health care system, not only reimbursing hospitals and doctors directly for care, but also helping to subsidize medical education, for example. The proposals from the House Budget Committee's working group suggest cuts in many of these areas.
There have been other efforts to control spending in the past, but what makes this round different is the squeeze already under way from employers, several analysts say. Those who view the health care system as a whole wonder what the impending changes might mean for the uninsured.
"You have a shrinking of all the places where hospitals tried to cross-subsidize treating the uninsured and underinsured," said Diane Rowland, senior vice president of the Kaiser Family Foundation, a research group that focuses on health issues. "I wonder what's going to happen to our uncompensated care system and our 41 million uninsured if the fiscal situation at some of these hospitals gets dramatically worse."
As all these concerns are raised in the days to come, Republicans will return again and again to their core arguments: that Medicare must be reshaped to keep it solvent for those now growing old, and that the Federal budget must be balanced by 2002 for the sake of future generations.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Three Named to Microsoft's Top Management

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
The Microsoft Corporation promoted three executives yesterday to its office of the president, a move that analysts viewed as a broadening of management control as the software developer moves into new businesses.
At Microsoft, the office of the president is the top-management group that works directly with William H. Gates, co-founder and chairman of Microsoft, in charting the company's strategy. The office of the president, formerly a three-person forum, will now have five members. 
 Along with the executive promotions, Microsoft also announced a reorganization that folds its advanced-technology unit into a product group, suggesting that its research will be increasingly expected to contribute to profits. The advanced-technology group has worked on projects ranging from Microsoft Network, an on-line service scheduled to begin later this year, to an interactive television effort called Tiger, which is probably years away from the marketplace.
The three new members of the office of the president are Pete Higgins, formerly a senior vice president and head of the desktop applications division; Nathan Myhrvold, formerly a senior vice president who ran the advanced-technology group; and Paul Maritz, formerly senior vice president for products and technology. Each assumes the title of group vice president.
As reported yesterday, Mike Maples, a 52-year-old executive vice president and member of Microsoft's office of the president, plans to retire, effective July 15.
"The promotions are part of the broadening of control and power at Microsoft as the place gets bigger and the people get older," said David Coursey, editor of PC Letter, a newsletter in San Mateo, Calif.
The three group vice presidents will oversee all of Microsoft's product divisions, which are being placed into two new groups, called the platforms group and the applications and content group.
The platforms group, overseen by Mr. Maritz, who is 40, includes the Microsoft operating systems for consumers and business, from Windows to Windows NT. The development work on common objects for software, security and tools for future systems will be part of the platforms group. Some of the advanced-technology unit is being placed under Mr. Maritz's supervision.
Both Mr. Higgins, who is 37, and Mr. Myhrvold, who is 35, will be in charge of the applications and content group. Analysts say that Mr. Higgins is the marketing expert, while Mr. Myhrvold's strength is as a technologist. The group will supervise the desktop applications business, consumer software, the new on-line service, and research in fields like speech recognition.
Mr. Myhrvold dismissed suggestions that basic research was being downgraded as a result of the reorganization. Instead, he said, the changes reflect a recognition that many company projects are moving from being ideas to being products.

HEADLINE: Rangel's Voice: Stronger Than Ever;
Dean of Delegation Furious Over Cuts

BYLINE: By MELINDA HENNEBERGER 

 BODY:
Even at a recent memorial service for an old friend, held in a Harlem church just down the block from the house where he was born, Representative Charles B. Rangel used his turn at the pulpit to preach against "the silence of good people" while, as he sees it, the world is falling apart.
"Black folks are being hurt as we never have before," Mr. Rangel told the crowd gathered to remember a community leader, Arnold P. Johnson, and a few people said amen to that. "And I say there are so many white folks affected who don't even know it!" he went on, his voice cresting. "The same thing happened in Germany, where people thought this was happening to somebody else. But they will find out they're on the list, too." 
 Though outrage is an overused word on Capitol Hill, Mr. Rangel gives every indication of actually being mad as hell. It isn't only the Republican Contract With America that sets him off, though he says it is contrary to everything he believes in. He is also furious at many fellow Democrats, whom he describes as complacent during an all-out assault on the poor.
He repeatedly likens what he calls the current apathy to the attitude in Nazi Germany that led to the Holocaust. He assails everyone from President Clinton to John Cardinal O'Connor, admonishing that they should speak out more forcefully. He also says he fears that the country is on the brink of violent revolution.
Sometimes, he sounds surprisingly like a conservative talk-show host, until he gets to the part about his proposed solution, which is almost always education. He says Hispanic and black teen-agers are alone among God's creatures in having no sense of self-preservation and he calls drug dealers so dumb they have to eat in Burger Kings because they can't read a menu.
And in this, his 25th year in Congress, the dean of the New York delegation, who will be 65 next month, is now the No. 2 Democrat on a powerful House committee, Ways and Means, and seems to have abandoned even the modicum of restraint traditionally maintained by those in his position.
"I'm starting a new approach," he said. "I'm going to become a terrorist, too" -- an oratorical bomb-thrower with a doomsday message and the unhappy conviction that he is mostly going it alone these days.
His role as spokesman for the have-nots is not new, but Mr. Rangel, who normally uses wit to make a point, has turned up the volume considerably.
"I've seen, since the fall election, a different Charlie Rangel," said Barbara B. Kennelly, a Connecticut Democrat on the Ways and Means Committee. "Now he's determined to let his life experience be known."
At the Democrats' recent retreat in Piney Point, Md., the House minority leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, said of Mr. Rangel: "We were all focused on what to do about economic problems and the angry middle class, and he quickly brought everybody back to earth by reminding us that some people have stopped even trying to get into the middle class because there's no hope. People listened."
But Mr. Rangel dismissed the retreat "as just so much chitchat."
After three decades in public life, the portly, gravel-voiced Mr. Rangel, who is very much the Old World-style gentleman yet sprinkles his sentences with mild profanity, still takes politics personally. And he is acutely embarrassed, he said, to see the New Deal falling apart while he is on the job.
After a constituent greeted him outside his office and praised his recent performance in a television debate, he shook his head and said: "They think I'm winning. I can't tell them what I've told you. I can't say it all stopped on my watch."
A particular sore point is both the substance and the language of the welfare debate, in which people on aid have been likened to wolves and alligators. "I don't know what the hell people felt in Germany when they would say the Jews were responsible for every goddamn problem that Europe and Germany had, but there were a whole lot of people who agreed with them," he said. "And more than those that agreed was the goddamn silence of the moral leaders."
In referring to the Holocaust, he said, he did not intend to compare that singular horror to anything happening in Congress today. But he does intend, he said, to be as outrageous as necessary to pierce the silence.
A Roman Catholic himself, he is particularly critical of leaders in his own church, including Cardinal O'Connor, who along with Catholic bishops has criticized the proposed welfare overhaul and said it could encourage abortions. But that is not enough for Mr. Rangel.
"We are talking about feeding the hungry!" he said, loosening his tie and moving into an impassioned monologue in his New York office, on 125th Street, where the view from his window includes one of the nation's first public housing projects. The Cardinal, he said, "sent somebody to say he saw me on C-Span and how proud he was of how I was dealing with the question of welfare and he was preparing to make a political statement.
"I said, 'You turn right back and tell him I don't need any political statement. Tell him to put his vestments on and get on the Capitol steps and read Matthew,' " he said, referring to the Gospel reading in which Jesus says heaven belongs to those who feed the hungry, take in the strangers and visit the sick and those in prison. "What the hell do you need a political statement for when it's in the New Testament?"
His own experience, he said, illustrates the need for a more aggressive approach.
Born in Harlem in 1930, Charles Bernard Rangel barely knew the father who he says physically abused his mother, never held a job and left the family when Charles was 6.
His mother, Blanche Rangel, cleaned houses, worked as a home attendant and cut the threads off shoulder pads coming off a factory assembly line. When he was 8, he too went to work, in a neighborhood drug store, delivering prescriptions and pouring castor oil into small bottles from 5-gallon cans.
He always worked, but by the time he was in high school he was often truant and occasionally driven home by the police. At 16, he quit school to sell shoes, and drifted, he said, until he served in the Army during the Korean War, when he rescued 40 men from behind enemy lines and was decorated with the Purple Heart and the Bronze Star.
And after he returned home to banner headlines in The New York Amsterdam News, he went back to school and became a lawyer.
Mr. Rangel's rocky start, overcome with the government's help, has made him a broken record on the subject of funds for education and programs for those he calls "second chancers" like himself.
Yet he is no softy in speaking about personal responsibility. "I've always talked about the problem of irresponsible women having babies that will turn into urban terrorists," he said. "Sure, that's just what the Republicans picked up on and I don't deny that. But it's an indictment of the educational system."
And he describes drug dealers in the harshest terms: "These young entrepreneurs are so stupid that they can't even count their money with a money counter. They have no idea what to do with the money, I mean after they get their mother a big television set and they buy some stupid Jeep with a boom system in it and they get every girl there is to like some gold teeth and some chains. If you told them, 'Why don't you go to Europe?' it's, 'Which way is Europe?' "
His own role model, when he was a child who could have easily got into trouble, was his mother's father, a courthouse elevator operator who always wore his uniform and badge home and knew all the judges and big-shot lawyers.
One of Mr. Rangel's most emotional memories is returning home alone and sad after his New York University graduation, which he had very much wanted his grandfather to attend, and finding him in the kitchen, all dressed up and drunk. He had gone to the graduation, it turned out, but had been unable to find his grandson in the crowd, so he went home.
When his grandfather wanted to continue working at his Civil Service job past the mandatory retirement age of 70, the young Mr. Rangel stopped by the local political club to ask for help in the matter. Soon after that he got involved in politics himself, mostly, he said, because he had seen how puny the competition was.
In Congress, the fight against drug abuse has been his great passion; he has vehemently opposed those who favor legalization, and defended Nancy Reagan when others disparaged her 'Just Say No' campaign.
But the Congressman's wife, Alma Carter Rangel, a former social worker whom he says he loved at first sight, which was nearly 40 years ago on the dance floor of Harlem's Savoy Ballroom, said without hesitation that his chief motivation in life is ambition.
Some of those ambitions have lately been dashed, at least temporarily, during an exceptionally difficult period for Mr. Rangel, both personally and politically. After the last election, he lost his chairmanship of a key Ways and Means subcommittee.
Then, in March, Mr. Rangel's mother, with whom he had spoken several times a day every day, died at age 90. And now, he said, he often goes around feeling like he has forgotten to do something, then remembers that he would ordinarily have been checking in with her.
Mr. Rangel declined to speculate on his political future except to say that he does not look forward to retirement. He has no hobbies, he said, can't relax past the third day of any vacation and has been warned by his wife that he is going to wind up friendless in his old age because he tends to neglect personal relationships in favor of work.
"I feel alone a lot, so that's what has been a source of complaint on my part," Mrs. Rangel said. "But then again, he loves what he does."
And for now, her husband said, a big part of his job is annoying his fellow lawmakers.
When asked the standard question about his current role, he laughed and said: "To be a thorn in the side of people who say they're Democrats" but sound increasingly like Republicans. "If you're going down the tube, if you're going to lose, lose fighting."

SECTION: Section D; Page 2; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 531 words

HEADLINE: New California Laws Will Aid The Recovery of Orange County

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: SANTA ANA, Calif., May 15

 BODY:
Gov. Pete Wilson of California signed into law today five bills crucial to the recovery plan of Orange County, Calif. But he vetoed a sixth bill that would have authorized him to impose a trustee to manage the financial affairs of the brankrupt county.
Mr. Wilson, in his veto message, contended that Orange County should be left to manage its affairs on its own. 
 "Having the state intervene to this level in the day-to-day management of local government affairs is not warranted at this time," he wrote.
Separately, the county, which fell into backruptcy last year after its investment pool lost about $2 billion, won a commitment from MBIA Inc. to insure $275 million in recovery bonds to finance partial repayment to the local governments that participated in the pool.
The insurance backing of MBIA fills a crucial hole in the county's settlement agreement with the nearly 200 cities, school districts and agencies that invested $5.1 billion in the pool. Approved this month by United States Bankruptcy Judge John Ryan, the proposed settlement enables the county to fulfill its promise to pay most of the money lost by the participants.
The school districts will now get back 90 percent of their investments in cash, while the other participants in the pool will receive 80 percent. The balance will consist of claims against the county.
The five bills signed into law, approved last week by both houses of the California Legislature, are supposed to help the county refinance more than $1 billion of debt. It plans to issue new debt directly backed by state motor vehicle license fees, waste management revenue and Teeter Plan notes. They will also remove certain restrictions on sales of county property.
In vetoing the trusteeship bill, Mr. Wilson said he might support such a measure in the future. "If the board of supervisors fails to show the necessary leadership to continue to lead the county through these difficult times, this issue may need to be revisited," Mr. Wilson wrote.
The county has asked the holders of more than $1 billion of debt maturing this summer to wait an additional year for repayment. On June 27 county residents will vote on a ballot measure to increase the county's sales tax by half a percent, to 8.25 percent. The passage of the tax increase, which would raise about $130 million annually, is considered essential to the recovery plan.
"The county still has to pass Measure R in June," said William Popejoy, chief administrative officer of the county, "as well as identify other new revenue sources to satisfy the $2 billion in claims resulting from the financial crisis."
MBIA officials said concern about the consequences for the $1.3 trillion municipal market if many of the participants in the fund defaulted on their coming obligations played a role in the decision to insure the securities. "Our goal was to help the participants," said Neil Budnick, senior vice president at MBIA. "California is a very big market for us."
MBIA declined to say what it was charging to insure the bonds, but analysts estimated that the county would have to pay a significant premium on what other issuers usually paid for insurance.

HEADLINE: Major Stock Indexes Set Records as Bonds Continue to Rally

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Stock traders, expecting no surprises in economic data due out today, bid up the major stock indexes to more record highs, as the bond market also continued its rally.
Many market analysts expect the Federal Reserve to do nothing about interest rates at its policy-setting meeting next Tuesday. "Fed watching is going to become pretty boring," said Sung Won Sohn, chief economist for the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis. 
 Beginning what stock analysts expect to be another record-breaking week, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 6.91 points, to a record 4,437.47, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 index rose 2.19 points, to 527.74, also a record. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 4.12 points, to 863.06, still another all-time high.
Long-term interest rates also fell. The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell to 6.94 percent from 6.99 percent.
But the dollar also fell against major currencies, but not by much, providing more evidence for the much-anticipated "bottom" for the dollar's steep decline this year. The dollar fell to 86.40 Japanese yen from 86.80 yen, while it fell to 1.4360 German mark from 1.4485.
At its lowest, on April 18, the dollar fell to less than 81 yen and less than 1.36 marks.
Today, the Government is scheduled to release reports on industrial production and factory use, as well as data on the housing industry, such as housing starts. The industrial data are expected to indicate a slowing economy, with April industrial production falling five-tenths of 1 percent and factory use at 84.2 percent, compared with 84.9 percent in March.
Housing reports, however, may be up but traders are likely to dismiss them as lagging indicators that say little about the future of the economy.
"I think the outlook is rosy and bullish for now," Mr. Sohn of Norwest said. One of the principal reasons for rising stock prices is the rally in bonds, which fell sharply last year.
"Bonds are reversing the carnage of last year," he said, "and getting back to the long-term trend," which is for higher bond prices and lower long-term interest rates. As bond prices rise, corporate borrowing costs go down, helping stocks.
Another major reason for the bullish sentiment for both stocks and bonds, Mr. Sohn said, is the deficit-cutting measures by the Republican leadership in Congress. Wall Street is focusing less on the specific amount of money proposed for cuts, some $1 trillion or more, but on the Republican determination to cut large amounts from the budget.
"In the past, talking about cutbacks in Medicare, for example, would have been immediate political suicide," Mr. Sohn said. "Now the leadership is actually willing to talk about it and that's new."
Indeed, the relative stability of the dollar, indicating that more and more traders are buying the American currency, removes the last argument for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates, as a way of attracting foreign investment, analysts say.
Dollar strength "removes a barrier to actually cutting interest rates rather than just leaving them alone," said William Dodge, chief investment strategist for Dean Witter. But job creation and unemployment data will be closely watched by traders, he said, to see when, or if, the Fed cuts rates.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was below normal, with 314.8 million shares changing hands, about 6 percent below this year's daily average of 334 million shares.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 1.11 points, to 284.01, with advancing stocks outnumbering declining stocks by 1,373 to 902. The American Stock Exchange market value index rose 0.55 point, to 488.31.
Among the advancing stocks was Hyperion Software, which rose 3 1/4, to 37 1/2, after a Soundview Financial Group analyst reiterated his recommendation of the stock as a "strong buy." Morgan Stanley, the Wall Street investment house, rose 3 1/4, to 78 3/8, as investors bet that the rally in stocks would also benefit brokerage houses.
Among the declining stocks was the Crop Growers Corporation, which markets crop insurances. It fell 5 1/2, to 24 1/4, after it reported a sharp surge in first-quarter earnings, but which analysts attributed to new Government legislation rather than the company's operations.
Exx Inc. class A and class B stock fell after the maker of toys based on the popular Mighty Morphin Power Rangers reported a sharp rise in first-quarter earnings on Friday. Both classes of shares had risen before the announcement. The class A shares fell 2 1/8, to 15 5/8, and the class B 2 5/8, to 14 3/4.
