HEADLINE: An Uphill Journey to Japan;
How the Price of a Jeep CLimbs 64% After Leaving the Factory

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 15

 BODY:
Jeep Cherokee No. SL542455 rolled off the assembly line last Oct. 9 at the Chrysler Corporation's plant in Toledo, Ohio. It left the factory with a price tag of an estimated $19,100.
But in a cramped showroom here in Japan, the retail price for such a car is now $31,372 -- about 64 percent higher -- at the current exchange rates. 
 This Jeep is a brilliant blue Sport model, with six roaring cylinders, automatic transmission and a power steering wheel on the right-hand side. A comparable model would have a sticker price of $20,698 in the United States. But this particular car did not just go from ship to showroom the way American-made Japanese cars do.
Instead, it took a much longer route -- first through a maze of tests, regulatory requirements and form-filling, and then through a complex web of relationships with distributors and dealers. It is all part of a system that drives the price of imported cars sharply higher and that American trade negotiators say helps to make Japan a market sheltered to benefit domestic auto makers.
After 20 months of bitter negotiations, Washington plans to announce on Tuesday that it will retaliate by imposing punitive tariffs on Japanese luxury cars within the next 30 days unless Tokyo relents. But the journey of Jeep Cherokee No. SL542455 illustrates the magnitude of the problem and the unlikelihood of a quick fix. For few of the added costs are particularly onerous or demonstrably unfair in themselves.
And even if Tokyo agreed to meet the American demands, perhaps making it easier for Detroit to sell more vehicles in Japan, it is still unlikely that the huge increase in the sticker price of imported American cars would decrease by much. Indeed, the current trade dispute focuses on opening the market for auto parts and putting more American cars into showrooms in Japan, not on eliminating this bureaucratic procedure or that quality check.
Still, underlying the confrontation between Washington and Tokyo is the intense, almost overwhelming frustration that Detroit's Big Three auto makers feel in trying to penetrate an unfamiliar Japanese market. And what is true for imported automobiles is also true for Japanese business practices over all, which tend to favor producers at the expense of consumers and make nearly all goods -- but especially foreign products -- substantially more expensive than elsewhere.
"The talks are all about the system itself, the fact that Japan is not as easy to sell into as the United States," said Peter Boardman, an auto analyst at UBS Securities Ltd. To Jerry K. Hsu, in charge of Japanese sales at the Chrysler International Corporation, the basic problem is that "it's an unlevel playing field."
In most countries, for example, Chrysler finds it fairly easy to market its cars through local distributors or its own subsidiaries. In Japan, by contrast, car dealers have such close ties with the domestic auto makers that they either refuse to sell American imports or put them in out-of-the-way showrooms.
When Japanese companies import their own American-made cars to Japan, they still need to comply with Government regulations. But they can translate their familiarity with the system into cost savings because they know how to take short cuts. And European auto makers have done better in Japan than Americans, primarily because they ship luxury models to buyers who are relatively unconcerned about price.
Conversely, Japanese-made cars exported to the United States roll off the ships into the fast lane to their dealers. So, even though the strong yen should help bring down prices in Japan while making Japanese goods more costly in the United States, the sticker price of the Jeep Cherokee is about 52 percent higher in Japan than in America, while the price of the Toyota Motor Corporation's American-made Avalon goes up only 28 percent in Japan.
Even more telling, the price of Toyota's Japanese-made Land Cruiser wagon is 17 percent lower when it is sold in the United States today. The company says that higher trucking and marketing costs, as well as options included on all cars sold here, increase the costs in Japan.
To be sure, Detroit is selling more cars in Japan these days. Jeep sales alone are expected to surge by more than 50 percent this year, to 20,000, from 13,000 in 1994. Chrysler has made some headway in overcoming the obstacles in its path, and with the dollar still weak, it is making a lot of money on every car sold. It might do even better if it goes through with plans to spend tens of millions of dollars on its own distribution system.
Even so, the sticker-price inflation that afflicted the ride of Jeep Cherokee No. SL542455 to the showroom floor in Japan is likely to slow the efforts of Chrysler to carve a meaningful presence in Japan. The Japanese distribution system, in short, will continue to rob Detroit's Big Three of much of their price advantage by the time the Japanese consumer gets a chance to kick American car tires.
Tracing the maze is not much easier than navigating it. Chrysler and other companies provided several cost figures but declined to disclose the exact prices at which they purchased or sold the Jeeps. So only rough estimates can be used to track the steady buildup of costs from the American wholesale price of an estimated $19,100.
In switching the price to yen, Chrysler must use a reasonable conversion rate, say 92 yen to $1, that will hold throughout the duration of the sale process. Thus, when the dollar weakens to 86 yen, the level at which it was trading yesterday, Chrysler receives a foreign exchange gain of $1,333 on each car sold.
Chrysler has tried to pass some of the gain along to consumers. In response to the weaker dollar, it recently lowered sticker prices by 10 percent, from the earlier 2,998,000 yen.
Jeep Cherokee No. SL542455 went by rail from the factory to a port in Baltimore. There, it was waxed protectively and various adjustments were made to adapt it to Japanese regulations, a process known as homologation. For example, Chrysler must insert heat-sensitive warning lights in the dashboard to alert a driver that a muffler is overheating.
The Jeep was then shipped at a cost of $200 through the Panama Canal and across the Pacific Ocean to the Japanese port of Chiba, arriving on Nov. 28. In Chiba, Chrysler turned over the ownership of the car to its importer, Chrysler Japan Sales Ltd., a joint venture in which Chrysler has a minor stake with J. Osawa & Company. Dock workers drove No. SL542455 and 621 other Jeeps from the ship to a parking lot, where employees of Chrysler Japan inspected the vehicles for dents and scratches.
The Jeeps cleared customs on Dec. 2, at a cost of $682 each, a relatively small fee. From there, they were trucked 50 miles to an inspection center run by one of Chrysler's two distributors, Seibu Motor Sales. Adding shipping and customs-clearance costs and the Chrysler exchange-rate bonus, the car carried a price tag of an estimated $21,315.
At that point, the importer took the car through a second homologation, including a five-minute brake test and a 20-minute test on exhaust levels in a specially built complex. The total cost of the homologations -- which are far more detailed than anything required in the United States -- on both sides of the Pacific was $1,100, increasing the price tag to $22,415.
Chrysler, however, still needed to show compliance with Japan's 238 regulations, a cumbersome effort that culminates in a 560-page book of documents. In the United States, the documentation can just about fit on a page. In response to previous complaints, Japan has speeded up the process. The cars breezed through a Government inspection in hours instead of the previous norm of seven days.
But the costs for the importer, Chrysler Japan, had only begun to rack up. It had to pay for trucking; make substantial rent payments for cramped quarters in an old building owned by its parent company; offer occasional rebates to distributors; spend millions of dollars each year on advertising and pay the salaries for 60 employees. While Japanese companies face similar expenses, they can spread those mostly fixed costs over a much larger number of vehicles than Chrysler, with its tiny share of the market.
Chrysler Japan will not disclose its profit margin on the Cherokee, but analysts estimate that it is 5 percent to 8 percent of the retail price of the car, or at least $1,569. That would bring the price tag so far to $23,984.
On Feb. 8 Jeep Cherokee No. SL542455 went through a beauty makeover at a Seibu inspection center, where employees checked for missing parts like floor mats, cigarette lighters and spare keys, removed the wax coating and made another search for scratches.
They polished the car again, to satisfy pickier Japanese consumers, and added options valued at $200, as well as the obligatory Japanese-made accessories like special side steps. Seibu also took a margin of 5 percent to 6 percent, or $1,725. Those two factors increased the cost of the car to $25,909.
In the United States, the margins to importers and distributors have been kept low, because Japanese car makers there have a much freer hand to set up their own subsidiaries to import and distribute. In Japan, high property costs and a longtime practice of limiting foreign ownership meant that Chrysler had to rely on Japanese distributors.
On April 3 Seibu received an order for a Jeep Cherokee from the Osawa Motor Sales Company, one of 406 dealerships in Japan that carry the Jeep. At the tiny Osawa Motors showroom in an out-of-the-way neighborhood in Tokyo, one Jeep and three Alfa Romeos crowded the floor. Masayoshi Iwamoto, who manages the dealership, said he paid $24,000 a month in rent, which is low by Tokyo's standards.
Mr. Iwamoto's dealership is different because it is controlled by a distributor, Seibu, rather than a Japanese manufacturer. He has an arrangement to sell cars made by Fiat S.p.A. of Italy that allows him to sell Jeeps, because they do not compete with the Fiat Alfa Romeos.
On April 8 Jeep Cherokee No. SL542455 was delivered to the dealership's showroom in Nagoya, about 75 miles from Tokyo, with a sticker price of $31,372. That would give the dealer a profit of $5,463. The buyer, a 28-year-old credit analyst, negotiated the price down to $30,209, but then paid a consumption tax of $906, for a total of $31,115.
Much of the high markup of the dealer can be attributed to the services it provides. For example, when a car it has sold breaks down, a salesman goes to the customer's home or office to pick it up for servicing, sometimes providing a temporary replacement. When the repairs are finished, the salesman drives the car back to the customer's home.
"We want to take care of the customer, but are we going beyond satisfying the customer?" said Mr. Hsu of Chrysler International. "Everything they do drives up the cost."

SECTION: Section A; Page 21; Column 5; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 716 words

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
When Is an Ally?

BYLINE: By A.M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
For America, the purpose and test of power is the ability to get things done that protect its security and interests or ward off dangers to them. In the use of power -- economic, political or military -- America can act alone or with allies.
What is an ally? Who are America's? And when? Full time? Or as temps, now and then? 
 At a time when Americans are increasingly edgy about using military power, will America use its economic might to protect its security? Will America's allies help?
If not, are we willing to use that economic power to force our allies, plus Russia or China, to respect our security and interests -- or at least not interfere with them? If not, is the U.S. still a superpower, or is it playing expensive games of self-delusion?
The questions rise out of Iran's plans to produce nuclear power that could be used for nuclear weaponry. The U.S. believes making Iran an economic outcast would stop Teheran. But Russia and China keep selling Iran the technology, materials and specialists of nuclear potential. Western Europe acts as if economic pressure against a terrorist state is an idea indelicate beyond the point of obscenity.
Iran now says it is not building one nuclear plant. It plans to build ten over the next two decades.
Ten -- that is not simply a number. It is a strategy, defensive and offensive. In 1981 Israel knocked out Iraq's nuclear weapon drive by a surprise strike on one plant. Iran's strategy scatters plants around the country, making a pre-emptive strike virtually impossible.
U.S. experts say Iran will be capable of producing material for nuclear weapons in three to five years. And Kenneth Timmerman, the enormously knowledgeable arms expert, reports in The Washington Times that for six years Iran has built stockpiles of uranium and other weapons-grade material, unguarded and uninspected.
A nuclear Iran would be a threat to the Persian Gulf states, Israel and Turkey and every other object on its hate list, headed of course by the U.S. Would Iran supply nuclear weapons to its protege terrorist groups? The mere possibility would hugely increase their power.
President Clinton did what his predecessors did not: he ordered an embargo on American trade with Iran. That removed Iran from the American market, and a burden of hypocrisy from the U.S.
But Germany, Japan, Italy, France and other U.S. allies that have been selling high-technology tools, pesticides or other products so useful in modern war told Mr. Clinton to take his embargo and run along. Communist China and North Korea have not been that courteous. They just send more material, missiles and specialists to Iran.
In Moscow, President Yeltsin was appreciative of President Clinton's visit -- but not enough to cancel Russia's deal to build a nuclear plant in Iran, the centerpiece of the new Iranian network.
Having cut off its own trade, the U.S. can and should now let our allies, plus Russia and China, know what it will do to persuade them to help prevent a nuclear Iran.
Next month at a meeting in Halifax of major industrial nations, including Russia, the U.S. will try again to convince them to join in economic measures against Iran.
But they should also be told that if President Clinton fails, either he or Congress will bar imports into the U.S. of companies that do business with Iran -- as formally proposed by Senator Alfonse D'Amato, Representative Peter King and other legislators.
Europe would be shocked -- they don't believe Mr. Clinton has it in him. Even Beijing might be less haughty. The companies peddling equipment and specialists to Iran are part of the economic empire of the Chinese Army, which provides a superb cash flow to the Politburo.
If Mr. Yeltsin turns the U.S. down again, Washington will have to choose between the likelihood of making more Russian nationalists mad at him and the certainty of making Iran nuclear. Closing U.S. ports to imports of Russian companies and agencies that build Iran's nuclear capability might work. If not -- then suspend American aid. Anything else would turn the U.S. from Mr. Yeltsin's friend to his hostage.
The goal is to block Iranian nuclear power. But there's a bonus -- getting some clear answers to the questions in the opening paragraphs of this column.

HEADLINE: New York Commits Budget Suicide

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"In New York, the Dying Days of Expansive Government" (front page, May 8) lays out a familiar argument: Slash government spending so we can cut taxes; then people can spend more and stimulate the economy. But much of what would be cut is essential for New York to be an effective, working community. 
 You don't get much support these days arguing that budget cuts will damage the lives of defenseless people. But if we cripple New York's infrastructure, we won't keep jobs, businesses and taxpayers around very long, regardless of tax cuts.
What happens if we cut mental health, alcoholism and drug treatment programs; cut off welfare for supposedly "employable" men and women after 60 days, and reduce housing assistance?
We would have tens of thousands more homeless and mentally ill people on our streets. What will that do to New York's attractiveness as a place to live and do business?
Gov. George E. Pataki wants to cut Medicaid spending by more than $3 billion -- half of it Federal matching aid we'd give back to Washington. Put aside for a moment what that will do to the elderly, disabled, and children who depend on it.
When hospitals lose Medicaid funds (more than $1 billion under the Governor's budget), they don't lay off nurses and doctors who only treat Medicaid patients. Even the wealthiest New Yorker who is wheeled in with a heart attack will get poorer quality care. Many will die.
New York's world-class hospitals depend on Medicaid revenue. Undermine them and you undermine New York's attractiveness to executives who make job-location decisions.
The Governor would cut more than $1 billion from the State and City Universities and from elementary and secondary schools. How can we thrive in the modern world if our young people go looking for work with a poorer quality education?
It hurts our economy if transit cutbacks mean that a business executive has to wonder when employees will arrive for work.
Thousands of years ago on the banks of the Tigris and Euphrates, villagers got together to build irrigation systems and huts to store grain. Ever since then, any community's ability to work and succeed has depended on its public sector.
Governor Pataki said in his State of the State Message, "When government takes responsibility for people, people stop taking responsibility for themselves." He's got it backward. When government shirks its responsibilities, our communities and our people cannot grow and prosper.
 
RICHARD N. GOTTFRIED
Chmn., Assembly Health Committee
Albany, May 9, 1995

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
For the Pirates, the Past Is a Lonely Hideaway

BYLINE: By Murray Chass 

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH

 BODY:
As Frank Sinatra said, when he could still put the words to good music, there used to be a ball park here. It was Forbes Field, and it served as the home park of the Pittsburgh Pirates for 61 years. Remnants of the park serve as reminders that before there were University of Pittsburgh buildings, there was a ball park here.
The center field wall, with its "457 FT" sign, and the right-center wall, with its "436 FT" marking, stand next to the building that houses the Joseph M. Katz Graduate School of Business. Home plate, the home plate that was in the ground for the last game in 1970, survives, too. It is under glass in the lobby of Forbes Quadrangle, home of the university's anthropology, black studies, economics and political science departments, among others. 
 Clemente Drive separates the buildings. Where the great Roberto once roamed, cars drive along, the occupants of most unaware of the sacred ground they violate but some occasionally stopping to gaze at the wall and remember.
The irony is that when the city and the team get around to building a new ball park, it will be Forbes Field, preferably without the view-obstructing posts. Three Rivers Stadium, the cookie-cutter multi-purpose edifice, has outlived its usefulness. Circumstances cry out for the new "old-fashioned" park of the type that has been a huge hit in Baltimore, Cleveland and Texas.
If the Pirates are to get a new home, they can only hope their timing matches that of the Indians, who not only have moved into a new park but also have moved into contending status for the first time in more than four decades. Like many of those Indians teams of the intervening period, the 1995 Pirates are dreadful.
"The thing that eats at me is when people ask what's wrong with this team," Jim Leyland, the Pirates' beleaguered manager, said yesterday by telephone from Los Angeles. "They expect us to be competing for a division title. I'm not going to try to fool people."
Leyland, as good a manager as baseball has, surprised people last week when he basically exploded at a questioner asking what was wrong with the Pirates. Thinking the answer should be obvious, Leyland said the Pirates have about nine players who belong in Class AAA and about five who should be in Class AA. That's the minor leagues.
Furthermore, he pointed out to anyone who had missed their departure, the Pirates no longer have the players who helped them win three consecutive division championships -- Barry Bonds, Bobby Bonilla, Doug Drabek, John Smiley, Andy Van Slyke.
The Pirate owners, giving a Tony-winning performance in their role of the hapless, helpless and hopeless small-market team, like to talk about how they couldn't afford to sign those players to prevent them from leaving. But with most of those stars, the Pirates chose to play economic hardball every step of the negotiating way rather than try to work out long-term, less expensive deals before the players could become free agents.
The Indians have executed that strategy remarkably well with their young stars, accomplishing their economic and talent goals before they became contenders. The Pirates became contenders without a signing strategy. That's why they are a contender no longer.
The new owner hopes to change all that. That is, he will if he becomes the new owner. John Rigas, a cable television entrepreneur, has been negotiating with the current owners and city officials for months trying to reach an agreement. The mental health of anyone desirous of buying a baseball team in these uncertain times is instantly questioned, but Rigas approaches the venture with sound mind and vision.
The primary hangup in the negotiations has been the desire of the current owners to have Rigas assume the losses they will incur this season, before the transaction is completed. Mayor Tom Murphy appears ready to help get the two parties over that hurdle.
On the other hand, some people familiar with the negotiations feel that some corporate members of ownership wouldn't mind having the deal fall through so they could sell the club for more money to a buyer who would move the Pirates to a city without a team.
The group that has owned the Pirates for nearly 10 years is a weird conglomeration of three individuals, one university, two banks and four major corporations. They apparently are not all civic-minded.
City officials would do everything possible to short-circuit any effort to move the team. Mayor Murphy has been aggressive in his behind-the-scenes efforts, and they could lead to a handshake agreement soon. To enhance the Pirates as an attraction and make it possible for a new owner to flourish, officials also know it's imperative to find a way to build a new Forbes Field.
Nothing will help the Pirates this season. The team is bad, and the crowds reflect its sad state. For the first eight home dates, the Pirates are 30,000 behind last year's attendance. Four of their crowds have been in the 7,000 range, a level they didn't see in the corresponding period a year ago.
"The bottom line is you have to put a good product on the field," Leyland said. "That entices the people. They're not staying away just because of the strike. It's because of the way we're playing. If we had the team we had in '91, they'd be coming out. They'd be teed off, but they'd be coming out. The only way to get them back is to have a good team, put a good product out there and treat the people the way they should be treated."

HEADLINE: A Driving Force Off Broadway

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

 BODY:
"Don't worry; it's not a real dead body," Ben Sprecher said reassuringly, leading the way into his theater.
In the bed center stage at the Promenade was the withered corpse of C, the otherwise nameless protagonist of "Three Tall Women," which is now in its second profitable year at Mr. Sprecher's profitable theater. 
 "We do Theaterworks in here on weekends," he continued, "and one time the lights were off and Sheldon Harnick was groping around in the dark and found it. I thought he was going to die."
Mr. Sprecher, too, was in the right place at the right time when the theater world, searching for a way out of the nightmarish economics of Broadway, stumbled on him.
Only about a dozen desirable Off Broadway theaters are available for rent. Mr. Sprecher owns or manages three of them: the Promenade on the Upper West Side, the Variety Arts in the East Village and the Lucille Lortel in Greenwich Village. All three are bustling: the 399-seat Promenade has the Pulitzer-winning play by Edward Albee; the 499-seat Variety Arts has "Death Defying Acts," a trio of one-acts by Woody Allen, David Mamet and Elaine May that opened to rave reviews, and the 299-seat Lortel just closed "Camping With Henry and Tom," which won an award as best Off Broadway play. (Admittedly, it looked a little awkward because it was the Lucille Lortel Award, which Miss Lortel underwrites and votes on and Mr. Sprecher administers, but a battery of independent critics voted, too.)
Plays are lined up to fill them. Steve Martin's "Picasso at the Lapin Agile" has put down a deposit on the Promenade; four or five plays are angling for the Variety Arts when "Death Defying Acts" peters out. The Lortel already has Uta Hagen in "Mrs. Klein" booked for the fall and will probably tide itself over the summer with a one-woman show about Marlene Dietrich starring a Norwegian actress named Torill.
Producers who have been known to be peevish give raves to Mr. Sprecher's managerial skills.
"He has carte blanche with the theater, which is the highest compliment we can pay anybody," said Gerald Schoenfeld, chairman of the Shubert chain, which has a reputation for running its theaters well. It owns 10 percent of the Variety Arts.
Even the producer James Freydberg, who had a screaming fight with Mr. Sprecher last year when Mr. Freydberg posted a closing notice on his play "Those the River Keeps" before it opened in a maneuver to try to get his rent deposit back to spend on advertising the play if the reviews were good.
Mr. Freydberg, who has produced three plays at the Promenade, still says: "Ben's extremely honest, not at all slippery, like some of the Off Broadway owners I've done business with. A deal's a deal with him, and no nonsense.
"Plus, his theaters are impeccably managed. The bathrooms are clean; the seats aren't broken; the box office is courteous. He understands that the patron needs to be respected.
"The only thing he does that drives me crazy is that even though he's rooting for you while you're in previews, he's out trying to rent the theater in case you fail. He's overanxious."
Anxiety works for Mr. Sprecher. He's the rare Off Broadway type routinely spotted in French cuffs and a yellow power tie who can also, like an actor, offer an 8-by-10 glossy of himself and fax over a succinct biography. Ask producers who've worked with him for a funny Ben Sprecher anecdote, and they draw blanks. "Hmm . . . gee . . . he's a real professional" is the standard reply.
But someone who was across the table from him during the last contract talks with the press agents' union called him "arrogant and really tough."
"It was like being hit with a ton of bricks," said the press agent, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "Of course," he reflected, "that may have been just a tactic."
As treasurer of the League of Off Broadway Theaters, Mr. Sprecher is a lead negotiator.
"Oh, sure, tough," said Elizabeth McCann, the producer of "Three Tall Women." "He amuses me because sometimes feels he has to be really firm. And I say, 'Oh, c'mon, Grumpy. You know you're really Bashful.' "
Mr. Sprecher, 40, is the son of a pharmacist and a high school teacher. He grew up in the San Fernando Valley of California, a gymnast and water-skier who studied theater design at California State University at Northridge.
He did the lighting for the rock group Earth, Wind and Fire and ran a San Diego dinner theater before moving to New York in 1975 to be a stage manager at Town Hall. He soon shifted to tours and was constantly on the road with shows like "A Little Night Music," "The World of Sholom Aleichem" and "The Mitzi Gaynor Show."
"By 1981, I got tired of never unpacking my bags, and Lucille Lortel had an opening," he said. "It looked good. As a theater manager, you're never out of work."
At 26, he was sure he knew where Broadway was heading, and he wanted his own theater. He found the Promenade, a former theater and church in a building at Broadway and 76th Street that was changing from a welfare hotel into co-ops. A hunt for investors brought him to William P. Miller, a semi-retired securities lawyer who prodded his partners to buy in "as a recreational investment."
"Hurlyburly," a David Rabe play that churned movie stars through the cast, put the theater on the map in 1984.
The economics are Spartan. The house can sell about $110,000 worth of tickets a week; the actors earn Off Broadway scale ($544 a week minimum, versus about $975 on Broadway). The box office has two people, not five, as a Broadway theater might. "Three Tall Women" has a wardrobe mistress and shares Mr. Sprecher's two house stagehands. On Sundays and Mondays, James Lecesne's one-man show "Word of Mouth" plays in front of the Albee set. At lunchtime on weekends, the Theaterworks/USA children's theater performs. Tucking in extra shows, nearly impossible under Broadway contracts, makes a theater far more efficient.
In 1990, Mr. Sprecher raised $1.5 million to buy the Variety Arts, a 1911 nickelodeon house that had sunk to running porn films. "Bill and I went in to take a look," he said, "and he's watching the movie while I'm going, 'Y'know, it's column-free. It's got a balcony. I could build a theater in here.' "
Presumably, he will outgrow managing the Lortel. Miss Lortel said recently that she would leave it in her will to someone who loves theater and needs a home. "Like the Signature Theater," she said, "or Andre Bishop if he didn't have his own place at Lincoln Center."
He could still manage it, she said. Mr. Sprecher declined to discuss that but has higher ambitions. He is producing shows at the Lortel: he was behind "Annie Warbucks" and is behind "Word of Mouth." He is working on a burlesque revue called "Variety Scandals" and a new John Pielmayer play, "Voices in the Dark."
He shuns the sobriquet "the Shubert of Off Broadway," pinned on him by Theater Week magazine, but he is still hunting for one more theater.
He's picky. It must have 499 seats and not be in a "questionable location," but be outside the "Broadway grid" -- Avenue of the Americas to Ninth Avenue from 34th to 72d Street -- because, he said, "once you're eligible for Tonys, you get a lot of problems."
It took "Death Defying Acts" to beat the questionable-location jinx on the Variety Arts, on Third Avenue at 13th Street.
He opened that house with "Return to the Forbidden Planet" on Sept. 27, 1991. The very next night, he married Amy Smukler, an actress whose picture he spotted in a stack of resumes. Why? Because it saved his parents a second trip from California. Efficiency works for him, too.

HEADLINE: Mental Illness Found Rising in Poor Nations

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, May 15

 BODY:
Mental illness and behavioral problems are on the increase in the world's poorest nations, even as advances are made against debilitating or fatal physical diseases, a team of experts assembled by Harvard Medical School said here today.
The deterioration in mental and social health threatens more violence, ethnic conflict and instability in developing nations, the team warned in a study prepared by 88 specialists from 30 countries. The study, "World Mental Health: Problems and Priorities in Low-Income Countries," being published as a book by Oxford University Press, was issued here as part of an effort by the authors to involve the United Nations in drawing attention to the problem. 
 "It is a myth that mental health is not a serious global problem," Arthur Kleinman, a co-author and the originator of the study, said in an interview from Boston on Sunday before coming to New York today to present the findings to Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali.
"Nothing could be farther from the truth," said Dr. Kleinman, an anthropologist and psychiatrist who has been studying mental health in Asia, primarily China, since 1968. He is calling for a world summit meeting on the issue, similar to those held in recent years on population and poverty. "The problem is broad, not just neuropsychiatric disorders, but also behavioral problems like substance abuse and violence."
There is an important link to the United Nations, Dr. Kleinman said. "What this book does is demonstrate that major demographic shifts, ethnic conflict, refugee movements, internal displacement, the international drug trade, the growth of megacities and to some extent economic restructuring have contributed to these problems."
The experts found that in many countries rapid social and economic changes are creating special stresses on the elderly.
Dr. Kleinman said national governments as well as international organizations needed to focus on mental and behavioral problems, which are often relegated to the margins of policy in some countries because of the stigma attached to the mentally ill.
Yet in many poor countries of what is called the global South there are imaginative and successful small efforts to deal with personal and community breakdowns, Dr. Kleinman said.
He described programs in Thailand in which Buddhist monks work with narcotics abusers and in Malaysia, where healers called "drug bomohs" treat heroin addiction in communal settings. In South India, women enrolled in an adult literacy program in Andhra Pradesh became the core of a large women's movement against alcoholism. More than 6,000 local liqour shops were closed in the state. In Swaziland, in southern Africa, community mental health programs involve traditional healers, public health workers and family members.
In many areas of the world, locally available herbs and familiar practices -- acupuncture, for example, or massage -- are employed.
These kinds of programs need national and international support, Dr. Kleinman said. "Few local intervention programs in the South are implemented at the national level," he said.
Among the findings of the study, conducted by Harvard Medical School's department of social medicine with the support of several foundations, are these:
*Mental retardation and epilepsy rates are up to five times as high in poor nations as they are in richer ones. In certain Asian and African nations, up to 90 percent of sufferers go untreated because anti-convulsive medications are not available or are too expensive.
*Reported schizophrenia cases in poor countries are likely to rise to 24.4 million by the century's end from 16.5 million in 1985. By 2025, three-quarters of the world's dementia cases will be in the developing world.
*Domestic violence and the abuse of children is high in many low-income societies. From 20 to 75 percent of married women in developing countries are victims of domestic violence. The use of minors in the commercial sex industry and slavery, and the abandonment of unwanted children are becoming "endemic" in many parts of the world.
*More than 40 million refugees and internally displaced people run a high risk of depression, anxiety disorders and other forms of mental distress caused by political violence.
The report recommends a major world initiative to upgrade mental health services in Africa, Asia, Latin America and the Middle East, with emphasis on the training of more health workers.
The researchers say that mental and behavioral problems cannot be isolated from general health and adverse living conditions, including poverty, high unemployment, overcrowding and sex discrimination.
Dr. Veena Das of the Delhi School of Economics in India, said at a news conference here today that ignoring mental and behavioral problems could have consequences not only in economic growth but also in political development, as societies become cynical about politicians' ability to deal with fundamental social disruptions.
"One reason why governments will be made to pay attention is precisely because in countries like India the future of democracy may be at stake," she said.

HEADLINE: Future of Endangered Species Act in Doubt as Law Is Debated

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS 

 BODY:
THE Endangered Species Act, hailed by its supporters as the strongest conservation law in the world, has come under heavy criticism in Congress, and its future is in doubt.
Although the act seemed to champion odd creatures like the snail darter and the furbish lousewort, it has been used by conservationists for a broader purpose: protecting whole ecosystems and their associated plants and animals, as in the case of the spotted owl, whose protection may have saved the old growth forests of the Pacific Northwest. 
 This bold and effective use of the act affected loggers, landowners and property-rights advocates, who are seeking radical changes in the 22-year-old act that is now up for renewal. One of the favored instruments of opponents of the act is a bill introduced last week by Senator Slade Gorton, Republican of Washington, that in effect would abolish the Government's principal method of enforcing the law on private property: fines or imprisonment for those who destroy the habitat of an endangered species.
The bill would also eliminate other important protections of the law, including its objective of conserving "the ecosystems upon which endangered species and threatened species depend."
"The Gorton bill upends every aspect of the act," said John Kostyack, counsel for the National Wildlife Federation.
A memorandum by a Gorton aide that came to light last month shows that representatives of timber, mining, ranching and utility interests were heavily involved in drawing up the bill.
House Republicans are preparing their own bill. Meanwhile, another measure already passed by the House would require the Government to compensate landowners whose property values are reduced by Federal regulation, including those under the Endangered Species Act. The Clinton Administration supports the act, though it would like to see it made less onerous for small landowners. The outcome of the impending political fight is uncertain but environmentalists fear that one way or another, the law is in grave danger.
Opponents of the Endangered Species Act raise a number of objections. For one, they assert that its regulation of habitat exerts a drag on the economy, driving down land values and "locking up" large acreages so that they cannot generate economic growth. They cite a number of studies by real estate, agricultural and timber interests to support their case.
One such study, by the Texas and Southwestern Cattle Raisers Association, concluded that real estate values had been depressed in vast stretches of the Texas hill country where the endangered golden-cheeked warbler lives. Turmoil over endangered species has been especially strong and visible there, and landowners throughout the the hill country are reportedly destroying potential warbler habitats to escape the possible consequences of the law.
Asserting that the act had turned into "a growth control ordinance," Representative Richard W. Pombo, a conservative Republican from California who heads a special House panel that is developing legislation on the subject, said, "We're going to try to stop that."
But conservationists, arguing that protected habitat often enhanced the value of neighboring land, cite contrary studies. For example, a recent analysis by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Project on Environmental Politics and Policy, found that while endangered-species listings might cause some local harm, economic data "strongly contradict the assertion that the Endangered Species Act has had harmful effects on state economies."
Dr. Stephen M. Meyer, director of the M.I.T. analysis, says the warbler study, when corrected for analytical errors, shows there is no difference in real estate values between Texas counties with and without endangered species habitat.
A second argument by opponents of the act is that the owners of land where endangered species have been declared to live have not been compensated for the fall in their property values.
Conservationists say instances of property value loss are not widespread but they agree there should be some mechanism to relieve owners who are genuinely affected by the act. "From a private landowner's point of view, the Endangered Species Act looks like a nuclear weapon," said George Frampton, Assistant Secretary of the Interior for fish, wildlife and parks.
A third contention by the act's opponents is that endangered species can be protected without saving every subspecies and subpopulation. "Do you really need 65 subspecies?" House Speaker Newt Gingrich has asked. Biologists reply that many subspecies and subpopulations are indeed needed because it is impossible to predict which genetic strain has the best chance of assuring the species' survival in the long run.
How well has the act worked in practice? Conservation biologists generally see the law as "the most effective tool in the tool kit for preserving this country's biological diversity," said Dr. Dennis D. Murphy of Stanford University, president-elect of the Society for Conservation Biology. In particular, he said, the law has become the "hammer" that forces disputing parties to the table to work out compromises that protect species and their habitats from encroachments of development.
As to whether the act has worked as well as it could, Dr. Murphy said, "the answer is unequivocally no." But he fears that "the 104th Congress is going to throw out the baby with the bath water."
The bare numbers show how many American plants and animals are in dire need of the act's protection. More than 950 domestic species of plants and animals and more than 560 foreign species, which are protected in trade, are currently listed as endangered or imminently threatened with endangerment. More than 3,900 others, accounting for 3 percent of all known species in the country, are candidates for listing. Nearly two-thirds of mammals are either listed or candidates, along with 14 percent of birds, 12 percent of plants and 10 percent of fish.
The good news is that although only seven species have recovered enough to be removed from the domestic roster of imperilment, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service says that nearly 40 percent of the listed domestic species are either stable or improving.
What can be done to reconcile the needs of species and their habitats with those of the private economy?
The Clinton Administration, agreeing with many conservation biologists, has adopted a strategy of relying first on Federal lands, which are at least nominally protected by a variety of conservation laws. Where private land is unavoidably involved, Mr. Frampton says, the act has the flexibility to allow for a number of innovative tactics now being tried.
For example, some real estate developers are being required to pay a fee for destroying habitat. The fee then goes into a fund to buy other tracts of habitat or to buy permanent conservation easements from private landowners. The object is to stitch together a large habitat block or network. Advocates of this "mitigation" arrangement liken the assessment on developers to "impact" fees that are routinely paid to help provide schools and streets.
The Clinton Administration has taken the lead, along with some states like California, in moving toward regional conservation plans based on this principle, encompassing whole ecosystems and multiple species. The most notable example, perhaps, is in Southern California, where the endangered California gnatcatcher has been the catalyst for a regional multispecies protection plan.
No one considers this type of solution to be perfect. These types of plans are still "rough-hewn," says Dr. Murphy, not least because scientists are not yet able to identify which patches of land are most important. Moreover, the approach still imposes some cost on those who develop the land, and it allows some habitat to be destroyed. In many instances, Dr. Murphy says, there is not enough habitat to begin with, meaning that what is left must be intensively managed by humans.
Still, the mitigation approach, which Mr. Pombo says he favors, appears to provide some landowners with an incentive, by virtue of being paid for a permanent conservation easement, to conserve habitat rather than destroy it. Many parties, including some environmentalists, have strongly advocated incorporating positive incentives into the act.
The Gorton bill provides for federally financed incentives to state and local governments for the planning and execution of habitat conservation plans on land they own or control. Some conservationists envision the setting up of a Federal conservation trust fund that would dole out incentives and, as a last resort, buy private property outright for conservation purposes.
Given the tidal wave in favor of Government retrenchment and budget-cutting, that sort of ambitious program is widely considered dead for now. For many conservationists, this means that the imperfect mitigation solutions -- made workable by the carrot of positive incentives and the stick of the Endangered Species Act -- may be the best that can be hoped for just now. And so the struggle over whether to retain the stick and what incentives to provide is being joined.

HEADLINE: A Budget Harsher Than It Seems

 BODY:
Now we know how House Republicans hope to pay for the huge $350 billion tax cut they have promised -- with rosy projections of savings and revenues that may never materialize. If the forecasts go awry, the Republicans would be forced in future years to clamp down on spending even more harshly than they are now proposing.
Both Representative John Kasich, chairman of the House Budget Committee, and Senator Pete Domenici, his Senate counterpart, have proposed cutting domestic discretionary spending by 30 percent to balance the budget by 2002. But Mr. Kasich needs to find far more savings than Mr. Domenici, whose plan does not include tax cuts that are heavily weighted toward upper-income families. 
 Budget experts are still puzzling over Mr. Kasich's numbers. But it is already obvious that Mr. Kasich would cut much more than Mr. Domenici from entitlements such as Medicare, Medicaid and welfare programs. To help offset tax cuts that would reach $90 billion annually in the year 2002, Mr. Kasich would chop Medicare by $25 billion more than Mr. Domenici in that year, Medicaid by $4 billion more, welfare and other programs for the unemployed and low-income families by perhaps $8 billion more.
These Kasich add-ons are harsh, but they do not come close to paying for his tax cut. So Mr. Kasich resorts to three flights of optimism.
The Government plans to revise the formula it uses to measure inflation. The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office expects the change to lower the official inflation rate, which would reduce the amount Washington pays in Social Security and pension benefits. Mr. Kasich estimates that the budget savings from the new formula will be three times larger -- about $15 billion in 2002 -- than the C.B.O. or Mr. Domenici build into their forecasts.
Mr. Kasich also adopts a C.B.O. estimate that if Congress adopts a balanced budget it will drive interest rates down and produce a $50 billion budget savings in 2002. Many economists are uneasy about the budget office estimate, and Mr. Domenici used none of the potential savings to balance his budget. He promised instead to use the savings to cut taxes only if the interest rate drops should occur. Mr. Kasich also builds into his budget a saving of $7.5 billion in 2002 from the elimination of corporate tax loopholes -- loopholes that leaders in his party want to preserve.
The upshot is that Mr. Kasich balanced his tax cut with more than $50 billion of hope. His numbers, though not wacky, are imprudent.
Even Mr. Domenici's relatively cautious budget would impose gargantuan cuts on Medicare (15 percent), Medicaid (30 percent) and domestic discretionary spending (30 percent). Mr. Kasich would pile on steeper cuts on Medicare, Medicaid and welfare to pay for tax cuts that enrich corporations and wealthy families. Worse yet, if Mr. Kasich's optimism proves wrong, the G.O.P. could be forced to cut another $70 billion in a single year.

HEADLINE: The Mayor and the Overseers

 BODY:
Never one to welcome criticism, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has responded petulantly to critiques of New York City's budget proposals by a state fiscal monitor. The Mayor thinks it would be a good idea to eliminate the monitor's job entirely. His pique is misplaced. The worst fiscal crisis in a generation is no time to discard the very agents that lend the city needed financial credibility.
The target of Mr. Giuliani's ire is the office of State Deputy Comptroller for New York City, a monitor created as the price for the state bailing the city out from bankruptcy in 1975. But the man who signs his name at the bottom of the deputy's financial reports (and at the top of the press releases) is State Comptroller Carl McCall, a potential candidate for mayor in the next election. Mr. Giuliani is crying foul, charging that the criticism is tainted. 
 In fact, the State Comptroller's reports have been fair, calling attention to important truths about Mr. Giuliani's budget proposals. The reports cite the potential weakness of the city's economy, the budget's reliance on savings from hypothetical state actions and labor concessions, and the use of one-time-only revenues to pay for ongoing expenses, among other questionable practices.
These points are surely on target. They are a main reason why Standard & Poor's has put the city on notice of a possible downgrading of its credit rating. For a city that has gotten into so much trouble in past years because of overreliance on dubious budget assumptions and financial gimmickry, the State Comptroller's office serves as a useful early warning signal for trouble.
If the Comptroller's reports have been judicious, the same cannot be said for Mr. McCall's response to the Mayor. In his first year in office, Mr. McCall erred in too eagerly cheerleading for his friend and political ally, Mayor David Dinkins. Now, in hinting and then hedging about a run for mayor if Mr. Giuliani did not provide "effective leadership," Mr. McCall has undermined his own credibility as Comptroller and given the Mayor ammunition to use against him. Both Mr. Giuliani and Mr. McCall should settle down and recognize that their disagreements are both inevitable and healthy.
Mr. Giuliani makes a good point when he complains that the city has to pay for the cost of not only the Deputy State Comptroller's office, but the Municipal Assistance Corporation and the State Financial Control Board, two other monitoring agencies, as well. All three were created during the 1975 fiscal crisis, and it may well be time to reassess whether there is needless duplication. But there should be a presumption in favor of intense monitoring. As the city struggles to remain solvent, the Mayor has to make tough decisions on cutting the budget without eviscerating services. The monitors are one of the public's best guarantees that the numbers add up.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
MASSACHUSETTS APPROVES NYNEX PRICE CAP REGULATION

BYLINE: Dow Jones 

 BODY:
The Massachusetts Department of Public Utilities has approved a petition by the Nynex Corporation to replace traditional "cost plus" regulation of its rates and profits with an alternative form of regulation called a price cap. The utilities department said that with the price cap, rate payers would benefit because Nynex's rates would be controlled according to a formula that accounts for inflation, productivity growth and certain other changes in costs that were beyond the control of the company. But the regulators would no longer directly control the level of Nynex's profits and the company could not pass costs of new technology on to customers. Rates for basic residential services will be frozen until August 2001.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Continue Rise in Light Trading

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities continued their recent rally yesterday, with both the 30-year bond and bills of shorter maturity rising.
The long bond was up 19/32 , to a price of 10817/32 for a yield, which moves in the opposite direction of price, of 6.94 percent, down from 7 percent on Friday. Bills were up an average of two basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. 
 Trading was described as light early in the session, only to get even lighter going into the afternoon. Dealers and traders said market sentiment, however, was still bullish.
Anthony Dwyer, chief market strategist at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, said that one reason bonds were higher yesterday was because "their real rates of return, or the yield less inflation, still made bonds the attractive investment."
"I think the long-bond yield is going to go anywhere between 6.25 percent and 6.50 percent over the intermediate term," he said, "as the technical forces in the market point in that direction." But, he added, "You can expect pauses along the way."
Analysts cited other reasons for the gains. Despite yesterday's easing by the dollar, bonds continued to draw strength from the currency's gains last week after its months-long slide, some said, as well as from the tough stance taken by Washington toward Japan in trade talks.
The strong dollar tempers fears of inflation and also make Treasury securities more attractive to foreign investors.
Other market participants also attributed some gains to talk of reducing the trade deficit and to rumors that a prestigious Washington research center had predicted the Federal Reserve would ease monetary policy in July. But a number of trading desks said they had not even heard that rumor and that the Fed was more likely to raise interest rates again before it would consider lowering them.
Today the Fed will release capacity utilization and industrial production numbers for April. "Last month those numbers suggested a slowing," Mr. Dwyer, "and there is no reason to believe that they will be any different tomorrow.
"With the economy appearing to be slowing," he said, "it suggests that the Fed will no longer be in a tightening mode, and given the real rates of return, investors who find the yield on the long bond attractive, will continue to do so. People are trying to extrapolate too many fundamentals into the long bond's rally."
At the Treasury's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, rates were up slightly, with the three-month maturity up 8 basis points, to 5.71 percent, and the six-month maturity up 4 basis points, to 5.69 percent.
Some tough talk between the United States and Japan includes a target list of possible trade sanctions, which could be released today, according to the trade representative's office. After publication, there will be 30 days' public comment before the list is narrowed for maximum impact in Japan and minimum impact on American interests. But 30 days also leaves time for negotiators to pull off an agreement.
In the municipal-bond market, declining yields induced issuers to consider refinancing oustanding debt, traders said. The Bond Buyer's index of 40 municipal issues dropped 3 basis points, as the average yield to maturity fell to 6.17 percent.
The following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new three- and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: Legal System and Science Come to Differing Conclusions on Silicone

BYLINE: By GINA KOLATA 

 BODY:
In the case of silicone breast implants, the courts and much of the scientific world have proceeded on strikingly unparallel tracks. While the courts have handed down multimillion-dollar awards based on the presumption of a health hazard, leading yesterday to Dow Corning's declaration of bankruptcy, the heavy-duty scientific studies now being completed have pointed to exactly the opposite conclusion, that there is no evidence that breast implants are harmful.
Part of the reason for this clash of cultures is that the legal world looks at individual cases of illness, whereas scientists hold that specially designed studies of whole populations are the only sure touchstone of truth. The cases that have convinced the courts concern women who complain of debilitating and mysterious maladies that they attribute to silicone leaking from their breast implants. Several years ago, those individual cases, typically described as "anecdotes" by scientists, prompted several epidemiological studies to be undertaken in an effort to search for statistically valid links between the implants and any disease. 
 The conclusions of seven large epidemiological studies have now been reported, with the surprising result that none have found any evidence of health effects from breast implants.
These findings have carried particular weight among scientists. "I don't know a single, high-quality immunologist who is convinced that there is a definable disease related to implants," said Dr. John Sergent, a professor of medicine at Vanderbilt University in Nashville and a former president of the American College of Rheumatology.
Health officials in other countries have also been convinced by the epidemiological studies. France allowed the implants back on the market in February and Britain's Medical Devices Agency, which never stopped the sale of the implants, concluded again in December that they were safe.
The beginning of the end for breast implants in the United States came in 1992, when Dr. David A. Kessler, the head of the Food and Drugs Administration, said his agency was calling a voluntary moratorium on their use. He said the data on record were not sufficient to show that implants were safe and he was concerned by the numbers of women who had come forward with health complaints.
Lawsuits by women claiming injury then began to snowball. Many were based on the theory that although silicone was an inert substance, it or its breakdown products nonetheless deranged the immune system, causing a variety of otherwise inexplicable maladies.
Medical experts summoned by the plaintiffs cited experiments showing that silicone could harm the immune systems of mice. Like many such experts, Dr. Nir Kossovsky, a materials scientist at the University of California at Los Angeles, who runs a testing laboratory for women with implants, said this "means that silicone can account for many of the symptoms reported by breast implant patients."
These experts have also criticized the epidemiological studies, saying that had they continued for longer or examined more women they would have found the same kind of illnesses that afflicted the plaintiffs.
But scientists who are convinced by the new epidemiological studies view the treatment of the issue in the courts as a regrettable misuse of scientific evidence. They regard the medical experts who testified for the plaintiffs as hired guns who do not represent the consensus of opinion developing in the medical field.
Dr. Shaun Ruddy of the Medical College of Virginia, the president of the American College of Rheumatology and a specialist in connective tissue diseases like those being claimed by women with implants, said that so much money was at stake that "it is very easy for people to lose their objectivity." He said he knew of academic doctors who started filling out forms for lawyers "at 1,000 bucks a pop."
"I'm tremendously bothered," said Dr. Elizabeth Connell, a professor of gynecology and obstetrics at Emory University School of Medicine in Atlanta. "I'm horrified."
Dr. Connell led a Food and Drug Administration advisory panel that concluded in 1991 that implants represented a public health need and should remain on the market while studies continued. In a second meeting, the group concluded in 1992 that there was still no evidence positively linking the implants to diseases and that a need for them remained, but it recommended that women receiving implants be followed in scientific studies.
In response to daily requests for interviews over the last week, Dr. Kessler's office repeatedly said that he was unavailable.
Dr. Bernadine Healy, a former director of the National Institutes of Health who is now director of health and science policy at the Cleveland Clinic, described the implant litigation as "an abomination for women," adding, "It's an abomination economically." She said women were the pawns and the losers in what she regarded as a trial lawyers' game. "I find it hideous," she said.
Scientists who have produced evidence or spoken against the link between implants and illness say their treatment by the plaintiffs' lawyers amounted to harassment in some cases. One of the most influential papers that criticized the supposed link between implants and disease appeared on June 14, 1994, in The New England Journal of Medicine. It was a study by Dr. Sherine E. Gabriel and her colleagues at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn.
The study examined the medical records of all the residents of Olmsted County, Minn., from 1964 to 1991, just before the implants were removed from the market. A long list of medical problems, including connective tissue diseases, was studied and the conclusion was that of 749 women with implants, none had excess medical problems.
Dr. Gabriel's study was accompanied by an editorial by Dr. Marcia Angell, the executive editor of the journal, noting that the courts had granted multimillion-dollar awards based on case histories that by no means showed cause and effect. Yet, she said, this misleading information "became accepted by the courts and the public as nearly incontrovertible truth."
Dr. Gabriel said that she was not naive when she published her paper, and that she knew it would infuriate lawyers for women with implants, particularly because it was financed in part by the Plastic Surgery Educational Foundation, the educational arm of the American Society of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgeons.
But, she said, she had never taken sides on the implant issue, the study had been conceived and designed by the Mayo Clinic investigators and had been under way for several months before the group received the grant from the plastic surgeons and she did not think anyone would seriously accuse her of bias.
As soon as the paper was published, plaintiffs' lawyers said the study was tainted because of the plastic surgeons' money. Dr. Gabriel faced demands for her documents from Charles E. Houssiere, a Houston lawyer who says he represents 2,000 to 3,000 women who are suing implant manufacturers.
"The magnitude of the demands is staggering; the burden is staggering," Dr. Gabriel said. "They want over 800 manuscripts from researchers that were here, they want hundreds of data bases, dozens of file cabinets and the entire medical records of all Olmsted County women, whether or not they were in the study."
The situation has continued for a year so far, Dr. Gabriel said. "It has taken a huge amount of time and it has been extremely stressful," she said. "It has severely compromised my ability to do research."
And, she said, it has had a chilling effect on implant research generally. She said colleagues had told her that after seeing what happened to her, they would not do an implant study. "Some determined that the price in terms of their own research careers is too high to pay," she said.
Mr. Houssiere said he asked for the documents to understand how Dr. Gabriel had concluded that there was no evidence that the implants caused illnesses. "The intent was to find out the basis of her opinion," he said. And, he added, he did find some things he will use against the implant makers in court.
Dr. Angell got the same sort of treatment -- voluminous requests for documents, this time from John O'Quinn, a Houston lawyer who says that he represents 2,000 women with implants. "I was subpoenaed twice -- once in November and once last month," Dr. Angell said. Her lawyers were able to quash the first subpoena but the second is pending, she added. "They wanted a large number of documents that don't even exist, alleging contact between me and the manufacturers," she said. "They thought the manufacturers paid me."
Mr. O'Quinn said of Dr. Angell, "Why doesn't she come clean and show us the documents?"
He said: "I thought we were in the truth business, but they don't want the truth out. I'd like to get her under oath."
Investigating what it found to be baseless charges by trial lawyers against another scientist, Dr. Peter Schur of Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston, a committee of the American College of Rheumatology wrote: "The committee is also aware that other rheumatologists who have expressed opinions or published work viewed as contrary to the interests of plaintiffs and plaintiffs' attorneys in implant-related litigation have been subjected to various forms of harassment in the work place or even at their homes. Much of this has been attributed to plaintiffs' attorneys."
The committee added that more than $4 billion was at stake in the litigation and that the college's board should "be free of any illusions as to the agenda potentially at work in the criticism of Dr. Schur or other rheumatologists.
"It also should not underestimate the vigor with which such an agenda could be pursued, given the resources at stake."
Dr. Sergent said: "It's a sad commentary. We're such a litigious society in every way. And there are so few curbs on this sort of behavior."
 The article also misstated his relationship to a testing laboratory for women with implants. While he has a financial interest in the lab, he does not operate it.

He is an associate professor of pathology who studies biomaterials, not a materials scientist.

LENGTH: 582 words

HEADLINE: Take the Lead, Mr. Clinton

BYLINE: By Matthew Miller; Matthew Miller resigned as senior adviser in the Office of Management and Budget in January.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
I left the Clinton Administration in January when the White House issued a budget that I felt turned away from its previous commitment to deficit reduction and sensible public investment.
Today, while supporting President Clinton in opposing the cruel and counterproductive Republican budget resolutions in the House and Senate, I also wonder why the White House has let the Republicans seize this issue. 
 Though the Administration is right to criticize plans that would cut spending for the most vulnerable Americans to help finance tax breaks for the well-off, it will not rally much support by hypocritically attacking cutbacks in Medicare and Medicaid or by resisting the idea of balancing the budget altogether.
Last week, the White House chief of staff, Leon Panetta, said that the Republicans would "make Medicare a second-class health care system for our seniors." The Administration's 1993 economic plan, "A Vision of Change for America," struck a different note. In it, the Administration hoped to "control the growth of Medicare and Medicaid spending in the long term, and thereby supplement the deficit reduction in this economic program."
Assuming "health care controls," the plan estimated that the deficit would decline to $87 billion in the year 2003 -- from what otherwise would have been $399 billion. Bringing down the combined annual growth rate of Medicare and Medicaid was the single most important factor in the reduction.
This slower growth would have meant saving about $66 billion yearly on average over a 10-year period. The Republican Senate budget resolution, by contrast, calls for savings that average $65 billion yearly over seven years, while the House resolution calls for $69 billion yearly over the same period.
It's hard to understand how a goal the Administration considered reasonable only two years ago can seem unthinkably draconian today.
Nor is the Republicans' aim of balancing the budget by 2002 as dangerous for the economy as the Administration suggests. Mainstream economists generally agree that reducing the deficit by the equivalent of 0.5 percent of the gross domestic product per year can be reliably offset by the Federal Reserve (for example, by lowering interest rates). With the Congressional Budget Office forecasting the deficit at 2.5 percent of the gross domestic product in 1995, that would mean a five-year path to a balanced budget by 2000 would be reasonable.
In any event, it would be far better policy and better politics for Mr. Clinton to take the lead by offering his own plan to balance the budget rather than merely sniping at the Republicans.
The G.O.P. resolutions would slash basic research, investment in infrastructure and in education, while leaving untouched most of the welfare for the well-off that permeates the budget. While families struggling on $35,000 a year would continue to bear a disproportionate tax burden, for example, $30 billion in health and pension benefits would still go every year to senior citizens who have incomes above $100,000 -- giving these retirees far more back than they paid into the system.
Yet all of the Administration's well-taken criticisms will be ignored if President Clinton does not renew his commitment to addressing the problem of the deficit. The Republicans' methods may be misguided, but the goal they have embraced is the right one. Mr. Clinton should waste no time in taking back an issue he claimed as his own from his first days in office.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

U.S. Sets 100% Tariffs On Japanese Luxury Cars
 The Clinton Administration placed a 100 percent tariff on 13 models of Japanese luxury cars, the largest tariff ever imposed by the United States against a trading partner. 
 Starting on Saturday, customs inspectors will double the wholesale price of every Toyota Lexus, Nissan Infiniti and several other cars that arrive from Japan. Administration officials said that the sanctions would be rescinded if the two countries could reach an accord by June 28. A1.
 Japan said it would take action to counter the U.S. tariffs by bringing the matter to the new World Trade Organization. D4.
 Toyota and Nissan said they would not pass the tariffs on to their dealers or customers at this time. Some analysts said that even if prices for Japanese luxury cars rose, buyers would switch to BMW or Mercedes, rather than Cadillac or Lincoln. D4.
 Many economists say Americans are unlikely to notice any of the pocketbook benefits they may anticipate from a trade battle with Japan. And they may end up paying an unexpectedly heavy price for a global order that serves America's interests. News Analysis. A1.
 
Bonds Surge on Economic Data
 Prices of Treasury securities rose sharply, as the market continued to rally on more data showing fresh signs of an economic slowdown. The price of the 30-year bond surged, and its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 6.86 percent, its lowest rate in 14 months. D6.
 The Dow fell 2.42 points, to 4,435.05, while the S.& P. 500 rose 0.45 point, to 528.19. D8.
 
Retailer Profits Decline
 Several retailers reported disappointing first-quarter earnings, as consumer demand softened for clothes and home furnishings. At Dayton Hudson, profits fell 72 percent. D2.
 
Shipyards Battle for Submarine
 General Dynamics and Tenneco are battling on Capitol Hill over which of their shipyards will win the $60 billion contract to build the Navy's new attack submarine. At stake are thousands of jobs in Connecticut and Virginia, homes of the shipyards. A1.
 
House Votes to Alter Water Act
 The House approved changes to the Clean Water Act, giving more authority to the states and more weight to economic considerations when setting water quality standards. A1.
 
Greenspan Hails Budget Plan
 In his first public comments since Congressional Republicans introduced plans to balance the budget by 2002, Alan Greenspan attributed the dollar's weakness to large Federal budget deficits and welcomed efforts to balance the budget. D2.
 
Bankers Trust Chairman to Retire
 In a surprise, Charles S. Sanford Jr., chairman of Bankers Trust New York, said he would retire next year, at the age of 60. D3.
 
Hewlett-Packard Shares Fall
 Hewlett-Packard shares fell $1.50, to $69.50, after reporting what Wall Street felt was a modest gain in second-quarter sales. The shares fell despite a 41 percent jump in earnings, to $577 million, or $1.10 a share. Sales rose 19 percent, to $7.43 billion. D3.
 
Better Days for I.B.M.
 Analysts are raising their earnings forecasts for I.B.M. and are enthusiastically recommending the stock. I.B.M.'s long nightmare may be over. Market Place. D8.
 The company will introduce a new version of its OS/2 operating system today with features to make it easier for users to communicate with other computers. D8.
 
Airlines Raise Ticket-Change Fees
 Many airlines are raising the fees they charge passengers for rewriting restricted tickets. Delta increased its fee on Friday, to $50 from $35, joining Northwest, United and T.W.A. Edwin McDowell: Travel. D5.

HEADLINE: 2 Submarine Makers Vie for a $60 Billion Project

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16

 BODY:
One of the fiercest naval battles in years broke out here today -- in an ornate Capitol Hill hearing room packed with admirals, lawmakers and lobbyists.
The battle pits the United States' two submarine builders in a fight that will most likely leave only one standing. At stake is a $60 billion contract to build the Navy's new attack submarine, thousands of jobs in Connecticut and Virginia and an industrial hedge against a resurgent Russia or other future enemy. 
 The Clinton Administration wants to award the contract for at least the first of the 30 new submarines without competitive bidding to the Electric Boat Division of the General Dynamics Corporation in Groton, Conn. But that tack provoked a sharp protest from Tenneco Inc.'s Newport News Shipbuilding unit, which makes submarines and aircraft carriers near Norfolk, Va., saying it can build the first five new submarines for $2 billion less than Electric Boat.
Animosity between the two submarine builders has been growing. There have been dueling studies, cost claims and counterclaims. As recently as this week, Newport News bought half-page and full-page advertisements in The Washington Post and The Washington Times. And finally, at a packed Senate Armed Services subcommittee hearing today, the rival company presidents sat side by side at the witness table sniping at senators as well as at each other.
"There are no facts anywhere to say they'll have a 40 percent savings," James E. Turner Jr., the president of Electric Boat, said of his competitor's cost estimates.
W. P. Fricks, president of Newport News, shot back: "His numbers are incorrect." His costs will be higher."
Under Republican administrations, free-market forces shaped the military industry. But President Clinton has adopted a more activist industrial policy combining economics and politics with military necessity. The Pentagon would preserve certain specialized industries that would otherwise disappear, even if there were no immediate need for their products.
A major beneficiary of the policy has been Electric Boat's Seawolf. The Administration decided to buy a third Seawolf for $2.4 billion not because of any urgent military need, but to keep welders and engineers at Groton busy until Electric Boat starts building the new attack submarine in 1998. About $900 million of the $2.4 billion has been spent, and the Navy is now asking Congress for the rest. As a consolation prize, the Pentagon agreed to build another aircraft carrier at Newport News.
But the Republican-dominated Congress takes a dim view of this Democratic President's industrial policy, especially when it ties up dwindling military dollars in New England that could be spent on ships or planes in Republican districts elsewhere.
It is a position Mr. Clinton has stuck to since the 1992 Democratic Presidential primary campaign. Former Senator Paul A. Tsongas of Massachusetts, a contender for the nomination, said it would be unrealistic to build a third Seawolf in Connecticut, and accused Mr. Clinton of pandering to the voters in the state by promising to build the submarine there. But Mr. Clinton maintained his position through the primary as well as in the general campaign against President George Bush.
Today the House and Senate are considering the cancellation of the third Seawolf and opening the new submarine business to a competition Newport News would probably win, given its greater size and lower wages. Without this work, Electric Boat says it will go out of business, leaving 6,000 employees out of work.
If the decision were based solely on cost, Newport News -- Virginia's largest private employer -- would win hands-down. The estimated savings of consolidating all submarine construction and repair work at Newport News range from $1.3 billion (the Navy's estimate) to about $10 billion (Newport News's figure).
But the Navy contends there is more than cost at stake. Nora Slatkin, who is stepping down as the Navy's acquisition chief to become the executive director at the Central Intelligence Agency, told senators that the Navy plan to keep open two "nuclear capable" shipyards preserved the option of competition in future submarine production and offered an industrial hedge if Russia or some other unforeseen naval power threatened the world's seaways.
Ms. Slatkin also said Newport News had overestimated its potential savings and understated the costs associated with closing Electric Boat and moving the work to Norfolk, which she said would delay delivery of the first new submarines by two to three years.
Both sides jumped on the free-market, open-competition bandwagon. Newport News wants competitive bidding now on the first batch of submarines, while the Navy wants to wait until Electric Boat has designed the first few vessels and the production line is large enough to support two builders. But Newport News and its Virginia supporters say the shipbuilder cannot afford to wait that long, and would have to close its submarine operations.
"This theory you're preserving two nuclear-capable shipyards sounds good, but it's phony," said Senator John W. Warner, a Virginia Republican who was Navy Secretary in the Nixon Administration.
Electric Boat's main champion, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut, countered that Newport News was using its Government contracts to unfairly subsidize a bid for the new submarine work. "You're pursuing not economic competition, but economic homicide," he told Mr. Fricks of Newport News. "You're trying to kill Electric Boat, and you're asking us to pay for it."
Denying that, Mr. Fricks replied, "We're not asking for the work, just to be able to compete for it."
