HEADLINE: Microsoft and NBC in Multimedia Alliance

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

 BODY:
The Microsoft Corporation and NBC announced an alliance yesterday to produce an array of multimedia products and services. But the details were so fuzzy that some industry analysts said the announcement was the digital-age equivalent of agreeing to be friends.
William H. Gates, the chairman of Microsoft, and Robert C. Wright, the president of NBC, said in a conference call with reporters that the companies would jointly develop CD-ROM's, interactive television services and products for Microsoft's new on-line service, the Microsoft Network. 
 "I'm a big believer that the interactive world can be very complementary with the broadcast world," Mr. Gates said.
But unlike the MCI Communications Corporation, which recently agreed to invest up to $2 billion in Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation -- in part for access to its programming -- Mr. Gates said Microsoft would not pay NBC up front for access to NBC services like its coverage of the Summer Olympics or the Presidential election next year.
"None of the discussions with NBC have, in any way, involved investing in all or part of NBC," he said.
Mr. Gates and Mr. Wright would also not say how NBC and Microsoft planned to divide revenue from new CD-ROM's or services on the Microsoft Network. And Mr. Wright said the deal did not address how network personalities like Tom Brokaw would be compensated for multimedia products that draw on their talents.
All told, said George Colony, the president of Forrester Research, a market research firm in Cambridge, Mass., "this is a very fancy way to say 'we're going to put our content on the Microsoft Network.' "
With digital technology opening vast but uncharted new markets, Mr. Colony said, entertainment, technology and telecommunications companies are racing to forge alliances without worrying too much about the details. "A lot of this is hedging bets," he said.
For all its fuzziness, yesterday's news had a measurable negative impact on two other commercial on-line services -- Prodigy and America Online -- that now carry material from NBC. Mr. Wright said NBC would phase out its involvement with both services, though the network would continue to maintain a site on the Internet's World Wide Web service.
America Online stock fell $3.125 to close at $38.625 on unusually heavy Nasdaq volume of almost 3.9 million shares. The stock had been down as much as $7.25 during the afternoon. Shares of Prodigy's two owners, I.B.M. and Sears, Roebuck & Company, also slipped, although only slightly.
Microsoft jumped $3.5625, to $84.875, as Wall Street reacted to the deal and to assurances by Mr. Gates that the company intended to ship Windows 95, its next generation of operating software, on schedule this August. But the deal had little effect on the shares of NBC's owner, the General Electric Company, which fell 75 cents, to $56.875.
Although the Microsoft Network does not yet have a single subscriber, industry experts say it will be an instant heavyweight among on-line services because it will be rolled out with Windows 95. Users of the new software will be able to sign on to the service at the touch of a button -- giving it a big edge over services like America Online, the largest on-line service.
Mr. Colony estimated that the Microsoft Network would sign up 2.5 million subscribers within three years, as many as America On-Line has now.
Thomas S. Rogers, the president of NBC Cable, who oversees the network's multimedia ventures, said, "When you use the reach of a broadcast network in television and the reach of Microsoft on the PC, it's a great combination."
Partly because of the lack of cash passing hands, NBC executives were quick to draw a distinction between this alliance and the one between MCI and the News Corporation. MCI paid up, they said, because it needs Mr. Murdoch's programming to fill its communications pipeline.
"We're really two companies that are in the software business," Mr. Wright said of NBC and Microsoft.
For example, he said NBC could harness Microsoft's expertise in CD-ROM's to bolster its efforts in this area. To date, NBC has produced only one CD-ROM title: a personal finance guide called "Your Portfolio." Mr. Wright said NBC would draw on Microsoft's expertise -- even borrowing the company's employees -- to create many more titles.
Some industry experts questioned the value of the alliance with Microsoft, because NBC's service will still be available to America Online and Prodigy subscribers who browse the World Wide Web. But Martin Yudkovitz, the senior vice president of NBC Multimedia, said the Web site would not include the "coolest" features of NBC's on-line offering.
The alliance also raises questions about Genie, an on-line service owned by General Electric. Mr. Wright said NBC would continue to promote its programs on Genie, which has 200,000 subscribers. But he said the Microsoft service was "a much larger undertaking" than Genie.
For his part, Mr. Gates said the Microsoft Network would be open to services from NBC's network rivals, CBS, ABC and Fox.
And he said the NBC deal would not conflict with a separate interactive partnership between Microsoft and Dreamworks, the entertainment company started by Jeffrey Katzenberg, Steven Spielberg and David Geffen.

HEADLINE: Comptroller Says Cuts May Prove Costly

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
New York City's Comptroller issued a report yesterday that said some city and state budget cuts could ultimately cost the city more money by forcing people now receiving some health or welfare benefits to turn to more expensive government services.
For example, the report concluded that a state proposal to eliminate rent supplements for welfare families, which cost the city $750 per family each year, could force more people into homeless shelters, which cost $8,486 a year. The report said that if only 1 of every 11 families getting the supplements became homeless, the city would save nothing at all. 
 In a lengthy, detailed analysis of budget proposals now being debated in Albany and at City Hall, the Comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, a Democrat, said many of the proposed cuts in spending on social services would have similar unintended consequences.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani dismissed the Comptroller's study, strongly suggesting that its findings were more political than empirical. "I have to emphasize that when you start dealing with secondary and indirect analysis, it very much is guided by the predisposition of the person who does the analysis," the Mayor said at a City Hall news conference yesterday afternoon.
Although Mr. Hevesi did not take a position against specific cuts, he said that ignoring what he called "secondary impacts" would not only "inflict huge pain on people but ultimately, in many cases, cost us more money than we save."
At the same time, in response to an urgent request from Mayor Giuliani, a group of 12 business and labor leaders signed a joint letter yesterday beseeching the state government for $950 million in assistance that the city has requested, even though members could not agree how much of the aid should come at the expense of welfare and Medicaid recipients.
The letter reflected the growing concern on the part of business, labor and city government that the city will get only a fraction of its request once state leaders work out a budget. For labor, that could mean layoffs of city employees; for business, that could hurt the city's economy and mean an end to promised cuts in taxes; for City Hall, that could mean politically painful service reductions and a downgrading of the city's bonds.
If the state money is not forthcoming, the Mayor has said that his budget cuts will be even deeper, potentially leading to more unintended consequences, by Mr. Hevesi's analysis.
The Comptroller's report said Mr. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki, both Republicans, had failed to consider the impacts of their budget proposals. "Savings are not always as easy to achieve as they seem," Mr. Hevesi wrote.
The Comptroller said the combined city and state cuts in social services could drain $2.8 billion from the city's economy. In health care alone, he said, the city would save $506 million by cutting its share of Medicaid, but as a result, it would lose 30,000 to 60,000 hospital jobs and an estimated $270 million in tax revenues from the lost earnings -- assuming those people do not find new jobs in the city.
The Comptroller's findings echoed arguments made in recent weeks by other Democrats on the City Council and in the State Assembly. They came as Mr. Pataki and legislative leaders in Albany continued to fight over the state's budget, now 47 days late.
It is unclear how much of an effect the Comptroller's findings would have on budget talks in Albany that have already gone on so long. Officials in Albany have said that some of the cuts cited in the report, including home health care for the elderly and disabled, will likely to be scaled back.
The Governor's press secretary, Robert J. Bellafiore, said the report appeared to defend spending on programs "that simply are not working." He added that the city and state, each facing huge deficits, had to reduce spending somewhere.
"There is almost no choice here," he said.
The Comptroller's report did not analyze the effects of all the proposed cuts in social services, most of which would be carried out on the state level, although the Mayor has expressed support for them. Mr. Hevesi said his office studied areas facing the largest cuts, including welfare, mental health, home health care and hospitals.
Both the labor and business leaders who signed the Mayor's letter seemed to embrace the general outlines of his budget, which cuts spending by more than any budget since World War II and would reduce welfare and Medicaid spending by unprecedented levels. The letter said that the budget offers "balance, fairness, and hope," all of which, it says, would be undone if the state fails to come through with the full $950 million.
Labor leaders who signed the letter included Stanley Hill, executive director of District Council 37; Sandra Feldman, president of the United Federation of Teachers, and Carl Haynes, president of Teamsters Local 237. Business leaders included David Rockefeller, Robert Tisch of Loews Corporation, the real estate executive Lewis Rudin, and the former Metropolitan Transportation Authority chairman, Richard Ravitch.
Mr. Giuliani said the eventual state budget could fall hundreds of millions of dollars short of the city's needs. He said he hoped that business and labor could press their respective representatives in Albany to come through. Specifically, he said it was important that Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver understand that municipal unions would be watching him carefully to see how much cash aid he could produce for the city.
Labor leaders denied that they were being used to pressure the Speaker, and said they were simply trying to send a unified message to all the leaders in Albany. Mr. Haynes said the unions could not agree on the magnitude of welfare and Medicaid cuts proposed by the Mayor.

HEADLINE: Weak First-Quarter Profits Reported by Large Retailers

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

 BODY:
Some of the nation's largest retailers reported disappointing first-quarter results yesterday -- an indication, many analysts said, of a continued economic slowdown.
Most retailers found that consumers, concerned about the economy, curbed their demand for clothes and home furnishings. Few analysts expect this trend to change significantly in the months ahead. "It may be a soft landing for the economy," said Daniel Barry, an analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company, "but it's turning into a hard landing for retailers." 
 Retailers sharply discounted merchandise in the quarter to encourage sales, which were also hurt by a late Easter and higher Federal income tax bills. But these discounts led to thinner margins as retailers attempted to reduce high inventory levels.
At the J. C. Penney Company, first-quarter profits fell 30 percent, to $156 million, or 63 cents a share, from $223 million, or 88 cents a share, in the comparable quarter a year earlier. At the Dayton Hudson Corporation, profits fell 72 percent, to $11 million, or 9 cents a share, from $39 million, or 48 cents a share, in the 1994 quarter.
"This is a lot more evidence of an economic slowdown," said Walter Loeb, who heads his own retail consulting firm. "We are seeing a cautious consumer who is being very careful with spending and is reacting only to sales."
Penney, based in Plano, Tex., primarily sells apparel and other "soft goods," a segment that was especially hard hit this quarter. And Dayton Hudson, based in Minneapolis, had problems at its Mervyn's division, which sells discounted clothes.
The main retailer bucking this downward trend was Wal-Mart Stores Inc. of Bentonville, Ark., the nation's largest retailer. Wal-Mart reported an 11 percent rise in earnings, to $553.4 million, or 24 cents a share, from $498.5 million, or 22 cents a share.
Home Depot Inc., a retailer specializing in home improvement products based in Atlanta, also reported higher earnings, but at a level that Wall Street found disappointing. Home Depot's earnings rose 13 percent, to $157.8 million, or 34 cents a share, from $139.8 million, or 31 cents a share. Home Depot executives attributed the poor earnings growth to severe storms and heavy rains in many parts of the country and not to the slowing economy -- an assessment shared by analysts.
David Poneman, an analyst with Sanford Bernstein, said Wal-Mart was the only retailer with a significant apparel operation that did well this quarter. He said that operating profits rose 17 percent, higher than the percentage gain in earnings per share, and that this increase came on top of record first-quarter earnings last year.
Mr. Poneman added that Wal-Mart often benefited from a sagging economy because some consumers switch from regular department stores to discounters like Wal-Mart for apparel purchases.
"You had a slowing of income growth and a reduction in consumer confidence," Mr. Poneman said. "People pick up the paper and they see various negative economic statistics. So the stores decline in a declining economy."
Most analysts predict that retailers will remain under pressure as long as the economy remains soft, which it is expected to do for the remainder of the year. But they also say the second quarter may show some improvement. Apparel sales, driven by warmer weather and a favorable consumer response to current styles, have been edging up slightly.
"The second quarter looks like it won't be as depressed as the first quarter," Mr. Barry of Merrill Lynch said. "But it doesn't mean that major retailers won't remain under pressure. Our view is that the economy will be slow all year, and retailers will be affected."

HEADLINE: Stocks Show Little Reaction To New Tensions on Trade

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The shouting match over trade between the United States and Japan may be deafening, and one of the most widely held stocks in the country may have taken a big one-day fall, but the overall stock market seemed to pay little heed yesterday.
Lower long-term interest rates and a strengthening dollar helped reverse a small drop in stock prices in the morning, and the major indexes closed mixed. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 2.42 points, to 4,435.05, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 index rose 0.45 point, to 528.19, another record. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 5.19 points to 868.25, also a record. 
 The Clinton Administration placed a 100 percent tariff yesterday on 13 luxury car models from Japan. But the worsening trade relations had already been incorporated into the price of automobile stocks, said Edward Laux, senior managing director for institutional equity trading at the Chicago Corporation.
"It's been everywhere you look for a week already," Mr. Laux said, referring to trade tensions. "It's old news."
Shares of Ford Motor and Chrysler were unchanged, though General Motors fell 5/8, to 47 1/2. G.M. stock had risen since May 5.
Dirk van Dijk, equity strategist for C. H. Dean & Associates, which manages nearly $4 billion in stocks and bonds, said he would buy more auto stocks but would wait and see about the market as a whole.
"Trade wars, historically, are never good for markets," Mr. van Dijk said. "It would be wise to be cautious."
Shares of Pacific Telesis, the regional telephone company, suffered one of their biggest one-day falls and by far their largest plunge since March 1994, when the company spun off its cellular telephone operations.
Pacific Telesis dropped 2 5/8, to 27. After the markets closed on Monday, the company said that it "expects 1995 earnings could drop by about 10 percent," citing a combination of fewer telephone calls and lower prices ordered by California regulators. With more than 424 million shares worth nearly $11.5 billion, Pacific Telesis is one of the 15 most widely held stocks in the country.
The troubles at Pacific Telesis underscored investor uncertainties about how local telephone companies would be able to compete when local service, like long-distance service, is deregulated. All nine companies in Standard & Poor's local telephone group fell.
In the broader market, a fall in long-term interest rates helped moderate the reaction to the trade tensions. The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell to 6.86 percent from 6.94 percent.
Moreover, the dollar rose against major currencies, providing more evidence for the end of the dollar's steep decline this year. The dollar rose to 86.57 Japanese yen from 86.40 yen, and to 1.4429 German marks from 1.4360.
At its lowest, on April 18, the dollar was trading below 81 yen and 1.36 marks.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was above normal at 366.2 million shares, about 10 percent above this year's daily average of 334 million shares.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.26 point, to 284.27, with advancing stocks outnumbering declining stocks by 1,401 to 912. The American Stock Exchange composite index rose 1.07 points, to 489.38, another record.
Among the advancing stocks was AG Associates, in its first day of trading, rising 5 1/8 from its offering price, to 16 1/8. AG makes equipment used in integrated circuits. Microsoft rose 39/16 , to 84 7/8, after the company and the NBC television network said they would develop products together for CD-ROM's and other new media.
Among the declining stocks was Crop Growers, which plunged sharply for a second day. It fell 11 5/8, to 12 5/8. The company, which provides crop insurance, reported lower-than-expected earnings. Rockefeller Center Properties, the real estate investment trust that was the mortgage lender for Rockefeller Center, resumed trading following a two-day halt after the center filed for bankruptcy protection. The trust dropped 1/2, to 4 3/4.
The most active stock, at 9.7 million shares, was Home Depot, which fell 2 1/4, to 41 1/4. The company reported lower-than-expected earnings.

HEADLINE: SANCTIONS OF JAPAN: THE OVERVIEW;
100% TARIFFS SET ON 13 TOP MODELS OF JAPANESE CARS

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16

 BODY:
Living up to its threat to impose harsh sanctions on Japan, the Clinton Administration placed a 100 percent tariff today on 13 luxury car models that accounted for $5.9 billion in sales in the United States last year, including the flagship products of Toyota, Nissan and Honda.
The tariff, the largest ever imposed by the United States against any trading partner, is to go into effect at 12:01 Saturday morning. Customs inspectors will be instructed to double the wholesale price of every Toyota Lexus, Nissan Infiniti and a number of other cars that roll off Japanese transport ships -- an increase that would make the cars all but unsalable. 
 But Administration officials said the sanctions would be rescinded if Japan and the United States could reach an accord by June 28, giving the two countries six weeks to resolve a dispute that has already gone far beyond the immediate issue of the openness of Japan's market for American cars and car parts.
As the argument has broadened tremendously in recent weeks, both sides have warned that the alliance of the world's two largest economies is being badly corroded.
"We've put ourselves pretty far out on this one, and there is no backing away now," one of Mr. Clinton's top trade officials said today. "We came to the conclusion that either we draw the line here, or throw in the towel on Japan."
Japanese officials contended today that the sanctions violated international trade laws, and said that within days they would bring an action against the United States at the new and still-fragile World Trade Organization in Geneva.
In Tokyo, Ryutaro Hashimoto, the Minister of International Trade and Industry, whose prospects of becoming prime minister are resting largely on his handling of the trade dispute, accused Washington of imposing "numerical targets" that Japan must meet "under the threat of unilateral actions, which is nothing but Government intervention in private business activities, and poses a serious challenge to the free trade system."
Japanese auto makers were more direct. "The U.S. Government conducts its trade policy in a coercive manner completely beyond our comprehension," said the executive vice president of the Toyota Motor Company, Masaharu Tanaka.
In private, Japanese Government officials contended that Mr. Clinton was simply playing Presidential politics, trying to shore up his support among labor unions and middle-class voters who see their jobs threatened by Japan's long reach into the American market.
But American officials say that for the first time they have found a way to hit Japan where it hurts -- and when it hurts most, with the strong yen already ravaging Japanese profits. It is unclear how long Japan's auto makers could endure the huge loss of sales that would come from a tariff that would add $20,000 to $40,000 to the cost of each car. After years of battling their way into the American luxury market, they would suddenly be surrendering it to Mercedes-Benz, BMW, Jaguar and some competitive American models.
"The U.S. is not going to stand by and watch its workers and its products unfairly treated," said Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, who has led the drive to be far tougher with Japan than any past administration has. Among American workers, he said, "very, very few people will be hurt."
In fact, the list Mr. Kantor announced today was more a political masterpiece than an economic one. All the cars on the list are produced in Japan, and they all make minimal use of American parts; no vehicles made at Japanese "transplants" in the United States are affected. All of the cars involved cost more than $25,000, enabling Mr. Clinton to argue that he has punished Japan without hurting middle-class American consumers. As one of Mr. Clinton's political advisers said in half-jest the other day, "So we lose the Lexus vote in Greenwich."
There are several possibilities for what could happen next. The simplest is that Japanese officials, concluding that they have misread Mr. Clinton's determination, try to patch together the minimal concessions necessary to resolve matters before the June 28 deadline. Presumably, most of the talking would take place before Mr. Clinton and Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama meet at the conference of the Group of Seven nations in Halifax, Nova Scotia, which begins on June 15. But several Administration officials warned today that they expected the two leaders' meeting to be inconclusive and said they doubted that Japan's Government would resolve internal disputes fast enough to act before the deadline.
The second possibility is that no agreement will be reached until Japanese auto makers feel enough pain to press the politicians to solve the problem.
A third -- and probably less likely -- possibility is that Japan will decide to tough it out, for fear that caving in on autos would lead to similar pressure regarding other industries. Japanese officials could calculate that such a move would ultimately cost them less and would give them a chance to argue that the sanctions are a violation of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Many American experts on trade law say Japan could win such an argument, although Mr. Kantor insists that the United States is within its rights to act unilaterally against Japanese imports. He contends that Section 301 of the Trade Act grants broad powers to retaliate after concluding that a trading partner is discriminating against American imports. Still, he may not want to test that proposition before a neutral panel in Geneva.
Today the Director General of the World Trade Organization, Renato Ruggiero, made what some trade experts saw as a veiled warning to the United States. Mr. Ruggiero, whose appointment the United States opposed for more than a year before reluctantly endorsing him, said, "I expect both parties to abide by the W.T.O. rules and procedures, which they know well."
In public the Administration has maintained a solid front on the trade issue, trying to send Japan the message that it must make progress on the economic issues if it wants to make sure there is no damage to the political ties, and ultimately the security ties, between the countries. But several Administration officials say there are signs of growing internal tension over the issue. Mr. Kantor has called for a full-court press, several White House officials say, while Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the new head of the National Economic Council, has been trying to temper the public oratory to prevent an already nasty argument from getting uglier.

HEADLINE: Harry Bergold, Ex-Envoy to Nicaragua, Dies at 63

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER 

 BODY:
Harry E. Bergold Jr., an official and diplomat who provided information to journalists that led to the discovery that American Government funds were being sent illegally to anti-Sandinista fighters in Nicaragua, died yesterday at his home in Paris. He was 63.
He had been suffering from cancer, said his wife, Karlene G. Knieps, a Foreign Service officer. 
 Mr. Bergold served as Ambassador to Hungary and Nicaragua before his career was cut short by conservatives in the Senate.
After returning from his post in Nicaragua in 1987 and spending a year in Washington, Mr. Bergold was nominated by President Reagan to become Ambassador to Morocco. But Senator Jesse Helms and several of his allies, who believed that Mr. Bergold had not been sufficiently tough on the leftist Sandinistas during his tenure in Managua, objected to his nomination and managed to defeat it.
Mr. Bergold retired from the Foreign Service in 1989 and moved to Vienna, where he was a visiting lecturer at the Institute for European Studies.
When his wife was named to a post at the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development in Paris in 1993, they moved there.
Mr. Bergold combined an encyclopedic knowledge of history with a laconic wit that won him friends in political circles throughout Europe and Latin America. While in Hungary, he advised Communist leaders on ways to loosen their ties to the Soviet Union. In Nicaragua, he developed a close relationship with the hard-line but intellectually restless Interior Minister, Tomas Borge, who often visited him for late-night conversations over cognac and cigars.
Opposition figures were welcome guests at Mr. Bergold's residences in Budapest and Managua, but he kept his contacts with them unobtrusive for fear that they might be denounced as puppets of the United States.
Mr. Bergold was considered a specialist in European affairs, and President Reagan's decision to send him to Nicaragua, at the suggestion of Secretary of State George P. Shultz, was surprising. Mr. Shultz explained that he wanted an ambassador in Nicaragua who had dealt with Communist governments.
Although he professed never to have developed a deep interest in Latin America, Mr. Bergold found that his post in Managua put him in the vortex of a political firestorm. He came to disagree with the view that the Sandinista Government represented a serious threat to United States security, and he angered conservatives in Washington by refusing to assume a militantly anti-Sandinista posture.
Mr. Bergold harbored serious misgivings about the wisdom of the war against the Sandinistas, which the Reagan Administration sponsored, and he repeatedly asked Washington for permission to open serious negotiations with Sandinista leaders. In the charged climate of the mid-1980's, however, he was not permitted to do so.
He headed a United States negotiating team that met with Sandinista delegates several times in Mexico City, but was under strict instructions from Washington not to allow the talks to expand into serious bargaining over important issues.
Later he provided information that led to discovery of an operation in which Lieut. Col. Oliver North, a National Security Council aide, was sending Government money to anti-Sandinista fighters at a time when such financing was prohibited by law. Supporters of Colonel North suspected the involvement of Mr. Bergold and took their revenge by scuttling his nomination as Ambassador to Morocco.
Although Mr. Bergold served in Nicaragua when Sandinista power was at its peak, he never doubted that the Government was headed for collapse.
He hung a large map of the Austro-Hungarian empire in his office in Managua, and when asked why, he replied, "To remind me that things change."
Mr. Bergold was born Nov. 11, 1931, in Olean, N.Y. He received his Bachelor of Arts degree from Yale in 1953, served in the Army, and then returned to Yale to earn a Master of Arts degree in 1957. He joined the Foreign Service that year, serving in Honduras, Mexico, Madrid and Panama before being called to Washington.
From 1973 to 1977 Mr. Bergold served in the Defense Department, first as Deputy Assistant Secretary for European and NATO affairs and later as Principal Deputy Assistant Secretary for Legislative Affairs. He was detailed to the White House in 1977 to help draft plans for the new Department of Energy. Later that year, he was named Assistant Secretary of Energy for International Affairs, a post he held until 1979.
He was Ambassador to Hungary from 1980 to 1983, and Ambassador to Nicaragua from 1984 to 1987. During the 1987-88 academic year he was a fellow at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington, and in 1988-89 he was a visiting professor of eastern European history at George Washington University.
In addition to his wife, Mr. Bergold is survived by a stepdaughter from a previous marriage, Celeste Bergold, a State Department employee who lives in Virginia.
A memorial service will be held Friday at 11 A.M. at the Eglise St. Clotilde in Paris.

HEADLINE: SANCTIONS OF JAPAN: THE IMPLICATIONS
100% TARIFFS SET ON 13 TOP MODELS OF JAPANESE CARS;
Trading War: No Way Out?

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
Once again Washington is playing hardball with Tokyo, imposing punitive tariffs against imports unless Japan yields in trade negotiations. But unlike previous confrontations, in which Japan invariably offered 11th-hour concessions to avoid a blowup, this conflict has created a gnawing fear among many economists that a weak Japanese Government will let the crisis escalate out of control.
"I think the Japanese have had it with threats from America," said William R. Cline, an economist at the Institute for International Economics in Washington. "I think they won't budge." 
 But in some important ways, it almost doesn't matter what Tokyo does. For whatever happens in the end, many economists say, Americans are unlikely to notice any of the pocketbook benefits they might anticipate. And they may well end up paying an unexpectedly heavy price in damage to a global order that serves America's long-term interests well.
"We usually get something when we play brinksmanship with Japan," said Van Doorn Ooms, director of research for the Committee on Economic Development, a New York public policy organization sponsored by a number of prominent American businesses. But, he added, "Confrontation is a very risky -- and very unfortunate -- policy."
Washington and Tokyo have a long history of coerced agreements intended to protect American industry from Japanese competition or to promote access by United States producers to the sheltered Japanese market. But the record of those past deals is at best mixed and at worst a dismal failure.
In one sense, the "voluntary" restraints that set quotas on the Japanese share of the American auto market in the early 1980's "worked." They protected Detroit from devastating competition when American auto makers had no high-quality, fuel-efficient models to sell to compete against Japanese cars.
But they also added billions of dollars to the cost of cars in America. And a good chunk of that cash went into the coffers of the Japanese auto makers, which chalked up big profits on each sale because the supply of sought-after imports was so limited. Perversely, that created an even worse threat by encouraging Japanese producers to enter the market for high-margin luxury cars -- Detroit's bread and butter. That's because the quotas were set in terms of the number of vehicles sold rather than their overall value.
Probably the most important agreement hammered out under the threat of sanctions was the 1986 pact on semiconductors, guaranteeing markets for American computer chips in Japan and in other nations where Japanese and United States chip makers competed. In a book written two years ago, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, now director of President Clinton's National Economic Council, conceded that "the conventional wisdom among economists is that the agreement was an unmitigated failure."
But she challenged that view, arguing that "a more nuanced conclusion" would measure the pact as "a qualified success" because it stabilized America's share of the world market and may have laid the groundwork for the resurgence of Silicon Valley.
More broadly, some experts question the conventional wisdom of most economists about dealing with Japan. "It's clear that a big piece of our trade deficit with Japan is structural," said Clyde V. Prestowitz Jr., president of the Economic Strategy Institute and a former trade negotiator in the Reagan Administration. "The dollar has gone from 260 yen to 80 yen but we don't sell any more paper, glass, auto parts, soda ash, you name it. That indicates that the assumptions of free market economics aren't at work."
But economists reply that the get-tough approaches haven't worked any better. Negotiating under the gun produced the Bush Administration's so-called Structural Impediments Initiative, yet another muddled milestone in the love-hate relationship between Washington and Tokyo. Ironically, that effort, which was aimed at getting at the root of the problem by overcoming barriers that make consumer goods particularly expensive in Japan, was initially applauded by most economists as an attempt to mesh the two economies more closely.
But in practice, noted Paul R. Krugman, a leading trade economist at Stanford University, the effort was soon informally dubbed the "simply insulting initiative."
What is clear from straightforward economic analysis is that all these efforts to reduce trade barriers have done little to overcome the problem as most people define it: Japan's huge trade surplus and America's gaping trade deficit.
Here's how economists explain the complex causes and effects at work.
"If America barred all imports of Japanese autos, the bilateral imbalance of trade with Japan would decline," said Gary R. Saxonhouse, an economist at the University of Michigan. But the overall trade balance of the United States with the rest of the world would not narrow unless Americans decided to save more or invest less.
Why? Cars not imported from Japan instead might be imported from, say, Germany or Canada. And if some Americans switched to domestic models, the increased demand would soon show up as limitations on the capacity to produce other sorts of goods at home. One way or another, argues Peter B. Kenen, an economist at Princeton University, "the trade balance is driven by macroeconomic policies" that play a much bigger role in determining how much of the nation's overall demand will be satisfied by imports than any specific trade barriers.
But critics argue that the standard economic argument ignores the message the United States sends to the rest of the world if it turns a blind eye to Japanese trade barriers.
"What the Clinton Administration is really challenging," said Mr. Prestowitz, the former trade negotiator, "is a whole web of practices, business relationships and government policies that many other Asian countries have adopted. They're really challenging how this game is going to be played in the future."
Still, pressuring Japan to set specific targets for auto parts imports sends the wrong signal, argues Mr. Cline of the Institute for International Economics. It will undermine America's decade-old effort to reduce government interference in domestic Japanese markets. "We're encouraging regulation," he says.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Sensing a need to polish its image, the World Bank gets ready for its first campaign.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
THE World Bank, for the first time since its founding in 1945, is becoming an advertiser.
But don't look for commercials promising toasters to the first 50 developing nations that open accounts at the bank's office in Washington. Rather, bank executives want to begin running sometime this fall a campaign that would serve as the equivalent of corporate image advertising. In the meantime, a series of print advertisements answering the critics of the bank is appearing this week in newspapers. 
 The campaign later this year has the ambitious goal of burnishing the image of the bank at a critical point in its history, and improving perceptions about its policies among so-called decision makers and opinion leaders.
The bank is scrambling to shift its focus as it comes under fire from environmentalists skeptical of large-scale development projects in the third world and from politicians eager to slash public spending. There is even a coalition of advocacy groups agitating under the banner "50 Years Is Enough," hoping to deliver the bank from what they deem a lengthy midlife crisis.
"This is a major, major departure on all sorts of fronts," said Mark Malloch Brown, who joined the World Bank in September in the new position of external affairs director. "For many years the bank has been trapped in this 'development club,' talking just to economists and nongovernmental organizations.
"Now we need a message that mainstreams the bank and makes it relevant again to where the world is going."
The idea of advertising predates the bank's pending change in top leadership, Mr. Malloch Brown said; James D. Wolfensohn is scheduled to become president on June 1, succeeding the late Lewis T. Preston.
As Mr. Malloch Brown begins a review on the account, he hopes to obtain a budget commensurate with a campaign "trying to create a global corporate image" for the likes of an investment banking firm, which runs in the range of $3 million to $5 million. With the help of Herb Schmertz, the corporate communications strategist best known for his work for the Mobil Corporation, Mr. Malloch Brown has drawn up an eclectic list of agencies expected to make presentations next month:
*Bartle Bogle Hegarty, the hot creative shop in London that handles accounts for giant marketers like Coca-Cola and Levi Strauss.
*Margeotes Fertitta Donaher & Weiss in New York, which specializes in campaigns for premium-priced products like Stolichnaya vodka, as well as image campaigns for corporations like the McGraw-Hill Companies.
*Shepardson Stern & Kaminsky in New York, founded by former executives of the Sawyer Miller strategic communications agency, now part of Robinson Lake Sawyer Miller, a unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt. Shepardson Stern works for clients like Time Warner Cable; Mr. Malloch Brown was a top executive of Sawyer Miller from 1986 to 1994.
*Young & Rubicam Business Communications in Geneva, a unit of Young & Rubicam Inc. specializing in what Mr. Malloch Brown called "corporate positioning advertising" for accounts like the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees; Mr. Malloch Brown was a staff member of that office from 1979 to 1983.
"There are a lot of valid points indeed about the bank being in a midlife crisis in terms of operating effectiveness," Mr. Malloch Brown said. "The bank needs to hear its clients better."
At the same time, he added, "we've allowed those critics to set the terms of the debate and let our operating failings be the sole standard by which we are judged."
"We want to convey that we've heard these criticisms and are responding to them and improving ourselves," he said.
Those are, of course, reasons for corporate image advertising, for which American companies spent an estimated $1.5 billion last year.
Indeed, Mr. Malloch Brown said, "the most important thrust of the advertising" will be to stress the bank's recognition that its "challenge is to serve its government masters while striking a partnership with the private sector, being a strategic bridge to channeling money to developing countries in ways that make them grow."
One element of the campaign, he added, will be to emphasize that 75 percent of the bank's estimated $22 billion in annual lending "is raised on world capital markets," rather than from governments.
In a prelude to the campaign, the ads this week, running in newspapers in New York and Washington, offer examples of American companies obtaining lucrative contracts from nations receiving loans from the bank. They urge members of Congress not to reduce financing for the bank's International Development Association unit, which provides loans to very poor countries.
The ads, which carry the theme "The World Bank. A good investment," respond to proposals in the Senate and House Budget Committees that the United States halve or eliminate its contribution to the development unit. They were created by Greer, Margolis, Mitchell, Burns, the Washington political and issues consulting company, and by Michael Deaver, senior vice president at the Washington office of Edelman Public Relations Worldwide.

HEADLINE: Added Slowdown Evidence: Industry and Home Building

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16

 BODY:
More signs of an abrupt economic slowdown emerged today as industry operated at a markedly lower pace in April while home building failed to rebound from a poor winter, Government statistics showed.
The bond market greeted the figures as further evidence that economic growth was slowing to a more moderate pace with low inflation. Bond prices surged and interest rates fell sharply. The yield on the Treasury's 30-year bond hit its lowest point since March of last year, dropping to 6.86 percent, from 6.94 percent on Monday. [Page D6.] 
 Still, economists said that today's reports indicated that the economy might be coming down harder than the hoped-for "soft landing," but they saw little risk of recession.
Robert R. Davis, chief economist for America's Community Bankers, a trade group, predicted that the economy would expand by a rate of less than 2 percent in coming months, a pace not lively enough to prevent unemployment from rising. But he and most other analysts said it was unlikely that business activity would actually contract rather than grow at a slow pace.
"The economy looks fundamentally sound," said Mark P. Vitner, an economist at the First Union Corporation in Charlotte, N.C. He found the main problem to be a temporary buildup of inventories, including new homes, which he said would likely correct itself without any need for the Federal Reserve to ease monetary policy.
According to the Federal Reserve, the nation's factories, mines and utilities operated at 84.1 percent of capacity in April, the third straight decline, well below the revised March pace of 84.7. Production fell to the lowest level in nine months, with April's decline bringing the first back-to-back shrinkages in nearly three and a half years.
Separately, the Commerce Department reported that builders broke ground on new homes at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1,236,000, a negligible four-tenths of 1 percent higher than in March. The Northeast was by far the weakest region, with both the biggest drop and the lowest pace of construction. Housing starts there tumbled 22.5 percent, to an annual pace of 107,000, far below the April 1994 pace of 150,000 dwellings.
Addressing directors of the National Association of Realtors here this morning, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, emphasized what he called the central bank's commitment to providing "a stable platform" for business, including real estate, an industry periodically battered by Government anti-inflation measures.
"I can assure you that it is not a goal of monetary policy to encourage fluctuations in interest rates," Mr. Greenspan told the realtors in what some analysts, mindful of a Fed meeting next Tuesday to review policy, took as a hint that supported their expectations of no change in short-term rates.
More than half the slump of four-tenths of 1 percent in industrial output last month was accounted for by motor vehicles and parts but production also fell for furniture, appliances, food, clothing, gasoline and even -- for the first time in almost three years -- business equipment.
Output fell three-tenths of 1 percent in March and was unchanged, upon revision, in February.
For factories, which account for 87.1 percent of industrial output, the decline was five-tenths of 1 percent last month, the largest of three straight contractions. Motor vehicle assemblies were at a 12.1 million annual rate, down from 12.8 million in March, with cars accounting for the entire decline.
Mining output rose two-tenths of 1 percent while utilities produced 1.6 percent more energy after a 2.4 percent March drop.
By market groups, production of consumer goods fell an additional five-tenths of 1 percent, to a level just 1.6 percent above that of April 1994 while business equipment fell four-tenths of 1 percent, construction supplies fell 1.5 percent and business supplies fell two-tenths of 1 percent.
The operating rate for industry, which was revised a bit lower for January, February and March, eased to 84.1 percent in April, meaningfully below the 85.5 percent peak now posted for December and January. While not predicting a cut in interest rates, Mr. Vitner, the bank economist, observed that the Fed "never cuts rates" until the industry capacity rate retreats.
Besides the skid in home construction in the Northeast, the housing report showed virtually no change in the Midwest and gains of nearly 3 percent and 9 percent, respectively, in the South and West.
Permits for future construction edged up five-tenths of 1 percent, with the West strongest, the South and Midwest somewhat weaker and the Northeast about unchanged at a rate of 127,000.
Shipments of mobile homes, which are reported with a lag, were at an annual rate of 333,000 in March, 2,000 fewer than in February, the Commerce Department found. Actual March shipments, with no seasonal adjustment, totaled 29,200.

HEADLINE: Class Notes;
Why employers aren't interested in the high school grades of prospective workers.

BYLINE: By Peter Applebome 

 BODY:
Researchers studying the hiring practices of American businesses have been alarmed at the lack of connection between schools and businesses, particularly the way in which employers seem to pay no attention to the grades and performance of high school students.
The concern is that if employers do not care, why should students. 
 But experts say there are two good reasons why employers almost never look at students' grades: They often cannot get them, and they are afraid they might get sued if they do.
Both reasons are lessons in the ways that reality complicates theory in education.
School-to-work transitions have been a major concern long before the Clinton Administration made the issue a cornerstone of its education policy through various programs intended to match the needs of employers better with the curriculum of the schools. The idea is not that schools should be judged only as producers of potential workers. It is that other countries, particularly Japan, do a much better job of matching those needs than the United States.
Among the issues is the degree to which employers disregard schools and look to other sources, particularly other work experience, when hiring. A survey of American employers by the Census Bureau, released in February, found that in assessing job applicants, employers looked to nearly every other attributes -- attitude, communication skills, recommendations from current employees or previous employers -- before they looked to the schools.
Almost everyone agrees that this sends the wrong signal.
"We've sent students the message that it's important to graduate, but not that it's better to graduate with B's than D's," said David Crawford, who teaches economics at the University of Pennsylvania. "If students aren't achieving, one reason for that is that they don't have an incentive to achieve."
One remedy is to have employers make it their business to use student achievement in sorting out job applicants. It would make sense for the schools, and, it turns out, studies of employers like the Lockheed Corporation have shown that high school records are excellent predictors of success in the workplace.
So why don't employers use them? Part of the reason is that many, particularly the more desirable employers, are so skeptical of the schools and of young people that they want someone else to hire and train them before they are willing to do so.
But more practical considerations also get in the way. One is legal.
In the landmark Griggs v. Duke Power decision, the Supreme Court in 1971 ruled that employers were prohibited not just from overt discrimination but also from practices that "are fair in form but discriminatory in operation." In that case, the Duke Power Company of North Carolina required high school diplomas for low-level jobs. That barred relatively few white applicants but many blacks. The Supreme Court found that a form of discrimination, and the result was a scramble by businesses to remove practices that had what the Court had called "disparate impacts" on minorities.
Many companies view the case as an indicator that they could be slapped with a lawsuit if they demand educational credentials that do not have a direct impact on the skills required for a job.
The other reason for not using transcripts more is practical.
High schools view transcripts as tools for colleges, not for employers. And employers and labor experts say that when companies request information from schools, it often takes too long to arrive and comes in a form they cannot readily decipher.
John Bishop of the Center for Advanced Human Resource Studies at Cornell University cited a case in which an insurance company in Columbus, Ohio, sent out 1,200 requests for information from transcripts and got only 92 responses. By asking for information, rather than the transcript itself, the company asked for additional work and thus reduced the response, Mr. Bishop said.
There are efforts to change things. The Educational Testing Service has developed a program, Work Link, that electronically provides information to employers. But since it requires active participation by students and electronic capability by employers, Mr. Bishop is doubtful that it will gain a broad-enough constituency to be useful.
A simpler and, he thinks, more promising experiment called Hire Education is under way in Delaware. When business leaders surveyed schools to find out how often they were asked for transcripts, they found that it rarely happened.
Under the new program put together by Delaware business groups, three companies, Bell Atlantic, Citicorp and PPG Industries, have bought fax machines for every high school in the state and have worked out a streamlined process of legally getting transcripts to employers.
As part of the program, schools are expected to raise awareness among students that employers will look at school records, and businesses are encouraged to recruit in schools and look at transcripts.
"You want a system that's simple and that includes everyone, not something that can be dismissed as a place to look for lemons," Mr. Bishop said.

HEADLINE: Abortions Up Slightly for Welfare Mothers

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, May 16

 BODY:
Abortions among New Jersey mothers on welfare increased slightly after the state began cutting off benefits for additional children born to mothers on welfare, figures released today showed. The revelations were deplored by foes of abortion, who have argued from the start that caps on welfare benefits would promote abortion, as well as by abortion rights advocates, who condemn the law for reducing welfare mothers' economic choices.
The study by the Department of Human Services showed that the rate of abortions per 1,000 women on welfare in the state increased from 9.43 to 9.78 in the eight months preceding and following the imposition of the new restrictions, known as the family cap, in August 1994. 
 Extrapolated, the increase amounted to an increase of about 300 abortions, said William Waldman, the Human Services Commissioner.
The study of abortions by welfare mothers was undertaken by the Department of Human Services after evidence surfaced that the size of welfare families had begun to decline after the imposition of the cap under Gov. Jim Florio. Mr. Florio promoted the change as a deterrent to additional children by welfare mothers.
Mr. Waldman took pains to argue that abortion rates fluctuate over time, and that it was too early to conclude that the family cap law was responsible for the apparent increase in abortions, which were paid for under Medicaid.
But anti-abortion groups pointed out that abortion rates have generally been falling in New Jersey, as they have nationally. A reversal of that trend among welfare mothers immediately after the imposition of the cap was proof that New Jersey's state law was promoting abortion, said Representative Christopher H. Smith, the New Jersey Republican who led the fight against the adoption of a similar cap in the recently passed House welfare reform act.
"It's very, very sad, but it's also predictable," Representative Smith said in response to the study. "If you take away funding for the poorest of our children and pay for abortions on demand through Medicaid, like New Jersey and New York and many other states do, it doesn't take a rocket scientist to conclude that you are either going to have poorer children or dead children."
It is a measure of the tangled logic of the abortion debate that Kate Michelman, president of the National Abortion and Reproductive Rights Action League in Washington, also condemned the family cap, but with a focus on the issue of choice rather than abortion.
"We are opposed to the family cap because we believe it will result in women being forced to choose an abortion that they may not want because they cannot see a way to support that child if it is born," Ms. Michelman said.
New Jersey's cap law was recently upheld by a United States District Court judge, Nicholas H. Politan. Both Ms. Michelman's group and the New Jersey Right to Life Committee have signed a friend-of-the-court brief opposing the law on the appeal.
"We are against coercing women into decisions like this," Ms. Michelman added, drawing a distinction between her group's stand and that of anti-abortion groups. "They're against the abortion."
New Jersey's family cap was "the buzz word all over Washington" during the debate over the Republican-sponsored welfare reform bill, Representative Smith said, and his efforts to remove the cap from the House version were unavailing.
But Marie Tasy, head of New Jersey Right to Life, said today that her members would lobby the Senate, which has yet to take up the measure, with today's statistics from New Jersey.
"We hope that they will look at what has happened in New Jersey under this law," Ms. Tasy said, "because after today, no one can say that this law does not encourage abortion."

HEADLINE: Gypsum Accepts Sweetened Bid Of $1.2 Billion

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
The National Gypsum Company, the nation's second-largest maker of gypsum-coated wallboard, said yesterday that it had accepted a sweetened $1.2 billion takeover offer from Delcor Inc., a private investment company led by National Gypsum's former chairman.
The agreement, which must be ratified by shareholders, also permits National Gypsum to solicit competing bids through the end of June. But in the wake of Delcor's new offer of $54 a share, two big European companies previously seen as potential buyers said they were no longer interested. Delcor has been pursuing National Gypsum since November. 
 "The transaction represents an excellent opportunity for the company's shareholders to realize the value of their stock while preserving the company's ability to identify and obtain the benefit of any superior transactions that may be available," Steve Humphrey, National Gypsum's chairman and chief executive, said in a statement issued yesterday.
Late last year some Wall Street analysts said the company, which had revenues of $630.5 million and earnings of $83 million in 1994, could fetch as much as $60 to $65 a share.
Yesterday's offer of $54 is in the ballpark, the analysts said, but only barely.
"Because of the decline in interest rates that has occurred since November, the $54-a-share offer could be considered at the lower end of what could be considered fair valuation for the company," said Ivy Schneider, an analyst at Salomon Brothers.
Based on the movement in National Gypsum's shares yesterday, investors and speculators do not seem to think the bidding will go any higher. National Gypsum shares closed at $51.875 yesterday in Nasdaq trading, up $2.125 a share.
Smith Barney Inc., financial adviser to a committee that National Gypsum formed to consider offers, said that the $54 offer was fair to the company's stockholders.
Delcor is controlled by C. D. Spangler Jr., who until earlier this year was the chairman of National Gypsum and is the company's largest single shareholder, with a 20 percent stake worth around $209 million. Delcor is a subsidiary of Golden Eagle Industries.
Joining Delcor in the deal are two North Carolina-based regional banking giants, the Nationsbank Corporation and First Union Bancorp, institutions that are normally fierce rivals.
Under the proposed terms of the transaction, Delcor and its partners will form a company to acquire National Gypsum and take the company private for the second time. National Gypsum went private in a $2 billion leveraged buyout by Aancor Holdings Inc. in 1986 to avoid a hostile takeover by the Wickes Companies.
Delcor and First Union, which owns about 4 percent of National Gypsum's stock, a stake worth about $42 million, will contribute their shares to the newly formed acquistion company. Nationsbank will contribute an additional $42 million in cash to buy equity.
With a net worth recently estimated at more than $800 million, Mr. Spangler is reputed to be North Carolina's wealthiest resident. Mr. Spengler was not available for comment yesterday.
National Gypsum, which emerged from bankruptcy protection in June, 1993 at $12.50 a share, is based in Charlotte, N.C.
In addition to its investment in National Gypsum, Delcor is one of the largest shareholders in RJR Nabisco and Nationsbank.
The $54 offer is the third Delcor has made for National Gypsum since November.
Its initial offer of $43.50 a share, or $940 million, was rejected as inadequate in December. In February, Delcor made a $600 million recapitalization offer for the company, an offer that included $34.50 in cash for each share plus a one-quarter share of the recapitalized company.
That offer was followed on Feb. 28 by a $1.12 billion, $48.50-a-share bid from BPB Industries P.L.C., a British company that is Europe's largest wallboard manufacturer.
National Gypsum rejected that offer three days later, but added it would consider a higher offer.
With a market capitalization of $2.5 billion, a healthy cash flow and little debt, BPB was seen as having the resources to raise its bid.
Lafarge-Coppee, a Paris-based wallboard maker that owns a 10 percent stake in National Gypsum, was also seen as a potential bidder.
But both companies said they were dropping out yesterday. Given the comparatively low cost of Delcor's current holdings in National Gypsum, buying all of the company's shares outstanding at a price of more than $54 a share was apparently seen as prohibitively high.

HEADLINE: Energy Commission Gives Utilities Freer Trade in Low-Cost Power

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
The Federal agency that oversees the nation's utility industry issued two orders yesterday aimed at widening access to the transmission system and making it easier for utilities and independent producers with surplus, low-cost power to sell it to other utilities.
Whether the savings will be passed on to consumers was not clear. The decisions by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission were another step in forcing the industry to allow more economical and freer trading of power. 
 Jeanine Hull, the president of the Electric Generation Association, an independent power trade group, said the decisions "will make it more likely that the person who has the lowest-cost power can get it to the end user."
As utilities get ready for more competition, those with low-cost excess power have been pushing for greater access to the tranmission systems, which are generally controlled by local utilities.
Utilities with high costs have often made it difficult for competitors to transmit power over their grids because they want to protect the viability of their own generating plants. The commision, however, struck a blow at such utilities yesterday.
In the past, the high-cost utilities have formed pools to transmit their own power and have been reluctant to allow outsiders to sell low- cost power over their systems. In the first action of its kind, the agency directed that all the members of a power pool provide more equitable transmission service to an outside utility.
The commission gave the 11 members of the Pennsylvania-New Jersey-Maryland Power pool 70 days to negotiate rates, terms and conditions for providing the Duquesne Light Company access to the pool's system.
The commission said the members should charge rates that are comparable to those they charge themselves for similar transmission service.
In a second order, the commission greatly encouraged regions to form regional transmission groups. Under such groups a large number of utilities, independent power producers and state agencies join to provide more equitable and easier access to power lines in an area covering many states.
The commission approved the first such group yesterday with the Western Regional Transmission Association, which has 40 members in a large area in the West.
A major goal of such groups, the commission said, was to move decision-making from Washington to the regions. The commission said it would defer to decisions made by such groups.
In March, the commission approved a sweeping proposal that would force utilities to open their transmission systems to competitors.
Under the proposal, which the commission is expected to carry out later this year, 137 investor-owned utiities would have to allow outside access to their transmission grids on the same basis that they use their grids.
Utilities would have to file prices for transmission service with the commission and disclose their transmission costs.
Yesterday's orders were seen as a further indication that the comission was determined to break down the barriers that block power sales among different producers.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Threatened Japan Car Tariffs Bring Broad Gains for the Dollar

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar strengthened against most leading currencies yesterday as expectations grew that the Clinton Administration's plan to impose punitive tariffs on 13 Japanese luxury car models would help cut the American trade deficit with Japan.
"The sanctions are being perceived as positive for the dollar," said Earl Johnson, at the Bank of Montreal/Harris Bank in Chicago. "Either the U.S. puts the sanctions on and that shrinks the deficit, or Japan makes concessions and that cuts the deficit." 
 Many analysts view the trade gap with Japan as the most important reason for the dollar's 13 percent fall against the yen this year. It leaves Japanese exporters with a steady supply of dollars to sell for yen when bringing their profits home.
The dollar rallied in European trading before the sanctions announcement. It also drew support from comments by two officials of Germany's central bank, who joined a chorus of specialists hinting at lower interest rates there. Lower German rates could help the dollar by making mark-denominated deposits less attractive.
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar settled at 86.57 Japanese yen, up from 86.40 yen late Monday. It rose to 1.4429 German marks from 1.4360 marks.
The dollar also strengthened against the French franc, rising to 5.1033 francs from 5.0325. It rose against the Swiss franc, to 1.2069 francs from 1.1988 on Monday. The Mexican peso strengthened to 5.925 to the dollar from 5.9300.
The dollar has gained 5.5 percent against the mark and 4 percent against the yen since May 8. It rose in European trading yesterday after a member of the Bundesbank Council, Olaf Sievert, said German interest rates were "on the high side." Another central banker, Edgar Meister, said the bank was keeping its options open on rates.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Surge on Signs Of Slowdown

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices rose sharply yesterday as the market continued to rally on more data showing fresh signs of an economic slowdown.
Reports showing a decline in industrial production in April and weak growth in housing fueled the rally yesterday. 
 "We are in a soft landing," said Jane Tedder, vice president and senior portfolio manager at the Security Management Company. "But I wouldn't be surprised to see rates bump up a little, just because I believe the market is a little oversold."
The price of the 30-year bond surged 14/32 , to 10921/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 6.86 percent, from 6.94 percent on Monday, the lowest since 6.84 percent on March 22, 1994. Two-year note yields fell five basis points, to 6.08 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Rates for shorter-maturity bills were also lower, but not as much as those for the longest maturities.
Dealers said the rally yesterday was hindered by rumors of central banks in Europe and Asia that were supposedly selling Treasury securities. But traders said there was no way to confirm the sales.
"Those rumors have been around the market since last week," said Matthew F. Alexy, chief market strategist for the CS First Boston Corporation in New York. "We basically inherited today's lofty levels from overnight trading."
The announcement of trade sanctions against Japanese imports had little effect on the market, as did comments by the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan. Speaking before the National Association of Realtors, Mr. Greenspan said, "It is not a goal of monetary policy to encourage fluctuations in interest rates."
The rally picked up pace after the Commerce Department reported that housing starts rose four-tenths of 1 percent in April, a weak rebound from a poor winter. Economists surveyed by Bloomberg Business News had expected housing starts would rise 9.1 percent.
Rusty Vanneman, a senior market analyst at Technical Data in Boston, said the housing starts report drove the market. "Even though the number was an improvement over the prior three months," he said, "the fact is it came in at a lower-than-expected rate, which showed that economy was still growing, but at a sluggish rate."
In addition, the Federal Reserve reported that industrial production slumped four-tenths of 1 percent. April capacity utilization use fell to 84.1 percent, the lowest in nine months.
Ms. Tedder of Security Management noted that the industrial production showed weakness in durable goods. "What that says is that people are spending less on large-ticket items and these signs bode well for the market going forward," she said.
"Although we've seen yields come down, we do think inflation is well enough under control according to signs in that economy," she added. " We could see the yield on the long bond down to about 6.50 percent by now and the end of the year."
Mr. Vanneman of Technical Data said: "Today the fundamental data support the bullish camp. But the bears kept the market from extending through last week's highs."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Fighting Piracy and Frustration in China;
Counterfeit Goods Flourish in a Legal System That Is Often Outwitted

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, May 16

 BODY:
Pu Xinghua, a plump man given to nervous giggling, leaned back in the witness box as he was asked whether the factory he manages had illegally copied compact disks, several of which were displayed before him in the courtroom.
"It's been a long time," Mr. Pu said, trying to suppress a laugh. "Maybe we made some like this, but I don't remember." 
 The chief judge, Yang Jun, raised an eyebrow. Lawyers said later that under an agreement that had been worked out before the court session, Mr. Pu was supposed to admit wrongdoing in exchange for avoiding further prosecution. Now Mr. Pu was apparently thumbing his nose at the agreement.
For the foreign plaintiff, an association of music companies from the United States and elsewhere, Mr. Pu's testimony in Shanghai Intermediate Court one recent morning was a sign that on top of all the many other frustrations in navigating China's evolving legal system the court was now unable to enforce its own decisions.
Only recently has it even become possible for a foreign company in China to take a local defendant to court and win. More than half the battle is simply getting into a courtroom, where proceedings are generally scripted to validate a decision that has already been made.
But if Chinese courts are inching toward greater fairness in disputes involving foreign companies, they are also becoming less able to control Chinese defendants. Fast-paced economic growth and receding regulation are making Chinese companies less accountable and harder to prosecute.
In the Shanghai case, the factory evaded any attempt at tough prosecution because Mr. Pu and other managers agreed to admit guilt, to produce previously withheld evidence and to promise not to copy any more CD's illegally. But the agreement turned out to be worthless.
"They're more afraid of their shareholders than they are of the court," said Cheng Ching-ming, the Chinese representative for the association of music companies, referring to Mr. Pu's factory and his partners in Taiwan.
Mr. Pu, whose factory is in Suzhou, about 50 miles from Shanghai, denied any wrongdoing, saying his partner from Taiwan was to blame for any illegal activity.
"We never promised to produce more evidence," Mr. Pu said in an interview later. "We said we'd go back and check to see if there was any more. But we cannot remember anything else. We can't remember, you understand?"
In light of the broken agreement, the court is considering possible sanctions on the Suzhou factory. But it is unclear how enforceable any sanctions would be.
Only a handful of intellectual property cases in China have ever been decided in favor of foreign companies. The first was the Walt Disney Company's victory in Beijing Intermediate Court in August, when it won a $77,000 judgment against Chinese companies that were producing children's books based on Disney's animated films.
With the complications and costs of going to court, international lawyers say many foreign companies prefer to counter their product-piracy problem quietly, by administrative measures. That usually means fines and sanctions -- smaller and swifter than those that can be won in court -- ordered by officials known as the copyright police.
Yet rather than settle disputes quietly, Mr. Cheng and a growing number of foreign companies choose to go to court to win redress for specific wrongs and to set precedents aimed at discouraging other pirates. But they are finding that things often do not go as planned.
Mr. Cheng represents the International Federation of Phonographic Industries, a trade association of more than 200 music companies from the United States, Britain and Hong Kong, including Sony Music and Thorn EMI.
The companies say they are losing hundreds of millions of dollars a year from piracy of their recordings in China, a crime so rampant that it was a big element in the trade dispute that flared between the United States and China early this year, and was solved only when China agreed to a detailed plan to get tough on offenders.
The Suzhou case -- which lawyers call a crucial test of the campaign to clamp down on piracy -- originated early last year, when Mr. Cheng found evidence that Mr. Pu's factory was illegally copying foreign recordings of music. Shanghai authorities investigated and arrested a Taiwanese man, accusing him of supplying the factory with CD's and copying at least 120,000 of them to be sold in Southeast Asia.
Although the Suzhou factory managers would not discuss the case in detail, the sequence of events described by Mr. Cheng was verified by court officials and by lawyers familiar with the case.
About a year ago, Mr. Cheng filed a suit against the partner from Taiwan, Xu Huale. But, even though he was ordered to remain in the Shanghai area and had his passport confiscated, Mr. Xu somehow fled to Taiwan to escape prosecution. Mr. Cheng then shifted his focus to the Suzhou Baodi Electronic Equipment Company, accusing Mr. Pu and other managers of violating copyright laws.
In the following months, Mr. Cheng repeatedly came under pressure from various parts of the Chinese Government, with officials urging him to settle the case and arguing that the $1.8 million in damages being sought might put the factory out of business. Mr. Cheng responded that bankrupting the factory would be the clearest possible signal to pirates that China was serious about cracking down on intellectual property violations.
In part because Mr. Cheng originally persuaded the authorities in Shanghai to investigate, Shanghai Intermediate Court accepted the case and scheduled a court date.
A delicate negotiation ensued. The authorities from Beijing, Suzhou and Shanghai each discussed the case with judges in the Shanghai court, Mr. Cheng said. Officials from Su-zhou pleaded a combination of ignorance and poverty, saying that the factory managers had not known they were doing wrong and that it was unfair to single them out when piracy is so common in China.
Officials from Beijing, seeking to show their American counterparts that they were sincere about cracking down on intellectual property violations, wanted a speedy solution that at least gave the appearance of decisive action. (American officials say they welcome China's new willingness to consider cases involving foreign companies, but will continue to press for legal, rather than political, solutions.)
And officials from Shanghai, where many local companies are themselves the victims of intellectual piracy by other Chinese companies, also argued for firm action. A majority of intellectual property cases in China now are between domestic companies, and a growing number of Chinese companies are arguing for tougher penalties against offenders.
A decision was finally reached a few weeks ago, Mr. Cheng said, shortly before the trial was held. Under the agreement, Mr. Cheng would drop his case against the Suzhou factory and name Mr. Xu of Taiwan as the sole defendant. In exchange, officials of the Suzhou factory promised to apologize, to release documents they had refused to disclose and not to copy any more CD's.
In addition, Mr. Cheng said, the chief judge assured him that if any evidence turned up later indicating that the factory was still up to its old tricks, the court would accept a new case against the factory.
"It's not what we wanted," said Mr. Cheng, a Shanghai native who now holds Hong Kong travel documents. "But we have to cooperate with the court" even when deals fall apart.
Mr. Cheng pointed out that he was in a difficult position. As the representative of foreign music companies, his overarching concern is to stem pirating of CD's. But as part of a foreign organization allowed by China to operate an office in Shanghai, he cannot ignore the Government's wishes.
The agreement, Mr. Cheng said, was a carefully calculated political solution. It allowed a foreign plaintiff with hard evidence to win its case, but it also let the Suzhou factory off the hook. And then the court proceedings could heap blame on Mr. Xu, who had already escaped.
"By the time the session opened, it was very clear which side would win," Mr. Cheng said. "Otherwise they would not dare hold a court session."
"It's probably true that they didn't know much about the law when this case started," he said of his adversaries. "When I first visited their factory, they gave me a freshly copied CD as a gift. Can you believe it?"
