HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
The Turkish Nightmare

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
On my way home from Moscow a couple of weeks ago, I visited Turkey. Talk about a country in a bad neighborhood. Look at a map. Turkey today provides one-stop shopping to all the troubles of the post-cold-war world. Turkey is connected geographically, ethnically or politically to the problems of Iraq, Iran, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Bosnia, Cyprus, Greece, Bulgaria, Russia, Tajikistan, Syria and Islamic fundamentalism. All the Turks are missing is a border with Chechnya. No wonder Turkey had four foreign ministers last year. Turkish foreign policy today is a 360-degree nightmare.
It is also more important to the U.S. than ever before. During the cold war, Turkey was the southern fringe of the NATO alliance. Today, Turkey is the epicenter of a new regional system born from the ruins of the Soviet empire. It's called Eurasia, and it stretches from the Balkans across the Caucasus to the new states of Central Asia. This is a predominantly Muslim, Turkish-speaking or ethnically Turkish grouping of new states, many of them still groping for a political identity. 
 A weak Turkey will be consumed by the troubles of this region and project them into Europe. A strong Turkey, tied to the West, can radiate its values (and counter Iran's) to millions of Muslims from Azerbaijan to Kazakhstan -- values that are basically democratic and inclined toward moderate Islam and integration with the global economy.
But Turkey's own identity now hangs in the balance. The good news is that the Turks are about to be admitted into the European Community's customs union, which would make them part of the single E.U. common market. That integration is a vital U.S. interest, because it would solidly anchor Turkey to Western Europe and its secular, democratic, free-market systems.
The bad news is that on the eve of this historic opportunity, the Turks are being sucked back into the snake pit of Middle East politics. Northern Iraq has been a power vacuum ever since the U.S. banned Saddam Hussein from governing there. That vacuum has been filled partly by the Marxist Kurdish Workers Party, or P.K.K., which is trying to break off the eastern half of Turkey to create a Kurdish state. The Turks recently mounted a massive incursion into northern Iraq to crush the P.K.K. But here's the rub: Many members of the European Parliament, who have a romantic commitment to Kurdish nationalism and despise the Turks because they are Muslims, now want to use Turkey's attack on the P.K.K. as an excuse not to ratify Turkey's accession to the E.U. customs union.
The Clinton Administration, which played a smart and decisive role in persuading the E.U. to admit Turkey, needs to urgently launch a diplomatic offensive to preserve the fruits of its labor. The Administration has a sound Turkey policy, but it has a dead-end northern Iraq policy, and unless this is straightened out, Turkey is going to fall out of the E.U. right into the abyss of northern Iraq.
I see four options: Option One, preferred by most Turks, is to cut a deal with Saddam to restore his authority over northern Iraq and clamp down on the Kurds there. The U.S., which wants to keep Saddam boxed up in Baghdad, opposes this. Option Two, favored by Washington, is for the U.S. and Turkey to work together with the moderate, but rival, Iraqi Kurdish clans -- the Barzanis and Talabanis -- to set up a power structure that can fill the northern Iraq vacuum. (I have my doubts about this. The Iraqi Kurdish leaders are the Hatfields and McCoys, obsessed with their tribal feuds. They don't not have a state for nothing.)
Option Three is for Turkish troops to keep going into Iraq, which would mean constant friction with the E.U. Option Four is getting someone to offer an exploding cigar to Saddam so he will go "boom" and be replaced by "nice" Iraqi dictators whom the U.S. would let restore Baghdad's authority over Kurdish northern Iraq.
The bottom line: If Washington believes in Option Two it had better get cracking -- offer the Turks technical help with sealing their Iraqi border. Send a top U.S. official there to persuade the Iraqi Kurds to set aside their differences, control their territory and keep the P.K.K. out. And remind the Turks that the best way to fight Kurdish separatism is to make Turkish Kurds feel at home, with more freedom of expression and human rights.
If all this fails, start rummaging in the C.I.A.'s basement for those exploding Havana cigars.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Greenspan Says Weak Dollar Is Caused by Federal Deficits

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, today attributed the dollar's weakness to large Federal budget deficits and welcomed recent efforts to balance the budget.
In his first public comments since Congressional Republicans introduced plans last week to balance the budget by 2002, Mr. Greenspan emphasized the importance of deficit reduction to the American economy and the dollar's value. But in keeping with the Federal Reserve's tradition of nonpartisanship, he avoided any specific reference to any proposal. 
 "I am encouraged with the increased attention the persistent Federal budget imbalance and its consequences have been receiving in the past few years," Mr. Greenspan said in a speech here this morning to the directors of the National Association of Realtors. "Important steps have been taken, but it is essential that the momentum toward reducing, and eventually eliminating, the deficit be accelerated."
Today's comments, although vaguely worded, are significant because Republicans are hoping that Mr. Greenspan will hold down short-term interest rates to reward them for any success in cutting budget deficits. Democrats have begun to argue that if Congress were to cut the deficit sharply without any move by the Federal Reserve to ease monetary policy, the economy might slow even further than it already has.
Mr. Greenspan's comments today strongly indicated that he thought serious deficit reduction would help the dollar's value, which might otherwise be undermined by lower or steady interest rates.
While Mr. Greenspan did not say so, a stronger dollar would also leave the Federal Reserve with more freedom to cut interest rates if it perceived the American economy to be slowing sharply. While the dollar has rebounded in the last week against the Japanese yen and German mark, it remains below its level at the beginning of the year.
Mr. Greenspan has consistently advocated deficit reduction, whether initiated by Democrats or Republicans. He was the object of Republican criticism in 1993 when he sat next to Hillary Rodham Clinton at the State of the Union address, leading some to conclude he was supporting President Clinton's deficit reduction effort that year.
Mr. Greenspan stopped short today of repeating his hint in Congressional testimony earlier this year that he might adopt a less restrictive monetary policy if Congress took decisive steps to curb the budget deficit. Instead, Mr. Greenspan spoke in another section of his speech today of the importance to business people of providing a stable business environment.
"I can assure you that it is not a goal of monetary policy to encourage fluctuations in interest rates, even if it does make your lives more interesting," Mr. Greenspan said.
The Federal Reserve's top interest-rate policy committee is scheduled to meet next Tuesday, but Fed officials have been playing down the prospects for policy changes then. While Mr. Greenspan did not specifically address what might happen next, it is unusual for him to mention interest rate policy at all so close to a meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, and today's reference came early and prominently in the speech.
Mr. Greenspan was a little more specific in linking the dollar to budget deficits. Federal deficits, and the accompanying Government borrowing, are absorbing large sums of American savings and forcing the country to look abroad to finance investment, he said, adding that foreigners may be growing reluctant to continue providing money.
"Looking back at the history of the past century or more, the record would suggest that nations ultimately must rely on their domestic savings to support domestic investment," he said. "Given the weakness in the foreign exchange value of the dollar earlier this year, world capital markets may have been sending us just that message."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gasoline Prices Set 3-Year Highs

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Gasoline prices surged to three-year highs yesterday after an oil company reported another refinery shutdown just before the start of the busy summer driving season.
The Marathon Oil Company, a division of the USX Corporation, said it had shut down nearly half its 70,000-barrel-a-day refinery in Texas City, Tex., because of an unknown mechanical problem. The company said there had been a small release of pollutants and that it did not know when the gas component unit would be restarted. 
 The announcement was the latest in a string of shutdowns at American and foreign refineries that threaten to drive up wholesale prices significantly, analysts said.
On other commodity markets, lumber prices plunged on weak economic data and coffee prices retreated in technical selling. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities jumped 0.99 point, to 231.67.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, gasoline for June delivery rose 1.40 cents, to 66.30 cents a gallon, the highest near-term contract price since June 10, 1992. Crude oil also rose, with the June contract ending at more than $20 a barrel for the first time in a week, settling 18 cents higher at $20.08 a barrel.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
It's almost nothing but blue skies for Big Blue. At least for now.

BYLINE: By Laurence Zuckerman 

 BODY:
WHAT a difference a quarter makes. Since reporting surprisingly strong earnings on April 20, I.B.M.'s stock has surged nearly 9 percent. Analysts who saw the company outperform previous estimates by a wide margin have since raised their forecasts to twice what they were at the beginning of 1994 and are enthusiastically recommending the stock.
After pleasantly surprising wary investors for 12 months, could it be that the long I.B.M. nightmare is over? 
 "I.B.M. is on the verge of going from a cost-cutting story to a genuine momentum story," said James J. Cramer, president of Cramer & Company, a New York money manager. "We are entering Year Three of what is going to be a legendary turnaround."
Last year was the International Business Machine Corporation's first profitable one since 1990, earning $4.92 a share. The current analyst consensus is that I.B.M. will earn $9.19 a share this year and $10.37 in 1996, according to Zacks Investment Research. Many analysts now predict that 1996 will surpass I.B.M.'s all-time earnings record of $10.77 a share set in 1984.
"I don't see why the stock couldn't sell at $140 or higher sometime next year," said Shelton Swei, vice president at Fred Alger Management Inc. in New York. Shares of I.B.M. slipped 37.5 cents yesterday, to $94.625, still near its 52-week high of $96.875 set on April 27 and the highest the stock has been since July 1992.
It was only a few months ago that Mr. Cramer, who began buying I.B.M. shares when they hit a low of $41 in August 1993, sold most of his 500,000 shares. At the time, he believed that the company had reaped all the benefits of a campaign to cut overhead and would not see much future revenue growth. But after the company's latest results -- which showed healthy growth in virtually all its businesses, especially in services -- he began buying again and now holds 150,000 shares.
Mr. Cramer is particularly impressed that I.B.M. has amassed more than $10 billion in cash while spending $1.4 billion buying back stock.
"This is a company that is not a mainframe company anymore," he said. "It's going to be an ultimate-solutions provider. That's a high-margin business."
While few argue about the positive outlook for 1995, not everyone is so optimistic about next year. The bears note that I.B.M. has been riding a wave of lucky circumstance hard to sustain.
For example, a third of the company's 18 percent revenue gain in the quarter came from currency-exchange rates as the dollar weakened against local currencies in key markets like Japan and Germany. The strong economy and pent-up demand also helped the company register surprisingly strong sales of its old-style mainframes. I.B.M. also benefited from favorable comparisons with a weak first quarter in 1994.
If the dollar firms and the economy slows, as many analysts predict, I.B.M.'s momentum may slow as well. Also, I.B.M.'s increasing dependence on volume businesses like personal computers and growing competition from rival service providers could erode its profit margins, making increased revenue all the more important. And I.B.M. is nearing the end of the $8 billion cost-cutting campaign that has constituted the bulk of its renewed earnings strength.
"By mid-1996, I.B.M. will have eked out the maximum benefit from its cost and expense-cutting efforts in the previous three years," Bob Djurdjevic of Annex Research, an industry consultant based in Phoenix, wrote in a recent issue of his newsletter. "To grow its profits again, it will have to start growing its revenues first. That will be easier said than done."
Mr. Djurdjevic estimated that I.B.M.'s 1995 earnings would be stronger than predicted, but that its 1996 earnings would be much weaker, at $8.04 a share.
Steve Milunovich, an analyst with Morgan Stanley, said, "My feeling is that I.B.M. will run into trouble again, but it will probably be when the stock is at a higher altitude."
Which, to some analysts, is forecasting too far. "For the next three quarters it's a no-brainer," Dan Mandresh, an analyst with Merrill Lynch & Company, said. "Wait until the stock gets to $125 and then we'll discuss it."

HEADLINE: Organic Industry Faces An Ethics Question

BYLINE: By MOLLY O'NEILL 

 BODY:
ORGANIC food customers have always relied on the good faith of growers, retailers and private certifying companies to assure them that the food they are buying has been raised with the fewest chemicals possible. But now, a class-action lawsuit filed recently in San Diego is shining a spotlight on the ethics and practices of the organic food industry, which is largely self-regulated.
In the suit, Nina Hopkins Brothers, 43, an organic-foods educator, charges that two produce companies and two associations that certify organic produce sold, as organic, Mexican bananas treated with a fungicide. 
 Although organic food is still a small part of the total food dollar, it is a rapidly growing part. Sales of organic food in the United States have soared 23 percent each year for five years, to $2.2 billion in 1994. The expansion has increased competition, brought in bigger companies and raised questions about whether self-policing should be replaced by Federal regulation. And consumers have become increasingly concerned about the purity of food.
Lawyers and members of the organic industry say that the suit, which was filed March 9 and seeks punitive damages as well as redress, is the first class-action lawsuit filed on behalf of organic consumers.
While rumors of taint and corner-cutting are commonplace among shoppers who seek organic produce and among retailers, the case of the questionable bananas is the first that "has reached a critical head and might affect consumer confidence," said Ken Mergentime, the associate editor of Natural Foods Merchandiser, a trade magazine in Boulder, Colo.
Indeed, many organic food customers interviewed in Berkeley, Calif.; Boston, and New York said the case could raise questions about all organic food.
"I would certainly be more leery of the organic label if it turns out that some growers are not being honest," said Nanette Cippa-Fukushima, a shopper at the Berkeley Bowl market in Berkeley. Customers, she added, "will start asking themselves if what they are buying is really organic."
For retailers, the issues raised by the questionable bananas are more pragmatic than they are emotional.
Bill Fujimoto, owner of the Monterey Market in Berkeley, has not stocked organic bananas for more than two years. "I may be assured by people with the greatest integrity that something is organic, but I can still have my doubts," he said. "The produce that comes out of Mexico right now seems to do so much too easily. There is a great deal of money involved, big new players. It's ripe for graft and manipulation. I have no details. It's just that the market is growing too fast."
Bob Scowcroft, the executive director of the Organic Farming Research Foundation in Santa Cruz, Calif., said the case "couldn't be better timed." He continued: "The case is a microcosm of every issue that the organic family faces. It questions standards, self-regulation and the role of government, as well as the impact of international growers and the effect of big-money success on what used to be a small niche market."
The case centers on tons of bananas grown in the Mexican states of Colima, Michoacan and Jalisco that, the suit says, were treated with chemical fungicides to combat black sigatoka, a tropical fungus that began to infest the states' plantations in 1990.
Filing alone on behalf of all organic banana customers, Ms. Brothers has charged that the companies violated the California Organic Act of 1990, committed fraud and deceit and misrepresented and falsely advertised their products.
Although the fungicides cannot legally be administered to organic produce sold in California, two companies are accused of importing, advertising and selling the fruit as organic -- the Mexican American Fruit Company of National City, Calif., and Made in Nature, a company based in San Rafael, Calif., that is now owned by the Dole Fruit Company.
In addition, the suit accuses two groups that certify organic produce, the Organic Crop Improvement Association of Bellefontaine, Ohio, and Quality Assurance International of San Diego of lending their stamp of approval to the treated fruit.
Made in Nature, stopped selling the bananas before the suit was filed.
"When they heard rumors about possible taint, they immediately withdrew the product," said Thomas Pernice, the vice president of public affairs at Dole Fruit in Los Angeles.
 The Mexican American Fruit Company still sells the bananas from the three Mexican states. "We believe the complaint is groundless, plan to fight it and expect to be vindicated," said the company's lawyer, Chris Healy of San Diego.
The two certification boards stand by the bananas in question. "The suit is useless and frivolous," said Griff McLellan, the director of Quality Assurance International.
Betty Kananen, the director of the Organic Crop Improvement Association, said that after review, her organization concluded that "the bananas that were treated were never represented as organic and that the bananas that were represented as organic were never treated."
Nevertheless, Ms. Kananen, whose organization has grown from 100 members in 1985 to nearly 20,000, said she was walking a fine line philosophically in choosing to fight the charges.
"The bigger the business is, the more chance there is for litigation, founded or unfounded," she said. "On the other hand, the organic industry has grown so fast that there is no way we can keep all the crooks out."
Mr. Scowcroft said "not a week goes by that I am not approached by venture capitalists interested in getting into the organic market, and I don't know of one major food company that isn't invovled in developing some organic product."
Along with major food corporations, Ms. Kananen said, isolated right-wing subsistence farmers have joined the "hard-core charter members who are by and large the sort of liberal environmentalists who have fought tooth and nail to maintain integrity and police themselves."
This internal diversification and growth, Ms. Kananen said, "has created a need for Federal regulation."
Eleven states have organic labeling laws, and most rely on -- and pay for the services of -- the country's 17 private certification companies to verify that food is organic. Generally, the certifiers visit commercial organic farms annually, test soil samples and collate records of agricultural chemical purchase and use to verify that growers are maintaining organic practices.
The charges in the lawsuit suggest that the time that elapses between such inspections and the investigation of complaints could allow nonorganic produce to be certified and sold. And Ms. Kananen said that impending Federal regulations could further slow investigations.
"The more bureaucracy and paper it takes to complete an investigation, the more chance there is that questionable product could hit the market," she said.
Like many growers, she says she hopes that the National Organic Program, a labeling law for fruits, vegetables, meats and processed foods that is being developed by the United States Agriculture Department, will not hinder timely response to consumer complaints.
But it is unclear when the Federal program, which seeks to establish a single national standard for organic food, will be set up, said Beth Hayden, a marketing specialist at the Agriculture Department in Washington. Meanwhile, the organic industry remains largely self-regulated.
Ms. Kananen said that the bulk of the complaints her association receives are "competitor driven" and are rarely substantiated. Of the 6,000 farms that have been certified by the Organic Crop Improvement Association over the last decade, for instance, only six have had their certification revoked. Noting that an equally small percentage of complaints have been substantiated in California since that state's organic foods act of 1990 went into effect, Mr. Scowcroft said, "Basically, self-regulation is working."
But to Ms. Brothers, who filed the suit, the bananas suggest that industry standards may be flagging.
"I teach the organic lifestyle to my patients all day long," said Ms. Brothers, who also is a practitioner of homeopathy, the leading Western scientific system of natural medicine. "And when they go out of their way to find organic food and pay up to three times as much to buy it, they deserve to know they are getting what they pay for."
In addition to raising legal and ethical concerns, the suit draws a furrow in a field long divided between people whose organic farming sprouted from environmental, taste or health concerns and those who produce organic food with an eye to profit.
Mr. Scowcroft said that organic farming is a business, not a movement. "The business is built on the consumer's right to know, but organic farming has always been a business," he said. "It has never been a not-for-profit movement.
"As the industry grows, the commitment to the public's right to know grays. The larger the business, the greater the pressure to move toward a less costly, less thorough delivery system of documentation."

HEADLINE: We'd Like to Make a Reservation: Table for 1,000, Please

BYLINE: By FLORENCE FABRICANT 

 BODY:
A RESTAURANT complex capable of feeding thousands of people opens tomorrow in Bryant Park, behind the New York Public Library. It is the latest of New York's mega-restaurants. And there are more to come.
Though big may not mean better food, restaurateurs say huge places are likely to be more profitable, and make it possible to give customers more for their money. 
 Just like the retailing giants flocking to the city, these restaurants are changing New York's dining scene. In the next few months, Crab House, a seafood chain, will open a 500-seat restaurant on Pier 61, at 21st Street, in the Chelsea Piers sports complex; the 350-seat Motown Cafe will open on West 57th Street; Robert Earl's 700-seat Official All Star Cafe will open in Times Square, and in Brooklyn, Lundy's in Sheepshead Bay is being renovated and will reopen with 800 seats in 17,000 square feet of space.
"It's easier to make money in a big restaurant," said Warner LeRoy, the owner of Tavern on the Green, which on Sunday served 2,800 dinners for Mother's Day. With 800 seats, its annual gross earnings are $32 million. But money is not the only attraction. "Big restaurants are also more fun," Mr. LeRoy said.
The Bryant Park complex is owned by Ark Restaurants, whose president, Michael Weinstein, started his portfolio with the Museum Cafe 20 years ago and recently bought Lutece.
Although Mr. Weinstein is accustomed to dealing with big restaurants -- his company owns the 350-seat America in the Flatiron District -- the Bryant Park operation is large even for him. Bryant Park Grill, an airy space that seats 220 in the wood and stone building with green trellis trim designed by Hugh Hardy, has a rustic formality. It can expand with 300 outdoor seats. The casual BP Cafe can accommodate another 700, and there is also a roof terrace with 200 seats.
On a glorious summer day, the restaurants could conceivably serve 4,000. "The numbers are staggering," said Ridgely Trufant, the manager of the Bryant Park complex. "I'll have 250 or so people just in the front of the house."
Increasingly, the charming 60-seat restaurant with impeccable food is the entrepreneur's nightmare, not dream. Few restaurateurs who are interested in the bottom line will even consider a space with less than 150 seats.
Other dining giants that have opened in New York in the last year include Cafe Centro in the Met Life Building, which has two dining areas seating 350 in addition to room for another 100 outdoors, and Brother's Bar-B-Que at 77th Street and Broadway, with 425 seats. Gramercy Tavern in the Flatiron District is no small potatoes either. It seats 260 in its main dining room along with 100 or so in the more informal barroom.
"In terms of management, going from 150 to 250 seats is not a backbreaking shift," said Michael Whiteman, who with his partner, Joseph Baum, is working on the renovation of Windows on the World. They hope the restaurant, which will seat 500 in three areas, will open by December. They expect gross sales to reach $35 million within two years.
Consumer demand for value, which began to affect all kinds of restaurants in the late 1980's, has also forced the restaurants to become larger. It is easier to serve casual food and charge less when the place seats hundreds.
Jonathan Waxman, the executive chef for Ark, planned the contemporary American menus for the Bryant Park restaurants, where the prices range from inexpensive in the outdoor cafe to a high of $18.95 for main dishes in the Grill.
"They say that volume cures all ills," he said. "It's largely true. With this kind of volume you have great buying power. And there is a point at which you don't have to increase your labor costs commensurately with the number of covers." For example, Mr. Waxman said, whether you have 30 seats or 100, you still need a bartender.
"I was scared to death of large restaurants," he said. "But once you learn how to organize and simplify, there's a lot you can do without sacrificing quality."
Providing high quality is the challenge. Mr. Whiteman said, "Quality is the easiest thing to fall apart."
One highly regarded chef who has accepted the challenge is Patrick Clark. He recently took over the vast kitchens, with 52 cooks, at Tavern on the Green. "You have to simplify some things and be realistic," he said. For example, the kitchen is so far from parts of the dining room that covers have to be put on the plates; that means he cannot use crisp garnishes -- that stylish tangle of fried leeks -- because they will become soggy.
Though efficient centralized management is critical to successful large restaurants, the daunting spaces are often broken into different areas, sometimes with separate kitchens, as at Bryant Park.
"You have to fracture the sheer size," Mr. Baum said. "And in the final analysis, you still have to think of it as serving the individual diner. You must pretend you're Andre Soltner all the time and never lose sight of that." At Windows on the World, there will be three kitchens, each with its own executive chef.
Though the potential for a high-profit margin is alluring, especially in New York, where the cost of doing business is greater than in other cities, big is not for everybody. For one thing, the start-up costs are immense. It's not just a matter of throwing a coat of paint on a storefront and changing the awning. Bayport Restaurant Group, which owns the Crab House, is investing $3 million to build the restaurant on Chelsea Piers. It is the first of three they plan to open in the region in the next year. One, seating about 300 in 10,000 square feet of space, will open in the fall in Great Neck, L.I., and the other will open next year on a pier in Edgewater, N.J., near the George Washington Bridge.
Often, merely negotiating for striking one-of-a-kind locations, which may be controlled by municipal agencies, takes much longer and eats more capital through planning costs and legal fees. Bryant Park, for example, took 11 years to develop. Ark Restaurants became involved in the project about five years ago, but still the restaurants are opening a year later than Mr. Weinstein had planned. The brutal winter of 1993-94 delayed construction because the ground was frozen.
Large restaurants have their own particular problems. Take storage. Ms. Trufant said that for the Bryant Park restaurants, beer deliveries are going to be made daily instead of the more typical once or twice a week. The restaurants have installed 25 phone lines just to register credit card payments. Mr. Weinstein said he also spent $100,000 to restore the statue of William Cullen Bryant, for whom the park is named.
Big restaurants usually take care of their own maintenance and printing. They have fleets of trucks that break down or get ticketed for double-parking. Tavern on the Green has its own upholstery shop. "And the bigger you are the more interested the unions are in you," Mr. LeRoy of Tavern on the Green said.
At one time, he owned the 800-seat Potomac in Washington, which is now owned by Ark Restaurants and has been renamed Sequoia. Mr. LeRoy said he sold it because he had landlord problems. "I spent $1 million in legal fees in one year," he said. "In retrospect, I probably should not have sold it. The restaurant was doing $11 million." There is a new landlord. And John Poon, who was the chef at Sequoia, is the executive chef at Bryant Park.
Like Mr. LeRoy, Mr. Weinstein and other restaurateurs find running big restaurants exciting. Frank Cretella, whose company, Tam Restaurant Group of Staten Island, owns Lundy's in Sheepshead Bay, said, "You create a whole atmosphere with a different kind of energy."
Nick Valenti, the chairman of Restaurant Associates, which owns Cafe Centro, explained that big restaurants make it possible to have enough seats to take care of the business at the busy times.
"To make value pay you need more seats and a good turnover," he said. "Each restaurant has its break-even point. After that, a certain percentage of every order will drop to the bottom line. The bigger you are the easier it gets.
Sometimes, a restaurateur does not need sheer size for high volume. Steve Hanson owns Isabella's on the Upper West Side, which serves more than 1,000 meals a day with 150 seats in 1,800 square feet of space. "That's not typical," he said. One of his other restaurants, Park Avalon in the Flatiron District, has 185 seats in 7,000 square feet and handles the same volume. But he, too, is looking at larger spaces, 300 seats near Lincoln Center and 250 in lower Manhattan.
"The economy of scale just works," he said. "It takes the same amount of energy to run if you do it right. But it's a double-edged sword because it can wipe you out faster. There's nothing like looking at a $35,000 weekly payroll and being faced with a major snowstorm."
And right now, in Bryant Park, no one is praying for rain.

HEADLINE: Mr. Moynihan's Sensible Welfare Plan

 BODY:
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, who knows as much about welfare policy as anyone in the country, has broken a silence on the issue with a blast of scorn for nearly everyone engaged in the battle on Capitol Hill. He has ridiculed Republicans for proposing "punishing, punitive" welfare reform and President Clinton for inviting the G.O.P. attack by promising reforms he could not achieve. The Senator offers a welfare plan of his own that provides an alternative to root for.
The criticism of Mr. Clinton is partly unfair. Yes, his campaign to impose time limits on welfare benefits invited the G.O.P. to press for even harsher limits. But at least he acknowledged the Government's responsibility to provide jobs -- along with child care and health insurance -- to recipients who exhaust their benefits but cannot find employment. The President can more properly be faulted for disappearing from the debate. He needs to back up his approach by pledging to veto any bill that strips poor families of all Federal guarantees of cash and food assistance. At least then, the Democrats will stand for something firm and just. 
 Mr. Moynihan's criticism of the Senate Republicans is on target. They plan to end Federal entitlements for cash and perhaps for food stamps. They would turn over fixed blocks of money to the states to use with no requirement that states contribute their own money. With some exceptions, states could use the Federal money pretty much as they please. Block grants would take little account of the need for Washington to help out during recessions when poverty rolls swell. Block grants would also invite states -- without fear of losing Federal money -- to cut benefits and apply the savings to keeping taxes low as a strategy to attract business and repel the poor. The House takes the Senate's bad plan and makes it worse, adding restrictions that would prevent states from helping legal immigrants and teen-age mothers.
Mr. Moynihan points out that the G.O.P. has no evidence that its punitive measures would cut down out-of-wedlock births or welfare dependency. He proposes a sensible alternative -- building on the 1988 Family Support Act, which he sponsored. Under that law, Congress provides matching funds to states for welfare-to-work programs. The act has produced disappointing results in part because Congress appropriated an inadequate $1 billion a year.
Mr. Moynihan would increase Federal money, reduce the state share and raise the percentage of recipients that states would be required to put into welfare-to-work programs. He would also give states more freedom to experiment with their own reforms. The strategy is sound because studies show that well-designed welfare-to-work programs have modestly reduced state welfare rolls.
Modest may not sound exciting -- stacked up against the President's pledge to overhaul welfare and the G.O.P.'s pledge to smash it. But Mr. Moynihan offers the only plan before Congress that is both feasible and compassionate.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Science Is for Childless Women

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I am one of those women who "leaked" out of the pipelines referred to in "Why Science Loses Women in the Ranks" (Week in Review, May 14). 
 There is no question that the hours are long and demanding for a bench scientist, and that this is difficult to reconcile with a family. However, the idea of solving this problem by "devoting time to the kids when they are young and coming back to the lab full-force when infant needs abate" is so unrealistic as to be comical.
In bench science, no second prizes are awarded, and the economic situation demands unrelenting writing of grant applications and publication of results.
I have not met a woman yet who, for example, left a tenure-track position in science to take four or five years out for raising infants and then returned to the tenure track.
In my experience, my female colleagues worked to within a week of delivery and averaged four weeks or less of maternity leave; maternity leave being time spent at home with an infant in one hand and a telephone connected to the lab in the other.
With funding for the biological sciences undergoing dramatic cuts, you will also find very few female scientists willing to discuss their difficulties for fear of being labeled lame ducks within their departments. It is not surprising that many eventually make a heart-wrenching decision to leave bench science to those who have no children or to those who are fortunate to have that acknowledged asset, a wife.
Women scientists are not so special. The vast majority of working women in the United States compromise their careers to raise their children.
This is not necessarily due to their spouses' refusal to contribute to parenting, but is more a practical decision driven by the fact that men are still commonly better paid than their wives, and it is the job with the lower wages that gets compromised to accommodate the needs of a new child.
Until the provision of child care is given a high priority and care givers are recognized as protecting our most precious resource, women will never fulfill their true career potential in any competitive field; scientific research is only one example of this phenomenon.
 
STEPHANIE DIMENT
Brooklyn, May 15, 1995

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: U.S. Makes A New Offer To Serbian

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 17

 BODY:
Grasping for ways to slow the renewed fighting in Bosnia, an American diplomat has presented Serbia's President with a new plan that would offer Serbia greater relief from sanctions than a previous rejected offer if in return it recognizes Bosnia's borders, Western diplomats said today.
The officials said they hoped the new plan, which was presented to Serbia's President, Slobodan Milosevic, in talks on Tuesday and today in Belgrade, would win his assent because it offers him more relief from sanctions than did a plan he rejected last winter. 
 He had rejected the previous plan because he wanted sanctions eased before he recognized Bosnia. The new plan promises faster relief than did the previous plan.
The new plan calls on Serbia to recognize Bosnia's borders -- a step that Western diplomats say would be an important one toward reducing tension -- and allow the United Nations to station more monitors along Serbia's borders to cut off trade with and the Bosnian Serbs. The plan also calls on Serbia to grant limited recognition to Croatia.
In return, Administration officials said, the United Nations would suspend economic sanctions on Serbia, except for the embargo on oil and arms.
"We hope it would be a defusing step that would back all the tensions down," a senior Administration official said.
In the hope of getting Serbia to step up pressure on the Bosnian Serbs, the new offer suggests that all sanctions on Serbia would be lifted, and not just suspended, if the Bosnian Serbs accept a compromise map that would give Bosnia's Muslim-dominated Government control of 51 percent of the country's land. The Bosnian Serbs, who now control more than 70 percent of Bosnia, would be given 49 percent.
"We have no indication that Milosevic is ready to accept at this point," a senior State Department official said.
American diplomats said the plan is intended to get Mr. Milosevic to apply more pressure on the Bosnian Serbs to make peace, to isolate them diplomatically and to cut off the flow of arms and goods that they need to continue fighting.
"All this is aimed at strangling Pale," said an Administration official, referring to the headquarters of the Bosnian Serbs.
Serbian recognition would not lead to immediate peace in Bosnia since Bosnia's Serbs have grown increasingly defiant of Mr. Milosevic. Nonetheless, such recognition is considered important because Mr. Milosevic, who is widely seen as having instigated the war, would in effect give up his dream of adding most of Bosnia to a Greater Serbia.
The new offer was completed last Friday at a meeting in Frankfurt of senior officials from the United States, Russia, Britain, France and Germany. Deputy Assistant Secretary of State Robert Frasure went to Belgrade this week to present the plan to Mr. Milosevic.
American diplomats see several reasons why Mr. Milosevic might accept the revised plan when he rejected a previous one, with the assertion that the sanctions relief should come before Serbia recognized Bosnia's border, not after. The United States sees Mr. Milosevic as the most powerful leader in the Balkans and a pivotal figure in any peace efforts in the former Yugoslavia.
According to American diplomats, Mr. Milosevic is concerned about a possible pullout of United Nations forces and was jolted and disappointed by the successful offensive undertaken two weeks ago by Croatia's Government against Serb-held territory in Croatia. These diplomats said he is also worried by the Bosnian Government's recent offensive and by increasing talk about lifting the arms embargo against the Bosnian Government.
Another important factor, American diplomats say, is that Mr. Milosevic has recognized that he will not be able persuade the United States and its allies to lift sanctions before he recognizes Bosnia.
According to one official, the new plan would suspend sanctions for 200 days if Mr. Milosevic recognizes Bosnia's borders. But he would not have to recognize Bosnia's Government formally.
Bosnia's Prime Minister, Haris Silajdzic, sent a letter to Secretary of State Warren Christopher today urging the Administration to use its influence to persuade its allies to allow air strikes in response to recent shelling by the Bosnian Serbs.
"If that is not accepted by your allies, then it is absolutely high time for the United States of America to unilaterally lift the illegal arms embargo on the Bosnian Government," he wrote.
The Clinton Administration has sought to persuade Bob Dole, the Senate majority leader, to drop plans to introduce legislation that calls on the United States to lift the embargo on its own.
After meeting here today with Mr. Christopher, Britain's Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, said his nation had no immediate plans to withdraw its peacekeeping troops from Bosnia. The two officials, said, however that they backed efforts to make the peacekeepers' mission more effective.

HEADLINE: ETHICAL INQUIRIES: THE PACKWOOD CASE;
Ethics Panel in Senate Accuses Packwood of Sexual Misconduct

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 17

 BODY:
The Senate Ethics Committee today accused Bob Packwood, chairman of the Senate's most important committee, of bringing "discredit upon the United States Senate" through sexual misconduct, tampering with evidence and seeking help from lobbyists to get his wife a job.
After a 30-month investigation, which Senator Packwood delayed at one point by going to court in a futile effort to block a subpoena for his diaries, the committee said it had found "substantial credible evidence" for each of its three charges. 
 The committee told the Senator, a 62-year-old Oregon Republican, that he could meet with its members to answer the charges or could request hearings to have the accusations examined in detail, an option the committee has even if Mr. Packwood does not seek it.
As chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, whose vast jurisdiction includes taxes, trade, health, unemployment insurance and welfare, Mr. Packwood occupies a decisive legislative position. Ordinarily dozens of senators would depend on him for favors. But he now faces a very uncertain future before the tight-lipped Ethics Committee, which has given no indication what it proposes to do next.
Mr. Packwood left a Finance Committee hearing on Medicare this morning to talk to reporters but declined to discuss the substance of the charges, saying, "It is irresponsible for me to comment on them."
Mr. Packwood, who had previously called for public hearings in the case, would not say whether he would seek them now. But he said he welcomed the opportunity "to request an appearance before the committee." He gave testimony under oath to committee aides for five days in January but said today that "I did not have a chance to appear" before the committee itself "at this preliminary stage."
The sexual misconduct charges against Mr. Packwood are the most detailed, citing 18 complaints by women who have sworn that he made unwelcome advances. But the accusation that he altered his diaries once he became aware that the committee would subpoena them as evidence may be the most menacing. The committee said there was a substantial basis to conclude that this effort was either "improper conduct reflecting upon the Senate
 and/or possible violations of Federal law" -- that is, obstruction of justice, a subject of a parallel investigation of Mr. Packwood now under way at the Justice Department.
Senator Mitch McConnell, the Kentucky Republican who heads the Ethics Committee, and Senator Richard H. Bryan, Democrat of Nevada, the vice chairman, declined to discuss the case today, as did other committee members. Senators McConnell and Bryan scheduled a news conference for Thursday, but they are unlikely to offer a timetable for resolving the case. In the turgid habits of the Senate, ethics proceedings usually last for years.
Committee members have not discussed possible punishments, which range from a letter of reprimand from the committee to a vote of censure by the full Senate or even expulsion.
Another punishment was urged in Portland, Ore., today by three of the women who have accused the Senator of sexual misconduct: Mary Heffernan, Gena Hutton and Gail Byler. At a news conference, all three suggested that the Senate oust Mr. Packwood from the chairmanship of the Finance Committee. "We are asking that Senator Packwood be fired," Ms. Heffernan said.
Ms. Heffernan, now a Portland consultant, has accused Mr. Packwood of squeezing her arm and kissing her on the mouth while they were in his Senate office in 1981 or 1982, when she was a lobbyist. Ms. Hutton, a campaign worker in 1980, has accused him of kissing her, forcing his tongue into her mouth and inviting her to his hotel room then. Ms. Byler has accused him of running his hand up her leg and touching her crotch when she worked as a dining room hostess in Portland in 1970.
The Senate majority leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, declined to answer today when asked whether Mr. Packwood should step down as chairman of the Finance Committee until the case is resolved. Mr. Dole, himself the Finance chairman in the early 1980's, worked closely with Mr. Packwood on the committee last year, especially on health care.
Indeed, Mr. Packwood abandoned his longtime support for universal health insurance to help Mr. Dole kill President Clinton's plan. "We've killed health care reform," Mr. Packwood said in a discussion with other Republican senators at the time. "Now we've got to make sure our fingerprints are not on it."
This year Mr. Packwood has endorsed Mr. Dole for President.
The depth of the "resolution for investigation" that the Ethics Committee issued today surprised some senators and Senate aides, who had feared that the committee would slough off the matter. Indeed, the resolution reported that some members thought it was unfair to hold against Mr. Packwood any accusations made before 1976, the year in which the Federal courts "recognized quid pro quo sexual harassment as discrimination under the Civil Rights Act, and the Senate passed a resolution prohibiting sex discrimination in the United States Senate." But 10 of the 18 complaints of unwanted advances refer to encounters after 1976.
The committee concluded that there was substantial credible evidence "that Senator Packwood may have abused his United States Senate office by improper conduct which has brought discredit upon the United Senate, by engaging in a pattern of sexual misconduct between 1969 and 1990."
On the alteration of his diaries, an offense that has been sworn to by Cathy Wagner Cormack, an aide who transcribed them, the committee found substantial credible evidence that he "intentionally altered diary materials that he knew or should have known the committee had sought or would likely seek as part of its preliminary inquiry."
The committee also listed, without naming them, five lobbyists who had business before committees Mr. Packwood served on, and concluded that there was substantial credible evidence that he "may have abused his United States Senate office through improper conduct by inappropriately linking personal financial gain to his official position."
 His former wife, Georgie Packwood, has said that after they separated in January 1990, but before their divorce became effective on May 20, 1991, several lobbyist allies of Mr. Packwood offered her jobs, which could have reduced his alimony.

ALTERING EVIDENCE
 The committee said there was substantial bases to conclude that the Senator might have intentially altered his diaries when he knew or should have known it would seek them. This effort may have violated a Federal obstruction of justice statute, the committee said.
 
ABUSE OF OFFICE FOR FINANCIAL GAIN
 The committee said there was a substantial evidence, including sworn testimony and documents, to conclude that the Senator might have improperly solicited financial support for his estranged wife from five lobbysts and businessmen who had interests in legislation that he could influence.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Trade Fight's Two Gladiators Square Off

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 17

 BODY:
Two seasoned political operatives are keeping a wary eye on each other from a distance of 7,000 miles, each pushing a political and an economic agenda that leaves the other mystified.
Mickey Kantor works from the old Winder Building across from the White House, where Abraham Lincoln used to consult his generals. Ryutaro Hashimoto, his hair slicked back and his cigarette holder ever present, works from the Ministry of International Trade and Industry in Tokyo, where the world's most productive and protected automobile industry was built from scratch. 
 Mr. Kantor, 55, is the ultimate political loyalist, and regardless of whether the 100 percent sanctions he has declared against $5.9 billion in Japanese luxury cars open Japan's markets, they will certainly play well in the Midwest and in union halls, territories President Clinton has alienated and wants to reclaim.
Mr. Hashimoto, 57, known in Tokyo as "the Prince," has a reputation for toughness and arrogance; he sees himself as Japan's next prime minister, maybe within months. Standing up to the Americans, many believe, is his strategy for realizing his life's ambition.
In private, the two get along passably well -- "two of a kind," one American official who knows them both said -- and talk about everything from Shintoism to baseball to their college days. But in public, they are performers, and the bombast spills out easily. Asked about Mr. Kantor at a recent news conference, Mr. Hashimoto quipped, "He's scarier than my wife when I come home drunk."
Today Mr. Kantor and Mr. Hashimoto are so far apart that both Japanese and American leaders fear they may be headed toward a far larger collision than either intended. The immediate subject is cars, but both are quick to say that the real issue is jobs, and a clash of two economic systems whose differences have been papered over, but never reconciled. Both talk about "containing" their disputes to the economic sphere, but both worry that the other is already poisoning the well.
"Every time the United States and Japan have faced trouble I've been able to see the way out," said a senior Japanese official who has worked closely with Mr. Hashimoto. "On this issue, I can't figure out how it will be resolved. We've never been this far apart." They meet again next week in Paris, doubtless in the first of many contentious sessions.
Mr. Kantor has been preparing for this confrontation ever since he moved from chairman of the Clinton campaign to become United States trade representative, a post that is usually considered out of the mainstream of policy-making. It was hardly his first choice. Nevertheless, Mr. Kantor attacked the job tenaciously and changed it along the way. He took a central role in pushing through two of Mr. Clinton's biggest international initiatives, the North American Free Trade Agreement and the accord that created the World Trade Organization.
He has dominated China policy -- often to the chagrin of the State Department -- calculating correctly that the Chinese would back down in the face of sanctions over the violation of American intellectual property rights. Now, with far bigger stakes, he is trying the same strategy with the Japanese.
"In the 1950's and the 1960's we could afford to open our markets and let countries like Japan maintain sanctuary markets," he said this morning over breakfast with a number of reporters. "There was a cold war on, and it was the right policy at the time. But we can't afford to do it anymore. We were 40 percent of the world economy then, and we are 20 percent of the world economy now."
Mr. Hashimoto also talks of a new age -- an age in which Japan emerges from America's shadows and stands up for itself. He has vowed to Japanese reporters that this trade dispute will be different from all the others, that Japan will not back down at the last minute. Whether he is bluffing is the subject of endless speculation within the Clinton Administration. Even his fellow Japanese politicians say they do not understand his endgame.
But this is hardly the first time American demands have gotten Mr. Hashimoto's back up. During the Persian Gulf war in 1991, when he was Finance Minister, the United States Ambassador to Tokyo, Michael H. Armacost, was pressing for Japan to make a huge contribution to the effort. Mr. Hashimoto resisted, but in the end he was forced to back down: Japan paid $13 billion, and Mr. Hashimoto let it be known he thought America was not sufficiently grateful for the contribution. Moreover, he resented the pressure and Mr. Armacost's quickness to do an end-run around him, negotiating with one of his biggest political rivals, Ichiro Ozawa.
When the current American Ambassador to Tokyo, Walter F. Mondale, called on Mr. Hashimoto at the Japanese politician's private office, the resentments were still there. As Mr. Hashimoto sat smoking, the former Vice President noted that new no smoking rules were in effect at the embassy.
"I guess I won't be visiting you very often," Mr. Hashimoto replied. Mr. Mondale, who has been through his share of political compromises, offered to meet Mr. Hashimoto in the embassy parking lot, where he could both smoke and find a rare concentration of American-made cars.
But if the Administration finds Mr. Hashimoto prickly and unpredictable -- he and Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin are on particularly bad terms -- so do his own bureaucrats. Mr. Hashimoto has been known to walk into negotiations and toss aside his notes, to the horror of his minions. That happened last fall, when he and Mr. Kantor broke a deadlock over the importation of American-made glass to Japan, one of the country's most hermetically sealed markets.
"He's pragmatic, realistic," Mr. Kantor said of his sparring partner the other day, whom he called Ryu. "I don't see him as an impediment."
Whether Mr. Hashimoto will be is unclear. He has often accused Mr. Kantor of moving the goal posts, and has wondered aloud whether the Clinton Administration really wants an agreement.
But the two men are talking the same language. Mr. Kantor says his actions will help "not only American workers but Japanese consumers," who need a break from high prices borne of anticompetitive practices; Mr. Hashimoto said that the sanctions would harm "not only the Japanese auto manufacturers, but also consumers and workers in the United States, as well as the free trading system of the world."
For both men, there is the lingering question of their next step. One possibility is that Mr. Hashimoto will hold the line against the United States and, if pushed too hard by the Japanese auto makers or his colleagues in the Liberal Democratic Party to cave in, he will resign in protest. That would allow a deal to go through and still leave Mr. Hashimoto on the moral high ground against his chief rival for the prime ministership, Foreign Minister Yohei Kono.
For his part, Mr. Kantor is forever fending off rumors that he is about to be swept back into politics, perhaps to run the Clinton re-election campaign. "I'm tired of hearing this," he said today. "Can't everyone see that I love what I'm doing?"

HEADLINE: College Segregation Persists, Study Says

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, May 17

 BODY:
Not one of 12 states that formerly administered segregated universities or colleges can demonstrate an "acceptable level of success in desegregating its higher education system," according to a comprehensive study released today, the 41st anniversary of the landmark Brown v. Board of Education ruling.
Instead, the report found that most flagship universities in the South remain more than 80 percent white, that 60 percent of black freshmen attend historically black colleges or junior colleges and that success rates for minorities, measured in graduation rates and enrollment in graduate schools, are stagnant or falling in all 12 states. 
 The report, compiled by some of the nation's top scholars and educators for the Southern Education Foundation, a group devoted to improving minority access to higher education, concluded that a 1992 Supreme Court decision provided an opportunity comparable to the Brown ruling to truly desegregate colleges and universities. In the ruling, U.S. v. Fordice, the Court said Mississippi had failed to satisfactorily desegregate its public higher education system.
The study said that changes at all levels of education would be necessary to bring about true desegregation in higher education. Improvements in school financing and curriculums are needed from the elementary level on up, the report said.
But at a time when education budgets and student aid are facing major cuts, the study painted a largely bleak picture of progress for black and Hispanic people in the states that as a group are adding the most population and have the largest percentage of minority members.
The study said that society had promised equal access to institutions of higher education regardless of race but that not a single state "can demonstrate an acceptable level of success" in reaching that goal.
To achieve equal representation of blacks among college graduates, each of the 12 states would have to more than double the number of black graduates. For Hispanic students the challenge is even greater.
And experts say that while the report looked largely at colleges and universities in the South, its findings, particularly that rising tuition and declining tuition grants for low-income students are freezing minority students out of higher education, is true across the nation as well.
"The access of poor people to higher education fell dramatically across the board in the 1980's," said Gary Orfield, a professor of education and public policy at Harvard and an expert on desegregation who served as an adviser to the study. "The shifts discussed in the report are in various forms occurring across the nation."
The report examined 12 of the 19 states that established segregated educational systems after the Civil War: Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Kentucky, Louisiana, Maryland, Mississippi, North Carolina, Pennsylvania, Tennessee, Texas and Virginia.
The study found that:
*In 8 of the 12 states, fewer than 10 percent of black freshmen were enrolled in their state's largest and most prestigious institutions.
*Black and Hispanic people are underrepresented among bachelor's degree recipients in every state and in virtually every field of study.
*The kind of financial aid most needed by low-income families, who are disproportionately minorities, is declining. In the 1970's, more students received need-based Pell Grants from the Federal Government than borrowed under Federal student loan programs. For 1995, the number of borrowers anticipated will be nearly 70 percent higher than the number of grant recipients and more than four times as much Federal money will be spent on loans as grants.
"One result of these changes," the section of the report on student aid concluded, "is that financial aid is now more oriented toward the needs of middle- and upper-middle-income students than it is to those of low-income students. Another is that students and their families are now paying about 138 percent of what they paid in 1980 to attend college."
In Mississippi, for example, tuition at public colleges and universities represents about 40 percent of the income of the average minority family. Blacks make up 43 percent of the state's college-age population, but only 11.8 percent of recipients of degrees at public institutions. Fewer blacks earned bachelor's degrees in 1991 than in 1979.
Other concerns cited in the report include the colleges' reliance on standardized tests that tend to exclude minority members, the shortage of minority faculty and administrators, and the degree to which the racial and social climate on campuses can be less than welcoming to minorities.
Experts say the findings reflect a lack of aggressive commitments to promote integration more than a desire to keep campuses segregated. In the 12 states, blacks account for 25 percent of the college-age population, but represent only 16 percent of full-time freshmen and 10 percent of bachelor's degree recipients. Blacks account for less than 4 percent of total doctorates awarded.
"Primarily, we're talking about historically very entrenched systems of segregation," said N. Joyce Payne, director of the office of Public Black Colleges of the National Association of State Universities and Land Grant Colleges.
The report studied 12 of the 19 states that after the Civil War established segregated colleges and universities. Most were desegregated during the civil rights era. But, until 1992, there was no Federal court ruling mandating desegregation comparable to the Brown decision, which covered elementary and secondary education. The 1992 decision, U.S. v. Fordice, required that states go beyond race-neutral admissions to desegregate higher education but did not compel any specific course of action. The court did, however, discuss four areas that could contribute to insufficient desegregation: admission standards, program duplication, institutional mission assignments and the continued operation of eight separate public universities dating to the days of legal segregation.
The ruling opened up a range of possibilities, like merging black and white institutions, changing admissions standards, offering courses that would lure blacks to white institutions and vice versa, offering remedial programs and other measures to foster desegregation.
Many educators and most blacks insist that desegregation cannot come at the expense of the historically black institutions. But many also contend that financially strapped Southern states are left with the vestiges of a dual system of education that is economically inefficient.
Indeed, some on the report panel had some misgivings about recommending against the consolidation of black and white colleges and universities. But they agreed that wholesale closings of black colleges would be unacceptable and that desegregation cannot be achieved at the expense of the institutions that historically have done the most to educate blacks.

HEADLINE: Abortion Clinic's Landlord Says He Feared Violence

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON 

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., May 17

 BODY:
Ronald Morey, a Garden City landlord, testified today that from the moment he acquired a building on Stewart Avenue a year ago, he so feared violent anti-abortion protests that he tried to break an 11-year lease with an abortion clinic there.
"On the one hand, I'm trying to protect the clinic's rights, and on the other hand protect the rights of anti-abortionists to peacefully protest," Mr. Morey said. "It's a delicate balancing act and I'm caught on the fence." 
 Later, outside court, he added: "If my wife came to that building to see a dentist and get her teeth cleaned and she was accosted, I wonder who the dentist would hold responsible. I am not prepared to put principle in place of everyone's safe use of that building."
Mr. Morey is trying to evict the clinic, Long Island Gynecological Services, and lawyers at a hearing today in State Supreme Court before Justice John DiNoto tried to depict the case as nothing more than a landlord-tenant dispute.
But it has attracted national attention because it offers a rare peek at the impact of the pressure that anti-abortion protesters have placed on all kinds of companies, from landlords to plumbers to medical suppliers, that do business with abortion clinics.
The case was also seen as a new challenge to a year-old Federal law that guarantees access to abortion clinics, prompting the United States Attorney's Office in Brooklyn to monitor events at the clinic.
Representative Charles E. Schumer, a co-sponsor of the Federal law, said Mr. Morey's testimony "shows that economic pressures are being exerted on clinics and that it's a serious problem."
The landlord testified that projectiles, ranging from lead sinks to bullets, had been fired at the windows in his building, that the windshield of his car had been smashed in the parking lot and that a 72-year-old nurse employed by a doctor with offices on the same floor of the clinic had been accosted by protesters twice, once with a knife.
Protests are held regularly outside the building, and in January a sign was posted warning: "Danger. This is a war zone. People are being killed here -- like Boston. You risk injury or death if you are caught on or near these premises."
Mr. Morey said, "When death occurred at an abortion clinic in Brookline, Mass., and other people were being killed at clinics around the country, I realized I had to do something to assure the safety of my tenants." In January, he issued a new rule for tenants prohibiting them from performing abortions.
"No other tenant was causing any problems," he said. "I know that had abortions not been taking place there, we would not be here in court today."
Mr. Morey is the principal owner of the three-story glass-enclosed building at 1103 Stewart Avenue, where the abortion clinic has leased space on the second floor until the year 2003. The other tenants include several doctors and lawyers, as well as Mr. Morey's radio station, WDRE, which occupies the third floor.
He said he acquired the building in a bankruptcy sale a year ago, and tried to negotiate an agreement to break the lease with the clinic's owner, Dr. Moshe Hochamavitz.
He said Dr. Hochamavitz had expressed strong interest in moving the clinic elsewhere, saying he did not want to be where he was not wanted or where he created any problems.
During a break in the hearing, Mr. Morey said that an agreement had been worked out in the last several days, which, in part, included a cash settlement. "But the day after I agreed to the settlement in principle, Dr. Hochamavitz rejected it, much to the chagrin of his own attorney," Mr. Morey said.
Dr. Hochamavitz was present for most of today's hearing, expecting to be called as a witness, either by his own lawyer, David I. Rosenberg, or Mr. Morey's lawyer, Joseph J. Ortego. Dr. Hochamavitz, however, declined to comment on the matter.
Mr. Rosenberg, who called Mr. Morey as his first witness, said he was pleased that Mr. Morey had acknowledged that he wanted "to break the lease with the clinic because he wanted to halt the clinic's performance of abortions."
"This does not meet the legal requirement of a reasonable act," Mr. Rosenberg said.
Justice DiNoto, who kept both lawyers on a tight time schedule and limited their questions when they began to be repetitive, said the hearing would resume on Thursday afternoon. Dr. Hochamavitz is expected to be among those called to the stand.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
In Surprise Sale, McClatchy Buys A Prominent Southern Paper

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON 

 BODY:
The family that owns The News & Observer of Raleigh, N.C., said yesterday that it had agreed to sell the newspaper, one of the few remaining larger independent dailies in the South, to McClatchy Newspapers Inc. of Sacramento, Calif., for $373 million.
McClatchy owns 12 dailies, including The Sacramento Bee and The Anchorage Daily News. It is known as a publisher of quality newspapers with a liberal political bent. 
 The News & Observer, which has been in the same family since it was bought by Josephus Daniels at a bankruptcy sale in 1894, was, until yesterday, one of the few family-owned papers that newspaper people thought might be able to buck the national trend of chain ownership.
Known in the 1960's as one of a handful of Southern newspapers that supported the civil-rights movement, the paper and the Daniels family have long had a reputation for integrity and aggressive journalism. For years, the paper's admiring nickname was The Raleigh Nuisance and Disturber.
In recent years, the paper has been known for one of the most sophisticated applications of technology in the industry. In a bittersweet emblem of the changing times for American newspapers, The News & Observer reported its own sale yesterday on its electronic "newspaper" on the Internet, The NandO Times. It is believed to be the first newspaper to deliver such news about itself digitally.
By midmorning yesterday, The NandO Times carried a color photograph of Frank Daniels 3d, the newspaper's 39-year-old executive editor and the great-grandson of Josephus Daniels, telling his reporters and editors about the sale of the News & Observer Publishing Company.
Frank Daniels Jr., the 63-year-old publisher, said no family divisions led to the sale. But he said company managers had concluded that the paper would probably not be able to remain in private hands during the next decade or so as the industry changed and the business passed to a fourth generation of the family.
To protect the paper as an institution, he said, family members had concluded that they would be better off selling to McClatchy, a newspaper company with similar political and journalistic traditions. "From a historical standpoint, sure I feel some sadness," the elder Mr. Daniels said. "But at the same time, I feel we're doing the right thing."
Mr. Daniels said he and many others in Raleigh recognized that the sale meant the end of a tradition that went back more than 100 years to his fiercely independent but partisan Democratic ancestor. Josephus Daniels, like many of his successors, won national prominence. He served as Secretary of the Navy under President Woodrow Wilson, and Franklin Delano Roosevelt served as his assistant secretary.
McClatchy will pay $250 million for the stock of the company and will assume $123 million in debt. Included in the sale are seven smaller publications in North Carolina owned by the company.
Frank Daniels Jr. will continue as publisher of The News & Observer. It was not clear what role his son might have at the paper, though he said he would like to remain.
With revenue of $107 million last year, the News & Observer company is much smaller than McClatchy, which had 1994 net income of $46.6 million on revenue of $471 million. Analysts said that McClatchy appeared to have paid generously, about 10 times what they estimated was the company's cash flow. Many publicly held newspaper companies trade at about seven times cash flow.
McClatchy, which went public in 1988, is controlled by descendants of James McClatchy, an Irish immigrant who worked for Horace Greeley at The New York Tribune and then went west during the Gold Rush. He acquired The Sacramento Bee in 1857.
Though McClatchy's stock is traded on the New York Stock Exchange, an ownership structure that includes two classes of stock has left effective control with the McClatchy family. Yesterday, McClatchy's class A shares closed at $23, down 25 cents.
Measured by daily circulation, McClatchy was the 17th-largest newspaper group in the country before the acquisition, according to the Newspaper Association of America. The Raleigh paper, with a daily circulation of 151,840, will not appreciably raise McClatchy's rank.
Still, analysts said The News & Observer was attractive partly because it is situated in a growing area. In addition, they said, The News & Observer's reputation for technological innovation would give McClatchy a solid base to move into electronic publishing.
Separately yesterday, McClatchy announced that James McClatchy, 74, who has been chairman since his brother, C. K. McClatchy died in 1989, was stepping down. He will stay a member of the board and retain his title as publisher of the company's newspapers. The company's chief executive, Erwin Potts, who is 63, will become chairman.
Mr. Potts said McClatchy had been drawn to The News & Observer mostly because it was a "good newspaper in a good market" and because it would permit McClatchy to be less reliant on the California economy, where most of its newspapers are situated.
Mr. Potts said the purchase was one of the biggest McClatchy had ever made, but he said he did not foresee a broad expansion.
"We have no interest in being a huge, big newspaper company," Mr. Potts said. "We've always wanted to be more quality minded than quantity minded."
Mr. Potts served on The News & Observer's board until March. Frank Daniels Jr. said he asked Mr. Potts not to attend a board meeting in March when the newspaper's operating committee suggested that the board might consider a possible sale, though there was no suitor at the time. Mr. Potts stepped down from the board.
Both men said Mr. Potts later expressed interest in buying the paper. Mr. Daniels said his family did not discuss a sale with any other companies and that McClatchy "came up with just enough money to keep us from going somewhere else."
The news of the sale surprised many in the industry. But some journalists at The News & Observer said they had heard that several years ago, a branch of the family had pressed for a buyout of their shares.
Frank Daniels 3d, said he was convinced that the paper needed a larger parent in part to give the paper the resources to nurture the new electronic efforts.
Asked if he was upset at the loss of the legacy of The News & Observer, the younger Mr. Daniels said, "It's been in the family 100 years and the identity that all of us have is intertwined with the newspaper. So there is some sadness there."

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Steep First-Quarter Loss Tied To Revamping at Woolworth

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The Woolworth Corporation reported a steep first-quarter loss yesterday as costs from an overhaul and sluggish consumer spending weighed down earnings.
Woolworth, the nation's ninth-largest retailer, lost $80 million, or 60 cents a share, up from a loss of $38 million, or 29 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter last year. Sales edged up to $1.79 billion from $1.76 billion. Wall Street had expected a loss of 27 cents a share, according to a survey of analysts by Zacks Investment Research. 
 Woolworth reported its earnings after the stock market closed. Earlier, shares of Woolworth rose 12.5 cents, to $15.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Many of the nation's leading retailers have reported disappointing first-quarter results as consumers, hit by rising interest rates and mounting credit card debt, have curbed spending.
Even the nation's largest retailer, Wal-Mart Stores Inc., reported on Tuesday that earnings rose 11 percent in the quarter, less than what Wall Street analysts had expected.
Woolworth, based in New York, said the results were in line with its expectations after accounting for costs for its restructuring. The company is selling underperforming divisions and getting rid of old, unsold inventory in its stores.
The retailer said the result included $38 million in costs related to inventory improvement programs. Minus those costs, the loss was in line with expectations, analysts said.
"On an operating basis, they were essentially fairly close to our projections," said Donald Trott, a retail analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds.
The chairman of Woolworth, Roger Farah, is working to pare down Woolworth's portfolio of nearly 40 store chains.
Since March, Mr. Farah has scrapped Woolworth's quarterly dividend, chopped capital spending budgets by 25 percent and disclosed plans to cut 2,000 workers -- all meant to save $100 million a year.
During the first quarter, Woolworth sold the Rx Place deep-discount drug chain and signed an agreement to sell the Little Folk/Kids Mart store chain.
These operations contributed a combined loss of $25 million in the first quarter, Woolworth said.
Some divisions were on the right track, Woolworth said. Its Athletic Footwear and Apparel division, including the Foot Locker chain, "turned in a particularly strong quarter," it said.

HEADLINE: Mexico Reports Economic Drop

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, May 17

 BODY:
The battered Mexican economy contracted by six-tenths of 1 percent in the first quarter of 1995, a milder decline than expected, but the surprising figures may have more to do with the way the Government keeps records than any underlying strength in the economy.
In Mexico, quarterly figures are compared with the corresponding period a year earlier instead of the previous quarter as is done in the United States. By comparing the first three months since the peso was sharply devalued and huge amounts of capital left Mexico with the first three months of 1994 -- when the Mexican economy grew only seven-tenths of a percent because of the guerrilla uprising in Chiapas -- the effect of the current crisis was diminished. 
 Financial analysts also said that the figures for first quarter 1995 reflected a surge in sales that took place just before a large increase in the national value-added tax took effect in April.
Finance Minister Guillermo Ortiz of Mexico said in Washington that he expected the Mexican economy to slow substantially in the second and third quarters.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: MEXICO (99%); UNITED STATES (93%);
