HEADLINE: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: BEHIND THE SCENES;
G.O.P. Unity Fractures Just Beneath the Surface

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 17

 BODY:
Republicans in the House of Representatives have often seemed this year to be flying like the Blue Angels in perfect formation. But sometimes, on close inspection, the drill proves not to be as smooth as it first appears.
A case in point is a philosophical disagreement over tax policy between two of the most powerful committee chairmen -- John R. Kasich of Ohio, who heads the Budget Committee, and Bill Archer of Texas, chairman of Ways and Means. 
 This disagreement, which arose while Mr. Kasich's committee was constructing the framework that is supposed to lead to a balanced budget by the year 2002, was nowhere to be seen today as the House began debate on that budget resolution.
But the difference in the way the two chairmen think about taxes is so fundamental that it is likely to recur later this year when Congress addresses the details of how revenue will be raised and money spent.
It illustrates the underlying tension within the Republican Party between those who see themselves as leading a popular uprising against the establishment and others who have spent their careers defending the interests of American business.
Mr. Kasich, who is 43 and the son of a mailman from Western Pennsylvania, is an acolyte of Speaker Newt Gingrich and very much a leader of the uprising. His budget proposal, he said today during the House debate, provided "a revolutionary image and vision of where America should go."
If the party is serious about balancing the budget, he said in an interview in the lobby off the House floor, then all segments of society must contribute, and that includes an end to "corporate subsidies."
Mr. Archer, 67, is from the River Oaks section of Houston and represents one of the most affluent Congressional districts in the country. He has spent a quarter-century in the House fighting for tax breaks for oil and gas producers, banks, timber companies and other industries. These tax advantages, he holds, are essential to keep the industries profitable and the economy strong.
If you take away a tax deduction or credit, that is a tax increase, he said, adding: "My position is that as long as I'm chairman, we're not going to have a tax increase."
The disagreement between Mr. Kasich and Mr. Archer broke into the open early this month.
On May 3, as Republican members left Washington for a two-day retreat in Leesburg, Va., a document entitled "Corporate Welfare" was circulated on House Budget Committee stationery. On the bottom of the first page was this notation: "Draft House Republican Budget Committee Recommendations."
The first page proposed that $25 billion in additional revenue be raised over seven years by eliminating or modifying tax rules "that can be clearly identified as benefiting one industry or a limited number of corporations, derive no general public benefits, lack market justification and/or create a benefit far in excess of what is necessary to address a specific public policy concern."
The rest of the document listed six items that were said to fit that description including tax breaks Mr. Archer strongly favors for mineral depreciation, natural-gas production and timber development. Other proposals would have disallowed some deductions for advertising costs and increased taxes on international businesses.
Mr. Kasich says now that this was a internal document not meant for public dissemination. In most cases, Mr. Kasich's proposals were discussed with the committee chairmen whose programs would be affected, but the tax matters were never cleared with Mr. Archer.
"I didn't have time to do everything I wanted to do to have the most solid examples," Mr. Kasich said.
While the Republicans were in Leesburg, the tax document fell into the hands of corporate lobbyists, who flooded the conference site with faxes. Eventually, Mr. Archer gave a speech to his colleagues defending the tax breaks on the Kasich list one by one.
Mr. Archer was annoyed, he said, because Mr. Kasich and the Budget Committee staff clearly did not understand the ramifications of what was being proposed. "Once I explained to him how these things worked, he agreed with me," Mr. Archer said.
In any event, neither the $25 billion figure, the six examples nor the term "corporate welfare" appear in the report that accompanied the budget resolution Mr. Kasich brought to the House floor today.
The report, which is not binding on anyone, only offers "illustrative examples of inappropriate tax benefits that may be considered by the Committee on Ways and Means."
It then lists three minor tax measures that Mr. Archer agreed to include because, he said, they would prevent companies from using tax breaks in ways not intended by the law. These changes, if enacted, would raise negligible revenue.
But this is not the end of the disagreement between the chairmen. In part, that is because Republican leaders pay such close attention to public opinion polls, and the polls have found that the public detests "corporate welfare," a term apparently coined by Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich.
Frank Luntz, a pollster who is close to the Republican leaders and who regularly tests words and phrases for their political appeal, said the phrase was third in the list of "things the public flips out on." First, he said, is "foreign aid." Second is "waste, fraud and abuse."
As one concession to Mr. Archer's wing of the party, Mr. Kasich said he himself had stopped using the phrase "corporate welfare." Instead, he talks about "corporate subsidies" and says he is determined to get rid of them.
How does he define one?
"I know it when I see it," he said.
For his part, Mr. Archer said, "If there are subsidies out of the appropriations process that go to companies, then you have the question of whether they are justified. When you get to the tax code, I don't find subsidies in the code."

HEADLINE: Do-It-Yourself Deregulation;
Utilities Hustle to Cut Rates to Keep Big Businesses

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

DATELINE: BEDFORD, Mass.

 BODY:
The Raytheon Company wants cheaper electricity and has threatened to go outside Massachusetts to get it. But with the winds of deregulation sweeping through the nation's utility industry, it probably won't have to.
"I can shop for my transportation, my heating oil, my telephone service, but for electricity costs we can't," complained William H. Swanson, an executive vice president at Raytheon, which is based in Lexington and employs 19,500 people in the state. "We're like sheep." 
 Maybe once, but no longer. Mr. Swanson, who said other states have been wooing the big military contractor with the promise of inexpensive energy, has banded together with other business interests and some consumers to lobby for an end to utility monopolies in Massachusetts. And their efforts are paying off: The state is considering a proposal to allow major corporate customers to bypass their local utilities and shop around for cheaper power from competitors.
But even before that can happen, the big industrial users are forcing some utilities to practice what might be called do-it-yourself deregulation. In fact, the very utilities that used to resist rate cuts or any other concessions to customers are now caving in to protect their turf. Boston Edison, for example, got regulatory approval in March to cut rates up to 20 percent for big industrial users that are able to show they would otherwise move jobs out of state.
The drama being played out in Massachusetts is repeating itself across the nation as utilities ready themselves for the inevitable: the deregulation of their industry.
California led the way with a proposal last summer to let utilities compete for customers, and the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission approved a sweeping plan last month to force utilities to open their transmission systems to competitors. After several delays, California regulators next week are expected to outline a somewhat scaled-back blueprint for opening the power business to competition.
Other states are also beginning to take the first steps on how to modify the monopolies that their utilities have long enjoyed.
Still, while deregulation is in its infancy, many utilities are not waiting. As more and more corporations and other big energy users put pressure on Federal and state authorities to loosen restrictions, they are positioning themselves to survive in what promises to be a fiercely competitive environment.
Their basic strategy is to give price breaks to keep big industrial users that might otherwise move elsewhere or, after deregulation, buy elsewhere. Many are hoping to make up for the loss of revenue by cutting expenses. But others fear that won't be enough, raising the prospect that they might pass the cost onto small businesses and home owners who lack political clout.
"Everyone is willing to dump the costs on somebody else," said Robert D. Glynn, the president and chief executive of Pacific Gas and Electric Company in San Francisco, the nation's largest investor-owned utility.
Mr. Glynn said pressure from industrial customers had replaced regulation as the main force for change in his state, whose economy has been hurt by cutbacks in Federal military spending.
While California authorities remain divided on how to proceed with their deregulation proposal, for example, Pacific Gas and Electric in 1994 decided to freeze its rates for all customers for five years. It has also cut the cost of power to its largest industrial users by about $70 million a year since 1994 in an effort to help preserve jobs.
"The regulators have become a secondary force," Mr. Glynn said. "The market and the state's economy have become the primary forces in having us lower our prices."
Other utilities, such as Detroit Edison, have given big discounts to the major auto makers in return for long-term contracts. The contracts are aimed both at keeping the companies in Michigan and in Edison's grip.
And at least one electricity provider has actually gone the distance and agreed to do what California wants its utilities to do. Cinergy, a utility that serves most of Indiana and Cincinnati, is allowing major customers such as Nucor, a major steel producer using vast amounts of power to run its electric arc furnaces, to begin shopping for some of its power from other utilities and producers.
Nucor can go to competitors for power that it needs after it reaches a certain level of use from the utility, which can match the price if it chooses. If the power Nucor finds is cheaper, then Cinergy transmits that power over its system.
The utility industry's new-found flexibility is a windfall for big businesses trying to cut costs. "Now is a good time to get a good deal," said Dan N. Bulla, the director of financial and public relations for Houston Industries, a major utility in Texas.
But the danger is that small users might get the short end of the stick. Stockholders, too, might suffer as utilities' profits shrink.
If the loss of revenue becomes large enough, utilities will have no choice but to phase out high-cost plants, which in many cases means nuclear plants, and take huge write-offs that could depress stock prices and endanger dividends.
And some of them are fighting back. In Massachusetts, for example, local consumer groups and some environmental groups have sprung into action to make sure that no group is left holding the bag.
Armond Cohen, a lawyer with the Conservation Law Foundation in Boston, worried that utilities would cut corners on conservation to make up for lost profits. Already, he said, some utilities have begun scaling back programs to make plants and office buildings more energy-efficient. "If we just listen to Raytheon we'll get it all wrong," Mr. Cohen said.
The pressure for deregulation keeps building, though, as states jockey to attract industry with promises of cheap energy. The Nucor Steel Corporation was recently the object of a bidding war between Virginia and South Carolina, for example.
For a time F. Kenneth Iverson, Nucor's chief executive, said he was leaning to Virginia for the location of a new $500 million steel mill because the local utility, Virginia Power, was offering lower rates to big industrial customers. The concession was important because the plant's projected energy costs will total $25 million a year, Mr. Iverson said.
The Legislature of South Carolina countered by authorizing Santee Cooper, the state-owned utility, to match Virginia's rates, Mr. Iverson said. Other factors made South Carolina more desirable to him, he said, and so he chose that state.
Both states coveted the 500 jobs that the Nucor plant would provide. It was that obsession with jobs that explained Raytheon's success in getting its message across to the Massachusetts political establishment: It employs 19,500 people in the state and said it might have to move some of its plants elsewhere unless it could cut projected spending on taxes, labor and energy by $600 million a year.
Massachusetts, which saw hundreds of thousands of jobs, many of them with well-paying military contractors, disappear in the early 1990's, is desperate to keep Raytheon. And Mr. Swanson, the company's executive vice president, is keeping the pressure on state authorities.
He said pointedly that he had been wined and dined by the Governor of Tennessee and wooed by development officials from states all over the South and West. "They're proud of their low power costs," he said in an interview. "It seems we're being approached by everyone in the world right now."
Stumping the state like a politician, Mr. Swanson has built a coalition of other companies, industry groups, energy suppliers and residents to lobby for opening up the Massachusetts electricity market.
His activities have made headlines and prodded politicians. Recently, three state senators toured a Raytheon plant in Andover, Mass., that uses large amounts of energy to test military equipment at a cost of almost 7 cents a kilowatt-hour. That is nearly twice as much as the company spends at its plant in Tennessee. The plant, Raytheon's largest, employs 5,100 workers.
Officials at the Department of Public Utilities, which regulates the industry, said the agency planned to issue a proposal for allowing energy users to shop around -- a process known as "retail wheeling" -- by this summer.
"We're at a crossroads," said Gloria Cordes Larson , the Secretary of Economic Affairs for Massachusetts. "We need to do something to change the rules."
It won't be easy. Utilities in the New England states get about 36 percent of their power from high-cost nuclear plants that would no longer be able to compete in an open market and would have to be phased out. The struggle over who would pay for the huge costs of shutdowns could delay deregulation.
But the jobs issue is forcing the pace. And that has Mr. Swanson looking forward to action. "This," he says, "is the year of decision."

HEADLINE: Stocks End Mixed, but Technology Issues Continue Their Rise

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The stock market closed mixed yesterday, but high-technology stocks continued to rally.
Prices mostly fell in the afternoon, but recovered somewhat by the session's end. Traders exercised some options in advance of Friday's "double witching" session, when two kinds of quarterly stock options expire. 
 Such expirations once led to wild gyrations at the week's end. But now many traders use these options to buy or sell stocks throughout the week of expiration, lessening the volatility.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 12.45 points, to 4,422.60, and the broader Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 1.12 points, to 527.07. But the smaller-company Nasdaq composite index moved in the opposite direction, rising 3.68 points, to 871.93, a new high. And the American Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.14 point, to 489.52, also a new high.
Thomas Gallagher, vice chairman and head of equity and fixed-income trading at Oppenheimer & Company, said he was not surprised at the minor decline in the prices of blue-chip stocks, especially in view of Friday's options expiration.
"But will there be a time when people start taking a lot of money off the table?" Mr. Gallagher asked. "I don't know. What I do know is that unless you see technology stocks declining, these declines that you see in the afternoon are not going to be significant."
Still, said James Solloway, director of research at Argus Research, "this bull is definitely due for a rest." Just when, Mr. Solloway was not willing to predict.
Inflation might be tame, the Federal Reserve could cut rates and corporate earnings might keep growing, Mr. Solloway said. "But there's a contradiction at the heart of many investors' outlook," he said. "They hope for a pickup in economic growth in the second half of the year, but that can't coexist with stable inflation and lower interest rates."
Technology stocks led the market yesterday, as they have in recent sessions, and Applied Materials Inc. led the technology stocks. The company, a maker of equipment that assists in the manufacture of computer chips, rose 1133/64 , to 8017/64 . After the market closed on Tuesday, Applied Materials reported a 70 percent rise in earnings to $1.08 a share that far exceeded analysts' expectations. At more than 8 million shares traded, the stock was yesterday's most active.
Other technology stocks, especially those of computer-related companies, also rose. Shares of the Intel Corporation advanced 1 7/8, to 110 3/4; those of the Compaq Computer Corporation rose 1 1/4, to 40, and those of the Microsoft Corporation closed at 86, up 1 1/8. Shares of EIP Microwave Inc., which makes telecommunications test instruments, rose 4 1/2, to 9 1/4, after the company reported strong earnings on Tuesday.
Among declining stocks were seven out of nine members of the S.& P. local-telephone group. Shares of SBC Communications Inc. fell 1 1/4, to 43 1/2, and those of the Bell Atlantic Corporation fell 1 1/8, to 53 3/4, in large part because the Pacific Telesis Group's poor earnings outlook cast doubt on the ability of such carriers to compete when local phone service is deregulated.
Eighteen of the Dow industrials' 30 component stocks fell, led by the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, which declined 1 1/4 a share, to 60 1/4. Of the S.& P. 500's component stocks, 266 fell, led by SBC Communications and Motorola Inc., which lost 1, to 60 1/8.

HEADLINE: This Time, New York City Is All Alone

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
When Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani summoned a dozen business and labor leaders to City Hall this week, hoping they could persuade Albany to save his teetering budget, the meeting immediately recalled memories of a similar coalition that helped rescue the city from bankruptcy in the 1970's.
But where the old coalition found a receptive ear in Albany 20 years ago, the new one can barely find an open door. Suddenly, the state has empty pockets of its own, and the big brother who stepped in to pull New York City from the brink in 1975 is in no position to help solve Fiscal Crisis II. 
 If Mr. Giuliani's budget does unravel because of a huge shortfall in state assistance, it will partly be the result of a lobbying strategy that impressed neither Democrats who might have provided financial aid nor Republicans who might have helped cut welfare and Medicaid benefits. But in a larger sense, it will have been a casualty to statewide and national fiscal pressures even greater than those that humbled the city two decades ago, according to several of the officials who dealt with the first fiscal crisis.
Felix G. Rohatyn, who as chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, was a key architect of the city's bailout in the 1970's, recalled that the state was flush with cash then and willing to give some to the city in exchange for firm cost controls. Now, however, the state's financial condition may be even worse than the city's, he noted, and the sour political atmosphere that pervades the capital makes compromise vastly more difficult. The city's budget gap is about $3.1 billion; the state's is as much as $5 billion.
"I think the overall situation the Mayor faces is very dire," Mr. Rohatyn said. "It's always dangerous to predict doomsday scenarios, but it does seem that this is as serious a situation as I've seen since 1975, and in some ways it's even more difficult."
Mr. Rohatyn said Mr. Giuliani has a much tougher job today than Mayor Abraham D. Beame had in 1975 because "no one has the political power to help him," he said.
Richard Ravitch, former chairman of the State Urban Development Corporation, who was also deeply involved in the city's 1975 bailout, said the absence of an immediate credit crunch has made it difficult for the state to recognize the intensity of the city's current problems.
"The glue that binds us all together is the severity of the city's fiscal problems," he said, referring to the members of the new business and labor coalition on which he was asked to serve. "You can't let the city get into the hole that it was once in again. That would be an utter and complete disaster."
In many ways, the city's house is in better order than it was 20 years ago. Peter F. Vallone, the City Council Speaker, notes that the city has for the most part ended its destructive practice of paying for long-term building projects with short-term revenue, and is doing a much better job of collecting tax revenue. But having eliminated many of the problems that led to the first crisis, he said, the city will experience the impact of the new crisis in a different way: not as a credit squeeze heading toward bankruptcy but as an immensely painful reduction in city services and city optimism.
"What will be worse than 1975 will be the service impact of all the cuts," he said. "This isn't an imaginary numbers game here like it used to be. These are real people who are going to get hurt unless we find some transitional way of getting out of here."
Mr. Giuliani has steadfastly denied that his budget would produce painful reductions in services -- if the state simply agreed to his plan for cutting the city's bloated welfare and Medicaid system and if he is allowed to flatten the bureaucracy at the city's Board of Education and elsewhere.
But with the board still out of his reach, and the Assembly Democrats in Albany blocking his request, the Mayor is getting worried. Not only did he ask the business and labor coalition to help, but in its letter to Albany he also allowed the coalition to back away from his insistence that $700 million of the $950 million in requested state aid be in cuts for entitlement programs. In effect, the letter was a rather desperate-sounding plea for nearly a billion dollars -- in whatever form the state decided to provide it.
Now that the plea seems likely to be denied, there are other options for achieving fiscal balance that do not necessarily involve the state. Mr. Rohatyn, for example, said the business community needs to shoulder its share of sacrifice, much as the labor and welfare communities are being asked to bear theirs. He suggested the Mayor ask for a four-year moratorium on big-business moves out of the city as a sign of their commitment. He also recommended increasing the property tax burden on single-family homes and placing tolls on the East River bridges.
"People only recognize an emergency when they're hit in the face with it, and that's what's about to happen here," he said. "The state has to come to the same conclusion that it did in the 1970's, which is that without a healthy city economy, the state will be sick, too."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Car Buyers Play a Game Of Beating The Tariff

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY 

DATELINE: ENGLEWOOD, N.J., May 17

 BODY:
For the last several months, Mary and Jim Pagiatakis had been thinking about trading in their 1992 Lexus for a shiny new one. Today they went out and did it.
They hurried to Lexus of Englewood to pick out a four-door LS400: color, diamond white pearl; sticker price, $56,550. A bargain, they said. 
 The car was sitting in the middle of the showroom, free of the Clinton Administration's 100 percent tariff, which was announced on Tuesday and is scheduled to start on Saturday for imported LS400's and 12 other Japanese-made luxury car models. The duty could eventually push the price of the top-of-the-line Lexus LS400 model to more than $80,000.
The sanctions may be rescinded if Japan and the United States reach an accord by June 28 on their longstanding dispute about trade in autos. And at least for now Toyota and some other Japanese auto makers say they will not pass on the higher tariff to their dealers and customers. Still, the Pagiatakis decided they did not want to run the risk.
"This more or less pushed us into it," Mr. Pagiatakis said. "This got us acting."
Business has been snappy at Lexus of Englewood and other dealers of Japanese luxury cars around the country since the reports began circulating in the news media and elsewhere about the impending tariff. In Dallas, Carl Sewell, owner of Sewell Lexus, said his sales had increased by about 30 percent in the last week.
"Customers wisely decided to purchase a new car before the prices rise," Mr. Sewell said. Looking forward to the possible huge increase in price, he added, only partly tongue-in-cheek, "It looks like we're going to have a half-price sale this weekend."
At Lexus of Englewood, Richard Karsian, general manager of the dealership, said he had sold 26 new cars on Monday and Tuesday. Four more went out the door today. That is normally a week's worth of sales, he said.
Those sales, Mr. Karsian said, have reduced his stock of 1995 Lexuses to 81. The company, which is owned by Toyota, has promised him 70 more by the end of the week, all duty-free, he said.
But beneath the talk of brisk sales, scores of anxious Lexus owners are calling in with all sorts of questions, many of which are unanswerable now. And some of the salesmen at the luxury dealership in this suburb of New York City, in Bergen County, are fighting a doomsday mood.
"In the short run the tariff will have a good effect on business," said one, who insisted on anonymity. "In the long run it could be totally devastating." Cars now in the country and tariff-free will be "gobbled up" he said. "But as far as a career goes, it looks like my career could end soon."
The murkiness centers on the future for Lexus and the makers of the other imported luxury cars if the White House goes ahead with the sanctions on the June 28 deadline, retroactive to May 20. Some of the calls to the Lexus showroom here have come from buyers hoping to buy before the tariff is imposed. But other callers have questioned whether the dealership would be around to provide service and repairs if the sanctions remained in effect for a long time.
Mr. Karsian sought to sound reassuring today on some points. He said Lexus had "ample parts -- parts to last the next few years" already available in the United States. And he said his dealership would not increase prices for new Lexuses in stock, even though the demand may exceed the supply.
Current Lexus owners might enjoy a windfall. Mr. Karsian predicted that sales of used Lexus models should be very strong if the tariff remained in place. "The value of those cars will remain very high," he said.
The American sanctions have thrown the marketing plans of the Japanese luxury car makers into turmoil. While some importers are holding fire for now, Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A., which imports five Lexus models -- all affected by the tariff -- plans to run newspaper advertisements on Thursday in six cities across the country that are strong sales markets. The ads are expected to run in Chicago, Dallas, Los Angeles, Miami, San Francisco and New York.
In Torrance, Calif., the national sales and marketing manager for Lexus, Richard Anderman, said the ads were designed to assure car buyers that business was proceeding as usual at local Lexus dealerships. The cars remain available at regular prices, he said.
"What this is really doing is causing uncertainty," said Mike Sullivan, owner of Lexus Santa Monica in Southern California. "Any time you have uncertainty in this business, it's bad."
Mr. Sullivan said some customers were asking about the tariff and the likely impact on prices. But he said he did not anticipate a big rush of new customers. "We are seeing some people accelerate their purchases," he said, "but really those are people who were going to buy the car anyway."
Indeed, many of those who have been thinking about acquiring a new Japanese luxury car are not wasting any time. At another dealership, Infiniti by Kea in Englewood, Linda Gellman hurried in from her home in Nanuet, N.Y., just across the state line in Rockland County. She leased a 1995 Q45, a top-of-the-line model from the luxury division of Nissan, with a base price of $52,850 and a 100 percent tariff in its future.
Like the Pagiatakis, Mrs. Gellman was also motivated by the tariff threat. "We were going to wait a couple of weeks until our old lease was up," she said. "But I'm rushing to do it now because I don't know what's going to happen."
There are still a number of unanswered questions. What about the price of imported luxury cars that customers have ordered, but which will arrive by boat from Japan after May 20, or after June 28 if the tariff becomes a reality then?
Mr. Karsian, the Lexus dealer, produced a newsletter from the American International Auto Dealers Association that echoed what Toyota was saying about the immediate future. "Dealers and customers are not responsible for paying any retroactive duties due," the newsletter said.
But the newsletter did not address the issue of who would be socked with any tariff that might be due if they remained in effect after June 28.
"I hope it doesn't go that far," Mr. Karsian said. "We support a settlement. When all the dust settles the only ones hurt will be the dealers. It certainly isn't going to affect the Japanese economy to any large degree."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Are Mixed In Slow Day Of Trading

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities were mixed in an uninspired trading session yesterday, with most longer maturities lower in price.
Renewed optimism about slow economic growth and low inflation kept market sentiment leaning toward the positive. But rates were bounced around by speculation that foreign central banks were selling Government securities that they had amassed this year, after they acquired dollars seeking to support the United States currency when it was falling against the Japanese yen and German mark. 
 Traders said some investors sold to lock in profits yesterday, after the yield on the long bond fell to 6.80 percent. Still, there was a general lack of enthusiasm in all directions.
"The inability of the market to hold onto overnight gains was slightly worrisome," said James Hale, a fixed-income analyst with MMS International, a market analysis and research firm in San Francisco, suggesting that the market might be running out of reasons to justify buying.
Dealers said they saw the market as overbought, but acknowledged that few were fighting the trend.
The price of the 30-year bond slipped 1/32 , to 10920/32 , for a yield of 6.86 percent, unchanged from the previous day.
Mr. Hale said the activity of the market fizzled after early strength carried over from overnight trading by overseas investors who may have been moving more money into dollar-denominated investments.
Even next week's supply of paper and a meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee failed to serve as inspirations for trading, Mr. Hale said.
As for the market yesterday, Mr. Hale said, "it seems that from the way the market is behaving, U.S. investors think we are reaching overbought positions, but foreign investors who like the recent stability of the dollar are leaning toward Treasury securities as an attractive investment." He said he did not expect yields to go much lower.
The Treasury said yesterday that it would auction $29.25 billion of new two- and five-year notes next week to refund maturing debt and raise new cash. In when-issued trading, the two-year issue being sold on Tuesday was offered at a price to yield 6.13 percent, and the five-year issue was offered at a price to yield 6.37 percent.
The two- and five-year notes, which will be issued on May 31, will be sold in minimum denominations of $5,000 and $1,000, respectively, and mature on May 31, 1997, and May 31, 2000.
In the municipal bond market, investors continued to find tax-exempt securities attractive. The average yield to maturity for the Bond Buyer's index of 40 municipal issues was 6.10 percent, down two basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, from Tuesday.
Traders said the yields on Treasury bonds had tumbled to 14-month lows, but tax-exempt bonds had lagged behind the benchmark Treasuries, narrowing the yield differential and making municipals more attractive.
In another development, the Tennessee Valley Authority said it was preparing its first global bond issue, to appeal to international investors.
The authority said it would visit investors in the large international financial centers of Europe and Asia beginning June 5.
The bonds are expected to be listed on the exchanges in Luxembourg, Hong Kong and Singapore and on the New York Stock Exchange.
The lead manager on the global bond deal will be Lehman Brothers, with Deutsche Bank as the joint lead manager.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Recovers After Retreat Vs. Mark and Is Little Changed

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar ended little changed yesterday, recovering from an early fall against the German mark that stemmed from worries about whether the new French Government would maintain a strong franc policy.
That concern bolstered the mark against both the French franc and the dollar. The dollar typically declines when dealers sell currencies to buy marks. 
 But the franc and the dollar recovered against the mark after a spokeswoman for President Jacques Chirac of France said rumors that the franc would be devalued were "absurd."
"The comments that devaluation isn't in the cards helped the dollar come back," said Hillel Waxman, manager of currency trading at the Bank Leumi Trust Company in New York.
In New York trading late yesterday, the dollar settled at 1.4441 marks, up from 1.4429 on Tuesday. The dollar edged up to 86.80 yen from 86.57. Also in New York, the mark was quoted at 3.5372 French francs, down from an early high of 3.5655 francs but up from 3.5373 franc yesterday.
Mr. Chirac took over today from Francois Mitterrand. Mr. Chirac's pledge to cut France's 12.2 percent unemployment rate has led some analysts to speculate that he will abandon the previous Government's strong franc policy.
"He is committed to reducing unemployment, which speaks against" a strong franc policy, said David Ogg, manager of foreign exchange at the Midland Bank in New York. That pushed the mark up against the franc, he said.
Moves to cut French unemployment could hurt the franc if they include an expanded budget deficit and lower interest rates, which make bank deposits denominated in a currency less attractive.
Traders' worries about Mr. Chirac's currency policy were heightened after Le Monde reported that he might seek to devalue the franc within the European monetary system. The system's exchange rate mechanism prescribes bands within which nine European currencies trade.
The Le Monde article said "some of Chirac's backers" want him to propose a redesign of the monetary system in his meeting today with Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany.
As for the dollar, Marc Chandler, currency strategist at the Deutsche Bank in New York, said he expected it would resume a rally that has lifted it 6 percent against the mark and 4 percent against the yen since May 8.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
A cut in deposit insurance rates may be a boon for bank stocks.

BYLINE: By Leslie Eaton 

 BODY:
THE Federal Government says it is about to get off the backs of American banks, and that could prove to be a boon for investors in bank stocks and perhaps even for banks' customers.
The Government agency involved is the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which insures the money that customers keep in their bank accounts. The insurance is not free -- banks pay for it, on a sliding scale ranging from 23 cents to 31 cents for each $100 of deposits. 
 Though 92 percent of banks pay the lowest rate, the agency says, those charges are still historically high, the result of the problems that financial institutions ran into in the late 1980's. (Remember the banking crisis?) The money thus raised has piled up in a reserve fund and now tops $24 billion.
And that may be just about enough. The law says the reserve fund should equal 1.25 percent of all the insured deposits, which total about $1.9 trillion, said David Barr, a spokesman for the F.D.I.C. At the end of March the reserve fund was at about 1.21 percent, and sometime between now and July 31 it will reach the legal level.
So when the board of the F.D.I.C. finishes its review of comments from the banking industry and meets sometime this month or next, it plans to cut the insurance rates by more than 80 percent. The average fee will fall to about 4.5 cents from about 23 cents, Mr. Barr said. The cut will probably take effect before the fourth quarter of the year, and banks may be eligible for rebates on some of their third-quarter payments.
"This is the most important bank regulatory event in years," said Michael L. Mayo, an analyst for Lehman Brothers. Because it will have "a direct, meaningful impact on earnings," he added, the change is even more significant than current Congressional efforts to repeal the Glass-Steagall Act, the Depression-era law that limits the businesses into which banks can go.
As Mr. Mayo sees it, lower insurance charges should translate into gains in earnings averaging 6 percent next year, and might increase the earnings this year by 2 percent. Though some banks will benefit more than others, "this is a rising tide that's going to lift all ships," he said.
A slightly more conservative view comes from James K. Schmidt, who manages mutual funds specializing in bank stocks for John Hancock in Boston. He says banks' earnings will gain by about 4 percent, because banks may use some of the money that used to go for insurance to increase the rates they pay on customers' checking and savings accounts.
Still, he said, "that's a permanent increase." And while the stock market may be "psychologically aware" that this gain in earnings is on the way, he said, analysts are just starting to reflect it in their estimates of future earnings.
That is true of Mr. Mayo, who said he had just raised his estimate of earnings for Nationsbank, one of his favorite stocks. He now expects the bank, which is based in Charlotte, N.C., but does business in many Southern states, to earn $6.95 this year, up from his earlier estimate of $6.85. Next year, he said, the bank should earn $7.70; of the increase of 30 cents in his estimate of earnings, 20 cents comes from the lower F.D.I.C. rates.
Investors who want to bet on the improved earnings of banks may be put off by the fact that bank stocks are trading at record levels right now. Indeed, the Nasdaq index of bank stocks has soared by about 16 percent this year, while the Dow Jones industrial average has gained about 15 percent and the broader Standard & Poor's 500 index has risen by almost 15 percent.
But bank stocks still have some things going for them. As Mr. Schmidt, the fund manager, noted, compared with their earnings, bank stocks are relatively less expensive than those in most sectors of the market. The average ratio of banks' stock prices to their earnings is about 9.5, he said, while the same ratio for the stocks in the S.& P. 500 is about 15.5.
Banks are also paying higher dividends than many other companies, said Mr. Mayo, the analyst. And their dividends are likely to rise by an average of 15 percent this year, leading him to suggest that despite their recent gains, "banks are nice, defensive stocks."
Even some confirmed bargain hunters say they are still hitting pay dirt by investing in banks. For example, Scott M. Black of Delphi Management in Boston, said, "there are still some great values" among small banks with strong managements that are trading for about eight times earnings.
And if analysts are right, the price cut by the F.D.I.C. will affect little, out-of-the-way -- and cheap -- banks just as much as their bigger, better-known brethren.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Iran Tells OPEC Nations Not to Lift Output

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: TEHERAN, Iran, May 17

 BODY:
Iran's oil minister warned today that his country would retaliate against other members of OPEC if they took advantage of a United States trade ban by increasing their own oil production.
In an interview with a small group of foreign journalists, the minister, Gholamreza Agazadeh, also acknowledged that the trade ban would cause some short-term disruption for Iran's oil exports. 
 Under the trade ban announced by President Clinton earlier this month, American oil companies can no longer buy Iranian oil for sale to countries outside the United States. Last year, these countries bought about $3.5 billion of Iran's oil.
Iran is concerned that while it is making alternative arrangements with other oil companies to deliver its oil abroad, other oil producing countries, particularly Saudi Arabia, will keep their own marketing networks and add Iran's American trading partners as well.
Since the ban would cause a "redistribution of markets," other countries might choose to increase their output, Mr. Agazadeh said. Iran and the 11 other member nations of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed in November to extend ceilings on oil production for another 12 months in an effort to support the price of crude. Still, past production agreements have been undermined at times by cheating by members.
While Mr. Agazadeh denied he was threatening any OPEC member, his remarks were clearly aimed at sending a clear signal to the international oil market that Iran had no intention of being a victim of the American trade ban.
The oil minister said Iran would not do anything to reduce the price of oil. "But if I see that other producers are going to change their policy, maybe we will choose another policy too," he said. "I'm not telling specifically we are going to raise our output. I'm only saying if others raise their output, N.I.O.C. will modify its behavior," referring to the National Iranian Oil Company.
Despite claims by other Iranian officials that the American trade ban would have no effect on Iran, Mr. Agazadeh acknowledged that in the near future it would force Iran to replace some of its fixed contracts with more volatile transactions on the spot oil market. He boasted that Iran had markets around the world that could eventually absorb its oil, but added, "In the short term, it takes us some time to pass through this transition."
Mr. Agazadeh sharply criticized the Clinton Administration's cancellation in March of Iran's $1 billion agreement with Conoco, a unit of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, to develop two oilfields 80 miles off the Iranian coast.
He called the American companies "hostage to the policies of their Government" and said that he hoped to "reach some tangible results" in the next several weeks with another company. He declined to say which companies were serious contenders for the project, although Total, Elf Aquitaine, Royal Dutch/Shelland Petronas are all believed to be negotiating with the Iranians.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The right's knee-jerk reaction: Fed hopeful is a knee-jerk liberal.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
HELP WANTED: Centrist economic policy maker. Modest salary, but substantial power, prestige and perks. Ability to stay awake at long meetings a must.
The White House thought it had come up with an ideal candidate for the current opening on the Federal Reserve's seven-member board of governors. She is Alicia H. Munnell, the Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Economic Policy, who had earlier worked her way up the through the ranks to become a senior vice president at the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston. 
 But for reasons not entirely clear, torpedoing the appointment is becoming a right-wing cause. The question now is whether President Clinton will actually submit her name. Or he may duck another confirmation fight where, in the words of Herb Stein, an economic adviser to President Richard M. Nixon (and no liberal), "the opposition is based on irrelevancies"
Ms. Munnell is no shrinking violet, but she has not been particularly controversy-prone. After earning a Ph.D. from Harvard in 1973, her public face has largely consisted of scholarly books and articles about retirement policy, tax reform and investment in public works.
Once in Washington, she dutifully adopted the Treasury's traditional role of prudent parent to the unruly adolescents making waves at Federal agencies with their own special-interest constituencies. She fought environmental hard-liners on Superfund, arguing for streamlined procedures to clean up toxic wastes. She beat back apparatchiks in the Labor Department who wanted private pension funds to make "socially useful investment." Most important in the context of the Fed job, she helped mute White House criticism of the central bank's anti-inflation policy.
Nonetheless, Paul Craig Roberts, a syndicated columnist who briefly led the "supply-siders" in the Reagan Administration, began crusading against her last fall, choosing to make Ms. Munnell the Clinton Administration's poster girl for Big Government. And last week a Wall Street Journal editorial denounced her as "an economist with ideas on the fiscal fringe."
Since then, 10 Republican Senators, including Phil Gramm, a Presidential contender, wrote to Mr. Clinton. They urged him to give the Fed job to someone with "a keen eye toward the stability of our currency and the importance of keeping our capital markets free from burdensome regulations, taxes and mandates." If there was any doubt what they meant, Senator Connie Mack of Florida sent along a press release alluding to Ms. Munnell's alleged heresies.
What is going on here? The Wall Street Journal editorial lumped her with liberals who want to tap pension cash for low-income housing and regional development. In fact, her own analysis of social investing -- published in the New England Economic Review -- concluded that this approach to investing was "alarming" because pensioners would bear the risk.
Another beef with Ms. Munnell's views concerns the tax treatment of pensions. She noted in an article in the National Tax Journal that deferral of taxes on employer-sponsored pensions cost the Treasury $51 billion in revenues in 1992. Yet only half the population benefits, with much of the break going to upper-income families. And in Ms. Munnell's reading of the numbers, the net addition to private savings is offset by the negative impact on public savings through the Federal budget. Her suggestion: tax the income accruing in sheltered pension funds.
That recommendation may be anathema to members of Congress who have never met a tax expenditure they didn't like. But in Mr. Stein's view, it is an "entirely reasonable point" to weigh the adverse impact on income distribution against the positive incentives to save. And, while controversial, it is hardly radical economics.
What, then, is really eating Ms. Munnell's critics? Probably not her attitude toward the Fed's core task of sustaining a healthy, low-inflation economy. For one thing, there is no hint that she disagrees with the semitough approach to monetary policy now in place. For another, her most vociferous critics are supply-siders who think the Fed is already too tough on inflation.
A more plausible explanation is that the banking industry still quietly blames her for the Boston Fed's study finding racial discrimination in lending. If that is the case, however, the bankers may be directing their ire at the wrong target. Indeed, while the Justice Department is trying to use civil rights laws to force banks to set up branches in poor neighborhoods where blacks are concentrated, the Boston Fed merely called for vigilance and better training for loan officers.
The very idea that a candidate with Ms. Munnell's credentials is fodder for a fight suggests just how vulnerable President Clinton must appear to Republicans. It may behoove him to fight, if only to demonstrate that appearances deceive.

HEADLINE: U.S. Can't Afford Economic Equality for All

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your May 11 front page contains the perfect example of one of the major contributors to our Government's fiscal problems. Representative Martin Olav Sabo of Minnesota is reported as saying that society's central problem is the gulf between the very rich and very poor. The policies that have been enacted to close this gap are the very entitlement programs that Congress is now attempting to rein in because of their extravagant costs. 
 Opinions like that of Mr. Sabo have led to the socialistic policies that have burdened not only our Government but future generations and have contributed to the multitrillion-dollar debt.
It is the nature of capitalistic societies that all individuals are not at the same socioeconomic level. Other governments have attempted to legislate a different result, and their collapse was recent enough to remain in my memory, if not Mr. Sabo's. I would love to live in a large mansion, but I can't afford it. Our nation cannot afford the policies necessary to drag all people to the same economic status, or even close, assuming that would be a good thing.
It is amazing that Mr. Sabo wants to spend more, while our cumulative tax rates already approach 50 percent of our income. I don't want to pay any more to our Government. My family pays more than enough.
It is amazing that even in the grip of a financial crisis so extreme that politicians are considering cuts in Medicare (the sacred cow of the American Association of Retired Persons) that Mr. Sabo has yet to understand that it is socialistic wealth-redistributing policies, along with the deficit spending they demanded, that have dragged us to the point where we cannot afford them.
And it is politicians like Mr. Sabo who, while perhaps well meaning, allow socialistic policies to continue and even expand, continuing their financial drag on our economy.
Since the Johnson Administration our Government has been spending more than it takes in, and we can no longer afford that luxury. Maybe, just maybe, Mr. Sabo will realize that American citizens would appreciate a little bit of financial accountability when he deals with our money.
 
FREDERICK L. KOPFF
Cooperstown, N.Y., May 12, 1995

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Estimated Budget Conservatively

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "A Budget Harsher Than It Seems" (editorial, May 16): My Republican colleagues and I strongly take issue with your contention that our budget proposal contains "rosy projections of savings and revenues that may never materialize." Just the opposite is true because we believe our numbers are, if anything, too conservative. 
 You state that "many economists are uneasy" about Congressional Budget Office estimates that reaching a balanced budget by 2002 will result in saving some $50 billion in lower interest payments. To which economists do you refer? Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, says that such action would result in a 2 percentage point drop in long-term rates. We have factored in a conservative 1.5 percentage point drop.
Since last November's election, the Republican promise of a balanced budget has already had an impact on long-term rates: they've fallen from more than 8 percent to 6.9 percent. It is more than coincidence that the decline in rates accelerated as the budget committee announced and then approved its balanced budget plan last week.
The 0.2 percent adjustment in the Consumer Price Index you support, as opposed to our 0.6 percent figure, will result from a simple recalculation based on existing formulas. From Mr. Greenspan to Alice Rivlin, director of the Office of Management and Budget, economists have argued that the C.P.I. now significantly overstates inflation and that the formulas should be reworked.
There is no confusion about the $7.5 billion in savings from the elimination of loopholes slated for the year 2002. The budget committee's reconciliation instructions will be clear: either by closing tax loopholes or through other measures, the savings will be enforced.
We have gone to great pains to be accurate as we put our budget together. If there was even slight doubt about our numbers, we chose in every case to be conservative. The Congressional Budget Office scored them conservatively. If our numbers are imprudent, as you claim, it is only because we underestimate the savings they will generate.
 
JOHN R. KASICH
Chairman, House Budget Committee
Washington, May 17, 1995

HEADLINE: The $100,000 Lexus

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration's desire to pry open Japan's closed automobile market is understandable. But President Clinton's decision to impose 100 percent tariffs on Lexus, Infiniti and other luxury imports is mistaken and unnecessary. It seems designed more to mend the President's relations with American unions than to resolve trade differences with Japan.
American sanctions violate the trade accord that the United States signed with over 100 trading partners last year. Flouting international law betrays America's historic role as a defender of open trade conducted under fair rules that are honored by countries large and small. The United States complains that the structure of Japan's auto market and regulatory barriers obstructs imports and nullifies Japan's trade commitments. But this valid complaint should be taken to the new World Trade Organization, which was created with American support to help untangle this kind of trade dispute. 
The two countries have already resolved many of their disagreements. Japan agreed to open more dealerships to American manufacturers and to dismantle regulatory burdens, including costly inspections of imported auto parts. But the Japanese Government remains unwilling to pressure manufacturers like Toyota to buy more American parts for their new models.
The United States should not demand that any government, even the Japanese, manage private industry. The basis for the American demand -- that Toyota and other manufacturers turn to local suppliers without giving American companies a fair shot -- is weak. After all, Toyota has a perfect right to tie itself even more rigidly to its suppliers, even through merger, without fear of violating any trade principles. It is hard to imagine the American Government telling General Motors and other American manufacturers they cannot produce many of their own parts.
Japan has vowed to haul the United States before the W.T.O. for imposing unilateral sanctions. Japan will almost surely win the case and authorization to retaliate. It could then impose sanctions against American exports like computers, software or aircraft. At that point, the trade war would threaten the jobs of Americans in ways the initial sanctions on high-priced Japanese autos do not.
The new American tariffs will not go into effect until next month. By then, Japan may accept the American demands. But even if it does, the Clinton strategy would be shortsighted. If the United States ignores its fair trade obligations, other countries will surely follow. Imposing sanctions also risks rupturing relations with a country that shares important security interests with America.
Having started down the wrong road, Mr. Clinton can still turn back by pocketing the agreements on dealerships and parts inspections and declaring victory. He could then refer remaining issues to the W.T.O. That way there would be neither a trade war nor bruised relations with an important ally.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Lyford Greene, 91; Served With AT&T As Chief Economist

 BODY:
Lyford N. Greene, a former chief economist of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company who helped influence Federal regulation of the telephone system, died on Tuesday at White Plains Hospital. He was 91.
The cause of death was complications from heart disease. 
 Born in Iowa, Mr. Greene was a graduate of Grinnell College and Northwestern University, where he received a master's degree in 1927. He began his career as an economist with Illinois Bell, moving to AT&T in 1929. He later became chief economist, filling that role until his retirement in 1969. Early in his career, Mr. Greene also taught statistics at Columbia University.
Mr. Greene was chief economist at AT&T when the Federal Government was increasing its regulation of public utilities and their pricing policies. He was a strong proponent of the notion that capital-intensive industries, like the telephone system, need to earn a sufficient rate of return on their investments in plant and equipment. In that role he was closely involved in AT&T's responses to the so-called rate cases that the Federal Government brought to regulate telephone rates.
Mr. Greene is survived by his wife, Margaret Emma-Louise Greene of Scarsdale, N.Y., a daughter, Gretchen Greene Yeo, the former head of foreign exchange at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, of New York City and Lowellville, Ohio; a son, Lyford Kluge Greene of Silver Spring, Md.; four grandchildren, and five great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: U.S. Can't Afford Economic Equality for All;
Flimflam on Medicare

 BODY:
To the Editor:
We certified public accountants may disagree about the Medicare issue, but we do know cooking the books when we see it. Congress's proposed cuts in Medicare is the main element of its high-wire budget-balancing act (front page, May 11). 
 Both the Medicare and Social Security Trust Funds get their money from a 15.3 percent payroll tax. Though the Social Security fund throws off an annual surplus of more than $50 billion, the Republicans say it will take annual cuts in Medicare of about $40 billion to avoid that fund's running a deficit after the year 2002.
But here's your political flimflam: Instead of the Treasury's using the Social Security surplus to pay the Medicare shortfall, it uses that trust fund to pay the other Government bills that create the budget deficit!
Thus the excuse for cutting Medicare and Medicaid budget allowances. Rather than Social Security subsidizing Medicare, they'd use it to continue subsidizing the well-to-do taxpayers and corporations, with tax cuts and subsidies for agribusiness, mining and lumber companies.
If Congress is serious about the deficit, they could wipe it out in about three years by a simple technical device: dropping the unfair tax loophole that stops charging any Social Security tax after a salary reaches $61,200. That costs the Treasury more than $80 billion a year. Yet they don't cut salary off for the Medicare part of the tax.
Now Newt Gingrich proposes a cap on Medicare benefits. Why not cap the old-age benefits on high-salaried professionals and managers instead? Or do they only oppose soaking the rich, but not the poor and elderly?
 
ARNOLD J. OLENICK
Cambridge, Mass., May 11, 1995

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
Using Our Brains

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Practical people agree that the best way to balance the budget is to reduce by half the relentless increase in the cost of Medicare.
But no politician of either party wants to face up to the need to push the elderly into cost-saving managed care, or to reduce benefits, or to ask rich geezers for substantial co-payments. 
 What sweetener can we come up with to make the budgetary medicine go down? Many seniors on Medicare are frightened; how can we replace their fear with hope?
A couple of Nobel laureates came to Congress this week with a big chunk of the answer. One is the molecular biologist James Watson, co-discoverer of DNA; the other is the physicist Leon Cooper, pioneer of superconductivity.
These heavy hitters left their original disciplines to concentrate on today's most exciting and productive field of medicine: the science of the brain.
"Neurological and psychiatric disorders," says Dr. Watson, "count for more hospitalizations and more prolonged care than almost all diseases combined." One in five Americans is directly affected. The Dana Alliance for Brain Initiatives estimates the yearly costs of everything from stroke, depression, tumors and head injuries, Alzheimer's, Huntington's, Parkinson's and other afflictions of the brain to exceed a half-trillion dollars a year.
Now here's the good news: According to "Delivering Results: A Progress Report on Brain Research," just released by the alliance, breakthroughs have been stunning in starting to treat and cure these ailments that fill up our hospitals.
Genes have been found that lead to Alzheimer's, and a transgenic mouse has been produced to test drugs to slow the disease's onset; brain scientists expect medication by 1999. A treatment has been identified to alter the course of multiple sclerosis. New findings show how genetic research may treat manic-depressive illness, drug and alcohol addiction and epilepsy. Relief for some sufferers of migraine headaches is already here.
Neuroscientists used to conceal their excitement about potential advances; other diseases, from cancer to AIDS, received more publicity and support. Now the brain scientists have awakened to the need to report to the public and Congress the results they have been delivering; they are willing to predict what other measurable results that private and public investment in more research would bring.
I was roped into helping raise awareness of brain science by David Mahoney, head of the Dana Foundation, who organized the scientists' alliance; Jim Watson calls him "this generation's Mary Lasker," after the philanthropist who energized health care.
As a Dana board member, I was inspired to write this piece by the examples of Mike Wallace, who is willing to talk candidly about his bouts of depression to help others, and Judy Woodruff, rearing a son with spina bifida and speaking out about the need for research on brain diseases.
To the political point that scientists cannot make: One way to slow Medicare's rising cost is to cure or ameliorate diseases that drive people into hospitals. Neuroscience has demonstrable momentum halfway through this "decade of the brain"; by pressing our strength now, we will save trillions in a few years.
With such a payoff in clear sight, common economic sense suggests Americans invest at least a few more billion in brain research. Let's see the state of play:
The Clinton budget for the National Institutes of Health proposed only a 4 percent increase, with not enough of that earmarked for neuroscience. Clinton is at least moving in the right direction; but the early G.O.P. proposals are far more shortsighted, actually cutting the dollars needed to finance tomorrow's cures.
That's a no-brainer, pennywise and pound foolish. The House Republican leader who grasps the potential -- life-saving and money-saving -- of biomedical investment is John Porter of Illinois; if he can sell Newt Gingrich on the need to outstrip the Clinton proposal, brain research is likely to find a sympathetic ear in the Senate's Pete Domenici.
The political message should be clear: Seed money invested in brain research will help contain the cost of Medicare while giving an aging generation new hope.

HEADLINE: No-Name Publisher Who Can Attract Big-Name Authors

BYLINE: By MARY B. W. TABOR

 BODY:
As Kenzaburo Oe, winner of the 1994 Nobel Prize in Literature, puttered in and out of bookstores and receptions in New York and Boston recently, on tour with his novel "Nip the Buds, Shoot the Kids," his main escort was not one of the powerhouse British or American publishers who usually claim Nobel winners.
 Instead, the soft-spoken and graying Mr. Oe (pronounced OH-eh) was accompanied by Marion Boyars, a petite, older woman with thick dark eyebrows, a brunette bob and a British accent, whose publishing ventures have been as unconventional as she is. Nonetheless, Marion Boyars Publishing puts out about 25 books a year, including works by Mr. Oe and three other Nobel laureates. 
In the case of Mr. Oe, in the 1960's and 70's several publishers, including Grove Press, M. E. Sharpe and Kodansha, published his works in English, but the books sold only moderately.
 So early last year, Ms. Boyars was not surprised to find herself the lone suitor for the English-language rights to "Nip the Buds," the story of Japanese reformatory boys at the end of a war, and "Hiroshima Notes," Mr. Oe's statement on the Hiroshima bomb.
 Ten months later, Mr. Oe won the Nobel, all but guaranteeing future commercial success. Grove quickly scrambled for paperback rights to the two books as well as five other previously untranslated Oe titles.
 "No one was buying Oe at the time, because he wasn't going to be a best seller," Ms. Boyars said during an interview in her East Side hotel in Manhattan, smiling politely and taking a long drag on a cigarette as she made the obvious swipe at publishers who lean toward blockbusters. "It was sheer chance, just sheer chance. We weren't thinking in terms of Nobel. We bought it because we liked it. Most of my publishing is out of enthusiasm."
 It clearly isn't out of fiscal prudence.
 Her first Oe book, for example, "Teach Us to Outgrow Our Madness" (1978), sold a mere 500 copies, failing to earn back its modest advance. Still, she eagerly bought two more.
 In fact, for most of her publishing career, she says, she has operated on a shoestring with a handful of employees who "do everything." An average print run for Marion Boyars Publishing is 3,000 copies. (John Grisham's first print run for "The Rainmaker" was 2.8 million.) And competing for British or American authors is usually unrealistic. "The moment I try to compete, the bigger publishers always have more money," she moans.
 Some American publishers say they have never heard of Ms. Boyars. Those who have tend to describe her as an odd duck who publishes bits and pieces of authors' oeuvres. It's partly true. She has, for example, only one of Eudora Welty's books, "The Collected Stories of Eudora Welty" and one work by Elias Canetti, "Kafka's Other Trial."
 But unlike many American publishers, who bridle at pursuing foreign authors in translation, Ms. Boyars, who speaks French and German, says that the overlooked books and translations are often her gems.
 Morgan Entrekin, president and publisher of Grove/Atlantic, the parent of Grove Press, said: "Marion is the last of a dying breed of eccentric, entrepreneurial, idiosyncratic publishers who publishes her passions. I have a lot of respect for her that she has hung in there for so long. It is very hard for a publishing program built entirely of this kind of work to survive."
 Though she now publishes in both the United States and Britain, her books are increasingly the types published not by big trade houses but by university presses and a handful of literary publishers, like Farrar, Straus & Giroux or and Knopf.
 "I am a multinational dwarf," she laughs. (She is in fact just over 5 feet tall.)
 A native of New York City, Ms. Boyars moved to England with her first husband and earned a bachelor's degree in politics, philosophy and economics from Keele University in Staffordshire, England. In 1960, with no previous experience in publishing, Ms. Boyars, then 31, newly divorced and the mother of two, bought 50 percent of John Calder Publishers and became the first woman in the Britain to be a publisher on her own, that is, not through inheritance or marriage.
 As Calder & Boyars, she and John Calder developed a reputation as one of London's more daring fiction publishers. Together, they published Heinrich Boll, Eugenio Montale, William S. Burroughs and Samuel Beckett as well as many modern French novelists. They also specialized in the writings of modern composers, including John Cage, Igor Stravinsky and Charles Ives, and of social commentators, including Ivan Illich, Robert Heilbroner and Thomas Szasz.
 "They were experimental publishers," said Roger Strauss. "They were into avant-garde literature at a time when other people weren't interested or willing to take a chance."
 In 1966, they were slapped with an obscenity suit based on their publication of Hubert Selby Jr.'s novel, "Last Exit to Brooklyn," in Britain. They ultimately won in what became a landmark publishing case there.
 "We were very daring," she says. (They also published Henry Miller's "Tropic of Cancer," "Tropic of Capricorn" and "Black Spring" in Britain, but were spared legal squabbles.)
 In 1975, her partnership with Mr. Calder crumbling, she formed Marion Boyars Publishers as a separate imprint. And the next year, she and Mr. Calder divided the list and began publishing independently. Among others, Ms. Boyars got their big money maker, "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest," by Ken Kesey, and the composers, among others.
 Since then, with a staff of five people, Ms. Boyars has continued on, a small independent publisher struggling to keep afloat financially. But through a combination of strategy and luck, she has acquired an intriguing list of some 500 titles and such writers as Michael Ondaatje, Georges Bataille and Tim O'Brien. She also publishes the correspondence of Gabriel Faure and Edvard Grieg, the autobiography of Darius Milhaud, and "The Dancer and the Dance" by Merce Cunningham.
 As for Mr. Oe, at one of his signings in New York he said he liked publishing with Ms. Boyars because of her wide literary knowledge. "I can talk with her about literature so easily," he said.
 Keeping up, however, seems to be wearing on Ms. Boyars. When asked about the future, she says she might be interested in selling her company if the right buyer came along. "I'm getting older," she added. "Perhaps I would like someone to take me over."

HEADLINE: HOUSE PROUD;
The Dream On the Hill

BYLINE: By HARRIET EDLESON 

 BODY:
IT was the opening sentence of her letter that captured his interest: I just bought a lot on a cliff 350 feet above the Cacapon River in West Virginia, and I'm interested in building a house.
"It could have stopped right there and I'd still have accepted," Mark McInturff, the architect, said. "You just imagine Frank Lloyd Wright getting a letter like that about Falling Water." 
 The letter writer, Jane Couch, had something a lot simpler in mind for her weekend retreat: three barnlike structures that she had dreamed about for years. Once she even built her own scale model. Her cat chewed one corner off before Ms. Couch, a computer programmer in Washington, gave up on finding the right site.
Then in 1991, driving near Paw Paw, W.Va., about three hours from home, she came upon the cliff and ravine she had pictured in her mind many years before, five and a half acres of mostly wooded hillside. "Just enough flat space for a house," she remembers thinking.
Ms. Couch bought the land for $33,000 and began to create the dream house with a budget of $127,000.
She had admired the rural simplicity of a friend's home designed by Mr. McInturff of Bethesda, Md. Could he create agricultural shapes with black roofs that looked like they fit the land, not like some import from another place or time? And could she have a two-story main house (living room, kitchen and sleeping loft), a one-story work studio with windows on three sides and, the avid bird watcher requested, a three-story tower of porches?
No dining room needed. She planned to eat at a little counter overlooking the river.
"I brought my orange cardboard model," Ms. Couch said, breaking into a smile. "It's a wonder he didn't throw me out or laugh in my face."
In fact, Mr. McInturff was intrigued. He'd never had a client who was as clear as Ms. Couch about what she wanted.
The project, almost three years from conception to completion, was, by design, developed and executed in stages by the owner, the architect and the builders, Bruce Behrens and Mark Smith. "We all helped it along," Ms. Couch said. "Then it sort of took on a life of its own." To economize and to allow herself time to become comfortable with the house, Mr. McInturff said, "she would hire us for a few days, go away and think about it for a long time, and then she'd come back and say, 'O.K., I like this.' "
The house on Hemlock Hill, as Ms. Couch calls her retreat, is a unique contemporary structure that opens onto a panoramic view of the Cacapon River below. Perched atop a mountain dotted with hemlock trees, some of which are 350 years old, the house combines a rustic exterior with a minimalist interior.
"It's almost like a lunar landing site," Mr. McInturff said, adding that the house "just comes down and touches the ground very delicately." Since he designed the house to fit the land, he situated the pieces at the level he wanted it, then, as he described it, "dropped the legs down." At the cliff side of the main building, the legs are 4 to 5 feet above the ground; at the studio, the legs are 8 to 10 feet tall.
An 88-foot stone wall visually and structurally anchors the house to the crest of the hill and connects the three buildings. Beginning outside the studio, it zigzags through the living room of the main house and continues along the outside of the tower building, which comprises a storage space at ground level, a second-story screened porch and a third-story open but roofed platform.
The road side of the 1,000-square-foot compound has just four small windows and presents an enigmatic facade, playing with scale and expectation. Shallow stairs peek out between the main house and the studio.
Inside the main house, the drama begins. Windows dominate three sides of the 16-by-32-foot living area, framing various views of the river and the surrounding mountains. Except for a small cabin in the distance, no sign of human life can be seen.
A stone, tile and hand-hewn-beam fireplace and the interior section of the stone wall are the focal points of the step-down living space. A contiguous kitchen with an eating counter, which affords an upstream river view, completes the first floor. There is no dining table for lingering -- Ms. Couch designed her home with privacy in mind.
A staircase leads to the second-floor 12-by-12-foot sleeping loft, where Ms. Couch can view the first two houses built on Hemlock Hill -- birdhouses. Her two Russian blue cats -- Gabriel, 15, and Daphne, 13 1/2 -- use the loft as their retreat. From here, a bridge leads to the 12-by-12-foot second-story screened porch and outdoor stairs, which climb to the tower lookout.
Since moving in on New Year's Eve, Ms. Couch has been awed. "I still find it hard to believe that I have this wonderful house," she said. Recalling her first morning in the house, she said: "I woke up and there were icicles on the trees. It was like a fairyland."
Yet, she said, "the way I live didn't change -- it's just a whole lot better." She still bird-watches, but from a more spectacular vantage point; reads, and intends to spend more time drawing and painting in the studio as she gets more settled. Meanwhile, she revels in her land, walking the paths she cut into the hillside with the help of a friend on weekends.
There were times during construction when Ms. Couch felt overwhelmed by the enormity of what she had undertaken. "I wondered, 'Will this ever end?' " she said.
She coped by looking at it one step at a time. "If you look at the whole thing at once," she said, "you're liable to throw up your hands and just say, 'I can't handle it.' "
Now, she speaks of her determination to see it through and the peace of mind the house has brought her. Have the courage to live out -- and in -- your fantasy, she urges others.
"If you want something badly enough," she said, "if you have it in your mind all the time, chances are it's going to happen."
 
Specs
 THE house on Hemlock Hill was a labor of love for both its owner, Jane Couch, and its architect, Mark McInturff of McInturff Architects in Bethesda, Md. Ms. Couch didn't want to spend a lot of money, and McInturff didn't expect to earn a lot. Rather than charging a percentage of the construction cost, which is the way he often works, Mr. McInturff agreed to work by the hour. "She was buying us in bits and pieces," he said.
The contract price was $127,000. Ms. Couch also paid for exterior drawings and models of the house. She chose Bruce Behrens and Mark Smith of the Mountaineer Construction Corporation in Romney, W.Va., to build the wood frame house with plywood subsiding and board-and-batten exterior poplar siding. The builder fee was to be 10 percent of the contract price.
"It's important to find a good and sympathetic builder," Mr. McInturff said, adding that anyone considering building at a great distance from the architect might consider "a simple, rational structure," which is easier to communicate to a local builder.
To that end, Mr. McInturff kept the detailing consistent wherever possible: all three roofs have the same eaves details and pitches, for example. The $127,000 contract price, which ran over by only $700, included $3,500 to pour the concrete footings, which, along with metal tie-downs, anchor the structures into the stone foundation.
"The porches and tower are subject to pretty significant winds," Mr. McInturff said. "You're not worried about the building falling but about it being lifted like an umbrella when the wind comes up under the roof."

HEADLINE: Man Killed After Stealing Tank for Rampage

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO, May 17

 BODY:
A man stole a 63-ton military tank from a National Guard armory here and used it to rampage through neighborhoods, flattening utility poles, fire hydrants and cars before getting stuck on a road divider. Police officers fatally shot the man as he tried to get the tank moving.
No bystanders were injured in the event on Wednesday evening. The tank's weapons -- a 105-millimeter cannon, a 12.7-millimeter antiaircraft gun and a 7.62-millimeter machine gun -- were not loaded, said Maj. Ed Gale of the California National Guard. 
 The driver was identified as Shawn Nelson, an unemployed plumber who had served in the military; he was believed to be in his mid-30's. The police said they had shot Mr. Nelson because they feared that if he got the tank moving again traffic would be endangered.
"The guy was just going crazy," said Kelly Bird, who said he saw at least 25 cars flattened. "He was mowing cars over."
Capt. Tom Hall of the police said: "He shifted into the proper gear and was preparing to spin the tank so he could get off the high-riser. He knew what he was doing."
The authorities were unsure how Mr. Nelson had managed to steal the M-60 tank from the armory.
Neighbors said Mr. Nelson's life had been crumbling. His home here was apparently in foreclosure and his utilities had been shut off. He also had a history of medical problems, including a broken back from a motorcycle accident.
