HEADLINE: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: NEWS ANALYSIS;
Once More, With Feeling

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 18

 BODY:
"Make no mistake about it, this bill is a historic watershed," said Senator Bob Packwood, Republican of Oregon. "If this bill does not work, or if Congress and the President attempt to frustrate it, we will lose our last significant opportunity to deal with the deficit."
Those sentiments were expressed repeatedly today as the House of Representatives approved a resolution that is supposed to lead to a balanced budget by 2002 and the Senate began debate on a companion measure. 
 But Senator Packwood's remarks were not made today. They came on the night 10 years ago when Congress approved the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings legislation, which was meant to put the budget into balance by 1991.
The fact is, Congress has been promising a balanced budget ever since 1978, when legislation was adopted stating that beginning in the fiscal year 1981, spending "shall not exceed" receipts.
But each time the screw was tightened so much that people were threatened with actual pain from reductions in Government programs, Congress passed new legislation that relaxed the pressure. And the Federal budget deficit -- the amount by which Government spending exceeds revenues each year -- continued to rise.
The question now is whether this year is different -- whether this time Congress will actually follow through on its resolve to adopt and stick to policies leading to a balanced budget, or whether today's promises will evaporate once the heat is turned up, like so many drops of water in a skillet.
No one can answer the question with any confidence. But economists and political analysts agree that this year feels different.
One reason is that the Republicans who control Congress are unified like no other party in decades, and they are committed to the goal of a balanced budget. Many of those elected for the first time last year believe that their advocacy of a balanced budget was crucial to their success at the polls.
Another difference is that the budget resolutions in the House and Senate this year, for all their lack of specifics, contain few of the gimmicks and unrealistic economic assumptions that characterized many of the previous measures that promised a balanced budget. Republicans have even promised to take risky political steps, like slowing the growth of Medicare so much that retirees will have to pay more for their medical insurance or face reduced services.
Even so, for those who believe that the country's economic future rests on a balanced budget, neither the history nor the politics of the issue is encouraging. It is important to remember that whatever gets enacted this year can always be changed by the next Congress or the ones that follow.
The Gramm-Rudman-Hollings legislation in 1985 set specific deficit levels for each of the next five years and required automatic cuts in Government programs across the board -- a process known as sequestration -- if the levels were exceeded.
Partly because the economy was never as strong as policy makers predicted, partly because the savings and loan bailout was so expensive and partly because politicians lacked the necessary commitment, the proscribed deficit limit was never met in any year. No meaningful sequestration ever occurred.
In 1987, facing the seemingly impossible task of lowering the deficit to $108 billion in the fiscal year 1988, Congress changed the law. New annual deficit ceilings were set, and the date for budget balance was put off till 1993. The deficit in the fiscal year 1988, incidentally, turned out to be $155 billion.
In 1990, with the economy in recession and the projected deficit so far above what the law required that sequestration would have proved crippling, Congress abandoned Gramm-Rudman-Hollings and adopted a new scheme of tax increases and budget reductions. The deficit in the fiscal year 1991, supposed to be $64 billion under the old law, was $269 billion.
The measures agreed to by President George Bush and Congress in 1990 and similar ones approved by President Clinton and Congress in 1993 kept the annual deficits substantially lower than they would have been otherwise. But these measures were intended to balance the budget. And largely because of the growth in health costs, the deficits will soar by the end of the decade without further belt-tightening.
As a political matter, Robert D. Reischauer, the former director of the Congressional Budget Office, provides this maxim: "No good deed goes unpunished when it comes to deficit reduction."
Republicans in the Senate, who were primarily responsible for enacting the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law in 1985, lost control of the Senate in the elections the following year. Mr. Bush, who broke his no-new-taxes pledge in the name of deficit reduction in 1990, lost his bid for re-election. And, of course, the Democrats who backed President Clinton's budget plan in 1993 lost control of the House and Senate last year.
Opinion polls show that while the public believes strongly in a balanced budget in the abstract, support plummets when people are asked whether they would be willing to accept specific sacrifices like a tax increase or less spending for Medicare to achieve the goal.
The first test of the Republican resolve will come later this year when lawmakers have to specify how they would achieve the savings they need in popular programs like Medicare.
Carol Cox Wait, president of the private Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget and a zealous advocate of a balanced budget, said she thought there was a slightly better than even chance that the necessary policies would be enacted this year. If they are put into law, she said, they might stick this time because Congress would be reluctant to vote to "unbalance the budget."
Mr. Reischauer, now a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, predicted that even if Congress set forth this year on a dedicated journey toward a balanced budget, substantial mid-course corrections would made in a few years when the pressure became unbearable. But that would not mean, he said, that the goal of a balanced budget would not eventually be reached.
Rudolph G. Penner, who was director of the Congressional Budget Office in the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings years, had this response when he was asked whether he thought this year was different:
"In every previous year, I would have been totally cynical. This year, I'm not cynical. I just don't know."

HEADLINE: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE OVERVIEW;
HOUSE ENDORSES BALANCED BUDGET IN 238-to-193 VOTE

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 18

 BODY:
With barely a glance at an embittered Democratic minority, Republicans in the House of Representatives took a daunting political step today and endorsed a broad blueprint, complete with dollars-and-cents targets, for balancing the Federal budget.
The vote for the plan was 238 to 193, with 8 conservative Democrats joining the Republican majority. A lone Republican, Representative Michael P. Flanagan of Chicago, voted no, saying the budget unduly punished urban areas. Four lawmakers did not vote. 
 Republicans easily rejected three alternatives to their proposal, two of them from factions of conservative and liberal Democrats, before the final vote.
The Republican plan is a seven-year behemoth plotting a course that would reduce by $1.5 trillion the spending now envisioned in Federal budgets through the year 2002. Most of that is aimed at erasing an annual deficit that threatens to race past $200 billion next year and stay there. Roughly $350 billion of the package, however, is earmarked to pay for personal and business tax breaks that the House approved last month.
The Senate began debate today on its version of the balanced-budget plan -- one that rejects any immediate tax cut -- with a final vote likely next week. The two houses must forge a single compromise plan out of their two proposals next month, with the difference over taxes the central issue.
That document would then become the framework for an actual 1996 Federal budget whose details will be filled in by House and Senate committees this summer and fall.
Difficult issues still remain. Chief among them is devising a specific plan for how to save $280 billion in spending for Medicare, the popular but costly Government health program for the elderly. But in the end, the Republicans must also present a final budget with enough Democratic support to mollify President Clinton, who is solidly opposed to some major components of the plan and may well veto parts of it.
The tax reductions, which the House's Democrats called a gift to the nation's monied class, were the bone of the two-day debate that amounted, at most times, to a struggle for the hearts and minds of the nation's broad middle class.
Democrats cast the Republicans almost as Dickensian characters, greedy Scrooges hoarding their shillings while the poor suffered, and called their budget plan "an attack on working-class Americans."
To dramatize the point for television viewers, they held up scores of photographs of voters who they said would be devastated by the daunting changes -- in Medicare, Medicaid, education assistance, for example -- implicit in the Republican proposal.
"You're not voting for charts and graphs and numbers, but you're voting for flesh-and-blood people who depend on you," said Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House minority leader, scolding the Republicans. Mr. Gephardt said the plan would cost retired people $1,300 in increased Medicare fees and reduced Social Security benefits by the time the budget is balanced in 2002.
"It would be one thing if what we were asking them to do is to balance the budget," he said, referring to the elderly. "But we're taking $1,300 from these folks so we can give a $20,000-a-year tax break to people earning $350,000 a year or more."
Mr. Gephardt was citing a Treasury Department study that estimated that the top 1 percent of wage earners would receive a tax reduction averaging $20,352 a year if the House tax plan became law.
Republicans, noting that Mr. Gephardt and other Democratic leaders had no budget-balancing plan of their own to offer, mocked their critics as "bereft of ideas" and accused them of fighting the proposal with scare tactics.
"The party that once said, 'There is nothing to fear but fear itself,' now has nothing to offer but fear itself," said Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader.
Republicans cast their proposal as a plan to shift money and power from Washington to the nation's hometowns, as a fiscal tonic that would lower inflation and increase employment, and even as a matter of principle.
Mr. Armey said the debate was not about numbers but about morality, "whether this generation will keep cheating on the next" by spending tax dollars yet to be paid.
The principal author of the plan, Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, held before Democrats a picture of his own, showing a row of babies. "I want to show you who we're doing this for," he told them.
Mr. Kasich, a 43-year-old Republican who heads the House Budget Committee, paid tribute to the Democrats' 40 years of House rule, saying they had wielded Government power for immense good and that approval of a Republican budget plan "doesn't mean the Government doesn't have a role -- it does."
But "the 21st century is about the power of the individual," he said. "It's not about the power of bureaucracy and red tape. Because bureaucracy and red tape and, frankly, misplaced compassion do not reward individual achievement."
At 79 pages, dense with number-clogged paragraphs and subparagraphs, the Republican budget proposal looks like anything but the political screed it is. But it commits Republicans for the first time to put their small-Government philosophy into effect by making the cuts and changes in Government services required to meet the measure's new limits on spending.
Past Congresses have balked at such changes, fearing a voter backlash. With today's vote, Republicans in the House effectively promised to make changes or face the political ignominy of failure.
"We've got a long way to go," Mr. Kasich said after the vote. "It's going to take a few years to make this imprint permanent."
Democrats never seriously threatened the Republican juggernaut. But they did offer a conservative alternative to Mr. Kasich's plan that gained enough support to suggest that a bipartisan alliance on a balanced budget may be possible this summer, if not likely.
That alternative, backed by a coalition of conservative Democrats, also was intended to erase the deficit in the next seven years. But rather than cutting taxes, the proposal would have scaled back the Republican cuts in spending on Medicare, Medicaid, student loans, agriculture and a number of other politically popular programs.
The plan gained 100 votes, 90 of them from Democrats. It was rejected by 325 House members, including the Democratic leader, Mr. Gephardt. Later, one of its sponsors, Representative Charles W. Stenholm of Texas, said his party was mistaken to remain silent in the face of a Republican budget initiative.
"The President was perfectly correct in saying to the Republicans, 'Let's see your budget,' " Mr. Stenholm said. "Now they've done that. John Kasich has done a very credible job of doing that. Now let the battle begin."
The Republican leadership also rejected two other alternatives to its plan. One, sponsored by the Congressional Black Caucus, would have sharply reduced spending cuts in many social programs and raised taxes to pay for deficit reduction, but was rejected by a vote of 56 to 367.
The second alternative was offered by Representative Gerald B. H. Solomon, a New York Republican who heads the House Rules Committee. It sought to balance the budget in five years, without a tax cut, by cutting future spending across the board. That plan was defeated by a vote of 89 to 342.
Congressman Flanagan, the only Republican who voted against the plan that was approved, represents the Chicago working-class district that Representative Dan Rostenkowski held until last fall. Mr. Flanagan later said in a statement that he believed his district and other urban areas would take "an unusually hard hit" should the plan be carried out.
The House later took a second vote on spending cuts and it, too, was largely along party lines. By 235 to 189, the House approved the final version of legislation that would excise $16.5 billion in spending from the current year's budget and allot money for disaster relief in California and Oklahoma City.
The President has vowed to veto that bill, contending that it also is a vehicle for pork-barrel highway projects for Republican lawmakers.

HEADLINE: Dow Plunges 81.96 Points In Largest Selloff of Year

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
In the biggest selloff of the year, stock traders knocked down prices from record highs, with the Dow Jones industrial average plummeting 81.96 points, to 4,340.64.
The plunge was so steep that at 3:34 P.M., when the Dow was off more than 50 points, it set off the New York Stock Exchange's "circuit breaker" rules, intended to slow high-speed computer-guided trading and calm a volatile market. But the Dow continued to fall another 30 points. 
 Before yesterday the Dow had risen more than 15 percent -- or 584 points -- this year, and some market-leading stocks like Microsoft had risen more than 40 percent.
"A drop like today changes your complacent attitude toward the market," said Thomas Gallagher, head of equity trading for Oppenheimer & Company. "It's a very spooky market when the Dow gets this high."
A few traders cited familiar reasons for the big move, pointing to a report on the rising trade deficit with Japan and fears that a decline in borrowing costs was coming to an end. Indeed, bond prices fell and long-term interest rates rose somewhat.
But there were also indications that after the nearly seven-month surge of the market, with the Dow hitting six new highs in a row recently, many traders were simply poised to jump out of stocks and take their profits at the first sign of a pullback.
Adding a large measure of selling pressure is the expiration today of two kinds of stock options, an event known as "double witching," which often leads to a large run-up in trading volume and wide swings in price.
Technical analysts also say that it is normal for stock prices to rise sharply for a period and then fall as much as one-third to one-half of the advance. Only when prices fall further do market analysts start talking seriously about a bear market.
"You have to keep this in statistical perspective," said David Holt, vice president of research and strategy for Wedbush Morgan Securities in Los Angeles. "You have to take today's drop of 82 points and compare it to the almost 750-point rise from Nov. 23, when this latest rally started."
Because stock prices have risen so far and so fast, the moves by the component stocks of the Dow tend to be magnified, both up and down. In 1993, for example, a one-point change in a Dow component stock would make the Dow change about two points. Now, a one-point change would move the Dow about 2.8 points.
Still, the decline yesterday was the biggest fall in blue-chip stock prices since the Dow dropped nearly 47 points on Jan. 19, and almost equaled the fall of more than 91 points last Nov. 22.
The 82-point drop of the Dow was a decline of 1.85 percent. The broader Standard & Poor's 500 dropped 7.49 points, or 1.42 percent, to 519.58, and the Nasdaq composite index fell 7.87 points, or nine-tenths of 1 percent, to 864.06.
The Dow is now below 4,400, the level crossed by the market only seven sessions ago, on May 10. It had broken through 4,300 only 19 sessions ago, on April 24.
Despite the fall, there were some signs of strength in the market, said Alan B. Bond, president of Bond, Procope Capital Management. High-technology stocks like Microsoft, Oracle Systems and Cisco Systems all traded higher than or near their opening prices until the last half-hour, indicating options-related trading. At the close of Nasdaq trading, Microsoft was down 1 3/8, to 84 5/8; Oracle was down 1 1/8, to 33 3/8, and Cisco was down 1 3/8, to 44.
High-technology stocks have often been the top performers in recent sessions. Even after the decline yesterday, the American Stock Exchange computer technology index was still up more than 30 percent this year.
"What we saw today was that the tech stocks' leadership is not faltering," Mr. Bond said.
Moreover, because economic conditions are favorable, with interest rates stable and inflation low, stock prices might rebound as early as this morning, said Edward Laux, senior managing director for equity trading at the Chicago Corporation. "The drop in the Dow might scare some weak players," he said. "But given the overall market outlook, we're more likely to have a technical snapback."
The market headed down after the Commerce Department reported that the overall trade deficit narrowed in March, while the deficit with Japan widened.
The narrowing of the overall deficit might have contributed to the fall in prices because it suggested that the economy was not slowing as much as had been anticipated. That would also suggest that inflation was still a threat, casting doubt that the Federal Reserve would cut interest rates in the second half of the year, as a growing number of market analysts have told their clients.
The volume on the New York Stock Exchange was higher than normal, at 351.9 million shares, about 5 percent higher than the daily average of 335 million shares this year.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 3.72 points, to 279.80, with advancing stocks lagging behind declining stocks by 552 to 1,780. The American Stock Exchange composite index fell 2.07 points, to 487.45.
Among the advancing stocks was Opal Inc., a maker of equipment used in manufacturing computer chips, which rose 6 1/4, to 19 1/4, in its first day of trading.
Among the declining stocks was Forest Laboratories, a medical supplies company, which fell 5 3/8, to 41 1/4, after the Food and Drug Administration refused to accept its application on a respiratory drug for premature babies. Xerox fell 4 3/8, to 117 3/4, after its board voted to keep its dividend unchanged.
The most active stock, with 10.7 million shares traded, was Intel, which closed unchanged at 110 3/4.

HEADLINE: Faster Exit Off Welfare?;
Connecticut Plan Stresses Job Placement Over Classes

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, May 18

 BODY:
At first glance, Takela Roberts would appear to be an example of what Gov. John G. Rowland wants from welfare recipients: a woman who desperately wants to get off the dole and is working hard to do it.
But after completing her first year of community college classes with a B-plus average, Ms. Roberts, 23, learned last Friday that the state may no longer financially support her effort to become a registered nurse and that the training program she has benefited from is being dramatically changed as the Governor revamps the state's welfare system. 
 "I'm devastated," she said, upon hearing that the program that provides aid for child care, transportation to school and tuition was being dramatically changed. "That money is my backbone."
Ms. Roberts, who said she may have to drop out of college, is one of hundreds of single mothers here caught in the fallout from the national welfare debate. Gov. Rowland has embarked on an ambitious program to move 40,000 families off the welfare rolls and into employment as rapidly as possible over the next four years.
To achieve that goal, he needs to place a large number of people fast. And so, the Republican Governor has decided to abandon the state's long-range education and job training program, which now typically takes two or more years to complete, and replace it with a brief job placement service that will reach more welfare recipients, but teach them more modest skills like how to write resumes, look for work and be responsible employees.
This will change the current program -- which graduated 2,030 people into the work force last year -- into an employment service that as of July 1, will begin immediately placing people in jobs. The goal is for the new program to find work for 9,000 people a year, more than four times the number currently finding jobs.
Many of those in favor of the change are not saying the current training and placement program does not work, but rather that it costs too much for the number being served. "The old way is too expensive," said David L. Boomer, a Republican Senate aide and a longtime Rowland adviser. "It's great to offer it, but when you have to serve 40,000 people, you can't give Cadillac services."
There is, however, one major question.
"Where are they going to get the jobs?" asked Janet L. Van Tassel, executive director of the Legal Assistance Resource Center of Connecticut and a critic of the Rowland approach. As of March, there were at least 92,600 unemployed people in the state, and the State Labor Department has projected only 51,431 openings between 1992 and 2000. Mr. Rowland would add thousands of welfare recipients to this mix.
The new direction in the state program, known as Job Connection, is part of a widespread debate taking place in Washington and state capitals about the best way to move people off welfare. It generally pits Republicans who want to take punitive steps to force people off the rolls against Democrats who say that such efforts are shortsighted.
Like many Republicans, Mr. Rowland says that the welfare system breeds dependency. Economic incentives -- lower benefits and tax credits to employers to hire welfare recipients -- will break this dependency and force recipients into the job market, he says.
Still, Mr. Rowland takes this argument one step further than many other Republican governors. States like Iowa that have tried to get people off welfare quickly have found that it has required increased spending for job training, child care and transportation in its early years. But Mr. Rowland maintains that he will achieve savings immediately and remove hundreds from the rolls in the first few months.
The restyled Job Connection program would be there to ease the transition, Mr. Rowland's supporters say.
Opponents contend that the Governor's approach ignores the realities of the economy, making women compete for a limited number of unskilled jobs that will not ultimately offer a long-term solution to their problems.
"The Governor's approach is too simplistic," State Representative Jack Thompson, a Democrat, said. "Just bringing economic pressure on these people is not going to bring about change. There's got to be a training component and there's got to be additional education."
Under Mr. Rowland's plan, beginning in 1996, all recipients of the Aid to Families with Dependent Children welfare program who are judged employable will have 21 months to find work before their benefits are cut off. If the plan is enacted, state officials estimate that the benefits of about 40,000 families will be affected by this deadline, expected to be the strictest in the nation.
To encourage the transition from welfare to work, Mr. Rowland has proposed cutting benefits for a family of three to as low as $514, the 1988 level, from $581, making a minimum wage job more financially appealing.
Employers who hire welfare recipients would be eligible for corporate tax credits of $1,500 for each recipient they hire. Medicaid and child-care assistance would be continued for two years after a person left the welfare rolls for work, so that health coverage and child-care would no longer be reasons for quitting a job.
In addition to their benefits, welfare recipients would be allowed to keep wages up to the Federal poverty level of $12,000 for a family of three for the 21 months. The state now deducts part of their benefits for two of every three dollars of nonwelfare income.
While the Governor's plan has won substantial support among lawmakers, it still must be passed by the State Legislature and then approved by the Federal Government.
But the State Department of Social Services has sent out notices to the nonprofit contractors that are financed through the Job Connection program saying that it was allowing their contracts to expire on June 30. In an April 25 letter to Governor Rowland, Joyce Thomas, the Social Services Commissioner, said, "There is a need for D.S.S. to begin the phaseout of contracts that will not result in a job immediately."
Earlier this month, the department issued an outline for the new Job Connection program, a step that begins the process of awarding new contracts for services that "lead directly to, and support, employment."
Although the state has made provisions for some of the 1,658 women currently enrolled in community colleges to continue their education, lawmakers from both parties, advocates for the poor and recipients said that the vast majority are in jeopardy of having to leave school. And with the new 21-month limit, community college will not be an option, as it takes at least two years to earn a degree.
The outline also says that all able-bodied recipients are expected to work, the exception being "teen parents satisfactorily progressing toward completing their high school education or its equivalent."
The department has established a goal of placing 3,000 welfare recipients in jobs in the first four months of the program, from July 1 to October 31, and ultimately of achieving an annual placement of 9,000 people a year.
This would represent a dramatic shift in the number of people passing through the program. Since the Job Connection program was established in 1985, it has successfully prepared between 2,000 to 4,000 people a year for employment, helping participants through community colleges, vocational training schools, on-the-job training programs and high school equivalency classes.
There were 13,682 of the state's 58,000 recipients of Aid to Families With Dependent Children in the program last year, with a waiting list of at least 10,000 people. Many have not been able to use its services because of a lack of funding for child-care services, officials said.
About $8.5 million in Job Connection money was distributed to more than 36 agencies this year. Mr. Boomer, an architect of the new plan, said that the state would use the same amount of money to accomplish much more.
Claudette Beaulieu, a spokeswoman for the Social Services Department, said that the new program would no longer require labor-intensive case management and the in-depth assessment of a recipients' skills, work history and career interests, making it less costly.
It is hard to gauge how well the new plan will do, since arguments about the effectiveness of training welfare recipients are grounded as much in philosophy as in hard fact.
For instance, Mr. Boomer cited a three-year study of a California program similar to Job Connection. It showed that 53 percent were moved off welfare through job training. In a control group whose members had no extra training, 50 percent still left the welfare rolls. The study also showed that for every dollar California spent on the program, it only received 76 cents back in savings.
Yet Mr. Boomer acknowledged that supporters of California's long-term training program could also draw favorable conclusions from the same study. The study revealed that those in the program had higher earnings. It also predicted that there would be greater savings for the state over the long run.
Among welfare recipients, there appears little doubt that Mr. Rowland's plan is, at best, misguided.
Last week in Hartford, single mothers in a Job Connection program at Capital Community-Technical College grew upset when they learned that it would stop on June 30 and they would have to find work.
"I will do anything to feed my kids," one woman told the group. "I will sell myself, I will sell drugs. But there are no jobs in Hartford."
At a meeting of welfare recipients last Friday in New Haven, mothers who had been in and out of Aid to Families With Dependent Childrenfor the last decade agreed with Mr. Rowland's desire to improve the system, but said the plan appeared to be more interested in saving money than helping them.
And they spoke bitterly about how much of Mr. Rowland's talk has been about welfare fraud and people being too lazy to look for work.
"Most of us aren't criminals or out to defraud the system," said Fern Coleman, 32, of West Haven, a welfare recipient who has alternated between menial jobs and welfare for the last 13 years. "I have no problem working, but the skills I have are not enough."
"People talk like being on assistance is just sitting back and waiting for your check," she said. "We all want a better life, but a job at McDonald's isn't going to take care of my three kids."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
The wallboard giant USG may be ready for another climb.

BYLINE: By Barnaby Feder 

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
WHEN the National Gypsum Company, the country's second-largest maker of gypsum-coated wallboard, agreed on Tuesday to a $1.2 billion takeover bid by an investment company led by its former chairman, interest turned as well to its rival, the USG Corporation. That same day, shares of USG, the industry leader with 35 percent of the market, jumped $1.50 in heavy trading and reached a 52-week high of $26.75.
USG's stock slipped back to $26 a share by the close of trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, but it is still up more than 50 percent from last fall's low of $17.25. 
 Despite that rapid ascent, analysts say USG has plenty of upside left. The company, which is based here, does not have the easiest balance sheet to understand, but some analysts say it is not difficult to conclude that the stock could climb another 50 percent or more before running out of steam.
"When construction stocks move, they move in leaps and bounds," said Barbara Allen, who follows the wallboard industry for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. Ms. Allen sees USG trading from $40 to $50 a share within 12 months.
Ivy Schneider, an analyst at Salomon Brothers, said, "It has at least another 20 percent upside potential before I'd start taking profits."
Behind the optimism is a widely shared view among analysts that investors unduly punished USG, along with other stocks sensitive to interest-rate swings, when they worried early last year that rate increases by the Federal Reserve would kill the housing market. The stock had reached $36 in March 1994, when the sectorwide rout began.
"Now the market has begun re-evaluating specific companies and the psychology has shifted so that being interest-rate sensitive isn't a curse," said Jonathan Goldfarb, an analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company who includes USG among a handful of building-related stocks with his strongest buy rating.
Some of the lift in USG's stock is coming from industry conditions: housing is stronger than pessimists projected when the rate increases started; the wallboard industry is operating at capacity everywhere except California, and wallboard prices have rocketed from a low of $68 for 1,000 square feet in early 1992 to about $112 now, with another increase expected this summer.
But analysts note that USG is also benefiting from growth in its acoustic-ceiling business, its strong position in remodeling markets and its overseas sales. USG has also invested in keeping its manufacturing plants up to date even while paring debt from $3.1 billion in early 1993 to slightly more than $1 billion today.
The biggest cloud is that USG's own material costs are rising rapidly, especially for the recycled paper that is made into backing for its sheetrock wallboard. And the company is still a defendant in tens of thousands of asbestos-related personal injury and property damage lawsuits. The number of outstanding suits declined last year for the first time since they began to appear in force in the 1980's, but to really be safe, USG will have to beat back efforts by its insurers to overturn court decisions that have ordered them to foot most of USG's liability.
It does not help that the company's balance sheet is still scarred by the financial mayhem of the 1980's, when it became the target of takeover attempts by the Belzberg family of Canada and then Desert Partners, an investment group organized by Texas oilmen. The debt it assumed to fend off the raids led to a prepackaged bankruptcy in 1993, from which it quickly emerged.
Accounting charges and the need to pay down debt from the reorganization keep USG's bottom line in the red. But the more revealing figure -- cash flow from operations -- has been surprisingly robust.
"They've beaten the tar out of our earnings estimates for the past three quarters," said David L. Smith, who follows the company from Austin, Tex., for the Southcoast Capital Corporation, an investment banking firm.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Europe Jobless Rate Dips

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, May 18

 BODY:
Seasonally adjusted unemployment across the 15 European Union nations dropped slightly to 10.8 percent in March, exactly double the United States jobless rate for the same period, the European Union reported today. The March rate for the union was down from 10.9 percent in February and from 11.3 percent in March 1994. The most substantial decreases in the last year came in Denmark, Finland, Britain, Sweden and Germany.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 960 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Trade Fight With Japan Is Widening

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 18

 BODY:
Washington's confrontation with Tokyo widened on two fronts today, as growing signs emerged that Japanese officials were winning allies abroad in the trade struggle while another big American exporter complained about Japan's trade practices.
European officials have condemned the Clinton Administration's decision to place huge tariffs on Japanese luxury car imports as a violation of world trade rules, and today the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, shot back. Mr. Kantor accused the European Union of looking for a free ride in siding verbally with Japan even as it hoped the United States would do the dirty work to open Japanese markets for all. "Our European friends are always willing to hold our coats while we get our nose bloodied," he said. 
 Meanwhile, one of the biggest American success stories in Japan, the Eastman Kodak Company, filed a broad action with the Clinton Administration charging that its film sales in Japan were being undermined by the same sort of collusive practices the United States was battling in the automotive market.
Taken together, the two developments seem bound to increase Japan's resistance to reaching an early settlement with Washington. The actions came on a day in which the Commerce Department reported that America's overall trade deficit of $9.12 billion for March was essentially unchanged from the previous month. But the gap with Japan swelled to $6.14 billion. [Page D4.]
Japanese officials appear to be counting on a broadside of international criticism of the Administration's car sanctions to sow doubts in the Clinton Administration over whether it can win its case before the World Trade Organization in Geneva. At the same time, the action by Kodak seems bound to confirm Tokyo's fear that America's appetite for economic concessions is insatiable. Any agreement to assure United States companies a share of the Japanese auto market, they may reason, will only create a precedent for other industries.
"Everyone realizes this is a much, much broader struggle," one senior Administration official said today. "And neither side is in any mood to blink."
Administration officials said Europe's response to the American action had been expected. Nonetheless, it was damaging to Washington's two-pronged attack on Japan: sanctions against the makers of Japanese luxury cars to prod them into purchasing more American-made parts, combined with a complaint to the newly created World Trade Organization challenging the fundamental structure of the Japanese economy.
The European officials said that the United States, by imposing sanctions on its own, was acting as both prosecutor and judge, sentencing Japanese auto makers before its case against them is presented. By doing so, argued Sir Leon Brittan, the trade commissioner of the European Union, the United States is threatening the world trading system. Even if America's case is solid, Sir Leon said on Wednesday, "to jeopardize the W.T.O.'s credibility so soon after its creation" earlier this year sent the wrong message. Already Japanese officials are fanning out elsewhere in the world, trying to elicit similar critiques.
The European response brought some sharp retorts in Washington today. "The Europeans are acting with great hypocrisy," said Jeffrey E. Garten, the Under Secretary of Commerce for International Affairs.
"They scream that we are acting unilaterally, and then they rush in within minutes to get the benefits of the openings that we achieve," he said. Europeans made similar complaints, he said, when the United States threatened sanctions against China earlier this year for violation of intellectual property rights. Weeks after the case was settled, Europe and China reached a parallel agreement.
"They allege that we are managing trade, while they have concluded their own quota arrangements with the Japanese for autos imported into the E.U.," Mr. Garten said.
On the corporate trade front, Kodak's complaint, seeking an investigation under section 301 of the Trade Act of 1974, is an unusual one. It comes from a company whose logotype is seen all over Tokyo and whose products are sold widely in Japanese stores. Kodak has 9 percent of the commercial film market in Japan, an impressive figure by most measures.
Kodak argues, however, that the figure would be far higher if the market were unfettered. Although the dollar has weakened by nearly 15 percent, retailers have kept the price of Kodak film artificially high, the company maintains, and its market share is declining. The complaint charges that the Fuji Photo Film Company, which commands 70 percent of the market, has set up a retail system that limits Kodak's sales.
"In this case," the complaint read, "the Ministry of International Trade and Industry and the Japan Fair Trade Commission have not only tolerated systematic anticompetitive practices, but have actively encouraged and reinforced them."
Mr. Kantor's office has 45 days to decide whether to proceed with an investigation. But it seems highly likely that it will. Kodak's argument -- that the retail system is so controlled by leading Japanese manufacturers that foreign products are discriminated against -- is a clear echo of the auto trade complaint. Kodak also argues that Fuji has created a "profit sanctuary" in Japan, keeping prices high to subsidize its sales abroad, where competition rules.
Kodak, one of the best-known names around the world, has generally been reluctant to file trade complaints. But its new chief executive, George M. C. Fisher, is a veteran of many Japanese trade battles and has argued that the company's market share in Japan should more closely reflect its 40 percent share everywhere else in the world.
